PHILADELPHIA - Everyone knows that long layoffs before the World Series affected the Detroit Tigers in 2006 and the Colorado Rockies in 2007. If not, here's a reminder: Faced with a six-day hiatus, the Tigers crumbled in St. Louis, losing in five games. Faced with an unprecedented eight-day break in 2007, the Rockies were swept by the Red Sox.

So yesterday it was the pay czar, Kenneth R. Feinberg, laying down the law for the seven companies that are still wards of the government, including Citigroup, A.I.G., and General Motors. I wrote a special Friday column about that, the essential point of which was that the only way the country is going to get control of executive pay -- whether on Wall Street or elsewhere in corporate America -- is by making it easier for shareholders to vote out directors who award excessive pay to their company's chief executive. Ira Kay, the well-known compensation consultant at Watson Wyatt, told me that "board members are terrified" of shareholder votes that would embarrass them.

Merlin Entertainments Group, the theme-park operator that owns Madame Tussauds and the London Eye Ferris wheel, plans to go public on the London Stock Exchange by mid-2010, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

The Bay Area Toll Authority staff has less than two months to decide how to implement its fare hike on every major bridge in the region (except the Golden Gate), but the jury is still out on which of the three proposed options it should pursue.

In the case of the wayward Northwest plane that overshot its destination, Minneapolis, by 150 miles, investigators are looking into whether the pilots were asleep when they were out of communication with controllers for an hour. The plane landed safely, and the pilots said they were engaged in a heated discussion and had lost "situational awareness."

The review by Nicholas Wade, a science reporter for The Times, of Richard Dawkins's "Greatest Show on Earth: The Evidence for Evolution" (Oct. 11) drew an unusually large number of letters to the editor. And an unusually large number of those came from readers who identified themselves as scientists or philosophers. Because we had room for just two responses on the letters page of the issue of Oct. 25, we thought it only fair to our credentialed correspondents to present their comments here. -Elsa Dixler

Wading into the health care debate, First Lady Michelle Obama said on Friday that a health care overhaul would ease the struggles faced by women with breast cancer.

Defenseman Chris Chelios was in a combative mood, and this was before he played his first shift for the Chicago Wolves of the American Hockey League. In a telephone conversation Thursday afternoon, Chelios made clear that his stint with the Wolves is not to be construed as a comeback because he never retired.

Think the gold and brown Denver Broncos throwback uniforms were hideous? Maybe, but that didn't stop fans from wanting a piece of them.
A lawyer for Jamie McCourt, the chief executive of the Dodgers, said she had been fired by the team owner, her estranged husband, Frank McCourt. The McCourts separated this month.

President Obama's proposal last week to essentially pay older Americans their regular, annual cost-of-living increases in their Social Security checks -- even though the cost of living has fallen -- has renewed debates on older Americans' dependence on entitlements.

The new Harriet and Kenneth Kupferberg Holocaust Research Center and Archives at Queensborough Community College was dedicated in a public ceremony.

In this Sunday's Latin America issue, the writer Seth Kugel goes beyond the Brazil of model-flecked beaches and eco-lodges, and explores the state of Minas Gerais, considered by many to be the country's rural heartland. He finds colonial towns, Baroque churches, soothing waterfalls - and some very bumpy roads.

"Beware the Cost of War," a show opening Friday at the Blackall Studios in London, will be conspicuous for many reasons - one of them being what it lacks: captions and credits next to the images, which were taken both by Israeli and Palestinian photographers.

Not content to simply work le red carpet, the Parisian "It" girl Olympia Le-Tan has toiled in the Chanel design studio, worked as a D.J. at Le Baron and written for French fashion bibles like Purple and Jalouse. Now she can add accessories designer to her résumé, with the release of her handbag collection inspired by first-edition covers of her favorite literary classics, including "For Whom the Bell Tolls," "Moby Dick" and "Satan refuse du monde," above. Named after the Bo Diddley song "You Can't Judge a Book by Its Cover," the 21-piece collection is hand-embroidered, lined with a vintage Liberty print and inscribed with literary quotes like "People Never Notice Anything." If only Holden Caulfield had carried a needlepoint man bag. Available here.

This just in from the Maplewood Police Department: Officers are looking for a man who was wearing a mask, white socks and work boots, and nothing else, while knocking on back doors on Monday. Several reports came in about a naked man walking in the back yards of the condominium complex on Elmwood Avenue and Meadowbrook Place. Witnesses say he knocked on several doors on Monday morning at about 6 a.m. He was described as black, possibly in his 30s, about 5-foot-10 with a medium build. Anyone with information about the man, or about other suspicious activity in the area, is encouraged to call the police immediately. --Tina Kelley

We've previously mentioned how celebrities -- like the Welsh-born actor Jonathan Pryce and Leonardo DiCaprio -- have pitched for carmakers, but turns out the reverse also holds true. Take the Studebaker Automobile Company, which, in addition to making its famed wagonaires and cruisers, was also a sponsor of "Mister Ed," the television series in the 1960s about a talking horse. Judging by the above commercial, the company's Studebaker Wagonaire is roomy enough to fit the family dog. Good news for Rin Tin Tin, but we wonder what Mr. Ed would have had to say about that?

Kurt Warner is coming over to Diner's Journal's house Sunday night to play with his Cardinals against the Giants, trying to best Eli Manning in the who's-the-best sweepstakes. (O.K., not really. It only seems that way on the huge flat-screen TV we got from Marian Burros when we rejoined the department. In fact, the game kicks off at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford at a little before 8:30.)

You think the U.S. has an epidemic of helicopter parents? Consider the case of 12-year-old Luca, who lives in northern Italy, and whose mother and grandparents are said to be so overprotective that they have been charged in court with child abuse.

An own goal was all it took for the Chicago Fire to secure its fifth consecutive berth in the Major League Soccer playoffs. Chivas USA defender Eduardo Lillingston headed in Fire striker Cuauhtemoc Blanco's corner kick in the 68th minute for a 1-0 victory.

Beyond New York City, the words "Bubby's" and "Veselka" may not mean anything except "grandmother" in Yiddish and "rainbow" in Ukrainian. Here in Manhattan, though, the names evoke pierogies, pies and homemade pastrami: both are downtown institutions of beloved comfort food. Bubby's Pie Co. is a TriBeCa brunch mecca (now with an outpost in Dumbo, Brooklyn), and Veselka is a 24-hour Ukrainian diner in the East Village. Both have published new cookbooks, revealing the secrets behind their signature sourdough pancakes and blueberry scones ("Bubby's Brunch Cookbook") and Ola's famous veal goulash and Veselka's famous borscht ("The Veselka Cookbook"). Now you can enjoy them at home, free of lines, strollers and hungover hipsters.

To check or not to check? It's a question that is becoming tougher to answer for airline passengers. The latest salvo in the complicated issue: Virgin America is testing a policy that allows passengers without carry-on items to be seated first.

The celebratory feeling in Vancouver took a sober turn with the death of Jack Poole, the chairman of Vancouver's Olympic Organizing Committee and the man who helped spearhead the city's drive to get the Olympics. Poole, 76, had been waging a battle with pancreatic cancer since 2007.

Americans are worried about global warming. We know this for many reasons. We know it because "An Inconvenient Truth" won an Oscar; because Al Gore's popularity has soared since he left the vice presidency; because the House and Senate are working feverishly on laws to limit greenhouse-gas emissions; and mostly because there are so many books from skeptics accusing environmentalists of having completely snookered the American public.
Alex Ureña is closing Pamplona, at 37 East 28th Street, at the end of service today. He has been in this location for more than four years, first as Ureña , then dressed down a bit as Pamplona.
At a press event in San Francisco on Thursday, Ford showed off a prototype of what might be called the Model T of the automaker's electric car strategy: the battery-powered Focus sedan.

Perhaps you looked at the schedule this week and were not impressed. No Oklahoma-Texas, no Florida-L.S.U. But that doesn't mean there aren't good games. Take the intriguing T.C.U.-B.Y.U. showdown -- it has B.C.S. implications and gives the underrated Mountain West a chance to get some love on a national stage. There are also many other storylines to follow. Can Iowa win at Michigan State? It's really one of the biggest tests left for the undefeated Hawkeyes. Auburn-L.S.U. at night? Why not? Can Oklahoma really go 3-4? Is that possible? Can Penn State win in Ann Arbor? What's going on with Virginia? Can the Cavaliers beat Georgia Tech? Can the Mississippi State coach and former Florida coordinator Dan Mullen turn college football on its head? Just when you think nothing interesting is going to happen is just when something ridiculous happens. Respect the college football.

Halloween has always been the season when Hollywood unleashes some of its most suspenseful and supernatural offerings. When I was a child in the late '60s and early '70s, the horror slate was a splendid array, ranging from the relative innocence of monster-ramas to the erotically tinged creature flicks of Britain's famed Hammer Studios. Somewhere in between were the less stylish but often enjoyable low-budget drive-in fare from America's exploitation studios (almost all of which went out of business years ago) and the occasional major-studio horror movies often rereleased at this time of year.

The federal corruption trial of Bernard B. Kerik, New York's former police commissioner, which was supposed to begin Monday, has been indefinitely postponed, according to a court document.

This is definitely not in the Football Management 101 handbook but on Friday morning, Vinny Cerrato, the Redskins' chief of football operations, announced on his radio show that Coach Jim Zorn would remain until the end of the season, at least. This comes just days after Cerrato pulled the playbook out of Zorn's hands and handed it over to Sherm Lewis, a consultant pulled from retirement and foisted on Zorn just two weeks ago who will start calling plays for the Redskins Monday night against the Eagles.

I love dining out at a Middle Eastern restaurant, but I'd never considered making any of these delicious foods at home. This week, Martha Rose Shulman offers new recipes that use sesame tahini, a paste made from lightly toasted hulled sesame seeds.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Here's the latest from the Pentagon. The generals are worried that the White House is spreading itself thin by trying to fight a war on two fronts, with Afghanistan and Fox News.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President Obama yesterday struck back at the fat cats who took government bailout money. Many of these C.E.O.s and these top executives at the companies are still earning tens of millions dollars a year, even though they took our tax money. But Obama now is ordering that their pay be slashed by up to 90 percent, and needless to say, the executives aren't happy about it. And in fairness to them, they point out that they destroyed the world economy last year, so, to take away their money this year isn't fair. They haven't even destroyed the world economy once this year.

The biggest leveraged buyouts from this decade's takeover boom are making a comeback in the debt market because of concessions from lenders, Bloomberg News has found. The revival comes seven months after investors concluded that these buyouts were almost certain to default.

Americans without health insurance are less likely to know if they have diabetes or high cholesterol than those with coverage, and they're less likely to keep their high blood pressure under control than the insured, a new study reports.

Overview | How would you explain Halloween to someone who never heard of it? In this lesson, students use the Times Topics Halloween page to explore the many facets of this popular holiday. They then make their own contribution to a new Halloween topic page for your school's Web site, inspired by their own memories and the articles and media features they will see today.

The stylist Serge Girardi, who worked on "The Brothers Grim" photo shoot for our fall men's issue, had plenty of gothic inspiration to draw from, like Alexander McQueen's Jack the Ripper show and Ann Demeulemeester's broken-in top hats and riding boots. But a less obvious - and possibly more important - reference was Girardi's love of Edward Gorey illustrations. Girardi used locations that brought to life the sinister atmosphere of Gorey's books, including dramatic gates, classic French gardens and dark skies that enhanced the clothes' eerie vibe. Here are some suggestions on how to make your life a little more mysterious.

Early reviews of President Obama's plans to spur small-business lending are trickling in. Seven years ago, Vancouver was awarded the 2010 Winter Olympics, and John Furlong shifted from his position as the leader of the city's bid to leader of its massive Games preparations. The chief executive of the Vancouver Organizing Committee (VANOC), Furlong shared his thoughts on the Olympics, from carrying the torch (literally) to the expectations heaped on the Canadian men's hockey team.

I rarely pay attention during "open-enrollment" season and just stick with the health benefits I've had in prior years. But as today's Patent Money column explains, doing nothing may not be an option this year.

Olympic teammates and adversaries four years ago, speedskaters Chad Hedrick and Shani Davis insist they have buried the hatchet. On Thursday at the United States World Cup Olympic qualifier at the Pettit National Ice Center in Milwaukee, they showed how close they are, at least competitively.

The European Commission on Friday began soliciting applications for its 2012 and 2013 European Green Capital Award. With four out of five Europeans now living in urban areas, the title -- established in 2006 -- is aimed at recognizing the local environmental efforts of cities of 200,000 or more inhabitants.

After rallying for three runs in the seventh inning against the apparently mortal Phil Hughes and holding on by a thread in the ninth, the Angels will head back to New York for Game 6. The Yankees will start Andy Pettitte, a reliable veteran who is statistically indistinguishable now from the pitcher he was in his mid-20s. The Angels will counter with Joe Saunders, who made the 2008 All-Star Game and is second in the American League in wins to Roy Halladay over the past two seasons.

It's not often that one can look at the world through the eyes of a genius, but thanks to a collaboration between Barneys New York and the California-based eyewear company Barton Perreira, you can at least view it through one's glasses. These frames -- a reproduction of a pair worn by the filmmaker Albert Maysles (of "Grey Gardens" and "Gimme Shelter" fame) since 1960 -- were conceived as the result of a crush. "Our whole office is in love with Albert," admits Julie Gilhart, Barneys' fashion director. The Madison Avenue store will host an event for Maysles on Nov. 4 from 6 to 8 p.m. Fans of the filmmaker -- and of his glasses (they start at $350) -- are welcome.

New Yorkers flock to one of the city's Greenmarkets or upscale grocery stores when they want to buy ripe heirloom tomatoes or crisp heads of lettuce. But for proponents of urban farming, local food from upstate or even just miles into New Jersey is too far. (City dwellers can relate.)

The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, prodded Congress on Friday to enact legislation overhauling the nation's financial regulatory system to prevent a repeat of the banking and credit debacles that thrust the country into crisis.

The cost of going solar fell last year, resuming a decade-long decline after several years of flat prices, according to a new study from the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

It was not entirely clear what message Ilene Jaroslaw meant to send when she appeared in court on Thursday dressed from head-to-toe in funereal black. But based on how things have gone so far in the criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers, Ms. Jaroslaw, a prosecutor in the case, could well have been in mourning.

The city of broad shoulders gave a cold one this morning to the 10 worst dining trends of the last decade. Christopher Borrelli, a reporter for the Chicago Tribune, interviewed chefs, consultants, journalists, people in and out of the clean-plate club to determine the most annoying tics and tradecraft of restaurants in the first decade of the 21st Century. (A tip of the toque to Brett Anderson of the New Orleans Times-Picayune for pointing the article out.) Mr. Borrelli's got foam in there, and media-crazy chefs, and menus big as books. Take a gander and tell us what he missed. (Overthought cocktails!)

As part of an investigation into donations made by nonprofit groups to politicians, the state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has ordered dozens of charities to take back illegal contributions -- or lose their tax-exempt status, The New York Post reports.

The National Automobile Dealers Association represents 17,000 car and truck dealers, whose interests have occasionally diverged from the carmakers (represented by the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers). This is quite apparent in their approach to the federal combined fuel economy and greenhouse gas standards for vehicles announced by the Obama administration last May and set to go into effect in model year 2012. A public hearing on those standards will be held in New York on Friday.

Since I wrote about China's currency in today's column, I had to confront the issue of what to call the darn thing. In fact, I sometimes think that the whole renminbi/yuan issue is a sinister plot by the Chinese designed specifically to deter people from discussing Chinese currency policy. (Note to literalist readers: that's a joke).

Mike Hulme, a professor at the University of East Anglia School of Environmental Sciences in Britain and a veteran climate adviser, has climbed way above the global warming debate to decode the nature of discord over climate change in a new book: "Why We Disagree About Climate Change."

On a weekend like this, when the major conferences have seemingly forgotten to offer up a marquee game, the Mountain West comes through. Texas Christian wants to keep its dreams of the B.C.S. alive, but to do so it will have to beat Brigham Young in Provo, not an easy task. And how about Penn State going to Michigan, where it seems the Nittany Lions can never win? Oklahoma goes to Kansas, but without Sam Bradford. In the Big East, Pittsburgh continues its quest to gain some national respect when it hosts South Florida, while Connecticut, which has experienced tragedy off the field this week, will find itself back on the field, at West Virginia. Lindsey Van is the reigning world champion in women's ski jumping, a sport that is fighting in court for its Olympic future. Van and 14 other women from five countries are pursuing a lawsuit filed in 2008 against the organizers of the Vancouver Olympics to force their inclusion in the Games after the I.O.C. voted not to include a women's event for 2010. With the recent addition of women's boxing, ski jumping is the only sport in the Olympics open to men's competition only. In 1991, the I.O.C. adopted a rule saying any new sport added to the Games must include both women and men.

The first time I ever opened a newspaper, it was for the express purpose of reading Bill Watterson's Calvin and Hobbes. And so it went throughout most of my childhood. Nothing -- not sports, local news or even the great Midwest flood of 1993 -- concerned me. The adventures of a boy and his stuffed tiger, however, kept me coming back daily. Until, that is, Watterson retired from the comic strip and, essentially, public life. Like Martin Margiela and Kate Moss, he famously refuses all interview requests, and he has spoken publicly about his work only once since 1995.
Today's idea: More and more hotels, restaurants, and retailers are adopting bad music as a branding device, a travel editor says. Please make it stop.

Last year's one-day inaugural edition attracted over a thousand people, so the founders decided to expand it to a full weekend event this year.

More than 70 years after her disappearance, Amelia Earhart, above, has once again eluded her pursuers, as a museum item believed to be a lock of her hair has turned out to be a piece of thread. The International Women’s Air and Space Museum in Cleveland put the sample on display this year, Agence France-Presse reported, and described it as a strand of Earhart’s hair that had been recovered by a White House maid after the aviatrix, who was a friend of Eleanor Roosevelt, stayed there before her final flight. But DNA analysis revealed that it did not match other possessions of Earhart that were found on the Pacific island of Nikumaroro. Earhart went missing over the Pacific Ocean in 1937 during an attempted solo flight around the world. The thread still remains on display at the museum as part of an Earhart exhibition that runs through Nov. 15. “We’ve changed the sign and explained everything,” Heather Alexander, the museum’s manager, told Agence France-Presse, adding that visitors “show more interest and are very grateful that we are telling the truth and the whole story.”.

R.E.M., Trent Reznor and Pearl Jam (with the lead singer Eddie Vedder, left) are among the musicians who have joined a campaign to close the prison at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, as they seek to learn whether their music was used during the questioning of detainees there, The Associated Press reported. The National Security Archive in Washington said it was filing a Freedom of Information Act request on behalf of a coalition called the National Campaign to Close Guantánamo, including an effort to gain details about how loud music was used as an interrogation technique. Based on public documents and interviews with former detainees, the archive said, Guantánamo prisoners were played loud music, including songs by AC/DC, Britney Spears and Marilyn Manson, as well as advertising jingles and “Sesame Street” tunes, in their cells and in preparation for interrogations. Thomas Blanton, the archive’s director, told The A.P., “At Guantánamo, the U.S. government turned a jukebox into an instrument of torture.” A spokeswoman for Joint Task Force Guantánamo, which handles the care and custody of detainees, said loud music had not been used with prisoners since the fall of 2003.
“Criminal Minds” placed first in the ratings on Wednesday night, drawing 13.7 million viewers and helping CBS lead the night over all, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

Days before Roman Polanski was arrested in Switzerland, American prosecutors were monitoring him in Austria and considered having him apprehended there. In an e-mail exchange that appears in documents obtained by The Associated Press, prosecutors in Los Angeles discussed the possibility of seeking the arrest of Mr. Polanski, 76, in Vienna in mid-September when he traveled there for the opening of a musical based on his film “Dance of the Vampires.” “I don’t have experience with any Austrian extraditions, so I don’t know how ‘friendly’ they would be to extradition on such a case,” wrote Diana Carbajal, a deputy district attorney, in an e-mail message dated Sept. 23 and reported by The A.P. Ms. Carbajal added that Mr. Polanski was already “on the move” to the Zurich Film Festival and asked if it was preferable to “maintain our position to extradite from Switzerland.” Lael Rubin, another deputy district attorney, replied, “Yes.” Mr. Polanski was arrested on Sept. 26 by the Swiss authorities as he arrived at the Zurich airport. He remains in a Swiss prison pending his possible extradition to the United States, where he fled sentencing in 1978 after admitting to having sex with a 13-year-old girl.

Opera purists may be pleased to learn that the renovation of New York City Opera’s home at Lincoln Center, the David H. Koch Theater, has eliminated the amplification system for live voices that was installed in 1999. New York City Ballet shares the house — formerly the New York State Theater — with the opera, and the stage had originally been designed to muffle footfalls. The acoustic system was revamped twice before amplification was added. City Opera opens its season on Nov. 5 in the renovated theater, where the changes include new acoustic side walls installed near the stage and new seats that have been tested for sound absorption.

Soho Rep, which drew wide notice last season for its critically acclaimed production of Sarah Kane’s “Blasted,” announced three works as major productions of its 2009-10 season. First up is “Lear,” written and directed by Young Jean Lee (“The Shipment”), which blends text from Shakespeare’s tragedy with elements from her own life. “Lear” is scheduled to run Jan. 7 to 31. “Orange, Hat & Grace,” by Gregory Moss (“punkplay”), a dark comedy about relationships and ecology, will be staged by the Soho Rep artistic director, Sarah Benson, and is set for March 11 to April 4. Cynthia Hopkins’s one-woman piece “The Truth: A Tragedy,” in which she pays homage to her dying father through memories, song and dance, is scheduled for May 6 to 30. Ms. Benson also announced a new program that would produce three panel discussions during the run of each production, drawing on writers, directors, musicians and others to address the themes of the works.

How often does one get to say that Eric Bogosian, below, is making a theatrical debut? Though Mr. Bogosian, the hyperverbal actor and prolific playwright, has appeared onstage and had his work produced on Broadway (a revival of his play “Talk Radio” ran at the Longacre Theater in 2007), he has not performed on Broadway himself — yet. But now Mr. Bogosian has been added to the cast of Manhattan Theater Club’s production of “Time Stands Still,” the Donald Margulies play that is coming to the Samuel J. Friedman Theater next year. In a news release, publicists for the production said that Mr. Bogosian, a cast member of television’s “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” will appear in the play as the editor of a photojournalist played by Laura Linney. The previously announced cast includes Brian d’Arcy James and Alicia Silverstone. “Time Stands Still” is to begin previews on Jan. 5 and open on Jan. 28.

ROSEN--Sandra, also known as Sally Fairchild of Manhattan, sadly passed away October 13th, 2009 in New York City. She was a distinguished painter and graduate of Brandeis University and Cooper Union. Her work has been exhibited since the 1970s at numerous art galleries; The Whitney Museum; The National Academy of Design; and in shows sponsored by The National Association of Women Artists. She has been listed in the Who's Who of American Women and has sold paintings since the 1960s to private collectors as well as institutions. Born to a French mother and raised in New Jersey, she was predeceased (1985) by her husband, Professor Edward Rosen, a prominent historian of science. She is survived by her loving only child, Carla Jeannette Rosen-Vacher. Donations in her memory may be sent to Defenders of Wildlife in Washington, DC.

Americans are increasingly gloomy about the costs and quality of their health care if Congress passes overhaul legislation, according to the latest USA Today/Gallup poll. The survey results underscore the political challenges for supporters of a health care overhaul, as few Americans see benefits for themselves in changing the system.

McNEVIN--Arthur John, died October 18, 2009 in Las Vegas, NV at the age of 83. Arthur was born in Brooklyn, NY to Clara and George McNevin and raised in South Ozone Park. At age 17, during World War II, he enlisted in the US Navy and spent four years as a radio man on a destroyer seeing action from Normandy to Okinawa. When he was discharged in 1947, he became a member of the NYPD where he remained for 41 years, earning BS and MSA degrees from John Jay College along the way. He retired in 1988 as Assistant Chief Manhattan South. He then joined MacAndrews & Forbes where he was Chief of Security from 1988 until his retirement in 1996. He is survived by his beloved wife Patricia, sons Douglas, Bruce (Joan Nix), and Scott (Maryvonne), daughter Bonnie Carson (Andrew) and their mother, Doris Scarangello, by six Grandchildren, Amy Valdes (Ricardo), Heather Bennis (David), Alexander (Abigail), John, Kelly, Courtney and Great-Grandson Aidan. Friends may call on Sunday, October 25 at Joseph Duffy Funeral Home, 255 Ninth Street, Brooklyn from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Service on Monday, October 26 at 10:45am at the Greenwood Cemetery Chapel.

R.E.M.,Trent Reznor and Pearl Jam (with the lead singer Eddie Vedder, left) are among the musicians who have joined a campaign to close the prison at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, as they seek to learn whether their music was used during the questioning of detainees there, The Associated Press reported. The National Security Archive in Washington said it was filing a Freedom of Information Act request on behalf of a coalition called the National Campaign to Close Guantánamo, including an effort to gain details about how loud music was used as an interrogation technique. Based on public documents and interviews with former detainees, the archive said, Guantánamo prisoners were played loud music, including songs by AC/DC, Britney Spears and Marilyn Manson, as well as advertising jingles and ''Sesame Street'' tunes, in their cells and in preparation for interrogations. Thomas Blanton, the archive's director, told The A.P., ''At Guantánamo, the U.S. government turned a jukebox into an instrument of torture.'' A spokeswoman for Joint Task Force Guantánamo, which handles the care and custody of detainees, said loud music had not been used with prisoners since the fall of 2003.

Even by the standards of the Oakland Raiders, the accusation that Coach Tom Cable had broken the jaw of an assistant coach during training camp was bizarre. On Thursday, the Napa County district attorney announced that after a two-month investigation, Cable would not be charged. Cable is not completely in the clear. The N.F.L. announced Thursday night that it would review the district attorney's decision and the surrounding investigation and then decide if Cable would face discipline under the league's personal conduct policy. Commissioner Roger Goodell has taken a hard line against players who have violated the policy, and last week Goodell left open the possibility of disciplining Cable even if he was not charged.

VASSALOTTI--Alfred Gaetano. Alfred was born on January 11, 1929 of immigrants from Riccia, Italy in the house built by his carpenter father. His deaf mother instilled a lifelong respect for education in him. Al was Queens College class of 1951 valedictorian and later earned a Masters in Mathematics from the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. He served on the fulltime faculty at Hofstra University in the Mathematics Department from 1961 to 1997. Thereafter, he remained as Associate Professor Emeritus. He enjoyed dining with family, playing chess, listening to classical music, and using his unique middle name. In his later years, Alfred was sustained through chronic illness by his devoted wife of 47 years, Carmela. Besides his wife, survivors include two sons; Joseph and Thomas; a daughter, Andrea; a daughter-in-law, Lisa; and two grandchildren, Alex and Emily. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30pm at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave., New Hyde Park, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10:30am at Our Lady of the Snows RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Hofstra University or Ozanam Hall of Queens Nursing Home.

The number of New York City residents receiving food stamps reached 1.6 million in August, reflecting a surge of nearly 30 percent in less than two years, the largest since the early 1970s. The increase amounts to about $680 million annually in additional federal assistance to low-income city residents, the city's Independent Budget Office reported on Thursday.

Remember when drug makers, hospitals, doctors and medical device manufacturers stood by President Obama earlier this year and pledged to cut $2 trillion in health costs over the next decade? A nonpartisan coalition of business, labor and religious groups has a message for Congress: write that promise into law. In a report issued Thursday, the National Coalition on Health Care called on Congress to write a trigger mechanism into any health care overhaul that would enforce savings through regulation if industry failed to live up to its promises after a set period.

SLAVIN--Theodore R.,born February 18, 1914, died October 1, 2009 in Cambridge, MA. Survived by sons Malcolm of Cambridge, Dennis of NYC, grandchildren Samuel, Anna, and Anya, and daughters-in-law Joyce and Julia. His cherished wife, Rose, died one year earlier. An architect in New York, he began a joyous second phase of his career in 1979 on Cape Cod, combining traditional Cape Cod forms with open, bright, contemporary interiors. We painfully miss our "voice of the heart." Donations in Ted's memory may be sent to The Cambridge Homes, 360 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

Senior American and Chinese officials urged their governments on Thursday to accelerate joint efforts to reduce pollution, even as their diplomats appeared at odds over crucial elements of a global strategy to fight climate change to be considered in Copenhagen in December. The calls for cooperation, led by Vice Premier Li Keqiang, came at a clean-energy forum attended by nearly 200 of both nations' leading experts on climate change issues and technologies. The forum's primary goal is to devise new ways in which Chinese and American researchers, corporations and others can work together to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

SCHINDLER--Charles Joseph, Jr. February 10, 1917-October 21, 2009. My father, my hero. A veteran of World War II wounded in the Anzio invasion, he was a prisoner of war who was awarded the Purple Heart. Charlie, as he was known to all, died at the age of 92 from heart failure, predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Rosemarie (nee Naccarato), and his son Raymond. The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, said on Thursday that Iran must cease all uranium enrichment, a statement that reflected Israeli concern over a draft agreement taking shape in Vienna, where earlier this week Iran took part in nuclear talks with the United States, Russia and France. Under the tentative agreement, about three-quarters of Iran's known stockpile of nuclear fuel would be shipped to Russia for enrichment to levels suitable for a peaceful reactor but too low for weapons.

Under a public plan, also referred to as a public option, the government would offer an insurance plan, perhaps similar to Medicare. The government plan would compete with private insurers as one of the choices in an organized marketplace or exchange that sets rules for coverage and pricing.

The last game at the old Yankee Stadium was over, Derek Jeter had offered a spirited speech to the fans and players had scooped up some dirt as a memento. Still, there was something left to do. For four Yankees, it was time to acknowledge what they had done together. So Jeter, Andy Pettitte, Mariano Rivera and Jorge Posada, who all made their debuts with the Yankees within five months of each other in 1995, gathered behind the mound. The players wrapped their arms around each other's shoulders and smiled for a picture, a picture that spoke of their sustained success.

Interment in Calverton National Cemetery.

An article on Sept. 26 about the transfer of Najibullah Zazi from Denver to New York to await a hearing on terror charges paraphrased incorrectly from comments by people briefed on the case about a theory that Mr. Zazi had previously built a test bomb in Colorado and detonated it. The theory was that he had set the bomb off in Denver or in the area surrounding it, not ''somewhere in the desert around Denver.'' (There is no desert around Denver.)

HERMAN--Judith Axelrood, a market research pioneer whose early career included stints working with Bill Simmons and Ernest Dichter, passed away peacefully on October 11 in Chicago surrounded by friends and family. The cause was pancreatic cancer. Born December 4, 1931 to Betty (Gottlieb) and Irving Axelrood, Judy was one of the first women to earn an MBA from Columbia University in 1955 and throughout her career was known for analytically sophisticated quantitative and qualitative opinion research. Judy held market research and planning positions at General Foods, Allied Stores Corporation, and Saks Fifth Avenue before moving to San Francisco in 1980 to become Manager for Multidivisional Research for Levi Strauss & Co. She founded her own consultancy, Information & Strategy, in 1984 and was busy working on projects through 2008. Her client list was a Silicon Valley Who's Who, including Cirrus Logic, Fujitsu Microelectronics, GE Calma, Hewlett-Packard, Hitachi, Informix, KAO Corp of America, National Semiconductor Corp., and Synopsis. Other clients included the California Milk Advisory Board and the California Tree Fruit Agreement, Cellular One, Jelly Belly jelly beans, Holland America Cruise Lines, Levi Strauss & Co., Oracle Corp, Pacific Bell, Ross Stores, and Sutter Health Systems. Judy worked closely with advertising agencies such as Dimmick & Fornari, Foote Cone & Belding, McCann-Erickson, Miller Communications, Poppe Tyson Advertising, Saatchi & Saatchi and the Stephenz Group. In addition to her work for corporations, Judy, along with her lifelong friend Jay Schulman, pioneered the use of market research methodologies in the selection of juries for civil and criminal trials. Judy loved cold calling, martinis and her dogs, and she was an avid reader of the New York Review of Books. Predeceased by Bert Herman, her husband of 49 years, Judy will be profoundly missed by her children Lydia Lazar and Roger Herman, and by her grandchildren Rachel, Naomi, Andrea and Michael. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to PAWS (Pets Are Worth Saving) at 1110 W. 35th St., Chicago, Illinois 60609. 773-475-9510. A memorial service will be held Saturday, December 5th at Scott's Restaurant in Oakland, California. Please contact lydialazar@msn.com for more details.

BEITCH--Irwin, 71, of Cheshire, Connecticut, died suddenly on October 12, 2009, from complications produced by an overwhelming and insidious bacterial infection. Surviving him are his wife Barbara; his son Rick (Jonathan Eric Beitch); his three grandchildren Andy (Andrew), Miranda, and Sarah; and his brother-in-law Joel Rose, and Joel's wife Pamela Rose. His large and loving family of cousins, nephews, nieces, and other relatives close to Irwin were shocked at this sudden loss and mourn his death. Irwin Beitch was a Professor of Biology at Quinnipiac University, where he taught courses in histology, histochemistry, and biomedical photography. As a dedicated teacher for over 40 years who loved his subject matter as well as his students, Irwin had tremendous impact on the many students whose life-science professions he helped to launch. He had no plans to retire. He was a conscientious, effective, and diligent teacher who kept himself on the cutting edge and incorporated the latest technology into all of his courses. His fraternity brothers at the University of Richmond, the students he taught (while a graduate student at the University of Virginia and later as a faculty member at Quinnipiac University), and the new educators who joined the Quinnipiac faculty all remember him as a caring mentor who took the time to reach out and help them become integrated into the community. He met his wife-to-be, then Barbara Susan Rose, in 1962, on their first day of graduate school at the University of Virginia and they were together ever since. As a married couple, they shared their studies and supported each other in their Ph.D. research, completing their respective degrees within an hour of each other. They started their family together in Charlottesville, where their daughter Deborah was born. Later, while working on postdoctoral fellowships in Ophthalmology Research at Columbia University, they planned their second child, Jonathan Eric ("Rick"), whom they adopted soon after they moved to Connecticut in 1969. Irwin was an active member of the Board of Directors for the Sleeping Giant Park Association, where he was the Chairman of the Hiking Committee and Photography Editor of the Giant News. He was a "behind the scenes" man, pouring love and energy into projects associated with the Sleeping Giant, as well as many endeavors at Quinnipiac University and volunteer work at the Yale Peabody Museum. He always seemed to manage to give to others the accolades and recognition for this work. He and his wife loved to travel. As avid scuba divers, they visited and photographed coral reefs and underwater volcanic ecosystems all over the world. In addition, they traveled together in Europe, in Ecuador and Central America, from the highlands of Papua New Guinea to the protected animal preserves of Zambia and Botswana, and recently went on an educational trip to cities and small towns in many parts of China. Irwin was an avid and talented photographer who recorded all of these experiences first on film and, in more recent years, digitally. His family and friends will be able to enrich their memories of Irwin as they peruse the wonderful photographs he took over the years. Irwin Beitch touched and truly enriched the lives of countless colleagues, friends, and students and will long be remembered for his empathy and caring for others as well as his infamous dry wit and gifts as a story teller. Although born of Jewish parents and raised in the Jewish tradition, he was a free spirit who always said that he "worshiped at the library." A memorial service for Irwin Beitch will be held on November 19 at 7pm, in Alumni Hall at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, CT. Memorial contributions in his name may be made to the Sleeping Giant Park Association, P.O. Box 185340, Hamden, CT 06518-0340. For further information call Levine Memorial Chapel at 518-438-1002.

Martin Brodeur entered the Devils' game Thursday seeking his 103rd career shutout to tie Terry Sawchuk's N.H.L. record, but he was after a more immediate target: he had not been the winning goalie in regulation at Madison Square Garden since Dec. 17, 2006, an eight-game stretch. Brodeur lost the shutout early in the second period, but he realized his greater ambition as the Devils survived a wild game with a 4-2 victory over the Rangers. That boosted the Devils' road record to 4-0 while sending the Rangers to their second straight loss after a seven-game winning streak.

STONE--Betty (nee Yolles). Born April 28, 1911, died peacefully on October 21. Loving mother of Amy Belkin and adored grandmother of Jeffrey Belkin; beloved sister of Dede Draper and adored aunt of Dr. William Grossman of San Francisco. We will all miss her sweet presence.

EVERETT--Horace Henderson "Sonny," 72, passed away on September 30, 2009 in New York City. He was born on August 31, 1937 in Fordyce, AR to Jasper Horace Everett, a Ford dealer, and Corrine Henderson Everett, a school teacher. Sonny graduated from Rollins College in Winter Park, FL in 1959, where he met his wife and best friend Toni Perzia Everett. They settled in Tampa, FL in 1962. His proudest accomplishments were his children and grandchildren. He is survived by Toni, son Anthony Mark Everett (Julie), daughter Henderson Everett Lee (Ben), and four grandchildren. Sonny moved to New York in 1987 to pursue a dream of being a Broadway producer. In just 20 short years, his theater credits include: Tony Award-winning Avenue Q, In The Heights, The Drowsy Chaperone, Irving Berlin's White Christmas, State Fair; The Vita and Virginia, The Beauty Queen of Leeane, June Moon, The Laramie Project, Gross Indecency, Tru, As Bees in Honey Drown, Blown Sideways Through Life, Avenue Boys, Madame Melville, Moon Over Buffalo, La Boheme, the current revival of West Side Story, and the upcoming musical Minsky's. He was Kitty Carlisle Hart's producer for My Life on the Wicked Stage and History of American Musical Theater. Beyond producing, Sonny was an important member of the theater community. He provided insurance to many Broadway and Off-Broadway productions, "insuring everything but the critics." He served on the board of several New York theater groups, and offered his encouragement, counsel and friendship to a generation of stage professionals. Sonny was a member of The University Club of New York and The Coffee House. Dramatic, effervescent and occasionally over-the-top, Sonny loved to dance, travel and enjoy friendships. He will be remembered for his sincerity, personality and style. A memorial service will be held at New World Stages, 340 W. 50th Street in New York on Monday, October 26 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Actor's Fund (actorsfund.org).

EMMONS--David Emmons, Professor of Criminal Justice at Richard Stockton College, died October 19 at Atlantic Regional Hospital, in Galloway, NJ. He was 69. David is survived by his daughter Molly, his two brothers John and James and his father, Alton Thomas. A memorial will be held Monday, October 26th at 6pm at Adams-Perfect Funeral Home, 1650 New Road, Northfield, NJ. Visitation will be held from 5pm until time of services at the funeral home. Donations can be made in David's name to Westtown Friends School. Services are entrusted to and written condolences may be sent to: www.Adams-Perfect.com.

It would have been difficult to mistake New York City as a stronghold for the disaffected Anglicans -- upset about the church's acceptance of women and gays in leadership positions -- whom the Vatican this week announced it would be wooing to join the Roman Catholic Church. But that point was made even more clear when Bishop Lawrence C. Provenzano, who represents the 146 congregations in the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island (including Brooklyn and Queens), dashed off a response to the announcement, made by the Vatican on Tuesday. ''At the heart of all of this is the reality that the Roman Church is willing to welcome angry, reactionary, misogynistic, homophobic people,'' he wrote in a statement.
ELAHI--Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

McMAHON--T. Gordon, on October 20, 2009. T. Gordon McMahon died at age 56 in New York City of multiple myeloma cancer. Gordon is survived by his wife, Dede Dalton McMahon and his three children, Katherine, Ryan and Rachel McMahon of New York City, his mother, Thelma McMahon of Washington and sisters Doris McMahon of Florida and Diane McMahon of Milwaukee, WI. Gordon is also survived by his former wife, Karen Li of New York City. Gordon was born in Washington December 29, 1952 to Thelma and the late Thomas Anthony McMahon. He grew up in Washington where he attended Archbishop Carroll High School a school that remained important to him throughout his life. He received his undergraduate degree in Psychology from Yale University and an MBA in Finance From Harvard Business School. After Harvard, Wall Street beckoned Gordon but he opted instead for the glamour and climate of California where he opened his first business venture, an ice cream parlor called "Just Desserts," but Wall Street still pursued him and in late 1976 the investment banking firm of Goldman Sachs convinced him that the real glamour was indeed on Wall Street and he began his career at the storied investment house. Gordon enjoyed phenomenal success at Goldman Sachs and, at age 31, was elected a general partner in the firm the youngest partner ever up until that time. After retiring from Goldman in 1993, Gordon worked briefly for one of his former clients, Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, but it was not long before Gordon realized that the business role he liked most was that of an entrepreneur and for the rest of his life, Gordon was involved in investing in and often times running start-up companies. He loved the challenges and the learning experiences they provided. Gordon always remembered and appreciated what he learned from others, especially his parents, Thelma and Thomas whom he considered his heroes. The central lesson of life he took from them is that "family is everything" and he shared this philosophy freely with everyone he knew. He also felt strongly about the positive influence his years at Archbishop Carroll had on him and he continued to give back time and money to the school throughout his adult life. The large number of family and friends Gordon left behind all feel tremendously blessed to have known and loved him and are thankful for the life that he shared with them.

The former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic has said in a letter to the United Nations war crimes tribunal that he will not attend the start of his trial on Monday, insisting that he needs more time to prepare his defense. Mr. Karadzic, who faces charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity for his role in Bosnia's 1992-95 war, has repeatedly asked for more time. The judges at the tribunal have maintained that Mr. Karadzic has had ample time to prepare for his defense since his arrest in Belgrade in July 2008.

KRAT--Irving. Father of Gary, Robert, Kurt and the late Donna, passed away peacefully at his home in Pennsylvania on Thursday, October 22nd at the age of 91. An accounting problem in the way some greenhouse gas emissions are calculated could critically hobble efforts to reduce them in coming years as nations move to combat global warming, scientists warn in a new report. The accounting irregularity even gives the impression that clearing the world's forests, which absorb and thereby diminish heat-trapping carbon dioxide, is good for the climate, the scientists write in an article published Friday in the journal Science.

In a flurry of legal paper in the Roman Polanski extradition case on Friday, one thing became clear: The Obama administration doesn’t intend to adopt Mr. Polanski’s considerable public relations problem as its own. Late Thursday, according to Swiss authorities, the U.S. government delivered its formal request that Mr. Polanski be returned to the United States to face sentencing on a 32-year-old charge of having sex with a minor. That means the Polanski team failed to persuade the Justice Department to terminate the extradition­ — a step that would almost certainly have stirred a heavy backlash from those who want to see Mr. Polanski face the courts.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan - Islamabad, once the safest city in the country, feels under siege, as the war has crept across the border from Afghanistan and now slowly into the capital with near daily Taliban bombings and shootings. Constant threats of suicide attacks have spread unaccustomed panic. Schools are closed. Shopping malls are deserted. Traffic has thinned. With winter approaching, evenings are darker and quieter with a foreboding air.

Whenever exchange rates enter into discussion, certain zombie fallacies -- ideas that you kill repeatedly, but refuse to die -- inevitably make their appearance. What I'm hearing a lot now is the old line that exchange rates have nothing to do with international imbalances: the trade deficit is the difference between investment spending and savings, and that's all there is to it. It's a fallacy that John Williamson of the Institute for International Economics calls the doctrine of immaculate transfer. So let me try killing the zombie once again.

The Vital Statistics column on Oct. 13, about a new state-by-state breakdown of diabetes cases among Americans 30 and over, referred incompletely to the findings, which were published in the online journal BioMed Central. The analysis covered all diabetes cases; it did not distinguish between Types 1 and 2. (About 95 percent of diabetes cases in those 30 and over are Type 2.).

An article in some editions on Friday about the Angels’ 7-6 victory over the Yankees in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series misstated, in some copies, the number of outs in the ninth inning when Angels closer Brian Fuentes intentionally walked Alex Rodriguez. Fuentes had already gotten two outs; he did not walk Rodriguez with no outs.

An article on Wednesday about an agreement on a new contract between the National Basketball Association and its referees union referred incorrectly to remarks made by David Stern, the league commissioner, to the news media in September. While Stern criticized the union, he did not “exchange insults” with the union’s lead negotiator, Lamell McMorris.

A chart last Saturday with an article about Britain’s growing national debt misstated the amount of the United States’ debt. According to the International Monetary Fund, the American government’s gross national debt as a percentage of gross domestic product in 2005 was 61.4 percent and the projection for 2010 is 93.6 percent. The figures cited in the chart, 37.5 percent in 2005 and 61.1 percent in 2010, were from the Congressional Budget Office and included only federal debt held by the public.

An article on Friday about allegations of deficiencies in federally financed cancer treatment trials at the Carle Cancer Center in Urbana, Ill., misstated federal oversight of such community research sites. While federal officials have not conducted a systematic patient safety review of the community research program with the level of scrutiny they are now applying to Carle, the National Cancer Institute audits such centers at least once every 36 months and has evaluated the overall program several times, most recently in 2007. It is not true that federal officials “have never conducted a systematic review” of the program.

American officials formally requested the extradition of Roman Polanski on Thursday, setting in motion the next legal struggle for the Oscar-winning film director over his flight in 1978 from sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. The American Embassy in Bern submitted the request to the Federal Office of Justice in Switzerland, where Mr. Polanski has been imprisoned since his arrest on Sept. 26 at the Zurich airport. The Swiss authorities will now forward the request to the canton of Zurich for a hearing, according to a statement from the Swiss federal office. If the local authorities order extradition, Mr. Polanski, who holds French and Polish citizenship, can still appeal the decision to the Swiss Federal Criminal Court and the Federal Supreme Court. Mr. Polanski’s French lawyers, Georges Kiejman and Hervé Temime, above, said that Mr. Polanski could end up spending six months or more in the Swiss jail while the appeals process runs its course. They said the director planned to fight the extradition demand.

Not all of Michael Jackson’s fans are eagerly awaiting the release of the documentary “This Is It”: a contingent of the King of Pop’s admirers have formed a group that plans to protest the film’s release, saying it sugarcoats the circumstances that led to Mr. Jackson’s death, Reuters reported. The documentary, which Sony Pictures is releasing on Wednesday, was compiled from footage shot during the rehearsals for the “This Is It” concerts that Mr. Jackson was to perform in London. He died on June 25 from an overdose of several drugs, including propofol, an anesthetic he had been taking as a sleeping aid. The protest group, which calls itself This Is Not It, says the movie presents Mr. Jackson as being in good health while it enriches people who the group says should have taken better care of him.

For now, at least, Steven A. Cohen, the hedge-fund billionaire and collector, seems to be content with buying art at auctions without buying the auction house too. Earlier this year Mr. Cohen’s fund, SAC Capital Advisors, disclosed in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had accumulated about a 6 percent stake in Sotheby’s. Around the same time, Mr. Cohen and his wife, Alexandra, loaned 20 artworks from their collection, which is estimated to be worth $750 million, for an exhibition at Sotheby’s. The two developments led to speculation about whether Mr. Cohen might enjoy the perks of owning an auction house, and might be interested in taking Sotheby’s private. But more recent S.E.C. filings show that as of the end of June, SAC Capital had sold all of its Sotheby’s stock. A spokesman for SAC, Jonathan Gasthalter, declined to comment on why SAC had sold the stock.

Ryan Trecartin, below, a 28-year-old painter, sculptor and filmmaker from Philadelphia, was named the first winner of the Wolgin International Competition in the Fine Arts on Thursday night, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The competition, which is endowed by the real-estate investor Jack Wolgin, with the winner named by the Tyler School of Art at Temple University, carries a prize of $150,000. Mr. Trecartin’s work has been shown at the 2006 Whitney Biennial and the Guggenheim Museum, as well as the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles and the Saatchi Gallery in London. The Inquirer said the competition did not accept unsolicited applicants; instead, an advisory board chose about a dozen nominators from the international art world who recommended about 20 candidates. The other finalists were Sanford Biggers, an artist from New York, and Michael Rakowitz, from Chicago and New York.

It is well known that during the nation's gale-force recession, many older Americans who dreamed of retirement continued to work, often because their 401(k)'s had plunged in value. In fact, there are more Americans 65 and older in the job market today than at any time in history, 6.6 million, compared with 4.1 million in 2001.

Americans without health insurance are less likely to know if they have diabetes or high cholesterol than those with coverage, and they are less likely to keep their high blood pressure under control than the insured, a new study reports. The researchers used national health survey data to look at three chronic but manageable health conditions -- diabetes, hypertension and high cholesterol -- that can lead to serious long-term complications often treated at public expense and thus contributing to overall health care costs.

The path to Nick Swisher's locker was blocked by a few dozen reporters Thursday night, so he waited. Swisher never said a word about needing to get around them, preferring to let others do it for him. It was more patience than Swisher showed at the start of his at-bat in the ninth inning of Game 5. When Swisher marched to the plate with two outs and the bases loaded and the Yankees trailing by a run, he was one hit away from expunging his dreary October. A two-run single and the Yankees could have been on their way to the World Series. But Swisher popped out, the Los Angeles Angels won, 7-6, and the American League Championship Series moved back to the Bronx for Game 6 on Saturday night.

In recent years, a long layoff before the World Series has been deleterious for the more rested team, with one exception. Faced with a six-day hiatus in 2006, the Detroit Tigers crumbled in St. Louis, losing in five games. After an unprecedented eight-day break in 2007, the Colorado Rockies were swept by the Red Sox.

Anybody watching the Yankee-Angels series understands the home field advantage. He who bats last often laughs last. Jockeying for the same sort of edge is going on in the Senate right now in the debate over whether to add a government-run insurance plan to the big health care legislation.

In a usual week, ''Question Time'' is a worthy but largely unexciting television production, a late-night panel discussion on the BBC that for 30 years has attracted a modest, pre-bedtime audience. But on Thursday, it was transformed into the forum for Britain's most widely anticipated political showdown in decades, drawing 8.2 million viewers, more than three times the program's usual audience, on a par with the World Cup games played by England's soccer team and more than the number of viewers for such weekly prime time hit shows as ''Strictly Come Dancing.''

Despite all the wailing and celebrating by opposing parties, it may be years before landlords and tenants in New York City know the full impact of a decision by the state's highest court on Thursday that the owners of two major residential complexes improperly charged market-rate rents for thousands of apartments. The New York Court of Appeals ruled that the owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, adjoining complexes in Manhattan with 11,227 apartments, improperly raised rents and deregulated 4,400 apartments while receiving special tax breaks from the city.

Beloved wife of the late Morris, loving mother of Naomi Toder (Steve) and Joel (Michelle), adoring grandmother of Matthew Toder, Emily Toder, Nicole Diamond, Michael Diamond and Lisa Diamond. She also is survived by an extended family for whom she cared deeply. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Sunday, October 25 at 2pm. Shiva at the home of Naomi and Steve Toder, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, 6-9pm. McNEVIN--Arthur John, died October 18, 2009 in Las Vegas, NV at the age of 83. Arthur was born in Brooklyn, NY to Clara and George McNevin and raised in South Ozone Park. At age 17, during World War II, he enlisted in the US Navy and spent four years as a radio man on a destroyer seeing action from Normandy to Okinawa. When he was discharged in 1947, he became a member of the NYPD where he remained for 41 years, earning BS and MSA degrees from John Jay College along the way. He retired in 1988 as Assistant Chief Manhattan South. He then joined MacAndrews & Forbes where he was Chief of Security from 1988 until his retirement in 1996. He is survived by his beloved wife Patricia, sons Douglas, Bruce (Joan Nix), and Scott (Maryvonne), daughter Bonnie Carson (Andrew) and their mother, Doris Scarangello, by six Grandchildren, Amy Valdes (Ricardo), Heather Bennis (David), Alexander (Abigail), John, Kelly, Courtney and Great-Grandson Aidan. Friends may call on Sunday, October 25 at Joseph Duffy Funeral Home, 255 Ninth Street, Brooklyn from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Service on Monday, October 26 at 10:45am at the Greenwood Cemetery Chapel.

Defense ministers from NATO on Friday endorsed the ambitious counterinsurgency strategy for Afghanistan proposed by Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, giving new impetus to his recommendation to pour more troops into the eight-year-old war. General McChrystal, the senior American and allied commander in Afghanistan, made an unannounced appearance here on Friday to brief the defense ministers on his strategic review of a war in which the American-led campaign has lost momentum to a tenacious Taliban insurgency.

When a survey commissioned by the National Football League recently indicated that dementia or similar memory-related diseases had been diagnosed in its retired players vastly more often than in the national population, the league claimed the study was unreliable. But confidential data from the N.F.L.'s dementia assistance plan strongly corroborates claims of a link between football and later-life cognitive impairment. Records indicate that pro football's retirees are experiencing moderate to advanced early-onset dementia at rates several times higher than the general population, the most glaring evidence to date of the dangers of professional football in past eras.

An article in some editions on Friday about the Angels' 7-6 victory over the Yankees in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series misstated, in some copies, the number of outs in the ninth inning when Angels closer Brian Fuentes intentionally walked Alex Rodriguez. Fuentes had already gotten two outs; he did not walk Rodriguez with no outs.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg looked like he couldn't get wait to get out of Howard Beach, Queens, soon enough. Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani couldn't stop grinning from ear to ear. That was how it went Sunday, when the two men who have ruled New York City for the last 16 years marched side by side in the Howard Beach Columbus Day Parade.

It is often said of good family films that they work on multiple levels: they entertain both adults and children. Creating a tale of multigenerational appeal usually entails combining the exaggerated, less subtle visual vernacular of youngsters with writing laden with meaning for their parents. That could have been the case with the new Where the Wild Things Are game. But it isn't. The Wild Things game works, serviceably, on only one level: that of the bored elementary or middle school student killing a few hours before dinner.

After several umpire calls were shown to be inaccurate by television replays during the playoffs, Major League Baseball has responded by assigning only more experienced umpires to the World Series. Usually baseball assigns one or two umpires to the World Series who have never worked at that level before. But according to a person in baseball familiar with the situation, this year's World Series will feature only umpires with at least one World Series on their résumé.

FOLEY--Patrick. The New York Law School community mourns the passing of Patrick J. Foley, Class of 1961, one of the Law School's most distinguished graduates. Mr. Foley spent 32 years with American International Group, Inc. (AIG), culminating in his retirement in 1995 as Vice President and Associate General Counsel. He was also General Counsel of AIG's domestic insurance companies. A man with infinite energy and creativity, Mr. Foley had his own definition of retirement: He served as a director for three of AIG's subsidiary companies, and founded two successful companies, for which he served as President--Foley Atlantis Consultants, an advising and consulting company based in South Florida, and Foley Atlantis Holding Corp., a real estate company. Challenged in recent years by illnesses, neither his great sense of humor nor his incomparable talent for storytelling wavered, and his thirst for knowledge and new challenges flourished unabated. Mr. Foley attended New York Law School as an evening student while working simultaneously for Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, graduating in 1961. An active, prominent member of the Law School community throughout his life, he served as a Director of the Alumni Association and continuously provided generous support. In 1986, he established the Patrick J. Foley '61 Scholarship Fund with additional funding provided by both AIG and his wife Ann through a matching gift from her employer, IBM. Since its inception, the Patrick J. Foley Scholarship has been instrumental in enabling evening division students who work in the insurance industry to achieve a legal education. The Law School is grateful to both Pat and Ann, whose passing we also mourned this year. We extend our condolences to their children John and Maureen, and their granddaughter Nicole. Pat Foley was a giant of a man, an example to us all, and we will miss him. Arthur N. Abbey Chairman of the Board of Trustees Richard A. Matasar Dean and President

DIAMANT--Lincoln, 86, on October 20 in Williamstown, MA. Survived by his wife, Joan Champion, son Rolf, daughter-in-law Nora Mitchell and stepson Anthony Bruck. Writer, adman, historian, and cartographer, he loved the outdoors as much as he loved libraries. Over his last few years, despite suffering from Parkinson's disease and loss of vision, he audited classes, wrote articles, listened to books on tape, and kept up with world and national events-- holding strong opinions on both. He was a person of substance and accomplishment whose wit, warmth, kindness, and even his jokes will be truly missed. A memorial service is planned for the spring.

A month ago, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, warned that the flu vaccination drive soon to begin would be ''a little bumpy.'' That was an understatement.

Carl C. Icahn, who joined the board of Yahoo last year after threatening a proxy fight, has stepped down, saying the company no longer needed an activist director. Mr. Icahn, below, said he did not have enough time to devote to Yahoo, according to a letter to the board that he released Friday. Mr. Icahn had sought to take control of the board and oust Jerry Yang as chief last year, after Yahoo spurned a $47.5 billion acquisition offer by Microsoft. To ward off a proxy fight, Yahoo gave board seats to Mr. Icahn and two of his candidates in August 2008. Since then, Yahoo has hired Carol Bartz as chief executive and forged a search partnership with Microsoft. ''Carol is doing a great job and I believe the Microsoft transaction will provide great long-term benefits, the potential of which many still do not understand,'' Mr. Icahn said.

David is survived by his daughter Molly, his two brothers John and James and his father, Alton Thomas. SCHINDLER--Charles Joseph, Jr. February 10, 1917-October 21, 2009. My father, my hero. A veteran of World War II wounded in the Anzio invasion, he was a prisoner of war who was awarded the Purple Heart. Charlie, as he was known to all, died at the age of 92 from heart failure, predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Rosemarie (nee Naccarato), and his son Raymond. He is survived by his daughter Diana, his loving grandchildren Kathryn and David, his sister Agnes, brother-in-law Frank and sister-in-law Harriet Naccarato and many nieces, nephews, and cousins. He will always be remembered as a gentle man filled with inner strength and integrity, and for his eternal smile and his deep love of family. Donations may be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation in the name of Charles and Rosemarie Schindler.

The concrete pedestrian ramps at the brand-new $1.5 billion city-subsidized Yankee Stadium have been troubled by cracks, and the team is seeking to determine whether the problems were caused by the installation, the design, the concrete or other factors, according to several people briefed on the problems. The ramps were built by a company accused of having links to the mob, and the concrete mix was designed and tested by a company under indictment on charges that it failed to perform some tests and falsified the results of others. But it is unclear whether work performed by either firm contributed to the deteriorating conditions of the ramps.

PEMBERTON--John de J. The American Civil Liberties Union mourns the passing of John de J. "Jack" Pemberton. Pemberton served as the national Executive Director of the ACLU from 1962-70, at the peak of the civil rights struggle and the escalation of the Vietnam War. Under Pemberton's leadership, the ACLU helped achieve victories in landmark cases such as Loving v. Virginia, which legalized interracial marriage; Gideon v. Wainwright, which ensured felony defendants have the right to an attorney at trial; and Griswold v. Connecticut, which found that Americans have a constitutional right to privacy. Based on these successes and others, the ACLU doubled its membership under his stewardship. Pemberton followed his tenure at the ACLU as a distinguished leader in labor and employment law, serving as Acting General Counsel and Regional Attorney for the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and as a law professor at the University of San Francisco (USF) School of Law from 1973-88. USF hosts an annual Pemberton Lecture on Workplace Justice in his honor. A passionate advocate of nonviolence and equality for all, Pemberton was instrumental in establishing the ACLU as a truly national organization through some of the most critical years in American civil rights history. The ACLU honors his legacy by continuing to be, in his words, "a firm and steadfast guardian of the American ideal." We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jack's family.

Reflecting on one of the more curious managerial moves he made in Game 5 of the American League Championship Series, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said it was ''extremely hard'' to take Alex Rodriguez out for pinch runner Freddy Guzman in the ninth inning. Girardi explained that with the Yankees trailing, 7-6, it was paramount to find every possible edge to score the tying run and extend the game, even if it meant playing extra innings without his most feared hitter.

Iranian authorities arrested the wives and family members of a number of high-profile political detainees at a religious ceremony in Tehran, several reformist Web sites reported Friday. The raid happened Thursday after the family members of one detainee, Shahab Tabatabee, announced on the Web site Norooz News that they were holding a prayer ceremony for his release. Mr. Tabatabee, a member of the reformist party Islamic Iran Participation Front, was sentenced to five years in prison last week.

N.B.A. referees ratified their new contract Friday night and will be on the court when the regular season opens Tuesday. The vote, which came after 10 p.m. Eastern, put an official end to a lockout that began Sept. 18 and cost the referees a month of salary. The league used replacement referees in the preseason, for the first time since 1995. The contract is for two years and includes some financial concessions as a result of the poor economy. Referees will report to training camp Saturday.

Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had a blunt response on Friday to the latest broadsides from former Vice President Dick Cheney: ''Who cares?'' In the latest exchange between old and new administrations, Mr. Biden rebuffed his predecessor's criticism about President Obama's handling of Afghanistan as ''absolutely wrong.'' And Mr. Biden rejected the last review of the war conducted by the White House under former President George W. Bush and Mr. Cheney as ''irrelevant.''

8 P.M. (HBO) MILK (2008) Sean Penn, above center, won an Oscar for best actor for his performance as the title character in this biopic from Gus Van Sant. It tells the story of Harvey Milk, a neighborhood activist elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1977 -- and one of the first openly gay elected officials in the country -- who was killed the next year, along with the city's mayor, George Moscone (Victor Garber), by a former supervisor, Dan White (Josh Brolin). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''accessible and instructive, an astute chronicle of big-city politics and the portrait of a warrior whose passion was equaled by his generosity and good humor.'' He added: ''Mr. Penn, an actor of unmatched emotional intensity and physical discipline, outdoes himself here, playing a character different from any he has portrayed before'' -- the difference being less a matter of sexuality than of Milk's extroverted, and occasionally stubborn, temperament. ''All of this Mr. Penn captures effortlessly through voice and gesture, but what is most arresting is the sense he conveys of Milk's fundamental kindness, a personal virtue that also functions as a political principle.'' Dustin Lance Black also earned an Oscar for best screenplay. 10:30 A.M. The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about the marketing of expensive properties to professional athletes misidentified the town in which Arlene Gonnella, a real estate agent, showed houses to Bart Scott, a linebacker for the New York Jets. It was Short Hills, not Summit. The article also misidentified the site of the condominium Brownstones at Convent Station. Convent Station is an unincorporated area in Morris County, not part of Chatham.

An article last Sunday about Toronto Maple Leafs General Manager Brian Burke and Coach Ron Wilson, and the implications of their holding the same positions with the United States Olympic hockey team, misstated the working relationship between the two men after they played hockey together at Providence College. An article last Sunday about a possible coming conflict between marijuana dispensaries and law enforcement officials in Los Angeles misstated the year that District Attorney Steve Cooley of Los Angeles County will be up for re-election. It is 2012, not “next year.”.

An article last Sunday about a period of stability in Afghanistan from the 1930s to the 1970s misidentified the office held by the Afghan leader Sardar Mohammad Daoud Khan when he was killed in a Communist coup in 1978. He was president — not prime minister, a position he held from 1953 to 1963.

An article last Sunday about American literature’s disregard for national boundaries referred incorrectly to the career of Bonnie Jo Campbell, whose “American Salvage” is a finalist for this year’s National Book Award in fiction. The book is her second collection of stories, not her debut, and it is her third book over all; she is not a “rookie.” (Her first book was “Q Road,” a novel, and her first collection was “Women and Other Animals.”).
The Reading File column on Oct. 11 with an excerpt about T. Boone Pickens, from an article on Bloomberg.com, misspelled the surname of the author for that article. He is Kambiz Foroohar, not Forooha.

A review on Oct. 11 about “Anne Frank,” by Francine Prose, misstated one aspect of the chronology of Frank’s wartime diary. She had already addressed entries to an imaginary companion called Kitty before her family went into hiding from the Nazis in July 1942; she did not begin doing so in their secret apartment.
