GREENBAUM--Maurice C. The attorneys and staff of Katten Muchin Rosenman LLP are saddened to report that our former partner, Maurice C. Greenbaum, died after a distinguished career and a remarkable life at the age of 91. Maury specialized in international corporate and literary property law, and he was a trusted advisor to many families. We will miss his sage counsel, his gentle spirit and the warmth and kindness he extended to all. Our condolences go to his wife of 67 years, Beatrice, to Debra and Bob Fisher, and to their entire family.

BOWMAN--Pearl, passed away on Friday, September 18th after a valiant battle with numerous health issues. She is survived by her daughter, Jane, son, Daniel, daughter-in-law, Ingeborg, and grandchildren, Thomas and Sarah. She was preceded in death by her husband, Thomas. Born in 1933 in Queens, Pearl graduated from Hunter High School and Syracuse University, cum laude. She moved with her husband to the Upper West Side in 1963 and became a quintessential Upper West Sider. Her husband passed in his sleep when her children were nine and three and Pearl courageously raised them while forging a successful career in publishing. She retired from the CUNY Academy in 2002. Her children fondly remember the exceptionally engaging conversations at dinner parties with her wordsmithing friends. After retiring, she enjoyed life in her cherished Upper West Side apartment, meeting frequently with friends, reading voraciously, and walking in the neighborhood. When her health became a hindrance, she moved to Chapel Hill, NC, to be near her son. There she greatly enjoyed her grandchildren and was happy and well cared for. She will be deeply missed. A remembrance will be held in early 2010. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to Amnesty International, the Doe Fund, or Bide-a-wee.

DIAMANT--Lincoln, 86, on October 20 in Williamstown, MA. Survived by his wife, Joan Champion, son Rolf, daughter-in-law Nora Mitchell and stepson Anthony Bruck. Writer, adman, historian, and cartographer, he loved the outdoors as much as he loved libraries. Over his last few years, despite suffering from Parkinson's disease and loss of vision, he audited classes, wrote articles, listened to books on tape, and kept up with world and national events-- holding strong opinions on both. He was a person of substance and accomplishment whose wit, warmth, kindness, and even his jokes will be truly missed. A memorial service is planned for the spring.

McNEVIN--Arthur John, died October 18, 2009 in Las Vegas, NV at the age of 83. Arthur was born in Brooklyn, NY to Clara and George McNevin and raised in South Ozone Park. At age 17, during World War II, he enlisted in the US Navy and spent four years as a radio man on a destroyer seeing action from Normandy to Okinawa. When he was discharged in 1947, he became a member of the NYPD where he remained for 41 years, earning BS and MSA degrees from John Jay College along the way. He retired in 1988 as Assistant Chief Manhattan South. He then joined MacAndrews & Forbes where he was Chief of Security from 1988 until his retirement in 1996. He is survived by his beloved wife Patricia, sons Douglas, Bruce (Joan Nix), and Scott (Maryvonne), daughter Bonnie Carson (Andrew) and their mother, Doris Scarangello, by six Grandchildren, Amy Valdes (Ricardo), Heather Bennis (David), Alexander (Abigail), John, Kelly, Courtney and Great-Grandson Aidan. Friends may call on Sunday, October 25 at Joseph Duffy Funeral Home, 255 Ninth Street, Brooklyn from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Service on Monday, October 26 at 10:45am at the Greenwood Cemetery Chapel.

Beloved wife of the late Morris, loving mother of Naomi Toder (Steve) and Joel (Michelle), adoring grandmother of Matthew Toder, Emily Toder, Nicole Diamond, Michael Diamond and Lisa Diamond. She also is survived by an extended family for whom she cared deeply. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Sunday, October 25 at 2pm. Shiva at the home of Naomi and Steve Toder, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, 6-9pm. Donations in her memory may be made to the Samuel Field "Y", Little Neck, NY or the National Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA.

BIRD-WATCHING FROM CANOPY TOWER, A FORMER UNITED STATES AIR FORCE RADAR INSTALLATION AT SOBERANÍA NATIONAL PARK, PANAMA, MAY 16, 2009 Vivienne Caballero, 32, a program officer for the Poverty-Environment Initiative of the United Nations Environment Program who was recently transferred from New York to Panama City. ''It's incredible that you have such wilderness so close to the city, and so close to the place where I'm living. Canopy Tower was a military radar station built by the U.S. Air Force back in 1965 to defend the canal. After the Air Force left, the tower was eventually converted into an eco-lodge. You really get to be in the canopy: open the window of your room and probably less than 40 feet away are hundreds of bird species. You see toucans flying by, fruit crows, motmots, blue cotingas and green shrike-vireos. They also have a library, which is really cool because you can easily check out what you just saw -- or think you saw. So you get engaged: it's not a boring activity as some people think. Some bird-watchers were saying that here, in a matter of days, they had seen as many species as they had in many other countries on many different occasions combined. The diversity is amazing.''

GORE--Stephen H.,of East Hampton, New York and Englewood, New Jersey, passed peacefully on October 8, 2009 at the age of 64 of brain cancer. Diagnosed on August 19, 2009 he lived the remaining weeks of his life with courage, grace, and dignity, never losing his sense of humor and singing joyfully for all who would listen. Being a loving husband to Lois and a devoted father to Samantha gave him his greatest joy. The only son of the late Natalie and Philip Gore, he grew up in New York City where he was exposed to the arts and developed a passion for collecting antiques, oil paintings, and memorabilia. Close to his heart were cousins Arthur, Leona, Joyce, Ira Jr., and Margaret and their families, brother-in-law and sister-in-law, Ron and Alice, niece Liz, nephews Olin, Trevor and Wesley and their loved ones. He possessed a warmth and gentle kindness, combined with an encompassing smile that will be remembered by all his cherished friends, many dating back to childhood at Riverdale Country School. After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania he obtained his law degree from Georgetown University. A passion for business led him away from practice in the financial sector to become General Counsel at Eastern Rolling Mills and then National Machinery Exchange, Inc. where he will be remembered for his intellect and savvy business acumen. Friends and family will gather at his home in Englewood, New Jersey to celebrate his life, on November 1, 2009 from 1-5pm.

A proposed new Consumer Financial Protection Agency is intended to protect Americans from abusive, deceptive and predatory lending in mortgages, credit cards and many other types of loans. So no one should be surprised that big lenders have been working the halls of Congress trying to weaken its powers. The House Financial Services Committee passed a bill last week that would give the agency important responsibilities and at long last bring consumer protection under the watch of a single regulator focused solely on the best interests of consumers. But at the same time, it would weaken other protections and restrict the agency in ways that could undermine its effectiveness.

The Federal Aviation Administration said Saturday that it might suspend the licenses of the two pilots of Northwest Flight 188 who flew 150 miles past their Minneapolis destination on Wednesday evening -- remaining out of contact for nearly 90 minutes -- while air traffic controllers repeatedly tried to reach them. Four fighter jets were put on alert. Air traffic control centers from Denver to Minneapolis tried numerous times to reach the pilots by radio, e-mail, data text and cellphone, with one center trying to reach the pilot 13 times. Even the White House was alerted to the wayward Airbus A320. Finally, a flight attendant was able to contact the pilots, and they turned the plane around and landed it safely.
Art Roberta Smith

WHEN I was growing up, we lived on a farm in Maryland and had dogs, chickens and cattle. In 1962, my mother, Eunice Kennedy Shriver, started a summer camp in our backyard for children with intellectual disabilities, which was the beginning of Special Olympics. From the time I was 3, I was exposed to recreational opportunities that included children with and without disabilities. That experience profoundly influenced me. My dad, Sargent Shriver, helped create the Peace Corps, Job Corps, Head Start and other programs. It was a time of enormous creativity and innovation in the work of social justice and peace.

WINTER--Elmer L. AJC is deeply saddened by the death of our former National President, Elmer Winter. Elmer was one of our most active and beloved officers for more than five decades. An inspirational leader, he served with distinction in numerous leadership positions. Long devoted to interfaith relations, social justice and opportunity for all, he helped advance public policy, housing and equal employment initiatives in his native Milwaukee and nationally. His steadfast and principled commitment to Israel, especially its economic development, and to the Jewish people worldwide was evident in his lifetime of philanthropic work. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Hope, his three daughters, son-in-law, eight grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Richard J. Sideman, President David A. Harris, Exec. Dir.

THE NEWS Devoted readers buy more books after they begin using an electronic reading device, some users and sellers of those devices reported. BEHIND THE NEWS Amazon says Kindle owners buy 3.1 times as many books as they did before getting one. Sony says its e-book users are also inspired. ''You are going to see very significant growth rates,'' said Jeffrey P. Bezos, the head of Amazon. Publishers had doubts. ''Do you really believe that people are going to be reading more because they can get it on a screen? I don't see the scenario,'' said John Sargent, MacMillan's chief executive .

sometimes a taunt -- inside and outside Washington: Why shouldn't members of Congress be forced to use the same health insurance that its members are now designing for people who have no coverage? In fact, various Republicans have introduced amendments stipulating just that. Some of these moves were clearly meant to undermine any health care overhaul. But both the Senate Finance Committee and the Senate health committee -- dominated by Democrats -- passed those amendments. So this is an option now as Democratic leaders meld the two committees' bills behind closed doors.

PEARCE--Phillip Edwards, passed away October 22, 2009. He was born February 18, 1929 to Thomas Butler Pearce and Anne Tribble Pearce in Columbia, SC. Phil was educated at Woodbury Forest School, the University of South Carolina and the School of Investment Banking at Wharton School University of Pennsylvania. He was a member of the National Association of Security Dealers and was Chairman of the Board of Governors and was often called the "Father of NASDAQ". Phil was Senior Vice President and Director of E. F. Hutton. He was a member of the advisory council to the Securities Exchange Commission on the Institutional Study of the Stock Markets. He was contributing author/ Editor of the Dow Jones Publication of the Stock Market Handbook. He served on the Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange and was listed in "Who's Who in America". Phil was preceded in death by his parents, his brothers Thomas Butler Pearce Jr. and Robert Roy Pearce, and his daughter Frances Pearce Steele. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Mary Anne Hood Pearce, his brother, James Tribble Pearce and wife Kit of Greenville, SC, daughter Mary Pearce Wilson and her husband Beau of New York City, son Phillip Edwards Pearce, Jr. and wife Sandy of Charlotte, NC, and son Bradley Barron Steele of Greenville, SC, six grandchildren, Frances Fairbanks Wilson and Katherine Pearce Wilson, Anna Pearce Steele and Bradley Barron Steele, Jr. and Mary Anne Pearce and Phillip Edwards Pearce III and their mother Kerri Alderson. Phil was a member of The Brook in New York City, The Pine Tree Hunt Club in Columbia, SC and the Charlotte Country Club. The family would like to thank the nursing staff at the Carrington and the Charlotte Hospice Group for their loving care. A memorial service will be held at Myers Park United Methodist Church in Charlotte at 2pm on Sunday, November 1 with the Reverend Bill Roth officiating. A reception will follow the service. In lieu of flowers, memorial may be made to Blowing Rock Art and History Museum (BRAHM), P.O. Box 828, Blowing Rock, NC 28605, or Hospice & Palliative Care of Charlotte, NC 1420 East 7th St., Charlotte, NC 28204.

In Paris, a popular leg covering this fall is the over-the-knee boot. Some resemble Robin Hood's, others a fisherman's waders with straps on a belt to hold them up. THIS Moonage Daydream Collar, right, from the fledgling label Assad Mounser is fit for a futuristic (and fashionable) rock goddess. The line's designer, Amanda Assad Mounser, who previously worked for Moschino and Alejandro Ingelmo, based her spring collection on David Bowie's ''Space Oddity.'' The resulting pieces, made of agate slices, amethyst chunks, polished stones, metal and crystal, are the last word in interplanetary chic. The necklace is $395 at kirnazabete.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

FIRE IN THE AMERICAN WEST is a season, like winter. Yet even though the number of large wildfires across the Western states has increased fourfold in the last few decades, we continue to build our homes in sagebrush; in steep, wooded canyons; in lightning country surrounded by dry chaparral -- in other words, we build in landscapes prone to burn. And when a fire comes through and destroys everything, we rebuild bigger. Twenty-five miles north of downtown San Diego, the Rancho Bernardo neighborhood is just such a place. The land was bought in 1961 by a developer from Texas who envisioned a sprawling paradise. In the early years, Rancho Bernardo was heavily marketed in the Midwest with an ad campaign that promised a relaxed lifestyle: ''the 52-week vacation.'' On Oct. 22, 2007, the fourth-largest wildfire in the state's history, the Witch fire, devastated Rancho Bernardo, burning hundreds of homes. Many residents had only minutes to evacuate. Afterward, larger, more lavish houses went up in the community of 40,000. Individually, the images on these pages are portraits of ravage and reconstruction -- phoenix-from-the-ashes stories played out in the subdivisions of Southern California. But seen collectively, they tell a broader and perhaps darker story about living in a landscape made ever more flammable by drought, improper forest management, climate change and runaway development. Sasha Bezzubov began photographing landscapes scarred by wildfires in 2003 as part of a series capturing the aftermath of tsunamis, earthquakes, hurricanes and other catastrophic events around the world. A few months ago, The New York Times Magazine sent Bezzubov back to Rancho Bernardo, which he photographed after the 2007 fire, to document what had happened since, from the same vantage points. What he found was the reassembling of ruined things. Opposite: The remnants of Erick and Raquel Aguilars' house. Above: Their new, bigger house.

SIMMONS--Robert James, died Saturday, October 17th of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Jim was born on November 11, 1962 to Robert and Frances Simmons who lived in Marietta, GA. Jim received his Master of Architecture degree from the Georgia Institute of Technology and after launching his career in Atlanta, he moved to New York and worked at Brennan Beer Gorman, Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, LLP (SOM) and Arquitectonica. Jim left SOM for a period of time and returned as an Associate Director in July 2007. While at SOM, Jim made great contributions to projects such as Time Warner Center; Manhattan West, 9th Avenue Towers; Dulles International Airport Main Terminal People Mover Station; Gem Tower; Inland Steel and the JP Morgan Chase renovations. Always valiant and caring, Jim was a survivor, a man who rejoiced in life and thrived in its multiple challenges. Jim is survived by his life partner Tom Kulesa of New York and Asbury Park; his mother, Frances Simmons of Fayetteville, GA; and his sister, Lisa Lambert of Raleigh, NC. Jim's family, many friends and work colleagues in New York and Atlanta will sorely miss him. Anyone wishing to make a donation in Jim's memory should contact the Callen-Lorde Community Health Center, at: http://www.callen-lorde.org.

Nick Swisher was in the starting lineup Saturday as the Yankees' right fielder for Game 6, which was rained out, and there was never much doubt he would be. Swisher was 3 for 29 this postseason after popping up to end Game 5 at Angel Stadium, but Manager Joe Girardi stuck with him, and stuck to precedent. Girardi kept Johnny Damon in the lineup after Damon went 1 for 12 in the division series. He has also watched Mark Teixeira deliver important hits despite a .171 average, and drew off his own memory of the 1996 World Series, when Joe Torre started him in the final game against Atlanta.

HALLOWEEN has always been the season when Hollywood unleashes some of its most suspenseful and supernatural offerings. When I was a child in the late '60s and early '70s, the horror slate was a splendid array, ranging from the relative innocence of monster-ramas to the erotically tinged creature flicks of Britain's famed Hammer Studios. Somewhere in between were the less stylish but often enjoyable low-budget drive-in fare from America's exploitation studios (almost all of which went out of business years ago) and the occasional major-studio horror movies often rereleased at this time of year. But this mostly imaginative crop devolved to the dime-a-dozen, cut-'em-up-and-watch-'em-bleed movies, of which ''Friday the 13th'' is perhaps the most famous example. Although I was one of the earliest group of writers for Fangoria, the horror-movie magazine, and also acted in a couple of horror films years ago, my opinion of the genre's more grotesque examples has changed.

THE name on the door says ''Sterling Cooper,'' but the real star of the show is New York City, home to many of the Mad Men and to the advertising agency that keeps them in booze, cigarettes and first-aid kits in case of foot amputations. While ''Law & Order'' has made a franchise of fictionalizing plots ripped from contemporary headlines, ''Mad Men'' uses historical news events as props to drive the running soap opera among its characters. Last year, the hopelessly ladder-climbing Pete Campbell exploited his father's death in the March 1, 1962, American Airlines crash in Jamaica Bay to try to bring the airline in as a client. This season, the agency's wooing of the crew building the new Madison Square Garden becomes a showcase for Don Draper's creative genius. ''New York City is in decay,'' he intones. ''Madison Square Garden -- it's the beginning of a new city on a hill.'' The creator of ''Mad Men,'' Matthew Weiner, is well known for being fastidious about period detail -- from the lingo and popular drinks to determining whether a guest at the wedding of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Margaretta Murphy (known as Happy) would have been able to drive to the Sterlings' country club party later that day. So, too, with bringing actual news stories to the screen. For the Madison Square Garden episode, he dug up old ''Save Penn Station'' fliers, though the most striking -- ''Rape on 34th St'' -- was his own creation.

Sunnyside and Woodside are the twins of Queens. Each has wide avenues, leafy streets and a mix of private homes, small apartment buildings and the occasional towering co-op. They are sunny and woody and ethnically rich -- just check out the Romanian, Thai, Irish, Filipino and Mexican bars and restaurants. Where the neighborhoods meet, near 50th Street on the No. 7 line, is a good place to get the feel. Exit the train at the 46th Street/Bliss Street station, named for a street that goes by two names -- one utilitarian, the other charming -- and head into one of the prettiest spots in Queens. WALD--Stephen L.,died peacefully at home in Telluride, CO on October 22, 2009 with his wife, Sheila at his bedside. He fought a long, valiant battle against Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. He was born in Brookline, MA on July 21, 1935. He was the son of the late Harold and Ellen Grossman Wald. He is survived by his beloved wife, Sheila and cherished children Alison Wald and Alex Seitz Wald. His eldest son, John was killed in an avalanche in 1996. Stephen attended Milton Academy in Milton, MA and was graduated from Harvard College and The Harvard Business School. He spent his entire career in the Investment Management Business, primarily as a managing partner with Reich and Tang in New York. Upon retirement, he was selected by the US Government to head up the Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund which was created after the iron curtain came down as a means of stimulating the economy in Eastern Europe. Stephen and his wife spent three years in Prague. Upon leaving this assignment he was instrumental in creating the first western brokerage firm in Eastern Europe, Wood & Co. which became the largest such firm in that part of the world. In 1994 Stephen & Sheila moved full time to Telluride, CO where they had maintained a part time residence. In Telluride, Stephen devoted himself to the non-profit world. He was a founding Board Member of the Telluride Foundation, serving on several committees. He was past Chairman of the Telluride Medical Center, Board Member of Mountain Film, Telluride Adaptive Sports Program, Telluride Repertory Theatre Company, Telluride Jewish Community and Investment Advisor to his Homeowner's Company. Stephen was always involved in giving back to the communities where he lived. In New York he was a founding Director of the New York Road Runners Club, Director Achilles Track Club, Director Outward Bound, New York Chapter, Director, University Hospital, Boston. He was an avid athlete, a longtime runner, finishing three New York City Marathons. He skied, played tennis and golf and was an enthusiastic biker. He and Sheila rode their bikes across the United States in 1999. He loved foreign travel and crossed the globe, taking many photos along the way. Photography was another passion of his. Above all he was devoted to the family and friends whom he loved. He was a people person in every sense of the expression. He will be greatly missed. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Telluride Foundation, 620 Mountain Village Boulevard, Telluride, CO 81435. Services will be held at the Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard St., Brookline, MA on Sunday, November 1 at 11:00am. A celebration of Stephen's life will be held in Telluride at a later date.

A proposed new Consumer Financial Protection Agency is intended to protect Americans from abusive, deceptive and predatory lending in mortgages, credit cards and many other types of loans. So no one should be surprised that big lenders have been working the halls of Congress trying to weaken its powers. The House Financial Services Committee passed a bill last week that would give the agency important responsibilities and at long last bring consumer protection under the watch of a single regulator focused solely on the best interests of consumers. But at the same time, it would weaken other protections and restrict the agency in ways that could undermine its effectiveness.

THE SPOKESMAN Richard Valvo, 56, owns a small public relations firm he started in 1996. Among his current or former clients are The National Enquirer, Star magazine, Osama bin Laden's niece, Denise Rich and Dame Celia Lipton Farris, a Palm Beach society matron he has known for 20 years.

BOBRICK--Elizabeth Most ("Sherry"), died October 20, 2009 in New York City. Born Elizabeth Sharnoff on November 28, 1908 in Berdichev, Ukraine, she emigrated with her family to the United States in 1909. She won a two-year fellowship to the Jewish School of Social Work, married a journalist, Melos Most, traveled throughout Europe, and in 1939 became the first woman to bicycle across Greece. When World War II broke out, her husband became a wire correspondent for the Associated Press and Elizabeth joined the American Red Cross. The German invasion of France overtook them, and together they were held captive by the Germans in Baden-Baden for thirteen months. After the war, Elizabeth became a Welfare Officer for UNRRA in a displaced persons camp at Wiesbaden, Germany. When Eleanor Roosevelt visited the camp, Elizabeth gave her the tour. In 1949, she was divorced, worked for the Margaret Sanger Bureau and Planned Parenthood, was connected by her friendships with the Abstract Expressionist movement, earned her doctorate in Social Work from Columbia University, and subsequently taught at the New School for Social Research, the University of West Florida in Pensacola and at Southern University in New Orleans. When her contract was not renewed at the University of West Florida after she spoke out against the Vietnam War, she became the subject of a celebrated First Amendment rights case in which the university was sanctioned by the National Association of Social Workers. Meanwhile in 1962, she had married Robert L. Bobrick, a lawyer. Together, they helped found "The National Committee for the Impeachment of Richard M. Nixon," which attracted attention worldwide. It also earned them a place on Nixon's "Enemies List." Elizabeth is survived by three stepsons, James, Robert Peter, and Benson Bobrick; and by numerous nieces and nephews and their children, and by all remembered with love.

At 6-0, this may be the greatest Minnesota Vikings team ever assembled, better than the 1998 flash in the pan that finished 15-1, better than the 1970s conference powerhouse that this team so closely resembles. The 1973-75 Vikings were led by an old daredevil quarterback (then Fran Tarkenton, now Brett Favre), a stalwart defensive line (the Purple People Eaters then, the law firm of Allen, Williams & Williams now), and a two-headed running game (Chuck Foreman and Ed Marinaro then, Adrian Peterson and Chester Taylor running circles round them now). In 1974, the Vikings went 10-4, forced 33 turnovers and netted 4,611 yards of total offense, which is more than three miles when you adjust for inflation. They beat the Cardinals and the Rams en route to Super Bowl IX, which they lost to the Steelers. It's easy to overlook host Pittsburgh (4-2) as it goes about its business. The Colts and the Broncos have better records, but the Steelers are experienced marathoners more likely to peak in January than October. The Steelers are pressuring quarterbacks again -- 17 sacks after a slow start -- and although they are still having some problems with turnovers and special-teams mistakes, their offense is good enough to overcome the miscues. Ben Roethlisberger has no reason to envy Favre in their first-ever meeting. Favre has a higher passer rating right now, but Roethlisberger has twice as many Super Bowl rings.

When shopping for airfare, it's easy to overlook smaller, unfamiliar carriers. But these so-called B airlines may offer the best deal. Vayama.com, an international airfare site, says travelers can save by flying on B airlines this fall and winter. For example, the cheapest nonstop, round-trip fare from New York to Madrid in October was $524 on Air Europa in a recent search -- $16 less than Continental and $184 cheaper than Delta. Icelandair, Martinair and Air Berlin are also good bets to Europe.

Her capacity for giving was inexhaustible, as was her ability to both smile and persevere in the face of adversity. She considered herself to have attained her greatest desire, to have raised a human being whom she loved and respected. (13, 49) ENDGAMEWilliam Hurt portrays Prof. Will Esterhuyse, the leader of an unofficial delegation representing white South Africa, and Chiwetel Ejiofor, above left, is Thabo Mbeki, the head of a group of exiles from the African National Congress (and the country's future president), in this ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' presentation. Based on ''The Fall of Apartheid'' by Robert Harvey, the film is set in the bleak mid-1980s, as civil war loomed. Jonny Lee Miller plays Michael Young, a public affairs specialist for Consolidated Gold Fields, who, despite the fact that his company has long benefited from apartheid, argues that economic and political chaos will result if the racist system is not dismantled. Derek Jacobi is the company's chairman, who agrees to finance Young's mission, and Clarke Peters is Nelson Mandela. Pete Travis directed this real-life political thriller; Paula Milne wrote the screenplay. 9 A.M. THE PERCENTAGE OF AMERICANS WHO BELIEVE GLOBAL TEMPERATURES ARE RISING as a result of human activity, such as the burning of fossil fuels, according to a survey by the nonpartisan Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. The number is down from 47 percent in April 2008. With less than two months before 192 nations are expected to gather in Copenhagen to discuss a binding treaty on global warming, the Pew survey found growing public skepticism about the issue.

A RECENT study suggests that most homeowners have qualms about abandoning a mortgage that they can afford to pay, even if it straps them to an investment that's unlikely to pay off anytime soon. But if the house has lost significant value, or if many neighbors walk away from their mortgages, the study says, ''strategic defaults'' are significantly more likely.

Whether the reduction in calorie intake by humans could increase their life span, similar to the findings for rats, may be in question, but most people under such circumstances would feel they have ''existed'' longer and not lived longer. Food is certainly one of the great pleasures in life, appealing to at least three of the senses: taste, smell and touch. Not mentioned in the experiment on rats is whether they were able to continue to maintain their activity level and whether they slept longer. In the reduction of the former and an excess of the latter, any claim to a fuller life is dubious at best. Silver Spring, Md.

The Obama administration and Congress have vowed to regulate derivatives, the complex and often highly speculative financial instruments that were at the heart of the meltdown. Two House committees have approved legislation, but -- after heavy lobbying from the banking industry and corporate America-- both versions are weak and unlikely to prevent another fiasco. Right now, many derivative deals are executed as private one-on-one contracts, outside the view of the public or regulators. This lack of transparency -- about participants, prices and volumes -- proved disastrous. In the bailout of American International Group, tens of billions of taxpayer dollars went to pay the world's biggest banks for derivative bets gone spectacularly wrong.

PEMBERTON--John de J. The American Civil Liberties Union mourns the passing of John de J. "Jack" Pemberton. Pemberton served as the national Executive Director of the ACLU from 1962-70, at the peak of the civil rights struggle and the escalation of the Vietnam War. Under Pemberton's leadership, the ACLU helped achieve victories in landmark cases such as Loving v. Virginia, which legalized interracial marriage; Gideon v. Wainwright, which ensured felony defendants have the right to an attorney at trial; and Griswold v. Connecticut, which found that Americans have a constitutional right to privacy. Based on these successes and others, the ACLU doubled its membership under his stewardship. Pemberton followed his tenure at the ACLU as a distinguished leader in labor and employment law, serving as Acting General Counsel and Regional Attorney for the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and as a law professor at the University of San Francisco (USF) School of Law from 1973-88. USF hosts an annual Pemberton Lecture on Workplace Justice in his honor. A passionate advocate of nonviolence and equality for all, Pemberton was instrumental in establishing the ACLU as a truly national organization through some of the most critical years in American civil rights history. The ACLU honors his legacy by continuing to be, in his words, "a firm and steadfast guardian of the American ideal." We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jack's family.

PROTAS--Roger Irvin. June 14, 1925-October 21, 2009, aka "Rip" by friends. Husband and best friend of Sydelle (Delle). Devoted father of Elisabeth (Daniel) Lewis and Ralph Wantje. Loving grandfather of Danny. Brother of Judith and the late Alan Protas. Much loved uncle. Honor graduate of NYHS of Music and Arts and Carnegie Tech (Mellon) University. Illustrious lifetime career in Industrial Design. Peter Muller-munk Assoc., Pittsburgh, PA and Roger Protas Assoc., NYC. U.S. Army Veteran WWII and Korean War. Funeral private. A future memorial service will be announced. Memorial donations: VNSNY Hospice Care; Carnegie Mellon Univ. Advancement, Pittsburgh, PA; NY Foundation for Senior Citizens, c/o Liz Kravetz.

HEYMAN--Esther, (nee White), 91, died at home, October 24, 2009, surrounded by family. Beloved wife of the late Sam, loving mother of Rachel Resnikoff (Carl) and Dan Heyman (Fran), adoring grandmother of Tevye Krynski (Dagmar) and Caleb and Hannah Heyman, loving great-grandmother of Jonah and Stella Krynski, beloved friend of the late Isaac Imber. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Sunday, October 25 at 12 noon.

The Obama administration and Congress have vowed to regulate derivatives, the complex and often highly speculative financial instruments that were at the heart of the meltdown. Two House committees have approved legislation, but -- after heavy lobbying from the banking industry and corporate America-- both versions are weak and unlikely to prevent another fiasco. Right now, many derivative deals are executed as private one-on-one contracts, outside the view of the public or regulators. This lack of transparency -- about participants, prices and volumes -- proved disastrous. In the bailout of American International Group, tens of billions of taxpayer dollars went to pay the world's biggest banks for derivative bets gone spectacularly wrong.
Film Stephen Holden

ALTERNATE-side parking rules, which were introduced by the city in 1952 to make street cleaning easier, is one of the more burdensome rituals of New York City life. And the city's diversity -- and its accompanying smorgasbord of religious and cultural holidays -- has made it more complicated, as politicians cater to various constituencies. At last count, there were more than 40 holidays each year on which the rules are suspended, and any number of snow days that are declared so the Sanitation Department can clear the streets.

The best case for the Angels would be to start John Lackey in a Game 7 on three days' rest. But they are also reserving the right to use him before that, if necessary. Lackey said he would be available in the bullpen for Game 6 on Sunday, and indicated he would be ready to pitch more than one inning. ''I wouldn't put a number on it, honestly,'' he said after Saturday night's game was rained out. ''A lot of things will be involved tomorrow. I think I would be O.K. to go for a while.''

A 19-yard field goal by Stefan Demos, left, with 21 seconds left capped a 25-point comeback by Northwestern in a 29-28 victory over Indiana, the Wildcats' fourth game decided by 6 points or fewer. Indiana State stopped the nation's longest losing streak at 33 games with a 17-14 victory over Western Illinois. The Sycamores of the F.C.S. had not won since Oct. 21, 2006.

THIS Moonage Daydream Collar, right, from the fledgling label Assad Mounser is fit for a futuristic (and fashionable) rock goddess. The line's designer, Amanda Assad Mounser, who previously worked for Moschino and Alejandro Ingelmo, based her spring collection on David Bowie's ''Space Oddity.'' The resulting pieces, made of agate slices, amethyst chunks, polished stones, metal and crystal, are the last word in interplanetary chic. The necklace is $395 at kirnazabete.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

PADEN--Esta (Mayersohn), died peacefully September 21, 2009. Resident of New York City having lived in Washington Heights since 1949. A strong, independent woman and single working mother at a time when those traits were rare. Known for making and wearing capes and hats of her own design. She worked for GM retiring in 1978. Volunteered for many years in the newborn nursery, Columbia Presbyterian. She always met life on her own terms. She is survived by her only child, Michael and wife Sally (Tucson, AZ), grandchildren Scott and Barbara and great-granddaughter, Sydney. Also surviving are her sister Adele (and husband Alex, Pittsburgh, PA) and nephew Mark and nieces Ellen, Bonnie, Beth and Karen. Your strength and positive attitude will be greatly missed.

ADELMAN--Donald. Heartfelt sympathies to Marlene and family upon the loss of their loving husband and father. A scholar and a gentleman deeply committed to family and community, he will be greatly missed. Harriet Elisofon, President Yashar Hirshaut, Chairman The Board of Trustees & Professional Staff of the Israel Cancer Research Fund

Here's a sign the recession is not over: New York City this year may stop buying scarves, backpacks, even watches, for the homeless at Christmas. Watches?

''DRESS CODES'' is the last show in the International Center of Photography's Year of Fashion, and the most idiosyncratic so far. Included are artists like Cindy Sherman, who does her best to mock fashion's herd mentality, above, and Mickalene Thomas, who makes a statement about black womanhood refracted through the prism of artifice. Perhaps the most amazing work belongs to Pinar Yolacan. She asked her Afro-Brazilian subjects to pose in costumes she created out of animal parts and velvet. At first glance, you would never guess that a woman wearing cow placentas, top, could have such a dignified bearing. NATASHA LUNN

GELMAN--Estelle, of Washington, DC and Palm Beach, FL, died on Friday, October 23rd, at her home in Washington, DC. She was surrounded by her family at the time. Mrs. Gelman was born on February 25, 1926, in Washington, DC, to Meyer and Edith Sody. She graduated from Central High School and received an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from the George Washington University. Mrs. Gelman was married to Melvin Gelman of Washington, DC. Subsequent to his death in 1978, Mrs. Gelman assumed the position of President of the Gelman Companies, a Washington, DC-based real estate company founded by her father-in-law, Elias Gelman. She was a renowned philanthropist, serving on boards of numerous organizations including The American Cancer Society (where she served as the first female President), The Jewish Foundation for Group Homes, Israeli Bonds, the Jewish Social Service Agency, The United States Holocaust Museum and Iona House. Mrs Gelman served as a trustee at the George Washington University as well as the Adas Israel Congregation. Mrs. Gelman endowed The Gelman Library at the George Washington University in honor of her late husband as well as the Melvin Gelman Religious School of Adas Israel Congregation. She also endowed the Melvin and Estelle Gelman Library at the Georgetown Day High School in Washington, DC. She was a member of Woodmont Country Club (Washington, DC), Palm Beach Country Club (Palm Beach, FL), and The Cosmos Club (Washington, DC). Mrs. Gelman is survived by her two daughters, Elise Lefkowitz and her husband Marc, and Elaine Miller and her husband William; her five grandchildren, Robin Friedman and her husband Brian, Michael Miller and his wife Jennifer, Matthew Lefkowitz, Charlotte Lefkowitz and Harrison Miller; her great-grandson Ryan Miller; and her sister, Charlotte Rudden. Services will be held Sunday, October 25 at 2pm at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington, DC; interment will follow at King David Memorial Garden Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the George Washington University Library.

DAVIS--Barbara Thompson. The Trustees and staff of PEN American Center mourn the loss of Trustee and Freedom to Write Committee Chair Barbara Thompson Davis, who, as a passionate defender of freedom of expression, was a deeply respected and admired member of the PEN family.

Clifford P. Hansen, a Wyoming rancher who fought for Western interests as a governor and then a United States senator in what was popularly known as the sagebrush rebellion, died Tuesday at his home in Jackson, Wyo. He was 97. Retta Feller, who described herself as a caregiver for the Hansens, confirmed the death. He died a few miles from the log cabin where he was born on Oct. 16, 1912. At his death, Mr. Hansen was the oldest living former United States senator. He represented Wyoming for two terms in Washington, from 1967 until stepping down at the end of 1978. He was elected governor of the state in 1962.
''No one could have told me that in a million years: I'd wake up in a homeless shelter. I had a house for homeless people. Now, I'm homeless.''

Is Sylar finally nearing the end of his tiptoe through the tulips of Nathan Petrelli’s brain? He hasn’t killed anyone in a while, and “Heroes” (NBC, 8 p.m.) isn’t the same when Sylar isn’t killing anyone. Here’s hoping that having his memory restored — not to mention spending some time in the sack with Lydia the self-tattooing lady — gets him back on track. Other things to look forward to: Hiro’s reunion with Charlie and the aftermath of the Claire-Gretchen kiss from two weeks ago.

One of the most popular topics on Twitter over the weekend was a category called One Letter Off Movies, a viral game that invited Twitterers to change or drop a single letter in the title of a popular (or not-so-popular) movie to yield a new and hopefully funny title: “Apocalypse Now” becomes “Apocalypse Cow”; “Die Hard” becomes “Diet Hard”; and so on.
What we’re reading on Monday morning.

It’s bound to happen every year or so: Justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg have found something they can agree on. On Saturday night, the Supreme Court justices were not only in attendance at the Washington National Opera’s opening night of Strauss’s “Ariadne auf Naxos” but also part of the production: they were among the five celebrity supernumeraries who appeared on stage during the performance, the Washington National Opera said in a news release. Though the supernumeraries (who also included the philanthropist Adrienne Arsht; Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington’s delegate to the House; and Justice Ginsburg’s husband, Professor Martin D. Ginsburg) did not sing or speak, Justice Scalia was treated to a special interaction with the Russian soprano Lyubov Petrova, who, in her portrayal of the character Zerbinetta, sat in the justice’s lap and put an arm around him. Both known opera buffs, the two justices also attended last year at an opera-themed luncheon held at the Supreme Court by the National Endowment for the Arts, and they previously appeared in the Washington National Opera’s 1994 production of “Die Fledermaus.”

Is there money to be made, and an audience to delight, with a modern version of “The Philco Television Playhouse,” the 1940s and ’50s show that broadcast plays and adaptions of novels and short stories? A new British online service, Digital Theater, believes so: It announced on Monday that five major theatrical companies had become partners in filming theater productions in high-definition technology and offering them for viewers to download for about $15.

A concert that Morrissey was scheduled to perform on Monday night in Britain was canceled after his collapse during a show on Saturday. In a news release on Monday, publicists for Morrissey, 50, said that his concert at the O2 Academy in Bournemouth, about 100 miles southwest of London, would not take place “on medical advice.” On Saturday, Morrissey, the former front man for the band the Smiths, started a concert at the Oasis Leisure Center in Swindon, west of London, when he fell to his knees after finishing his first song. Two band members pulled him offstage, and he was taken to Great Western Hospital. In a statement, his publicists said, “Morrissey has now been released from hospital and is under doctors’ instruction to rest,” but they offered no additional details. Ticket-holders for both shows were told to await further news about new dates or possible refunds. Morrissey, who is about to release a new album called “Swords,” canceled a series of performances in the spring because of health reasons.

The rustic properties on the Baltic island of Fårö — where the director Ingmar Bergman lived and worked, produced several of his films and died — will become a nonprofit retreat for artists and scholars.

Updated | 1:14 p.m. Add another musician to the list of ailing British rock and pop stars: Eric Clapton said he was withdrawing from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame concerts at Madison Square Garden later this week because he has gallstones. In a news release, a publicist for Mr. Clapton said he would “undergo a minor medical procedure for gallstones” and would “spend time recuperating at home” in Britain but still planned to fulfill his touring schedule for next year. Mr. Clapton was to perform at the Garden on Friday, the second show in a two-night celebration in honor of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame‘s 25th anniversary. Other artists scheduled to perform include Crosby, Stills and Nash; Stevie Wonder; and Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band (on Thursday); and Aretha Franklin, Metallica and U2 (on Friday). HBO will show an edited version of the concerts on Nov. 29.

Update | 1:04 p.m. Stagehands at the Joyce Theater voted on Monday to be represented by Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, joining the union that handles negotiations for colleagues on Broadway, in concert halls and at major homes of dance in New York, including the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center and City Center.

Updated | 4:13 p.m. Linn Ullmann tells us that Woody Allen and Ingmar Bergman did indeed meet, though Mr. Allen never made it to Bergman’s home on Fårö. See here for the story of the filmmakers’ encounter in 1975.

Has Broadway got room for one more Neil Simon show? The musical “Promises, Promises,” for which Mr. Simon adapted the book from the 1960 Billy Wilder comedy “The Apartment,” and which features a score by Burt Bacharach and Hal David, is headed back to Broadway for its first-ever revival since its original 1968 production. In a news release, publicists for the revival said that it would star Sean Hayes (of “Will & Grace” and the recent Encores! revival of “Damn Yankees”) as Chuck Baxter and Kristin Chenoweth (“Wicked”) as Fran Kubelik; those roles were played by Jack Lemmon and Shirley MacLaine in “The Apartment,” and by Jerry Orbach and Jill O’Hara in the original Broadway run of “Promises, Promises.”

Nickelodeon announced Monday that it had begun production on a new comedy series from the creator of “iCarly” and “Drake & Josh,” starring the teenage actor and singer Victoria Justice. The new series, “Victorious,” will be set in a Hollywood school for the performing arts and feature an ensemble cast that will sing, dance and act. Nickelodeon is partnering with the Columbia/Epic record label group to produce the series, meaning it might produce soundtrack albums and weekly musical releases, something that has proven popular this fall with Fox’s prime-time network series “Glee.” Dan Schneider, the series creator, has been responsible for several of Nickelodeon’s biggest hits including “Zoey 101,” which featured Ms. Justice. An Aug. 8 “iCarly” special that starred Ms. Justice alongside Miranda Cosgrove, the star of “iCarly,” drew 7.9 million viewers, a series record and the week’s top cable telecast among young viewers.
DALLAS — When the Dallas Opera opened its 53rd season in its splendid new home here on Friday, the New Yorker who might have been hosting the event, had things gone differently, was missing.

Back in March, Ricky Gervais told us that hosting an awards show like the Oscars was “a thankless task for a comedian.” “What’s the best that could happen?” he asked rhetorically. “You’re funny? You should be. The worst that can happen is, they say, ‘Worst host ever.'”

Terence Riley resigned on Monday as director of the Miami Art Museum, effective immediately, after nearly four years in the job. The museum’s chairman, Aaron S. Podhurst, announced that Mr. Riley would continue as a consultant through June 30, 2010, about the museum’s new home in downtown Miami, for which final designs were unveiled last week.

Broadway has found itself another photogenic, swoon-inducing duo to help fill the void when “A Steady Rain” packs up on Dec. 6 (taking Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman with it): Liev Schreiber and Scarlett Johansson will arrive soon after for a revival of Arthur Miller‘s “A View From the Bridge” that will run for 14 weeks at the Cort Theater. Mr. Schreiber, of the Broadway revivals of “Talk Radio” and “Glengarry Glen Ross,” will star as Eddie Carbone, the lovelorn longshoreman obsessed with his niece, Catherine, who will be played by Ms. Johansson (“Lost in Translation”), who is making her Broadway debut. Gregory Mosher will direct; previews are to begin on Dec. 28 with an official opening set for Jan. 24. A previous revival of “A View From the Bridge” that transferred to Broadway in 1998 starred Anthony LaPaglia and Brittany Murphy, and won the Tony Award for best revival of a play.

As Halloween approaches, A. O. Scott looks back on “Dead of Night,” an “obscure and fascinating” British film from 1945. The movie is actually a collection of several spooky tales — a man is bewitched by a haunted mirror, a ventriloquist is driven mad by his dummy — held together by a framing narrative. “Dead of Night” is largely unknown to American audiences, “but it’s worth hunting for in dusty, antique, out-of-the-way video stores,” Mr. Scott says. “Bring it to your friends and show it to them. They’ll be amazed, and terrified.” Share your thoughts on “Dead of Night,” if you have seen it. And please let us know: what are your favorite films to watch when you’re in the mood for a good scare?

With food prices remaining high in developing countries, the United Nations estimates that the number of hungry people around the world could increase by 100 million in 2009 and pass the one billion mark. A summit of world leaders in Rome scheduled for November will set an agenda for ways to reduce hunger and increase investment in agriculture development in poor countries.

A Swiss investment company plans to raise awareness about the shortage of women on corporate boards around the world and generate returns for its investors in the process, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier reports from London.

In the best-selling book, "Born to Run,'' author Christopher McDougall has reframed the debate about the wisdom of distance running. He makes the case that running isn't inherently risky. Instead, he argues that the commercialization of urban marathons encourages overzealous training, while the promotion of high-tech shoes has led to poor running form and a rash of injuries.

Forbes, the magazine that once used "capitalist tool" as a motto, is now seeing the downside of capitalism. The magazine plans to lay off several staff members this afternoon, responding to the miserable advertising climate for business magazines.

Just over a year ago, HTC, until then a relatively obscure Taiwanese maker of tech gadgets, delivered the first smartphone powered by Google's Android software. Its collaboration with Google was something of a coming-out party for HTC. With it, the company, which had spent much of its life as a contract manufacturer for the likes of Compaq and Palm, was intensifying efforts to promote its own name in hopes of becoming a globally -recognized brand.

Cancer is typically viewed as something that always grows and gets worse without treatment. But as Gina Kolata reports in today's Science Times, it's becoming increasingly clear that untreated cancers sometimes stop growing, shrink or even, occasionally, disappear.

On Friday, Facebook began introducing changes to its primary home page, which its 300 million members land on when they log on to the social network. Now, instead of the live feed of their friends' status updates and activities, which had come to resemble the chaotic, hive-mind buzz of the Twittersphere, Facebook users now get a "news feed" -- essentially the most significant and most-commented-on status updates and activities from their contacts in the last day.

Bar 3 and its new little sister, Restaurant 3, are second homes to Berlin's art community. "You know that bar where the whole '60s L.A. art scene used to hang out?" said Jessica Backus, the assistant director of Peres Projects Berlin. "The saying in L.A. at the time was that if it caught on fire, then the entire L.A. art world would have vanished overnight. That's basically what Bar 3 is for Berlin."

There are some ingredients one associates with Chinese-influenced dishes and some one doesn't. Beets, surely, fall into the latter group. But what Jackie (my wife) and I had the other day were: a yen for something to eat with a bowl of rice; and a nice bunch of beets, greens and all. As I walked home pondering this, I thought of a couple of things: You don't have to boil or roast (or microwave) beets before using them in a dish - this I first learned back in the days of so-called nouvelle cuisine when, on one of our first trips to Paris, we were served a dish of sautéed sliced beets deglazed with sherry vinegar and finished with butter - something I still make from time to time. And, secondly, root vegetables are not alien to Chinese home cooking. Jackie's former colleague, who was Chinese and who used to cook with us every few weeks, made wonderful turnip dishes.

The New Jersey Devils suffered a twin blow after Saturday's convincing 4-1 victory in Pittsburgh -- the game has cost them their top defenseman and a key defensive forward. Defenseman Paul Martin is out for four to six weeks with a broken left arm, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said. Martin is also a top candidate for the United States Olympic Team at February's Winter Games in Vancouver. If he takes six weeks to recover, he should be ready in time for the tournament.

LONDON | Move over Hollywood, and make way for Notting Hill, Mayfair and Camden. These areas of London probably don't boast as many celebrities as Hollywood but they have their fair share of starry connections. And a tour offers the opportunity to visit spots where celebrities live or have lived (Madonna), performed (Pink Floyd and the Beatles), partied (the Rolling Stones) and even died (Jimi Hendrix).
The Senate health care legislation will include a government-run insurance plan, but states would be allowed to "opt out" of it, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, announced Monday afternoon.

Many parents were sympathetic to James H. Burns and his criticism of the horror film commercials that run during televised football games (which is often a family-viewing experience). Many of the parents themselves shared their experiences of dealing with children who are afraid to stay home alone, in part because of watching frightening things on television. Others were more skeptical of the parental concern, noting that football is itself one of the more violent sports.

The opening alpine races of the World Cup circuit were on the Rettenbach glacier in Sölden, Austria over the weekend, an early season primer before the races get serious in the coming weeks. There were few surprises in the giant slalom but there was injury misfortune and a bit of controversy.

Overview | Why do people like to solve puzzles? How are they good learning tools? In this lesson, students try to solve math puzzles and explain the strategies used to come to the solutions. Students will hone their problem solving skills and their ability to explain their process. They will come away with a broader view of "math" and see its recreational capacity.

Update | 5:19 p.m. Lorin Maazel will fill in for James Levine, conducting the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Sixth and Seventh symphonies in Boston on Oct. 30 and 31 and at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 2, the orchestra announced Monday. Mr Levine, the music director of the orchestra, had surgery earlier this month for a herniated disc and has been advised by his doctors to postpone his return to his conducting schedule until he is more fully recovered, according to the statement. On Oct. 15, the orchestra had said that Mr. Levine would return to the podium for the Sixth and Seventh symphonies. He is next scheduled to perform with the Boston Symphony on Jan. 28; he also has an engagement at the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 3.

CNN, which invented the cable news network more than two decades ago, will hit a new competitive low with its prime-time programs in October, finishing fourth - and last - among the cable news networks with the audience that all the networks rely on for their advertising.
About one in six Americans say they have at some point been diagnosed with depression, and the rate is nearly twice as high for lower-income people, according to new Gallup survey data.

After a months-long process of soliciting and winnowing thousands of ideas for "transformational" energy initiatives, the Department of Energy has selected the first 37 recipients of $151 million in grants under its Arpa-E program (Advanced Research Projects - Energy). The selection committee faced the difficult task of choosing proposals based on the soundness of the underlying science and engineering and trying to avoid choosing winners based on predispositions or on the geography of congressional districts. The agency noted that 62 percent of recipients of the first round of grants are businesses and 35 percent are educational institutions. (On its face, this seems to imply that the Obama administration sees the private sector as more apt to be the source of game-changing breakthroughs.) How do you think the selection committee did? You can find the list on the Arpa-E Web site here. I'll be seeking reactions from researchers studying the interface of money, intellectual inquiry and innovation.

The 2009 Yankees are a playoff team with virtually no weaknesses, but if you had to pick an Achilles' heel, it would be their left-handed relief pitching. Phil Coke is little better than a stopgap, while Damaso Marte is a wild card, given how little he pitched in the regular season. Of course, Mariano Rivera himself has a pronounced reverse platoon split - he has allowed a combined on-base and slugging percentage of .598 to right-handed batters over his career, versus .517 for lefties - but Manager Joe Girardi certainly won't want to transform his best bullpen arm into a latter-day Mike Myers. If the Phillies are to repeat as champions, their victory scenario will almost surely involve Ryan Howard and Chase Utley doing serious damage against Marte and Coke in key spots.

Sometime in the near future, Comcast, predominantly a cable company with about 24 million customers in 39 states, is likely to buy a majority state in NBC Universal, David Carr writes in Monday's Media Equation column.

Nendo, the Tokyo design studio founded by Oki Sato in 2002, is known for its product designs -- for companies like Cappellini, Moroso and Boffi -- that bring out the poetry in contemporary technology. (Several of its products have been featured in T Design.) Tomorrow, "Ghost Stories," an installation of four of Nendo's newest creations, opens at New York's Museum of Arts and Design. Prototypes and and videos will accompany the pieces, in the museum's MADProjects Gallery, to illuminate the process behind their design. Sato says that he treasures life's "Aha!" moments and wants to share them with others, and in that respect this exhibition will not disappoint. Among the pieces on display will be the Cord chair, a wooden chair whose impossibly fragile appearance is made possible by an aluminum skeleton; the Blown-Fabric lamps, made from a new, nonwoven polyester fabric (first seen last April at the groundbreaking "Senseware" show in Milan), that can be inflated like a balloon; and the Fade-Out Chair, an acrylic chair with a faux wood finish that disappears toward the base of the legs, making it seem as if the chair is starting to vanish into thin air. "Ghost Stories" runs through Jan. 10, 2010.

From our colleagues at DealBook:

The occasional big boy at J.G. Melon or fat bomb at Prime Meats aside, Diner's Journal generally comes down for the diner-style griddled burger when it comes to questions surrounding New York's Best Hamburgers. A Sunday stop at the Five Guys outpost in Brooklyn Heights showed exactly why: a crisp exterior giving way to a mineral interior, with as much flavor coming from the mayonnaise, cheese, salt and fresh jalapeño as from the meat. (When it comes to burgers, the DJ is a toppings and condiments man, not a meat-nerd minimalist.) Fresh-cut, peanut-oil-fried potatoes? Yes, and there were more than enough of these to feed the Journal and his thieving brother. Five Guys does excellent fries: salty and firm. (Douse them in vinegar, not ketchup.) But the point was the burger -- canvas for the oils of its friends, a true in-and-out pleasure on its soft bun. Pretty great, the Journal declared, out in the sunshine of Montague Street. "Yeah, and Panera is better than Subway," said his brother, affecting the wisdom of Buddha. There was braised organic bok choy for dinner that night, rice. Moderation in all things. Right?

Critics are given to sweeping statements, and maybe none more so than pop music critics. Long ago, Robert Christgau declared that the Kinks' "Waterloo Sunset" was "the most beautiful song in the English language." Greil Marcus, on the other hand, has described "Waterloo Sunset" as "one of the most beautiful songs in all of rock" - far more measured, and far more defensible.

The World Bank recently released the results of its 2008 World Bank Group Entrepreneurship Survey. The results show something free marketers around the globe should appreciate. After accounting for differences in per capita income across countries, the World Bank researchers found that countries with easier and less expensive procedures for registering new businesses have higher rates of new business creation.

Now that Takashi Murakami has established himself as a household name with his collaborations with Louis Vuitton, it's clear that artists are no longer afraid to embrace their commercial potential. It's surprising, however, to see movement in the opposite direction. Take Simon de Pury. It turns out that the charismatic auctioneer and chairman of the esteemed art house is also an artist -- his second show of large-format photographs opened last week in Berlin at the Corner, the city's answer to Colette. Although he's best known as a champion of contemporary art and design, de Pury has a long-standing interest in creating his own paintings, drawings and photographs. He observes that "many curators and gallerists are also artists, but they tend to be very discreet about it. Thomas Krens [the former director of the Solomon Guggenheim Foundation] for instance, is a printmaker. I've always enjoyed making work, but I lead a very busy life, so it's not easy. That's one of the reasons why photography is a good medium for me."

In March, Vertigo, an imprint of DC Comics, will release the first issue of “American Vampire.” The new series, illustrated by Rafael Albuquerque, will open with a five-issue arc that contains two 16-page stories: one by Scott Snyder and one by a rather more well-known name, Stephen King. The series will focus on a new breed of vampire through the lens of different eras in American history, above. Mr. Snyder will tell the story of Pearl, who is seeking fame in the jazz age, while Mr. King will focus on Skinner Sweet, the first American vampire who does not fear the sun. Mr. King’s involvement began when Mr. Snyder sent him the series pitch in the hopes of getting a blurb. “He wrote back saying he really liked it and would do a couple of issues if anyone would let him,” Mr. Snyder said.

Friends and colleagues of Clive Barnes, the influential theater and dance critic who died last year, will remember his life and work on Nov. 2 at an event hosted by the New York Post columnist Michael Riedel. Scheduled speakers include Edward Albee, Paul Taylor and Frederic Franklin of American Ballet Theater, as well as The New York Times’s chief dance critic, Alastair Macaulay, and his predecessor at The Times Anna Kisselgoff, among others. Mr. Barnes, who worked for The Post for the last 30 years and The Times before that, helped usher in a new generation of dancers in the 1960s and as a theater critic helped make playwrights like David Mamet and Tom Stoppard famous. The free event, with limited seating for the public, will begin at 3 p.m. at Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center.

Meiji University in Tokyo has announced plans to open a library devoted to the art of manga, the Japanese graphic novel genre. According to Agence France-Presse, plans for the Tokyo International Manga Library include storage for two million comic books, animation drawings, video games and other artifacts. The library’s first phase, to be named after the critic and author Yoshihiro Yonezawa, will house his collection of 140,000 comic books and is scheduled to open this month. The rest of the library is scheduled to be completed by 2015. “Manga has been taken lightly in the past, and there has been no solid archive for serious study,” Susumi Shibao, a library official, told Agence France-Presse. The private university plans to offer international researchers, as well as students and fans, access to its collections.

It can be difficult to keep a straight face, or even stay upright, when you are running next to Sarah Jones and she suddenly becomes Chinese or Dominican or Kenyan. Or a Jewish grandmother. Jones's pitch-perfect accents and intonations, and her poignant take on the immigrant experience in her one-woman shows, have earned her wide acclaim and a Tony Award. It seems fitting, then, that she should be training for Sunday's New York City Marathon, a race that showcases New York's ethnic blend and includes thousands of runners from overseas.

TRIEGER--B. Terri, resident of Larchmont, NY passed away on October 24, 2009. She died of lung cancer. Terri was the wife of Dr. Norman Trieger and mother of Barrie and Simon Jacob of West Orange, NJ: Michael and Rebecca Trieger of Springfield, IL: Joel Trieger of Mamaroneck, NY: and Eva Trieger of Solana Beach, CA. Mrs. Trieger, a graduate of Brandeis University, volunteered as a remedial reading teacher, before studying to become a docent at the Jewish Museum in New York City, where she worked for almost 40 years. An active member of Dorot, Terri taught classes for the homebound via telephone, and created a community for them as they learned about the world and each other. Mrs. Trieger served as curator for the Koslower Gallery at the Westchester Jewish Center, where she and Norman have been active members for over thirty years. Terri will be remembered by her thirteen grandchildren, their spouses, and her eleven great-grandchildren. Mrs. Trieger's interests were endless. She was a voracious reader and a seasoned traveler who celebrated life more fully then most. She delighted in the company of friends and family, and left a huge impression on so many acquaintances who have become her family. Terri is survived by two brothers and their wives, Leland and Phyllis Beck of Seaford, NY, Charles and Lorna Beck of Winston Salem, NC. Charitable contribution in her memory may be made to the Koslowe Gallery at the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, NY.

How do you solve a problem like ''La Damnation de Faust''? Berlioz's ''légende dramatique,'' inspired by Goethe's tragic play ''Faust,'' is among the highlights of that composer's oeuvre for its extraordinary music and visceral impact. From a dramatic perspective, though, the work is less a sustained narrative than a sequence of scenes vividly limned through beguiling melodies and brilliant orchestration. Robert Lepage's technologically groundbreaking production, created for the Metropolitan Opera last season and revived on Friday night, embraces that episodic quality. Working with the interactive-video designer Holger Förterer, Mr. Lepage offers dazzling images on a scaffoldlike set that doubles as a colossal video screen. Grassy fields ripple as soldiers march up the set; demons madly clamber across it, and projected sprites writhe in smoky tendrils on its surfaces.

Shani Davis, 27, capped an impressive week of racing at the United States World Cup Olympic qualifier in West Allis, Wis., with a victory in the 10,000 meters. His time of 13 minutes 29.01 seconds was his personal best at sea level, he said. During the four days of competition, Davis also won the 1,000 and 5,000, was second in the 1,500 and third in the 500. Members of the United States squad can secure berths for the 2010 Olympics by accumulating points in the five World Cup events. ''I like trying to push myself to reach bigger and greater and better heights,'' said Davis, who could race in two to six events at the Vancouver Games. He said he would start with his best events, the 1,000 and 1,500, ''and I'll branch out from there.'' Davis added, ''I would not like to water down the potency of my skating by just trying to go out there and skate everything.''

Lou Jacobi, the mustachioed, scene-stealing Canadian-born actor and comedian who made a film and stage career playing comic ethnic characters but was praised for serious dramatic roles as well, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95. The death was confirmed by Leonie Nowitz, a social worker who had been overseeing his care for several years.

SILTON--Robert Julian, passed away October 24th, 2009 at age 96. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Alice, his daughter Mary, his son, Robert Jr., and grandchildren, John and Sarah. Born in New York City, Bob was a graduate of Brown University and passionately served his country as a Lieutenant in the Army Signal Corps during World War II. Much of his career was spent as Vice President of the Wallerstein Co., which pioneered enzyme technology for the food and beverage industries. An avid yachtsman, Bob was a member of the New York Yacht Club. Known for his unwavering integrity in every aspect of his life and his dedication to help all around him, he will be greatly missed as a loving husband to his adored Alice and guiding light to his children and grandchildren. Memorial service to be held on Tuesday, October 27th at 12 noon at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester (corner of Kenilworth Road and Westchester Ave. in Rye). In his memory, donations may be made to White Plains Hospital Center, Davis Avenue and East Post Road, White Plains, NY 10601.

Mark McGwire, the slugger who smashed prodigious home runs, was later suspected of using steroids and has been absent from baseball since his retirement in 2001, will return as a batting coach for the St. Louis Cardinals. During questioning at a Congressional hearing in 2005, McGwire would not discuss whether he had used steroids, wounding his chances of being elected to the National Baseball Hall of Fame and intensifying his desire for privacy. But McGwire is expected to be in a Cardinals uniform from the first day of spring training until the final out of their season.

ANTHONY--Dee. Legendary music manager and impresario Dee Anthony, who guided the careers of artists as diverse as Tony Bennett, Peter Frampton and Peter Allen passed away today, October 25, 2009 in Connecticut. He was 83 years old. During a career that spanned over 50 years, Anthony was a seminal figure in the music industry, whose managerial skills helped pave the way and set new standards for rock music. He first gained major prominence when rock and roll began to take off during the mid-1960's. Anthony led the charge in the United States by introducing to the American audience a host of fledgling young British rock bands, such as Traffic, Jethro Tull, Joe Cocker, Free, Spooky Tooth, Mott the Hoople, Savoy Brown and King Crimson, breaking them into headliner status as well as establishing many of those artists in the pantheon of rock. Anthony started his career as a personal manager in the music industry in the 1950s, working with a young Jerry Vale, a neighborhood friend. In 1954, Anthony met singer Tony Bennett at a Yonkers nightclub and went on to represent Bennett for well over the next decade. In 1968, Anthony, with his brother Bill, founded Bandana Enterprises, a global management company that sheparded the careers of artists such as Joe Cocker, Humble Pie, The J Geils Band, MC5, Ten Years After, and Emerson, Lake, and Palmer. But it would be Anthony's management of musician Peter Frampton that would cement his legendary status in the music industry. Anthony first met Frampton while managing Humble Pie, of which Frampton was a member. When Frampton left the band to pursue a solo career, Anthony continued to manage him, helping to launch one of the most successful solo careers of the 1970s. The double album, "Frampton Comes Alive," would shatter industry records, eventually selling more than 14 million copies worldwide. Anthony would also receive praise from his industry peers, being named "Billboard Manager of the Year" in 1976 and 1977. During the 1980s, Anthony continued to manage music artists including Peter Allen, Basia, and Devo. Anthony retired from the business in the mid-1990s. Dee Anthony, was born Anthony D'Addario and grew up in the Bronx. In 1944, he joined the Navy serving in the submarine force. During his three years of service he was decorated with three medals-- the Victory Medal, the Asiatic Pacific Medal and the American Theater Medal. Anthony then returned to New York City, opened a luncheonette, and followed his passion for show business. Anthony is survived by his wife, Valerie, four daughters, Michele, Marla, Vanessa and Jessica, two brothers, Bill Anthony and Bobby D'Addario, sister Tina Cursio, and six grandchildren, Jack, Charlotte, Olivia, Joey, Dylan, and Chase. Anthony's daughter, Michele has carried on the family business. During her career she became the highest-ranking female record company executive as the President and COO of Sony Music. Currently she is a music industry consultant, whose clients have included Pearl Jam, Bjork, Macy Gray, Sharon and Ozzy Osbourne, and Prince. A visitation will be held on Wednesday, October 28th from 6-9 pm and a memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 29th at 11am both at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Dee Anthony's name to "Wounded Warrior Regiment", C/O Charitable Organizations, 3025 John Quick Road, Quantico, VA 22134.

Inheriting a series from a venerable ensemble like the Guarneri String Quartet must be daunting for a relatively young quartet, but it is also a great opportunity. The Pacifica Quartet finds itself in that position, having just taken over the berth at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that the newly retired Guarneri held for 43 seasons. But despite their youthful looks and energetic performances, the Pacifica players are not novices: they have worked together since 1994, which means that the group is far more seasoned than the Guarneri was when it first performed at the Met. In its introductory program, on Saturday evening, the group seemed intent on demonstrating its flexibility. In Mozart's Quartet No. 19 in C (K. 465) it produced a dark sound and played with unusual restraint, as if anything louder than a mezzo forte would shatter the work. Still, the ensemble's expressive range was striking: the Dvorak-like warmth of the Andante cantabile proved a stark contrast to both the strained, ghostly dissonances of the work's opening Adagio and the cheerful briskness of the finale.

BONOFF--Ethel, passed away October 23 from head injuries sustained in a fall the previous Saturday. Still fiercely independent at age 95, Ethel insisted on walking unaided almost every weekday to the 92nd Street Y, where she took Shakespeare courses, played bridge, enjoyed seeing friends and attended concerts. Music was always a joy; she likened the classics to "old friends." Elegant, cultured, gracious and warmly hospitable, she was much loved and will be greatly missed by her survivors: sister Audrey Rosenbluth, daughter Laurie Flamm and son-in-law Paul Flamm, son Bill Rosenthal and daughter-in-law Carrie Rosenthal, granddaughters Carolyn and Lizzie Flamm, grandson Jae Rosenthal, granddaughter Andrea Davitt and grandson-in-law John Davitt, and great-grandchildren Katie and Will Davitt. Services at 9:45am Tuesday, October 27, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the 92nd Street YMHA.

Playing the complete Beethoven piano sonatas or string quartets is a challenge adopted by many soloists and ensembles. It is unusual in such series, however, for works from different genres to be juxtaposed in the same concert. For its exploration of Beethoven's string quartets, which began last season at the 92nd Street Y, the Tokyo String Quartet has organized the works by early, middle and late periods and set them off against piano sonatas from the same time frames. On Friday at the 92nd Street Y, quartets from Beethoven's middle period (around 1803 to 1814) were programmed with his Piano Sonata in C, the ''Waldstein,'' performed by the young pianist Inon Barnatan.

It's part of the peculiar magic around Apple that there's always more curiosity about what the company does not announce than what it does. And none of the products it announced last week -- a new MacBook, new iMacs with 21.5-inch and 27-inch displays or a new Magic Mouse (above) -- can account for one of the factors that Apple gave last week in explaining its estimate of a falling gross margin for its coming quarter: an abnormal increase in air freight costs. Timothy D. Cook, Apple's chief operating officer, said in a conference call with analysts that the cost increases had ''nothing to do with iPhone,'' and ''are about getting units into the channel for the holiday.''
