The traditional software market has plenty of competition from free applications and cloud computing. Sales fell to $3.3 billion in 2008, from $3.7 billion in 2007, a drop of 11 percent. Games like Sims 3, above, are the best-selling category this year, followed by systems utilities like antivirus software and finance titles like Turbotax and Taxcut. Two franchises share the top five spots among the games. Sims 3 is joined by Sims 2 Double Deluxe and the World of Warcraft series: World of Warcraft, World of Warcraft: Battle Chest and the Lich King expansion pack. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Pop purists and discerning hipsters alike should find something to satisfy their musical tastes in the 2010 season of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, which runs from Jan. 13 through March 6 at the Allen Room of Frederick P. Rose Hall. The series, whose lineup was announced on Tuesday in a news release, will begin with a performance by Marianne Faithfull. Other artists on the roster include David Hidalgo and Louie Perez of Los Lobos on Jan. 15; Martha Plimpton on Jan. 16; Nellie McKay (who performs a tribute to Doris Day) on Feb. 18; the Brooklyn rock band Dirty Projectors on Feb. 19; and Chita Rivera on March 6. On Jan. 27, Hal Willner will produce a one-night musical exploration of the David Lehman book “A Fine Romance,” featuring musicians like Rufus Wainwright and Bill Frisell performing songs by Irving Berlin, George Gershwin and other Jewish songwriters.

Combine the wish list of any Broadway producer with the hit list of any TMZ cameraman and you have the lineup for this year’s production of the 24 Hour Plays on Broadway. Among the many performers scheduled to take part in the event are Ashton Kutcher (making his Broadway debut), Demi Moore, and Jennifer Aniston, as well as Liev Schreiber, Anthony Mackie, Billy Crudup, Sam Rockwell, Julia Stiles, Rachel Dratch and the downtown power couple of David Cross and Amber Tamblyn. This year’s playwrights include David Lindsay-Abaire, Nathan Jackson and Theresa Rebeck, and the musical guests include the Swedish rock band A Camp. The annual production, which will take place on Nov. 9 at the American Airlines Theater, calls for creative types to write, direct and perform six original short plays in just under a day. The event is sponsored by Montblanc and is a benefit for Urban Arts Partnership, which provides arts programs for New York public schools.
If you can’t wait until Wednesday night to see your beloved Yankees again, then you’ll just have to watch “The Biggest Loser” (NBC, 8 p.m.), where Derek Jeter drops in to lead a “baseball challenge.”

When Bruce Springsteen said he canceled a concert scheduled for Monday night in Kansas City, Mo., because of a death in the family, he meant it in both the literal and figurative senses: Reuters reported that the concert planned for the Sprint Center was canceled after the death of Lenny Sullivan, 36, who was Mr. Springsteen’s cousin and had worked with the E Street Band for 10 years, most recently as assistant road manager. A statement on Mr. Springsteen’s official Web site, brucespringsteen.net, said: “A warm and sensitive person, he was beloved by Bruce, the Band, the crew, and the entire Thrill Hill family.” (Thrill Hill is the name of Mr. Springsteen’s touring company, as well as his recording studio in New Jersey.) Citing the entertainment Web site TMZ.com, Reuters reported that Mr. Sullivan was found dead in his hotel room on Monday and that the police were investigating, although the death was not being treated as suspicious. Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band are among the artists scheduled to perform at a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame anniversary concert at Madison Square Garden on Thursday.

Six picketers from the Westboro Baptist Church, based in Topeka, Kan., stood outside the Cooperman Jewish Community Center on Northfield Avenue in West Orange today, while people gathered inside discussing intolerance and opting against a counter-demonstration.

The Idaho Junior Steelheads of the Tier III Western States Hockey League are caught playing "strip hockey" during a practice at a municipally owned rink, shedding a piece of equipment each time they miss during an impromptu penalty-shot contest. Shades of the championship game in "Slap Shot." Some players get down to their underwear, and one 17-year-old actually takes off his underwear for a moment, according to The Associated Press report, which wryly notes: "the city forbids people from showing their buttocks in public, largely to curb erotic dance parlors. Exemptions include dance, ballet, music or dramatic performances, or artistic displays; nudity during hockey practice isn't on the list." The 17-year-old is suspended by the team, and the Boise police are investigating whether public decency charges have been violated.

"Fearless the cobweb swings from the ceiling," Emily Dickinson wrote in one of her poems. But not in the front parlor of the Homestead, her house in Amherst, Mass, which is now part of the Emily Dickinson Museum. Part of the ceiling there collapsed on Sunday afternoon while the house was open for tours. No one was in the parlor at the time, and no one in the house was hurt, though some of the Dickinson family furniture and belongings on display there, including a sofa and a teapot, may have been harmed.

Over the weekend of October 25-27 scientists at CERN sent a beam of protons into the Large Hadron Collider, and ran them part way around the giant underground ring successfully before dumping them. It was the first time protons have traveled in the giant particle accelerator since last September when the first attempts to turn on the $6 billion machine ended in a fury of sparks and smoke. Later that weekend the engineers ran lead ions around part of the machine for the first time; they will eventually be collided in hopes of producing a so-called quark-gluon plasma.

Certain art is subject to what I think of as the Ramones effect: it's indispensable in small doses, but punishing if you spend too much time with it in one sitting. That's how I've been feeling lately about Padgett Powell's new novel, "The Interrogative Mood." This thing, as you'll recall if you saw Josh Emmons's review on Sunday, consists entirely of questions - some 3,000 of them - strung together with no connection but the discursive genius of their author. Here's how it starts: "Are your emotions pure? Are your nerves adjustable? How do you stand in relation to the potato? Should it still be Constantinople? Does a nameless horse make you more nervous or less nervous than a named horse? In your view, do children smell good?" It's a delight, and I can read it for about five minutes at a time before I need to put it down.

Two hit reality shows that could have started out as video games will soon be receiving the video game treatment. "The Deadliest Catch" and "Man vs. Wild," both of which are shown on the Discovery Channel, are being adapted for video games by Crave Entertainment, the publisher of titles like World Championship Poker 2 and The Bible Game, The Hollywood Reporter said. The Deadliest Catch game, which will be released for PlayStation 3, Nintendo Wii and Nintendo DS, will allow players to run their own crab boats and navigate the Bering Sea; Man vs. Wild, which will be released for those systems as well as for the Xbox 360, will let players follow the guidance of Bear Grylls, the survival expert who hosts the show, in all sorts of dangerous wilderness settings. Though "Deadliest Catch" was previously adapted as an Xbox 360 game, Betsi Gijanto, the Crave executive vice president, said, "We really didn't feel like it stayed true to the action of the show," according to The Hollywood Reporter.

I recently had a few days off in between European fashion weeks and I wanted to get away from the crowds. Why not visit Normandy? So I took a train from Paris to Deauville and then a taxi to Honfleur. The drive took me through winding roads, past beautiful French chateaus and cows in open fields. In Honfleur, I was immediately charmed by the small streets of the 17th-century city, not to mention my attic room in the farmhouse-style inn, La Maison de Lucie.

The World Series matchup has already generated several names like the Liberty Series, the New Jersey Turnpike Series and the Amtrak Series. Using the Jersey Turnpike, a trip from Citizens Bank Park to Yankee Stadium is 108 miles  1 hour 44 minutes without traffic. The Phillies traveled to New York by Amtrak train on Monday, leaving after a rally in downtown Philadelphia and arriving at Penn Station at about 6:30 p.m. But as seasoned frugal travelers between Philadelphia and New York know, you would not have to take Amtrak at all to get from stadium to stadium. A fan leaving Citizens Bank Park around 2 p.m. Monday could have gotten to Yankee Stadium for less than $25 in less than four hours.

The Broadway stage veteran Terri White, who appears in "Finian's Rainbow," which opens on Broadway on Thursday, has lived lyrics of heartbreak more personally than even the most die-hard method actress would want. In the summer of 2008, Ms. White, 61, could not make rent. She was evicted from her apartment of 14 years, after a breakup with a longtime girlfriend. She could not work. She also could not find a way to ask for help. For three months, when she was not crashing on a friend's couch, she slept in Washington Square Park. [NYT]

When it comes to fish, size isn't everything. Take the tiny Black Sea anchovy, known in Turkey as hamsi. It may be small, cheap and unremarkable looking, but is nevertheless known as the "little prince" of fishes. In the Black Sea area, where hamsi are caught, the finger-sized fish are a staple, used in dozens of dishes and forming an important part of the local economy. The arrival of fall means the start of hamsi season, and for many Istanbul food lovers, it's a time of celebration.

The last five 49ers drafts have produced more unemployed coaches than first-round success stories, but three of the team's most exasperating picks in recent years -- Alex Smith, Vernon Davis and Michael Crabtree -- nearly led San Francisco to a come-from-behind win at Houston on Sunday. Smith, the No. 1 overall choice in 2005, replaced quarterback Shaun Hill at halftime and threw three touchdown passes to Davis, the sixth overall pick in 2006. The resurgence of Davis, a tight end whose tremendous physical tools have rarely been matched by comparable production, has been the biggest surprise of the 49ers' 3-3 start. But the debut of Crabtree, the 10th pick in this year's draft, was a more welcome development for San Francisco.

Stagehands at the Joyce Theater voted on Monday to be represented by Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, joining the union that handles negotiations for colleagues on Broadway, in concert halls and at major homes of dance in New York, including City Center and the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. The vote was 12 to 0, with one ballot voided, said James J. Claffey Jr., the local’s president. Three other Joyce stagehands were not present, he said. “They came to us,” Mr. Claffey said of the Joyce workers, adding that they were mainly interested in job security during troubled times for the arts. Local 1 said it would now handle negotiations with the Joyce Theater Foundation. In a statement, the Joyce Theater said, “While we are disappointed in the results of this election, we of course will honor the wishes of our employees, and we look forward to sitting down with Local No. 1 to negotiate a collective bargaining agreement.”.

The rustic properties on the Baltic island of Faro where the director Ingmar Bergman, below, lived and worked will become a nonprofit retreat for artists and scholars. The sale of Bergman’s property, which includes a library, film collection, furniture and art, was arranged by Linn Ullmann, his daughter with the actress Liv Ullmann. “Now the legacy of my father will be preserved,” Linn Ullmann said Monday in a telephone interview. “Nobody has bought it to make Bergman’s Bed-and-Breakfast or Bergmanland.” Mr. Bergman first visited Faro, off the coast of Gotland, Sweden, in 1960 while scouting locations for his film “Through a Glass Darkly.” He died at his home there in 2007 and was buried at a local church alongside his wife, Ingrid. “In the 12th hour,” Ms. Ullmann said, the Norwegian archaeologist and inventor Hans Gude Gudesen bought the estate from the Bergman heirs and donated the use of the facilities for research and artistic pursuits. (She declined to say how much he paid.) Ms. Ullmann said the estate would begin looking for an artistic director and planned to have its official opening in early summer 2010.

A new British online service, Digital Theater, announced on Monday that five major British theatrical companies had become partners in filming productions and offering them for download for about $15. The first production is the English Touring Theater’s “Far From the Madding Crowd,” an adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel by Mark Healy. Additional productions are expected to be available on Digital Theater’s Web site shortly (www.digitaltheatre.com). The project comes four months after the National Theater in London drew wide notice for its live broadcasts in London, New York and elsewhere of its production of “Phèdre,” starring Helen Mirren.

Terence Riley resigned on Monday as director of the Miami Art Museum, effective immediately, after nearly four years in the job. The museum’s chairman, Aaron S. Podhurst, announced that Mr. Riley would continue as a consultant through June 30, 2010, to advise about the museum’s new home in downtown Miami, for which final designs were unveiled last week. Mr. Riley said in a telephone interview on Monday that his resignation was not connected to problems with the building project. “If this project was in some sort of trouble or in some sort of holding pattern I would be here till the thing got righted and got done,” he said. “This is a project with verifiable legs.” The new building, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, is scheduled to open in 2013. The museum said financing was in place for construction. Mr. Riley, formerly chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, will resume his role as a partner at Keenen/Riley Architects. Mr. Podhurst said the museum would form a search committee to find a new director. “Architecture is his first love,” Mr. Podhurst said. “That’s what he wants to do, and I think it’s a good deal for both.”.

Does Broadway have room for one more Neil Simon show? The musical “Promises, Promises,” for which Mr. Simon wrote a book adapted from the script of the Billy Wilder comedy “The Apartment,” with a score by Burt Bacharach and Hal David, is headed back to Broadway for its first revival there since its original production in 1968. Publicists for the revival said that it would star Sean Hayes (of “Will & Grace” and the recent Encores! revival of “Damn Yankees”), above left, and Kristin Chenoweth (“Wicked”), above right, in roles played by Jack Lemmon and Shirley MacLaine in the film and by Jerry Orbach and Jill O’Hara in the original Broadway run. The revival is to be directed by Rob Ashford (the choreographer of “Thoroughly Modern Millie”), making his Broadway directorial debut. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Broadway Theater on March 28, with its opening night set for April 25.

Broadway has found itself another photogenic, swoon-inducing pair to help fill the void when “A Steady Rain” packs up on Dec. 6 (taking Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman with it): Scarlett Johansson, right above, and Liev Schreiber, right below, are to arrive soon after for a revival of Arthur Miller’s “View From the Bridge,” to run for 14 weeks at the Cort Theater. Mr. Schreiber, of the Broadway revivals of “Talk Radio” and “Glengarry Glen Ross,” will star with Ms. Johansson (“Lost in Translation”), in her Broadway debut. Gregory Mosher will direct; previews are to begin on Dec. 28, with an opening on Jan. 24.

Lorin Maazel will fill in for James Levine by conducting the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven’s Sixth and Seventh Symphonies in Boston on Friday and Saturday and at Carnegie Hall on Monday, the orchestra announced. Mr. Levine, the music director of the orchestra, had disc surgery this month and has been advised by doctors to postpone his return to conducting, Monday’s statement said. On Oct. 15, the symphony had announced that Mr. Levine would return for these dates. He plans to appear on Jan. 28. (He also has a scheduled date with the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 3.).

The mystery began when Belgian customs officials examined shipping records for dozens of giant tanker trucks that outlined an odd, triangular journey across Europe. The trucks, each carrying 22 tons of liquid sugar, swung through eight nations and covered a driving distance of roughly 2,500 miles from a Belgian sugar refinery to Croatia and back -- instead of taking the most direct, 900-mile route.

SILTON--Robert Julian, passed away October 24th, 2009 at age 96. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Alice, his daughter Mary, his son, Robert Jr., and grandchildren, John and Sarah. Born in New York City, Bob was a graduate of Brown University and passionately served his country as a Lieutenant in the Army Signal Corps during World War II. Much of his career was spent as Vice President of the Wallerstein Co., which pioneered enzyme technology for the food and beverage industries. An avid yachtsman, Bob was a member of the New York Yacht Club. Known for his unwavering integrity in every aspect of his life and his dedication to help all around him, he will be greatly missed as a loving husband to his adored Alice and guiding light to his children and grandchildren. Memorial service to be held on Tuesday, October 27th at 12 noon at Congregation Emanu-el of Westchester (corner of Kenilworth Road and Westchester Ave. in Rye). In his memory, donations may be made to White Plains Hospital Center, Davis Avenue and East Post Road, White Plains, NY 10601.

If the natural nickname for this rare Yankees-Phillies pairing is the Amtrak World Series, consider that when these two teams met in October for the only other time, in 1950, Amtrak didn't even exist. Trains connecting New York and Philadelphia that year rolled along the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks, more than two decades before Amtrak was Amtrak. Consider that in 1950, only five years after the end of World War II, the Yankees had won only 12 of their record 26 Series titles and the now-gutted Yankee Stadium was still creating its aura and mystique, and their 4-0 sweep of the Phillies was merely the second of a record five consecutive Series victories.

HERBICH--Barbara Kathleen, 55, of New York passed away on October 17, 2009, in New York City. Services are set for 1pm Wednesday, October 28, at St. Anthony's Catholic Church in Bryan, Texas. Barbara was the daughter of John Bronislaw Herbich (1922-2008), who fled his native Poland during WWII and was a world-renowned ocean engineer, and Margaret Pauline (Boylan) Herbich. A 1972 Bryan High School graduate who studied journalism at the University of Texas at Austin, she attended University of Strasbourg in France. In 1977, she received her Bachelor of Arts in French literature from UT and then moved to New York and received her Master of Arts degree from Columbia University as a President's Fellow. Her passion for her Polish heritage was ignited when she visited Poland in 1970 with her father and frequently returned to Poland to organize conferences and consult on emerging entrepreneurship in the Eastern bloc. At the time of her death, she was working on two films: a rough cut of a documentary about the persecution of Polish priests by the Third Reich, and another film devoted to the destruction of the Polish intelligentsia under the Nazi occupation. Her films tackled important political and historical topics, giving them a nuanced, human face. "Stitch for Time" was nominated for an Academy Award in 1988 and a later film, "USSR Art," documented the groundbreaking Sotheby's auction of Russian avant-garde and contemporary underground art held in Moscow in 1988. Both were aired on PBS stations. An indefatigable, creative personality with a good sense of humor and finely-honed flare for self-irony, Barbara is survived by her mother, Margaret (Boylan) Herbich; brother, Gregory; sister, Patricia Herbich O'Connor; and nieces, Kaya O'Connor and Aleksandra Herbich. Donations may be made to the Beverly Sills Greenough and Meredith Greenough Multiple Sclerosis Fund, 733 Third Ave., Third Floor, New York, NY 10017. Services are entrusted to Hilli-er Funeral Home, www.hillierfuneralhome.com.

The Israeli coach who created a stir at Madison Square Garden last week issued an apology. Pini Gershon, the head coach of Maccabi Electra Tel Aviv, became the subject of headlines and punchlines after he refused to leave the court after being ejected from an exhibition loss to the Knicks. Gershon, who caused a 10-minute delay in the game on Oct. 18, said in a letter sent to Commissioner David Stern and Donnie Walsh, the Knicks' president, ''Our trip to the U.S. was for a wonderful cause -- the children of Migdal Ohr -- and hopefully a few minutes of bad behavior on my behalf won't detract from all the good that was accomplished by our spirited competition with the Knicks and the Clippers.''

While Leon Washington kneeled panting on the grass at the Oakland Coliseum, the shock momentarily gripped his teammates. Some had witnessed his injury, a compound fracture of his right tibia and fibula, and others were ushered away, warned that they did not want to get a closer look. On the sideline, Jets Coach Rex Ryan was piecing together what had happened and immediately, he said, felt devastated for Washington. It took a few minutes for him to understand just how significant one seemingly routine 6-yard run would be for his team.

Brett Favre looked glassy-eyed Sunday night after he took one last hard hit from the Pittsburgh Steelers, but the Minnesota Vikings' first loss of the season will take only a little shine off the return of the prodigal Favre in Green Bay next week. Favre will protest that these games do not really mean much to him, but consider this: when the Vikings hosted the Packers a few weeks ago, Favre broke from his routine of going on the field early to throw the ball around and chat up his buddies from the other team. Favre is such a world-class schmoozer that when Steve Mariucci took the San Francisco 49ers into Lambeau Field to play the Packers years ago, Favre stopped throwing his warm-up passes, walked over to Mariucci and 49ers quarterback Steve Young, and said, ''Let's take a picture,'' Mariucci recalled, adding: ''So the three of us took pictures.''

The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has designated Nov. 5 a nationwide ''Day of Action'' for its eight million union members to press their representatives in Congress to support sweeping health care legislation, including a government-run insurance option. ''We hope to flood the halls of Congress with calls from working families that want to see real reform,'' the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president, Richard L. Trumka, above, said Monday in a telephone news conference.

The Yankees and the Phillies have already met this season, in a Memorial Day weekend series in the Bronx in which Jimmy Rollins smacked a home run on the fi rst pitch thrown, the Yankees got a walk-off hit and the Phillies won an extra-inning battle. It was a vibrant interleague matchup that suggests that this year's World Series will not be quickly resolved, nor overly polite. A.J. Burnett hit Chase Utley with a pitch right after Rollins's home run, and Brett Myers immediately responded by throwing behind Derek Jeter.

KRIEGER--Dale Bruce, 59, son of the late Eli and Helen Krieger of Huntington, NY, left this world unexpectedly after a tragic accident on October 24, 2009. Dale earned a B.A. from Syracuse University and for more than thirty-five years, he managed the finances of wealthy families through money management firms, including those firms that he founded, Carnegie Hill Company and Krieger, Ruderman & Co., LLC. Based on his commitment to healthy living and a desire to provide an affordable opportunity for all, Dale founded Onsen For All, a wellness center located in the historic village of Kingston, NJ. One of Dale's many passions was restoring historic buildings, such as the Princeton Nurseries Village and the Higgin's House, which houses Onsen For All. Dale was a visionary entrepreneur, an avid runner, boater, and music enthusiast. He was dearly loved by his friends for his charisma, sharp intellect, quick wit and humor. He was a loving and loyal family man, married for thirty-seven years to his wife, Veronica, and had three children, Gavin, Lance, and Casey, all residing in Princeton, NJ. Words cannot express how dearly they will miss him. He is predeceased by a brother, Jay Krieger. A private family service will be held on Wednesday, October 28 at 11am, at the Krieger's home. Friends are welcome to the home to pay their condolences from 2pm to 7pm.

She ran away from her group home in Medford, Ore., and spent weeks sleeping in parks and under bridges. Finally, Nicole Clark, 14 years old, grew so desperate that she accepted a young man's offer of a place to stay. The price would come later. They had sex, and he soon became her boyfriend. Then one day he threatened to kick her out if she did not have sex with several of his friends in exchange for money.

The deciding game of the American League Championship Series and prime-time football squared off Sunday night in New York -- and the Yankees' win over the Los Angeles Angels routed the Giants-Arizona broadcast in local ratings. The Yankees' 5-2 victory, which moved them into the World Series, produced a 26.4 local Nielsen rating (or 1.98 million households in the nation's No. 1 market), nearly tripling the 9.3 (699,000 homes) for the Giants' 24-17 loss. Clearly, more was at stake with a playoff game on Fox than a regular-season game on NBC.

Member of the US Armed Forces, USN, in the Pacific Theater, WWII. Graduate of NYU with BS and MA in Education. He will be missed forever by the many who knew and loved him.

BAXT--Roland. The Board of Directors and Staff of F.E.G.S are saddened by the death of Roland Baxt, who passed away on October 23rd at age 98. As Executive Director of F.E.G.S (1942-1976), Roland leaves a legacy of passion, commitment, service and accomplishment. He will be long remembered. Our heartfelt condolences to his sons Sherwood (Saida), Paul, and Robert (Cindy) and their families. Contributions in Roland's memory may be made to F.E.G.S, 315 Hudson St., New York, NY 10013.

The Obama administration is putting pressure on Pakistan to eliminate Taliban and Qaeda militants from the country's tribal areas, but the push is straining the delicate relations between the allies, Pakistani and Western officials say. The Pakistani military's recent heavy offensive in South Waziristan has pleased the Americans, but it left large parts of Pakistan under siege, as militants once sequestered in the country's tribal areas take their war to Pakistan's cities. Many Pakistanis blame the United States for the country's rising instability.

A year ago, governments around the world scrambled to pull their biggest banks from the brink of collapse. Now, policy makers are wrestling with just how much to rein in the financial behemoths that contributed to the crisis. How large and interconnected banks should be, and whether they should ever be bailed out again by taxpayers, boils down to whether financial institutions should be allowed to become too big to fail. Regulators are already putting down some markers.

Hal Steinbrenner tried to hide behind his sister in the crowded Yankees clubhouse, but it was useless. As a smiling Derek Jeter approached the Steinbrenner family with a bottle of Champagne on Sunday night, he first poured some on Jennifer Steinbrenner Swindal, then dumped some on Hal's head. ''He used to do that to my father all the time,'' Hal said. ''I guess it's my turn.''

Evoking a bygone era when rail travel was the main mode of transportation in baseball, the Philadelphia Phillies rolled into Penn Station on a chartered train about 6:03 p.m. Monday, but they were not looking to the past century for inspiration. The Phillies previously took the train to the World Series in 1950, when they were swept by the Yankees. But that dreary omen did not deter the defending champion Phillies from using the same mode of transportation that Philadelphia's Whiz Kids took 59 years ago.

Fourteen Americans were killed in Afghanistan on Monday in two crashes involving helicopters, making it one of the deadliest days in America's eight-year war here. Neither crash appeared to involve hostile fire, American military officials said. The American casualties occurred amid fresh tensions between Afghan politicians over a runoff presidential election scheduled for Nov. 7.

ANTHONY--Dee. Legendary music manager and impresario Dee Anthony, who guided the careers of artists as diverse as Tony Bennett, Peter Frampton and Peter Allen passed away today, October 25, 2009 in Connecticut. He was 83 years old. During a career that spanned over 50 years, Anthony was a seminal figure in the music industry, whose managerial skills helped pave the way and set new standards for rock music. He first gained major prominence when rock and roll began to take off during the mid-1960's. Anthony led the charge in the United States by introducing to the American audience a host of fledgling young British rock bands, such as Traffic, Jethro Tull, Joe Cocker, Free, Spooky Tooth, Mott the Hoople, Savoy Brown and King Crimson, breaking them into headliner status as well as establishing many of those artists in the pantheon of rock. Anthony started his career as a personal manager in the music industry in the 1950s, working with a young Jerry Vale, a neighborhood friend. In 1954, Anthony met singer Tony Bennett at a Yonkers nightclub and went on to represent Bennett for well over the next decade. In 1968, Anthony, with his brother Bill, founded Bandana Enterprises, a global management company that sheparded the careers of artists such as Joe Cocker, Humble Pie, The J Geils Band, MC5, Ten Years After, and Emerson, Lake, and Palmer. But it would be Anthony's management of musician Peter Frampton that would cement his legendary status in the music industry. Anthony first met Frampton while managing Humble Pie, of which Frampton was a member. When Frampton left the band to pursue a solo career, Anthony continued to manage him, helping to launch one of the most successful solo careers of the 1970s. The double album, "Frampton Comes Alive," would shatter industry records, eventually selling more than 14 million copies worldwide. Anthony would also receive praise from his industry peers, being named "Billboard Manager of the Year" in 1976 and 1977. During the 1980s, Anthony continued to manage music artists including Peter Allen, Basia, and Devo. Anthony retired from the business in the mid-1990s. Dee Anthony, was born Anthony D'Addario and grew up in the Bronx. In 1944, he joined the Navy serving in the submarine force. During his three years of service he was decorated with three medals-- the Victory Medal, the Asiatic Pacific Medal and the American Theater Medal. Anthony then returned to New York City, opened a luncheonette, and followed his passion for show business. Anthony is survived by his wife, Valerie, four daughters, Michele, Marla, Vanessa and Jessica, two brothers, Bill Anthony and Bobby D'Addario, sister Tina Cursio, and six grandchildren, Jack, Charlotte, Olivia, Joey, Dylan, and Chase. Anthony's daughter, Michele has carried on the family business. During her career she became the highest-ranking female record company executive as the President and COO of Sony Music. Currently she is a music industry consultant, whose clients have included Pearl Jam, Bjork, Macy Gray, Sharon and Ozzy Osbourne, and Prince. A visitation will be held on Wednesday, October 28th from 6-9 pm and a memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 29th at 11am both at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Dee Anthony's name to "Wounded Warrior Regiment", C/O Charitable Organizations, 3025 John Quick Road, Quantico, VA 22134.

Don Ivan Punchatz, whose surreal art was splashed on popular horror and science-fiction paperbacks, magazines and the first ''Star Wars'' film poster, influencing a generation of illustrators, died on Thursday near his home in Arlington, Tex. He was 73. He died of cardiac arrest after 11 days in a hospital on life support, said his son, Gregor.

The World Series matchup has already generated several names like the Liberty Series, the New Jersey Turnpike Series and the Amtrak Series. Using the Jersey Turnpike, a trip from Citizens Bank Park to Yankee Stadium is 108 miles -- 1 hour 44 minutes without traffic. The Phillies traveled to New York by Amtrak train on Monday, leaving after a rally in downtown Philadelphia and arriving at Penn Station at about 6:30 p.m.. But as seasoned frugal travelers between Philadelphia and New York know, you would not have to take Amtrak at all to get from stadium to stadium. A fan leaving Citizens Bank Park around 2 p.m. Monday could have gotten to Yankee Stadium for less than $25 in less than four hours. 1. Take the Broad Street subway from Pattison Station to City Hall, and transfer to the Market Frankford Line and exit at 30th Street Station: $2, 28 minutes.

Despite a six-year effort to build trusted computer chips for military systems, the Pentagon now manufactures in secure facilities run by American companies only about 2 percent of the more than $3.5 billion of integrated circuits bought annually for use in military gear. That shortfall is viewed with concern by current and former United States military and intelligence agency executives who argue that the menace of so-called Trojan horses hidden in equipment circuitry is among the most severe threats the nation faces in the event of a war in which communications and weaponry rely on computer technology.

BRENNAN--Flor Paris, died October 20, 2009 at the age of 97. Born in Caracas, Venezuela and educated in Switzerland, Flor began a forty-year career working with Nelson Rockefeller during WWII when he was Assistant Secretary of State for Latin American Affairs and later in New York City at the Rockefeller Family Office. Flor's intelligence, wit, grace and elegance will be missed by her family, friends and the many people whose lives she touched. She was predeceased by her husband, Harold Brennan and her daughter, Jill B. Lee, Ph.D. She is survived by her sisters, Lucrecia Boccardo and Alicia Kitch of Caracas, Venezuela; her son-in-law, Richard Lee; her grandchildren, Mark Lee and his wife, Judy, and Nina Lee; and her great granddaughters, Lucy and Krista Lee.

All progress paves over some bit of knowledge or washes away some valuable practice. Within a few years, e-mail and Twitter moved the art of letter writing to the trash bin. And in an age when all psychic life is being understood in terms of neurotransmitters, the art of introspection has become passé. Galileos of the inner world, such as Soren Kierkegaard (1813-1855), have been packed off to the museum of antiquated ideas. Yet I think that the great and highly quirky Dane could help us to retrieve a distinction that has been effaced.

Some comments on yesterday's post (Nos. 10, 15 and 42, among them) end up arguing that religion must be treated differently from other forms of discourse because it is based on faith and hence not amenable to rational argument. I don't agree. Once religious beliefs are mustered in discussions of public policy, as they are routinely in regard to, for example, reproductive rights or the laws governing marriage, then debate must be conducted rationally: you have to make your case. Even when a believer's actions affect only co-religionists, they are still subject to moral scrutiny. What's more, those comments give short shrift to the intellectually rigorous (and courteous) discussion that can be found among religious thinkers.

In 1956, the photographer William Klein traveled to Rome to work on Federico Fellini's "Nights of Cabiria." Soon after his arrival, the film's production was postponed and Klein, instead of returning home to Paris, decided to stay and photograph the city and its inhabitants. Encouraged by his first book on New York and shooting in his signature frenzied style, Klein walked the streets of Rome finding inspiration in subjects like cafes, crowds and antiquities. Published three years later, "Rome" is a classic man-on-the-street photography book. To celebrate its 50th anniversary, the Aperture Foundation is releasing an updated two-volume edition in November. The first book contains numerous full-bleed double-page spreads of the gritty and frank images for which Klein is known. The second includes his distinctive photo captions, which highlighted his Roman experience. La dolce vita, indeed.

Is Broadway ready for a portrayal of Helen Keller by an actress who has been described -- in The New York Times, for starters -- as "a dumpling of a child" with "a seemingly endless reserve of optimism"? We'll find out in a few months: Abigail Breslin, the Academy Award-nominated star of "Little Miss Sunshine" (and, lately, "Zombieland") is set to play Helen Keller in a new production of "The Miracle Worker" that will also star Alison Pill ("Milk," "Blackbird," "In Treatment") as Annie Sullivan. Publicists for the revival, which was announced Tuesday, said that it would be directed by Kate Whoriskey, who recently directed Lynn Nottage's "Ruined" for Manhattan Theater Club. It is to be staged in the round at Circle in the Square Theater, with previews to begin on Feb. 12 and an official opening set for March 3. It is the first time "The Miracle Worker" has been revived on Broadway since the original 1959 production that starred Patty Duke and Anne Bancroft.

Whenever fashion trots out harem pants (as it did last summer), allusions to the Ballets Russes are never far behind. Somewhere, in the not-so deep recesses of the fashion corps' collective unconscious are Leon Bakst's indelible images of the Orient, of the costume he sketched for Nijinsky in a brilliant apricot and blue, the dancer poised to do a plié in a pair of sequined, see-through harem pants. Almost a hundred years after they were first shown, Bakst's costumes and sets continue to titillate, according to John Bowlt in "The Ballets Russes and the Art of Design," a new coffee table book from Monacelli Press. They certainly still evoke the voluptuousness of the East, perhaps because it was Bakst who invented the East - or at least our image of it - having put an ethnocentric gloss on the Orient as promiscuous as any fashion designer's.

Just in time for an era when wardrobe-challenge performers like Katy Perry and Lady Gaga can be considered feminists, the Lilith Fair -- that vintage-1990s concert series that emphasized female artists -- is planning a comeback. Terry McBride, the chief executive of the Nettwerk Music Group, who, with Sarah McLachlan, was among the founders of the tour, said in a news release that the Lilith Fair would be revived next year, with stops planned in at least 18 cities. Previous incarnations of the Lilith Fair featured artists from Sheryl Crow to Erykah Badu to the Dixie Chicks to Tegan and Sara; a lineup for the new tour was not announced, but a newly launched Web site, lilithfair.com, listed the cities where shows would take place, including New York, Los Angeles, Washington, Montreal, Vancouver and London.

Founded in 1953 by the architect Ben Thompson, Design Research -- or D/R, after its striking logo -- became known as America's first "lifestyle store," introducing to the United States market now-prominent modern European design brands like Iittala, Artek and Marimekko. Fans included Julia Child, who frequently stopped by the striking concrete and glass flagship store that Thompson designed in Cambridge, Mass.; Ray Eames, who shopped at the Beverly Hills, Calif., location; and Jackie Kennedy, who purchased her first Marimekko dress (she's said to have owned at least eight) at D/R's Hyannis, Mass. store. The company closed in the late 1970s but has had widespread influence on 20th-century retail design, counting among its disciples Crate and Barrel's founder, Gordon Segal; the designer and retailer Jonathan Adler; and Moss's co-owner Franklin Getchell.

New York City Ballet said on Tuesday that five of its dancers had been promoted to the rank of principal dancer and that a sixth member of the corps had been promoted to soloist. The new principal dancers are scheduled to make their debut performances in their new roles at an opening-night benefit on Nov. 24 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center in a new work by Peter Martins, the company's Ballet Master in Chief, set to John Adams's "Naïve and Sentimental Music."

Days after an unidentified ailment caused Morrissey to collapse on stage and cancel two concerts, he resumed his tour on Tuesday night in an occasionally self-mocking show at the Royal Albert Hall in London, BBC News reported. "Fasten your seat belts," Morrissey said on Tuesday as he took the stage. "It's going to be a bumpy night." A performance on Saturday at the Oasis Leisure Center in Swindon, west of London, had been rougher for Morrissey, the 50-year-old former front man of the Smiths: During that show, he fell to his knees after finishing his first song. Two band members pulled him offstage, and he was taken to Great Western Hospital. He canceled a second show scheduled for Monday at the O2 Academy in Bournemouth, citing "medical advice." At his Tuesday concert in London, Morrissey pretended to faint again, the BBC reported, then stood up and jokingly declared: "Thank you, Swindon!" Though he did not explain what had caused his earlier collapse, Morrissey told the crowd: "The doctor said I shouldn't smile. I told him, 'I don't.' "

If you read my post last week about the new issue of Arena Homme Plus, you already know that I'm obsessed with the 1980s stylist Ray Petri. After writing about him (again), I began scouring YouTube for some of my favorite videos from that time, and came across the band Bros. The Bros boys, who were lily white and looked about as tough as a group of German hairdressers on the way to a tea dance, certainly weren't directly involved with Petri, whose work focused on street-smart guys of mixed race. Still, their look of oversize blazers, bomber jackets and rolled up jeans - as well as the block lettering that appears midway through their video - shows just how widespread Petri's aesthetic had become by 1988. In their biggest hit, Bros keep asking when they will be famous. Ultimately, they got their 15 minutes; I thought I might as well extend it by 15 more seconds.

Thursday, Oct. 28, 1909(use this link to access today's entire issue)

A distant relative of the 30th president, Calvin Coolidge lives in the upstate town of Jay, N.Y., next door to the home where he spent his childhood. He is 49 and, with his wife, raises alpacas on ancestral farmland. The Coolidge family has been in Jay since the early 1800s, so his distinctive name does not seem to faze neighbors. The only time Mr. Coolidge recalls encountering any doubt about his identity was when he was trying to make a collect call. This composition, with an alpaca named Tracey Lynn, recalls a 1931 photograph of President Coolidge, after he left office, on his farm in Vermont. (The names of the photographer, and of the horse, are unknown.)
FRONT PAGE.

An obituary on Oct. 20 about Howard Unruh, who killed 13 of his neighbors in Camden, N.J., in 1949, misstated the given name of the spokesman for the prosecutor’s office in Camden County, who said Mr. Unruh had been in state custody since his arrest. He is Jason Laughlin, not James.

An obituary on Oct. 12 about Raymond A. Brown, a civil rights lawyer with many controversial clients, referred incompletely to the outcome of legal action against The New York Times and one of its reporters, M. A. Farber, that was initiated after Mr. Farber refused to yield investigative notes during the murder trial of a client of Mr. Brown’s. While The Times indeed paid fines of $285,000 at one point, it was refunded $100,000 of that money after the newspaper and Mr. Farber were pardoned in 1982 by the governor of New Jersey; the paper did not ultimately pay $285,000 in fines.

An obituary and a headline on Sept. 9 about Sylvia Schur, a food editor and pioneering food consultant, referred incorrectly to Mrs. Schur’s work on the diet drink Metrecal. Although Mrs. Schur’s company did some consulting work on Metrecal, the product was developed by C. Joseph Genster at Mead Johnson & Company, a maker of nutritional products; it was not developed by Mrs. Schur. Mr. Genster pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Friday.

An article on Oct. 15 about converting assets from a traditional Individual Retirement Account to a Roth I.R.A. for a second time referred incorrectly to the waiting period. Once a conversion of assets has been undone, the same assets cannot be converted again until the year following the original conversion or more than 30 days after the conversion was undone, whichever is longer. The 30-plus-day period does not apply to the date of the original conversion.

An art review on Friday about “From Klimt to Klee: Masterworks From the Serge Sabarsky Collection,” at the Neue Galerie, misidentified the curator of the exhibition. It was organized by Renée Price, director of the Neue Galerie — not Janis Staggs, an associate curator at the museum.
A music review on Monday about the Tokyo String Quartet and the pianist Inon Barnatan, at the 92nd Street Y, misstated the date of the performance. It was Saturday, not Friday.

The Books of The Times review last Wednesday, about “When Everything Changed: The Amazing Journey of American Women From 1960 to the Present,” by Gail Collins, referred imprecisely to the exclusion of women from the National Press Club in Washington. While they were not allowed to become members until 1971, female reporters were allowed to enter the club’s quarters starting in 1955. It was not “off limits” to women until 1971.

Stephen Rubin, the former publisher of the Doubleday Publishing Group, who worked closely with Dan Brown, John Grisham, Pat Conroy, Bill Moyers and other authors, is taking over as president and publisher of Henry Holt & Company. A month ago Mr. Rubin, 67, resigned as publisher at large at Random House, the world’s biggest publisher of trade books. He had held that position for just seven months after stepping down at Doubleday, which was dismantled in a restructuring of Random House last December. Holt, a division of Macmillan, was at one time a storied publisher of authors including Philip Roth and Sue Grafton, but it has struggled lately to produce hits. Since February 2008, when its previous president and publisher, John Sterling, stepped down, Holt has been led by Dan Farley, who will continue in the role of publisher of the Macmillan Children’s Publishing Group.

Combine the wish list of any Broadway producer with the hit list of any TMZ.com cameraman and you have the lineup for this year’s production of “The 24 Hour Plays on Broadway.” Among the many performers scheduled to take part are Ashton Kutcher, above left (making his Broadway debut), Jennifer Aniston, above right, and Demi Moore, as well as Liev Schreiber, Anthony Mackie, Billy Crudup, Sam Rockwell, Julia Stiles, Rachel Dratch and the downtown power couple David Cross and Amber Tamblyn. This year’s playwrights include David Lindsay-Abaire, Nathan Jackson and Theresa Rebeck, and the musical guests include the Swedish rock band A Camp. The annual production, to take place on Nov. 9 at the American Airlines Theater, calls for creative types to write, direct and perform six original short plays in just under a day. “Fearless the cobweb swings from the ceiling,” Emily Dickinson wrote in one of her poems. But not in the front parlor of the Homestead, her house in Amherst, Mass., which is now part of the Emily Dickinson Museum. Part of the ceiling there collapsed on Sunday afternoon while the house was open for tours. No one was in the parlor at the time, and no one in the house was hurt, though some of the Dickinson family furniture and belongings on display there, including a sofa and a teapot, may have been harmed. The mess has still not been cleaned up, Jane H. Ward, the executive director of the museum, said on Tuesday, because the museum is waiting for a complete inspection to determine what went wrong. The ceiling that fell is not original to the house, Ms. Ward explained — the plaster was laid over wire mesh, not lath — and was probably installed in the 1960s, when the house was privately owned. For once, an overflowing tub was not to blame. “It appears that the plaster just detached itself from the wall,” Ms. Ward said, “but we won’t really know the extent of the damage until the inspection is completed.” For now the museum is closed at least through Friday, and Ms. Ward said she hoped in the next couple of days to determine when it can reopen and what to do about repairs.

Eric Clapton said he was withdrawing from a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame concert at Madison Square Garden this week because he had gallstones. In a news release, a publicist for Mr. Clapton said he would undergo a minor medical procedure for gallstones and spend time recuperating at home in Britain but still planned to fulfill his touring schedule for next year. Mr. Clapton was to perform at the Garden on Friday, the second show in a two-night celebration honoring the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame’s 25th anniversary. Other artists who are to perform include Crosby, Stills and Nash; Stevie Wonder; and Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band (on Thursday); and Aretha Franklin, above, Metallica and U2 (on Friday). HBO will show an edited version of the concerts on Nov. 29.

''AMERICANS are not exposed to cabbage,'' said Andre Heimann, the owner of Andre's Cafe on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, and of Andre's Hungarian Strudels & Pastries in Forest Hills, Queens. ''They know coleslaw.'' But in Hungary, ''cabbage is used for soup, for entrees, for stuffed cabbage,'' said Mr. Heimann, who is 60. And it's used for cabbage strudel, a richly flavored dish of flaky phyllo wrapped around tender cabbage that has first been baked until it becomes both sweet and savory.

Cloudy skies and a wayward cargo ship at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida disrupted the launching of a prototype of a rocket intended to replace the space shuttles. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will try again Wednesday morning when forecasts put the chances of favorable weather at 60 percent. The launching of the rocket, the Ares I-X, had been scheduled for 8 a.m. Eastern time, but clouds above the launching pad thwarted that timetable. When a break in the clouds appeared, NASA decided to launch the rocket at 9:44 a.m., but a cargo ship in the Atlantic sailed too close to the launching area. The countdown resumed as the ship moved away, but the clouds returned and did not clear again before noon.

A Paris court on Tuesday handed a prison sentence to a former interior minister, Charles Pasqua, and a heavy fine to the son of former President François Mitterrand for their involvement in illegal arms trafficking to Angola in the 1990s. Mr. Pasqua, who was interior minister from 1986 to 1988, was sentenced to three years in prison, two of them suspended, and fined about $150,000, for taking commissions on sales to the Angolan Army in violation of a United Nations arms embargo. Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, once his father's adviser on Africa affairs, was convicted of taking more than $2 million in payments and fined $562,000 and given a two-year suspended jail sentence. The masterminds of the sales, a French arms dealer, Pierre Falcone, and a Russian-Israeli billionaire, Arcadi Gaydamak, were each sentenced to six years in prison, although Mr. Gaydamak is at large.
VICTOR--Reese. Legendary garment center salesman who was brash, creative, lovable and thought he could talk his way out of anything except his health. Remembered by the Gumowitz Family

The last five 49ers drafts have produced more unemployed coaches than first-round success stories, but three of the team's most exasperating picks in recent years -- Alex Smith, Vernon Davis and Michael Crabtree -- nearly led San Francisco to a come-from-behind win at Houston last Sunday. Smith, the No. 1 overall choice in 2005, replaced quarterback Shaun Hill at halftime and threw three touchdown passes to Davis, the sixth overall pick in 2006. The resurgence of Davis, a tight end whose production has never matched his physical tools, has been the biggest surprise of the 49ers' 3-3 start. But the debut of Crabtree, the 10th pick in this year's draft, was a more welcome development for San Francisco.

DAVIS--James. After a brief illness on October 26, 2009. After graduating from Drew University in 1950 and earning a Master of Library Science at Columbia University, Jim had a long and productive career as a catalogue librarian at Yale University and at Jersey City State College. He loved books and he will be missed.

The European Commission will urge the 27 European Union countries on Wednesday to reserve a uniform slice of broadcast spectrum for a pan-European mobile broadband network, one that could enable flat-rate, international voice and data calling plans. A copy of the nonbinding proposal, reviewed by The International Herald Tribune, sets technical guidelines for member countries that choose to redeploy part of their low-frequency spectrum, a bandwidth that has been used exclusively by television broadcasters since the inception of the industry more than 50 years ago.

The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, got to have his say Monday on a government-run insurance plan. But now that Mr. Reid has announced he will include a public plan in the health care legislation, he must persuade his entire caucus -- 58 Democrats and two independents -- to unite behind it. The chatter in the hallways of the Capitol on Tuesday indicated that Mr. Reid still has work ahead of him. Some senators are mostly with him but want changes to the legislation. Others are mostly against him.

In a reversal of his longstanding position, Senator Arlen Specter, the Republican-turned-Democrat from Pennsylvania, called for repealing the Defense of Marriage Act, which bans federal recognition of same-sex marriages. Mr. Specter, who became a Democrat in April in acknowledgment that his moderate views severely jeopardized his chances to survive a Republican primary in 2010, now faces a primary challenge on the left, from Representative Joe Sestak, a Democrat, who has long championed gay rights issues.

COHN--Peter J.,engineer and philanthropist, died peacefully on October 25. He is survived by his wife Bernice, his sons David and Claude, David's wife Carmela, his beloved grandchildren, Silvia, Sabrina, and Max, as well as by his brother Michael and his wife Sue. He was born in Leipzig, Germany on September 27, 1921 and emigrated to the United States with his family shortly after the Nazi take-over. During the Second World War he served in the China-India-Burma theatre. After the war he finished his studies at the University of Colorado. On retirement he became active in many philanthropic causes both here and abroad. Services private.

Newspapers have tried many things to stave off a seemingly relentless decline in readers. Now France is pushing forward with a novel approach: giving away papers to young readers in an effort to turn them into regular customers. The government on Tuesday detailed plans of a project called ''My Free Newspaper,'' under which 18- to 24-year-olds will be offered a free, yearlong subscription to a newspaper of their choice.

A string of 12 row houses built between 1909 and 1918 along Ocean Avenue, across from Prospect Park in Flatbush, Brooklyn, became a historic district on Tuesday by a unanimous vote of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The 8-to-0 vote to create the Ocean on the Park Historic District gives landmark protection to the houses, which sit on land that was owned in the mid-17th century by Jan Aertsen van der Bilt, a progenitor of the Vanderbilts. One of the houses, at 193 Ocean Avenue, was owned and occupied for 11 years by Charles H. Ebbets, who owned what became the Brooklyn Dodgers and developed Ebbets Field, which was demolished in 1960 after the team moved to Los Angeles.

Cordner Nelson, who drew on his youthful fascination with Olympic athletes to create, with his brother, Track & Field News in 1948 and help turn it into the sport's premier monthly magazine, died Monday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 91. The cause was T-cell lymphoma, his daughter Rebecca said.

When the Yankees went to Philadelphia on Sept. 1, 1997, they had not played the Phillies there in 47 years. More than 50,000 fans poured into Veterans Stadium, the Phillies' largest crowd in two years. A last-place Phillies team swept the playoff-bound Yankees in the three-game series. It was just interleague play, of course, hardly revenge for the previous sweep by the Yankees in the 1950 World Series, over the Whiz Kids of Richie Ashburn and Robin Roberts. The teams have shadow-danced for years since then, never reuniting in the World Series until now.

Running backs Cedric Benson and Ricky Williams have a few things in common. They starred at the University of Texas. They were top-five picks in the draft (Benson fourth in 2005, Williams fifth in 1999). And they were considered busts by the teams that drafted them (Benson by Chicago, Williams by New Orleans). On Sunday, they had the chance to exact some revenge, and they delivered.

Many seaside towns make much of their location. Their shops are gussied up with nautical décor -- rigging, buoys, mounted fish -- and their restaurants often have the word "captain" in the name. The Brooklyn enclave of Sheepshead Bay avoids this waterfront kitsch. Yes, there are boats and bait shops and plenty of fishing, but there are also historical monuments and retro restaurants, all played out against the backdrop of the neighborhood's sometimes grimy, sometimes gorgeous bay.

The Olympic flame had not yet left Greece for Canada when the first doping dust-up of the Vancouver Games happened. That's because Greek Olympic officials included Fani Halkia, a banned hurdler, in the torch relay in Athens on Wednesday, drawing a rebuke from the International Olympic Committee.

A decade ago, high-end travelers to Milan had essentially two hotel options: the internationally modern Four Seasons, smack in the middle of shopping's Golden Triangle, or the somewhat stuffy and very Milanese Principe di Savoia, a 1920s landmark in a less central but nonetheless upscale residential square. (In the late '90s, when I worked in Milan, my visiting colleagues stayed at the Principe, and we held meetings in an editor's immense bathroom, while two Bumble and Bumble stylists coiffed her. It was that sort of place.) Then, starting in 2003, the Park Hyatt, the Bulgari and a slew of boutique operations gave the city a much-needed dose of competition.

The new report on the gross domestic product deserves to be taken with a grain of salt, if only because the first guess is often substantially wrong. It's not easy to predict literary success. Million-dollar advances don't always pan out, great books sometimes fail to catch on, and promising writers become sidetracked by mortgages and teaching careers - the publishing equivalent of a top-drafted athlete who doesn't produce. Dumb luck often seems more essential than smart talent. So it's worth noting the track record of the Whiting Writers' Awards, which for 25 years have singled out authors early in their career and said: Hey! Pay attention to this crowd.

Faces doubled. Faces given. Faces taken away. The result, in every case, is an illuminating new view of a subject. Tyler Hicks of The Times, who has three pictures today, showed personal effects confiscated from the Taliban (Slide 3). It's a surprisingly intimate view of what seems at time like a faceless enemy. By contrast, Suzanne Plunkett of Reuters cropped two important faces - Queen Elizabeth II and President Pratibha Patil of India - out of her photograph (Slide 7). Nevertheless, there is no mistaking who's in the picture.

Updated, 6:13 p.m. | The Empire State Building will remain lit -- in orange, black and white -- all night for Halloween, one of two nights of the year it remains so. (The other is St. Patrick's Day, which is the anniversary of the groundbreaking of the building.) Usually the building's lights turn off at 2 a.m., but on Halloween they will stay on until daybreak on Nov. 1.

The story behind the demise of Washington Mutual, the nation's largest bank failure, seems to have faded amid the chaos last fall as the financial crisis accelerated. But The Puget Sound Business Journal dug deep into the bank's collapse and published a report on Thursday that showed panic and confusion among its bankers as they futilely tried to save the bank before it failed in late September of last year.

Shortly after I ran a post on Motherlode about how to talk to your children about the drinking and drugging of your youth, Mike Adamick, whose Web site is Cry It Out: Memoirs of a Stay-at-Home Dad, sent me this week's guest essay. His drinking, he writes, is not all that far in the past, and while he swore off alcohol for the sake of his family, he is learning that it might not be possible to completely hide our demons from our children.

After Cliff Lee pulled off a convincing Sandy Koufax impression in Game 1 of the World Series, the heavily favored Yankees now find themselves in a 1-0 hole. Although the only true "must-win" games are elimination contests, dropping the first two at home would leave New York facing a daunting deficit. To avoid this fate, they will have to outduel a familiar foe: Pedro Martinez, who is yet to live down calling the Yankees his daddy during his time with the Red Sox.

Following is the second set of answers from Sam Roberts. His most recent book, "Only in New York: An Exploration of the World's Most Fascinating, Frustrating and Irrepressible City" (St. Martin's Press, 2009), collects 70 self-contained essays that take a stand on what makes New York unique -- offering insights that will surprise New Yorkers and out-of-towners alike.

Sony said "This Is It," the Michael Jackson concert documentary culled from rehearsal footage, opened on Wednesday to $7.4 million in ticket sales in North America and $12.7 internationally (including revenue from limited Tuesday night screenings). A $20.1 million weekday total is certainly impressive -- the studio noted that the North American gross was the highest for a Wednesday in October -- but it isn't the immediate smash many predicted. The film, which opens in 10 additional countries Thursday, will rely on strong word of mouth to drive big results for the weekend. Encouraging the studio are surprisingly upbeat reviews (about 83 percent of top critics gave it positive marks, according to RottenTomatoes.com) and an "A" grade from CinemaScore, the company that surveys moviegoer reactions to films.

Overview | Why have women been underrepresented in literature and film? Are there "boy stories" and "girl stories," or are there simply "human stories"? What are we missing by not hearing women's stories? In this lesson, students consider the representation of women in the curriculum and discuss their experiences reading books by and about women. Then, they examine images of women from all over the globe, bring them to life by crafting stories that reveal their humanity, and reflect on why women's stories are worthy of examination.

The New York City Council approved the Museum of Modern Art's request to build an 82-story tower on Wednesday. The tower, designed by French architect Jean Nouvel, would rise 1,025 feet, down from 1,250 feet, which was the height first proposed. The City Planning Commission stipulated the change last month.

A trustee for the fund established for two child actors from "Slumdog Millionaire" said they were in danger of losing their stipends as well as the fund itself if they did not start attending school more often, The Associated Press reported. After the release of "Slumdog Millionaire," its director, Danny Boyle, and a producer, Christian Colson, helped establish trusts and find new homes for Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 11, and Rubina Ali Qureshi, 10, who played the young incarnations of two of the film's lead characters. But Noshir Dadrawala, who helps administer the fund, said Azharuddin was showing up at school 37 percent of the time, and Rubina had a 27 percent attendance rate. The trust decided that the children must raise their attendance above 70 percent or forfeit their monthly stipends of about $120.

The Wall Street Journal will close its Boston bureau, laying off nine reporters, Journal editors told their staff on Thursday. It was The Journal's reporters in Boston who won the prestigious Pulitzer Prize for public service in 2007, for revealing the practice of back-dating stock options for corporate executives.

Though the Cuban government did not exactly get along with John F. Kennedy, it has come to an arrangement with the Boston library named for the 35th president to give it copies of thousands of papers from Ernest Hemingway. The Boston Globe reported that Cuba's Ministry of Culture had given the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum copies of 3,000 letters and documents Hemingway amassed during his years in Cuba, from 1939 to 1960. Among the documents are corrected proofs of "The Old Man and the Sea'' and an alternate ending to "For Whom the Bell Tolls" (The Globe report did not say what that ending was), as well as correspondence with Robert Capa, Marlene Dietrich, Sinclair Lewis, Lillian Ross, Ingrid Bergman and various members of his family. The library is already home to the Hemingway Archive and the Hemingway Room, which was dedicated in 1980, and includes relics like a lion-skin throw rug, journals of his fishing trips and shrapnel from wounds he suffered during World War I.

Cyrus R. Vance Jr. is more than two months away from officially becoming Manhattan's new district attorney, but his initiation into the fraternity of the city's top prosecutors began Wednesday in the basement of a TriBeCa restaurant over a Cobb salad and club soda.

Just when a "South Park" cover of Lady Gaga's "Pokerface" seemed like the most unusual pairing she could be part of, the singer herself has upped the ante. Lady Gaga, the pop star known as much for her baroque wardrobe as for her music, will be performing with dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet in a new work that will be presented at gala for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles. In a news release, the museum said that it had commissioned Francesco Vezzoli, the Italian performance artist, to create a production called "Ballets Russes Italian Style (The Shortest Musical You Will Never See Again)" that will feature the unlikely matchup. The work, which will be performed at MOCA Grand Avenue on Nov. 14, is also to feature the debut of a song by Lady Gaga called "Speechless."

Evgeni Malkin will miss two to three weeks with a shoulder strain, Penguins coach Dan Bylsma says. "He strained his shoulder about 10 days or so ago," Bylsma tells the team web site. "We are worried about the safety of the shoulder. A couple weeks of rest and rehab will get that thing healthy so he can get back onto the ice." The injury ends a string of 254 consecutive regular-season games played by Malkin, the current holder of the Art Ross and Conn Smythe Trophies. In 12 games this season for the 10-2 Pens he is 4+10=14, tied with Sidney Crosby for the team lead, although his plus-1 mark is one of the lowest on the roster.

President Obama traveled early Thursday morning to Dover Air Force Base, where he met with family members and paid his respects as the bodies of 18 Americans killed this week in Afghanistan were returned to the United States.

Anyone in need of a good excuse to visit Vienna this week or next should get ahold of the program for the 2009 edition of the Viennale, the Austrian capital's film festival, which started last week and continues until Nov. 4. This year's festival features an eclectic mix of films - everything from the American director Greg Mottola's "Adventureland" to the Iranian artist Shirin Neshat's "Zanan Bedoone Mardan" ("Women Without Men") - and includes three tributes, to the British actress Tilda Swinton, the Filipino director Lino Brocka and the American actor Timothy Carey.

The Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation announced the recipients of the 2009 Whiting Writers' Awards at a ceremony on Wednesday night. The awards, each of which comes with a cash prize of $50,000, are given annually to poets, fiction and nonfiction writers, and playwrights "of exceptional talent and promise in early career." The fiction recipients were Adam Johnson, Nami Mun, Salvatore Scibona and Vu Tran. Recipients of the nonfiction prize were Michael Meyer and Hugh Raffles. Poetry prizes were bestowed on Jericho Brown, Jay Hopler and Joan Kane. Rajiv Joseph received the sole award for playwriting. The foundation, which supports the humanities and writing, was established in 1963 by Flora E. Whiting, and its writing prize was first awarded in 1985.

The modern Olympic movement borrows heavily from the traditions of ancient Greece. So when organizers went to light the Olympic flame for the Vancouver Games last week in Olympia, Greece, they called on an actress dressed in a traditional white robe and sandals, who used a mirror to harness the sun's rays.

Hello again, Newman: Wayne Knight will be among the comic actors and Broadway performers who will star in the coming New York City Center Encores! revival of "Girl Crazy," a publicist for the Encores! series said on Thursday. Mr. Knight, the "Seinfeld" and "Sweet Charity" star, will play Gieber Goldfarb, joined by Ana Gasteyer (currently of "The Royal Family") as Frisco Kate Fothergill, Marc Kudisch ("9 to 5") as Slick Fothergill, and the real-life husband and wife Chris Diamantopoulos and Becki Newton as the musical's love interests, Danny Churchill and Molly Gray. The cast also includes Jeremy Beck, Mylinda Hull, Richard Poe, Daniel Stewart Sherman and Gregory Wooddell. The musical, which features music and lyrics by George and Ira Gershwin and a book by Guy Bolton and Jack McGowan, is to run at City Center from Nov. 19 through 22. It is directed by Jerry Zaks and choreographed by Warren Carlyle.

An obituary on Monday and in some copies on Sunday about Lou Jacobi, a theater and film actor, misstated the year in which he appeared in a Connecticut production of the Clifford Odets play “Rocket to the Moon.” It was 1983, not 1988.

One of the editors is Ian Markiewicz, not Markiewitz, and the composer is Paul Grimstad, not Grinstat.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about “Painting Below Zero: Notes on a Life in Art,” by James Rosenquist with David Dalton, misspelled the surname of an artist the art world was ready to move beyond when Mr. Rosenquist began painting seriously. He was Jackson Pollock, not Pollack.
Tom McGeveran told the staff of The New York Observer on Wednesday that he wants to pursue “a new venture” after he leaves at the end of the year.

In the very first World Series game played, on Oct. 1, 1903, Deacon Phillippe of the Pittsburgh Pirates had 10 strikeouts, no walks and won the game. That never happened again in the World Series until Cliff Lee did it for the Phillies on Wednesday night in a 6-1 victory over the Yankees.

An article on Oct. 20 about the Galleon Group, the hedge fund at the center of an insider trading case, erroneously included a state pension system among its investors. The Virginia Retirement System is not an investor, having withdrawn its Galleon Group investment last year.

My Thursday column argues that we shouldn't send more troops to Afghanistan, but that dispatching 40,000 schools might make sense. It looks as if President Obama is going to try to muddle along, sending more troops but not the full 40,000 -- while we continue to underinvest in education in Afghanistan and Pakistan -- and that does not strike me as worthy of a Nobel Peace Prize winner.
The law extends federal hate crimes to include those perpetrated against people because of sexual orientation, gender identity or disability.
Five people have been taken into police custody in connection with an attack on a 15-year-old girl outside her high school homecoming dance.
The Phillies take a 1-0 lead in the World Series with a 6-1 victory over the Yankees.
The businessman at the center of a federal investigation of corruption in Alaska politics has been sentenced to three years in prison.

The Big City column on Tuesday, about Terri White, an actress who is back on Broadway in “Finian’s Rainbow” a year after an eviction left her homeless, overstated her professional achievements, based on information provided by Ms. White. Although she was featured in the Tony-nominated “Barnum” in 1980, she did not herself earn a nomination.
A special prosecutor has been appointed to investigate accusations that the Larimer County sheriff violated privacy laws in the case of the runaway balloon that was believed to be carrying a boy.
A judge dismissed murder charges against two men awaiting retrial in the 1991 killings of four teenagers at an Austin yogurt shop.

A news analysis article in some editions on Wednesday about the debating styles of New York’s top two candidates for mayor referred incorrectly to the performance of the city’s schoolchildren on federal tests during the tenure of the incumbent, Michael R. Bloomberg. Reading scores for fourth and eighth graders, and math scores for eighth graders, either declined or were flat, but math scores for fourth graders rose in 2005 and 2007; the grades were not flat in all years.

The line of Yankees fans was more than 25 people deep, snaking around itself into the concourse on Yankee Stadium's 300 level. One by one, they stepped up to the stand, made a big decision about onions, and forked over $10.75 for a steaming, dripping cheese steak - a Carl's Philly Cheesesteak.

An article on Oct. 23 about tensions between the Obama administration and the Fox News Channel misstated the day on which Fox News’s competitors refused an attempt by the administration to exclude Fox from a round of official interviews that was to be recorded by a pool camera crew shared by all the major news networks. It was last Thursday, Oct. 22 — not Tuesday, Oct. 20.
FRONT PAGE.

An article on Saturday about China’s reported executions of four people convicted for their roles in the anti-Chinese riots that convulsed Tibet last year misstated when the Dalai Lama, Tibet’s spiritual leader-in-exile, fled his homeland for India. It was five decades ago, in 1959, not three decades ago.

An article on Monday about the dubious rules issued by local bureaucrats in China, so common that ridiculing them is a pastime of China’s web users, included several errors. A school in southern China where students are required to salute every passing car as they walk to and from school, in order to instill courtesy and reduce traffic accidents, is Luolang Elementary — not Luolong or Loulong.

An article on Oct. 21 about the dwindling number of reporters who cover executions in Texas because of cutbacks at news organizations misstated the coverage given to executions this year by The Fort Worth Star-Telegram. The newspaper has covered all five executions involving cases from Tarrant County, which includes Fort Worth, publishing a staff-written article in one case and articles from The Associated Press in the other four. It did not miss covering two executions altogether.
There is a way to deliver all the cash Heineken would need to bid for Femsa of Mexico while keeping the Heineken family in control.

Amazon.com is trying to take some pain out of the process of buying stuff online. I'm not sure that the new service it is introducing tonight, PayPhrase, accomplishes that, but it may be an important building block for the future of Amazon's fledgling subsidiary, Amazon Payments.
The Phillies’ Cliff Lee was dominant, striking out 10 in a complete game performance, as the Phillies took a 1-0 lead over the Yankees in the World Series.

As President Obama contemplates America’s own future in Afghanistan, he would be well advised to learn from the Soviet experience.
A compelling argument against more troops in Afghanistan rests on this trade-off: For the cost of an additional soldier stationed in Afghanistan for a year, nearly 20 schools could be built.
