Days after an unidentified ailment caused Morrissey to collapse onstage in Swindon, England, and cancel two concerts, he resumed his tour on Tuesday in an occasionally self-mocking show at the Royal Albert Hall in London, BBC News reported. “Fasten your seat belts,” he said as he took the stage. “It’s going to be a bumpy night.” During the show Morrissey, 50, the former frontman of the Smiths, pretended to faint, the BBC reported, then stood up and jokingly declared, “Thank you, Swindon!”.
Even in repeats, CBS’s crime drama “NCIS” remained unbeatable, delivering Tuesday’s largest audience.

Vampires and indie-pop fans, rejoice: The soundtrack to “The Twilight Saga: New Moon” (Chop Shop/Atlantic), which features Grizzly Bear and Thom Yorke, didn’t quite nab No. 1 on last week’s Billboard album chart, but has reached that summit in its second week out, with 153,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Tim McGraw’s new “Southern Voice” (Curb) opened at No. 2 with 137,000, and Michael Bublé’s “Crazy Love” (143/Reprise), the chart-topper for the last two weeks, fell to No. 3 with 102,000 sales, a one-week drop of 50 percent. Jay-Z’s “Blueprint 3” (Roc Nation/Atlantic) fell one spot to No. 4, with 43,000, and Miley Cyrus’s “Time of Our Lives” (Hollywood) held at No. 5, with 39,000. Perhaps most notable this week was the rise of Owl City, the one-man project of Adam Young, a 23-year-old from Minnesota whose song “Fireflies” has been a sleeper hit on the radio. Owl City’s album, “Ocean Eyes” (Universal Republic), rose 12 spots to No. 8, with 28,000 sales, possibly helped by the inclusion of one of its songs on the soundtrack to the CW show “90210.”.

Is Broadway ready for a portrayal of Helen Keller by an actress whose breakthrough role has been described — in The New York Times, for starters — as “a dumpling of a child” with “a seemingly endless reserve of optimism”? We’ll find out in a few months: Abigail Breslin, right, the Academy Award-nominated star of “Little Miss Sunshine,” is to play Keller in a new production of “The Miracle Worker” that will also star Alison Pill (“Milk,” “Blackbird,” “In Treatment”) as Annie Sullivan. Publicists for the revival, which was announced on Tuesday, said it would be directed by Kate Whoriskey, who recently directed Lynn Nottage’s “Ruined” for Manhattan Theater Club. “The Miracle Worker” is to be staged in the round at Circle in the Square Theater, with previews to begin on Feb. 12 and an opening set for March 3. It is the first time the play has been revived on Broadway since the original 1959 production.
The Parents Television Council reported on Wednesday that the portrayal of violence against women and teenage girls on prime-time broadcast television shows had increased.

Matt Cavenaugh’s time at the Broadway revival of “West Side Story” is coming to an end, though in a less tragic manner than that of the character he plays. Mr. Cavenaugh, who portrays Tony, said Tuesday that he would depart the musical when his contract ends. His final performance will be on Dec. 13. In a telephone interview he said that although “West Side Story” and the character of Tony had inspired him to get into musical theater, “it’s also very demanding.” Mr. Cavenaugh, right, said that while the experience had been fulfilling, “I just feel that it’s time for me to move onto what’s next.” Among the projects he’s pursuing: a role in the pilot episode of a musical comedy, and a concert series he is writing with his wife, Jenny Powers (of Broadway’s “Grease”), that would feature Leonard Bernstein’s music. A representative for “West Side Story” said a replacement had not been named.

New York City Ballet said on Tuesday that five dancers had been promoted to principal dancer and that a member of the corps had been promoted to soloist. The soloists Tyler Angle, Robert Fairchild, Tiler Peck, Amar Ramasar and Teresa Reichlen were named principal dancers, and Kathryn Morgan, right, a corps member since 2007, was made a soloist. The new principal dancers will make their debut performances in their new roles at an opening-night benefit on Nov. 24 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

The Lilith Fair — that vintage-1990s concert series that emphasized female artists — is planning a comeback. Terry McBride, chief executive of the Nettwerk Music Group, who, with Sarah McLachlan, was among the founders of the tour, said in a news release that the Lilith Fair would be revived next year, with stops planned in at least 18 cities. Previous incarnations featured artists like Sheryl Crow, Erykah Badu, the Dixie Chicks and Tegan and Sara. A lineup for the new tour was not announced, but the Web site lilithfair.com listed the cities where shows would take place, including New York, Los Angeles, Washington, Montreal, Vancouver and London.

Divided over climate change policy and whom to name to two new leadership jobs, the European Union's leaders will be looking to Germany's newly re-elected chancellor, Angela Merkel, to signal a way out of the stalemate when they meet Thursday. Though the two deadlocked issues are unrelated, the wishes of the leader of Germany, the E.U.'s biggest and richest nation, hold the key to both, analysts and insiders say.

The government detained a United Nations torture investigator, Manfred Nowak, on Wednesday at the airport in Harare, Zimbabwe's capital, Reuters reported. Mr. Nowak questioned the reason given by the government ''at such a late stage'': that it needed to change the timing because of a visit by regional ministers looking into a breakdown in the power-sharing government, the United Nations said in a statement. It also said allegations that human rights workers and supporters of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai had been intimidated and arrested in recent days ''highlights the urgency of objective fact-finding by an independent U.N. expert.''

In recent weeks, polls have shown solid support for a government-run insurance option, seeming to breathe new life into its viability as a provision of health care legislation. In fact, advocates of the so-called public option -- whether left-leaning groups, pundits or many Democratic lawmakers -- have seized on each new number and trumpeted it across the 24/7 news spectrum. But while those polls may have bolstered Senator Harry Reid's decision this week to include the public option in the merged Senate bill, a closer examination shows once again that public opinion on this issue shifts and shimmies depending on how the question is phrased and what is stripped away from -- or added to -- a compound sentence.

First Lady Michelle Obama and Jill Biden, the wife of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., participated in the ceremonial first pitch before Game 1 Wednesday. Along with the Yankees Hall of Famer Yogi Berra, they escorted Tony Odierno, a Yankees employee and Iraqi war veteran, to throw out the first pitch to Derek Jeter. When President George W. The Ford Motor Company said Wednesday that the preferred bidder for Volvo was a consortium led by the Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, a Chinese conglomerate that has been trying for years to become a global player in the auto business. A deal for Volvo, Ford's Swedish car-making division, would be one of the most prominent advances by a Chinese company into Europe or the United States, and another sign of China's growing economic reach. But any deal would have to overcome a series of obstacles first.

Muslim women in a district in Aceh Province will be forbidden to wear tight pants or jeans under a regulation that will go into effect in January. Officials in West Aceh district said the Shariah police, who are charged with enforcing Islamic law, will shred any offensive clothing and require women in tight pants to change into government-issued skirts. The district has already ordered 7,000 skirts of various sizes. Last month, Aceh Province's Parliament passed an Islamic penal code that could subject adulterers to death by stoning.

GALSTON--Clarence E.,lawyer and insurance executive, died at 100 on October 27, 2009 at his home in Westwood, MA. The son of a federal district judge, he was raised in Woodmere, Long Island. He attended Woodmere (now Lawrence Woodmere) Academy, which his father had founded. After a year at Exeter, he went to Harvard, earning the BA magna cum laude in 1930 and LLB (later JD) in 1933. He joined the law firm of Spence Hopkins & Walser in New York and became a partner in 1940. He served in 1942-44 in the Army Air Force in England as Combat Intelligence Officer under Col. Curtis LeMay in the 305th Bombardment Group, 8th Air Force, directing strikes on targets in Germany and France; afterward he joined the Pentagon staff of Gen. Trubee Davison and was assigned to assess the postwar potential of corporations that supplied airframes and engines. He was discharged as Colonel in the U.S. Air Force Reserve. In 1948 he became president of the Motor Haulage Company in NYC and oversaw its merger with U.S. Trucking Company, which he served as vice president. In 1960 he joined Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and College Retirement and Equity Fund (TIAA-CREF) as general counsel and secretary and later became executive vice-president. After his retirement in 1974 he directed the Life Insurance Council of New York (LICONY), an industry association based in Albany. Mr. Galston was married in 1937 to Constance Matthiessen. The couple lived in Huntington, Long Island, and had three children. They were divorced in 1952. Three years later Mr. Galston married Nina Moore Shields, a lawyer and member of the faculty of the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia University, who died in 1997. He was a former treasurer and member of the executive committee of the Association of the Bar of New York City. He was a founder in 1946 of the East Woods School in Oyster Bay NY and served as its president. He was treasurer of the Cold Spring Harbor Biological Laboratory from 1974 to 1980. An active supporter of Phillips Exeter and Harvard, he received the John Phillips Award from Exeter in 1997, the highest honor given by the school to an alumnus. He was president of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club in 1960-62 and of the Ausable Club-Adirondack Mountain Reserve in St. Huberts NY from 1984 to 1988. A tournament bridge player, tennis player, and racing sailor, Mr. Galston remained a serious golfer into his late 90s. He was a regular at U.S. Seniors golf events and at the annual Father-Son Tournament in Garden City, where he competed until last year. He is survived by his son, John Galston, of Colorado Springs, CO; two daughters, Jill Galston Walsh, of Santa Monica, CA, and Linda Galston Fates, of Ipswich, MA; and a stepson, William Shields, of Hamilton, MA. He leaves 12 grandchildren and 20 great-grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Ausable Club Preservation Foundation, St. Hubert's, NY 12943. The funeral will be held at 2pm on Monday, November 2, at Trinity Episcopal Church, Concord MA.
STOCK--Pearl. Condolences to our friend Susan Fleischer and her family on the loss of her mother - a grand lady. Adele and Carl Frischling

BALANCE bikes, long popular in Europe, are making inroads in the United States as a way to teach children to ride a two-wheel bicycle without the need for training wheels. The bikes do not have pedals; instead, toddlers use their feet to steady themselves, propel forward and brake. Eventually they learn to coast -- and balance. Technically, the bikes are ride-on toys, because they lack gears. But they do look like small bicycles, with rubber tires, adjustable seats and adjustable handlebars (on the metal-frame ones, at least). All are low to the ground, so that diminutive riders can straddle them while standing on both feet.

AGNEW--Nancy Longley, 81, died on October 24th. A 1950 graduate of Wellesley College she also earned an MBA from N.Y.U. She began her career at Look Magazine in 1951 and worked at the Herald Tribune before helping to found American Heritage Publishing Company and a sister magazine, Horizon. Later she taught English and was an administrator at the Nightingale-Bamford School. From 1981 until her retirement she worked for Wellesley College as Director of Communications, Director of Corporate and Foundation Giving and Vice President for Public Affairs. She served on the board of the Dana Hall School. Mrs. Agnew studied at The Juilliard School and sang in numerous choral groups. She was a daughter of the late Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Harry S. Longley. She was the widow of Seth M. Agnew whom she married in 1966. She is survived by her daughters from Mr. Agnew's first marriage, their husbands and her four beloved grandchildren. She also leaves a brother, Robert F. Longley, of Salisbury, CT, a sister, Lucinda Slate, of Mendham, NJ, and many nieces and nephews. Service November 4, 2pm, St. Andrew's, Wellesley. Memorials to Wellesley College.

AMERICAN investors can buy bonds issued by foreign governments that are designed to provide protection against inflation, but strategists say those bonds are really more of a bet against the dollar. ''If you are a U.S. dollar-based investor, the currency fluctuations will overwhelm anything you get from inflation indexing'' on the foreign bonds, said Aaron Gurwitz, the head of global investment strategy at Barclays Wealth.

After a Somali-American teenager from Minneapolis committed a suicide bombing in Africa in October 2008, the Federal Bureau of Investigation began investigating whether a Somali Islamist group had recruited him on United States soil. Instead of collecting information only on people about whom they had a tip or links to the teenager, agents fanned out to scrutinize Somali communities, including in Seattle and Columbus, Ohio. The operation unfolded as the Bush administration was relaxing some domestic intelligence-gathering rules.

LICHTENBERG--Herbert S.,USMA 1955, was a founder and the treasurer of the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund. In the mid 1960s, together with his brother Alan, USMA 1951, he formed a group of West Point graduates and nongraduates, Jews and nonJews, who raised the necessary funds and in 1984 completed the construction of the Jewish Chapel at West Point. No Jewish cadet in the last 25 years knew what it was not to have a Jewish chapel at West Point. He was generous to a fault and supported cadet athletics and all religious programs. The Licthenberg Tennis Center and Class of 1955 Coaches Housing area, as well as the Jewish chapel at West Point, will remain a timeless tribute to his love for his alma mater. In recognition of his outstanding accomplishments, Herbie was sited by the West Point Association of Graduates in 2006 as a Distinguished Graduate of the United States Military Academy. He will be sorely missed. We mourn our loss. Burial at West Point Cemetery at 2:30pm, Friday, October 30, 2009. West Point Jewish Chapel Fund. Louis Gross, Chairman

The guests were still sleeping when the gunmen, dressed in police uniforms, arrived early Wednesday. In the dark, they shot the guards, scaled the front gate of the guesthouse and began firing grenades, the beginning of a terrifying two-hour siege that showed just how little it takes for the Taliban to trap foreigners in central Kabul. By the end of the siege, at least five United Nations employees, two Afghan security officials and the brother-in-law of a prominent Afghan politician were dead, as were their three attackers. But the story of how the rest of the people in the Bakhtar guesthouse had survived was one of courage -- particularly by several United Nations security guards, one of them an American identified by survivors as Max, who held off the attackers for about an hour.

Sanjay Jha's honeymoon as co-chief executive at Motorola lasted just a few minutes into his first meeting with employees in 2008. ''Why should we trust you?'' one employee blurted. The frustration was understandable. Motorola, which pioneered cellphones and built such consumer favorites as the StarTac and the Razr, had not had a hit phone in years, and a succession of leaders could not find one.

''YOUR elbows are nature's push-up bra,'' Go-Go Amy said, squeezing her own arms to her sides to compress and lift her chest. Amy, a burlesque performer who uses only her stage name, brims with the kind of professional wisdom that could turn any latter-day Twiggy into Bettie Page. On a recent Monday, as Halloween approached, she shared her makeover secrets, gleaned from books, Web sites and old Sears catalogs, with a clutch of aspiring calendar girls. Gathered in the basement at Live Fast, a clothing store and costume shop on the Lower East Side, those students focused intently as Amy (top right) and Bettina May (top left) , a colleague, outlined the steps that would transform them into Vargas-worthy pinups -- and fetching alternatives to Halloween's requisite goblins and ghouls. The women provided tips on how to create pie-pan eyes and a pout that lasts, how to create a proper sausage curl and how to effect an S-shape posture that plays up every curve.

MARTINEZ WARMS UPPedro Martinez can't help himself. Long one of the most interesting players in baseball, he can turn any news conference into an event, and he did so again on Wednesday as he looked ahead to his Game 2 start. He told reporters he was ''the most influential player that ever stepped in Yankee Stadium,'' talked about how some news media outlets had portrayed him as an ''ogre'' and again expressed regret about the 2003 playoff altercation in which he threw the Yankees coach Don Zimmer to the ground. ''I thought when I saw Zim down on the ground, I thought so much of my dad,'' Martinez said. ''I respect elders.'' For more Pedro, stay tuned Thursday night.

Gerry Davis wanted to be certain that his umpiring crew made the correct call, so he gathered the five other men for a meeting. The six umpires stood by the mound and talked about whether the Yankees' Robinson Cano had hit into a double play. Everyone watched them. After the umpires discussed the tricky play involving a looping shot to shortstop, Davis pumped his fist for an out sign. Yes, the umpires ruled, Cano's ball was a double play. The videotaped replays indicated that the umpires were right.

After all, as part of Yusuf's continuing quest to please his father back in the Persian Gulf, I had already stolen a military helicopter off a yacht in the harbor (before blowing up the ship with the chopper's rockets) and commandeered a small tank from the Department of Homeland Security (before reducing a squad of police cars and tactical vans to charred husks along the East River Drive).

The Yankees were tired of trying to hit Cliff Lee's pitches for nine innings. They had exasperating at-bats. ''Don't overthink things,'' Alex Rodriguez said. ''It was a dominant pitcher that dominated our lineup and probably would have dominated any lineup.''

IN the days leading up to Halloween, many people like to decorate to reflect the season. But haunting design can be appealing year-round, if it makes use of accessories with a sense of history -- even those with a slightly macabre cast. Spaces that incorporate such objects ''have a human quality,'' said Jason Volenec, who runs the New York interior design firm RKIT with Silvia Zofio. ''They gradually reveal themselves as you pass through them.''

When the Philadelphia Phillies traded for Cliff Lee in July, there was no playoff data to explore. There were no highlights of Lee striking out Alex Rodriguez three times or fielding a bouncer behind his back. Lee had pitched for the last team to win a postseason series at the old Yankee Stadium, but he was not even on the roster. In the two years since, Lee has taken to the Bronx as few visitors have. He started the final All-Star Game at the old Stadium, won the opener of the new place in April and made its World Series debut his personal showcase on Wednesday night.

Edward Brooke, a Republican senator from Massachusetts in the 1960s and 70s, rebuked lawmakers for partisan bickering on Wednesday at a ceremony awarding him the Congressional Gold Medal, the body's highest honor. ''What is it? If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen? We can't worry about those things, Mitch,'' Mr. Brooke said, addressing the Republican leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky. ''We can't worry that you all can't get together. We've got to get together. We have no alternative.''

JONES--Patricia Bleecker died October 27. Mrs. Jones was born in New York City August 29, 1930 to Ruth Hall and Benjamin DeWitt Bleecker. Married for 38 years to the late Edward Sprague Jones, she is survived by three children, Susanna Jones, Abigail Jones Feder, and Thomas Jones; sons-in-law, Robert Beguelin and Andrew Feder; daughter-in-law, Soraya Chemaly; and six grandchildren, Andries and Catalina Feder; Aaron Beguelin; and Isabelle, Caroline, and Noel Jones. At her death, she was the Senior Warden at Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY. From 1988 to 1991, she served as President General of The Colonial Dames of America where she led the effort to transform the Society's New York museum into the period appropriate Mount Vernon Hotel; she remained active in the Society until her death. For decades, she led her Abbot Academy Class of 1949 as president and class agent. A talented development professional, she worked at General Theological Seminary and also volunteered, most recently on the Campaign Steering Committee, at East Woods School in Oyster Bay, NY. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 on Friday, October 30 at Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum, 421 East 61st Street, New York, NY 10065.

No second baseman on a winning team has ever been named the World Series most valuable player, but Chase Utley is off to a promising start. It was only Game 1 -- and Cliff Lee was of course its hero -- but Utley put his imprint emphatically on the Phillies' 6-1 victory against the Yankees, doing something that had not been done since 1928. Utley homered twice against the left-hander C. C. Sabathia, notching the first two runs of the game and giving the Phillies confidence that they could get to the Yankees' ace and win the game.

For first time since 1981, the rocket that took off Wednesday from a launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center here was not a space shuttle. With a clearing in a partly cloudy sky, the Ares I-X rocket -- a prototype of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's next-generation Ares I rocket -- zipped off at 11:30 a.m., heading east over the Atlantic Ocean.

Q.I recently bought a netbook with Ubuntu as its operating system and would like to know if there is any simple way to defragment the drive. The help manual for the system talks only about a complete start-over with reinstalling the OS, rather than defragmenting it. A. Ubuntu Linux uses a different file system, or method of storing and organizing data, than other operating systems do. Most Ubuntu systems use the ext3 file system, which does not need regular defragmentation like a Windows system does.

Two games stand out on Saturday's schedule. The first is in Stillwater, Okla., where Oklahoma State will try to prove that it is a team to be reckoned with in the Big 12. The Cowboys will host Texas, which has seemed a little flat all season but still stands smack in the middle of the B.C.S. conversation. The other marquee matchup comes from Eugene, Ore., where the Oregon Ducks have seemed more like phoenixes lately, rising from the ashes of their season-opening debacle at Boise State to get back in the Pac-10 mix. Now Southern California comes to town. The Trojans already have a disappointing loss on their résumé, but they remain the team to beat in the conference and are in a good position when it comes to the B.C.S. Will they still be at the close of Saturday night? Our merry group of prognosticators has their opinion. If you want to share yours, feel free.

The Ridgeway is the oldest continuously used road in England, dating back 5,000 years. Officials in Switzerland rejected an offer by Roman Polanski to post higher bail in return for his freedom pending review of a request for his extradition to face sentencing in the United States on a 32-year-old conviction of having sex with a minor, according to The Associated Press. Folco Galli, a spokesman for the Swiss Justice Ministry, said the request had been denied because of concern that Mr. Polanski would flee. He said that the offer was "not cash" and that it "could not be seized if he fled," Agence France-Presse reported. Hervé Temime, a lawyer for Mr. Polanski, said the bail request would now move to the Swiss courts, The A.P. said. Earlier this week, 15 California legislators signed a letter supporting efforts by the Los Angeles County district attorney, Steve Cooley, to have Mr. Polanski returned to the United States, from which he fled on the eve of sentencing in 1978.

"Frank O'Hara worked as a curator at MoMA and Wallace Stevens worked for an insurance company, so I guess it's not unusual that I started to paint," says Michael Hainey, who spends his days as the deputy editor of GQ. "I've always been inspired by creative individuals who pursued their visions." His show "Less Human More Being," which opens tonight and runs through Nov. 11 at the Thom Browne store in TriBeCa, features 20 of his paintings. The centerpiece is "How I Learned to Pray," made up of 16 works, each with an image of a crow and a line from a poem Hainey wrote. Though the black and white images have the folksy quality of artists like Donald Baechler and Hugo Guinness, the poet Wallace Stevens and his "Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird" also come to mind.

We are pleased to announce the return of The Score, a forum for contemporary American composers to discuss their work and the larger issues involved in creating music in the 21st century. The project debuted in the spring of 2007 with five composers of modern music (four who contributed writing, and one, Steve Reich, who offered an interview). Their work, all of which can be read here, ranged from documentary to polemic to memoir and gave readers an inside look -- and sometimes a listen -- at this large and continually evolving branch of American culture, in which the traditional notion of "classical" continues to be reconsidered, revised, reimagined and sometimes rejected.

Update | 3:27 p.m. The House and Senate on Thursday passed a budget increase for the National Endowment for the Arts and for the National Endowment for the Humanities. The Interior Appropriations Bill for fiscal year 2010 sets budgets for each agency at $167.5 million, up $12.5 million from last year. President Obama is expected to sign the bill into law shortly. The funding comes as Rocco Landesman, the new chairman of the N.E.A., prepares to start a nationwide "Art Works" tour next week. "It's never enough," Mr. Landesman said. "But we're looking for progress at a time when every dollar is precious. For us to get a notable increase is extremely heartening."

A swinging light bulb illuminates a sign on a dark background. "Two Choices," the sign reads. The light bulb swings. The words change: "My Face." Another swing. "Your Face." Another swing. "True Face." Then a solar eclipse and a butterfly. What these images from the new short film "LX Forty," released to promote Swiss International Airlines' revamped first-class cabin, have to do with adjustable-firmness flat-bed seats and 23-inch high-def TVs is a Delphic secret known only by the film's maker, Marc Forster, better known for movies like "Monster's Ball" and "The Kite Runner." Not quite a commercial and not truly a short film, "LX Forty" is the airline's latest bid to align the company with cultural tastemakers. (In 2002, the Wallpaper founder Tyler Brûlé was brought in to "design" the brand for its reintroduction.) The video is a utopian romp through Forster's mind, which is apparently filled with cinder blocks and butterflies and Khalil Gibran-like ducats of wisdom. One such self-narrated axiom goes, "There are two types of lies we are living. Lies we tell ourselves and lies we tell others. Love is the only answer I have found that carries any truth." The C.G.I. meditation continues for another minute or so until, at the very end of the film, Forster reveals what this is all about, showing himself in a comfortable-looking airplane seat, sipping a cup of coffee. He is, of course, in the clear apex of an animated pyramid that fades to oblivion.

You might want to avoid the rare meat at Volterra, a new restaurant based on the "Twilight" books and movies that a pair of proprietors plan to open in Forks, Wash. Annette and Tim Root told The Peninsula Daily News that their new eatery, Volterra, named for the Italian city that is home to the aristocratic vampires in Stephenie Meyer's best-selling "Twilight" novels and their film spinoffs, would be a family-friendly steak and seafood restaurant and has applied for a liquor license. "We have a lot of renovations and permitting and licenses we need to get, so it probably will be spring before we open," Ms. Root told The Daily News. They'll have plenty of competition for "Twilight"-themed fare in Forks, the Olympic Peninsula town where Ms. Meyer set the action of her first "Twilight" book before she'd ever visited there: the town is also home to the Twilight Lounge, as well as the Dew Drop Inn Motel (with a Bella Suite) and Sully's Burgers, home of the pineapple-topped Bella Burger (with plastic vampire fangs), both named for the franchise's human heroine.

If you can't get Mel Gibson to star in your latest "Mad Max" sequel, you can always turn to other A-listers who hail from the southern hemisphere. Charlize Theron, the South African native and Academy Award-winning star of "Monster," will be featured in "Mad Max: Fury Road," the latest entry in the post-apocalyptic action series that helped launch Mr. Gibson and his fellow Australian, the writer and director George Miller. Variety reported that Ms. Theron would star in the film, the fourth entry in the "Mad Max" series that started in 1979, opposite Tom Hardy (of "Bronson"), who is inheriting Mr. Gibson's role as the futuristic patrolman Max Rockatansky. Mr. Gibson will not be involved, but Mr. Miller, who has lately dabbled in children's movies including "Babe" and "Happy Feet," will write and direct. A release date hasn't been announced.

A story in The Times of London examines new expressions of concern by scientists about the perils of overstating the links between extreme events and climate change. Not long ago, I attended a meeting of the Bureau of Friends, a recently formed group of creative people devoted to the appreciation of beauty, the pursuit of quality and authenticity, and how best to attain those things without killing the planet. Masterminded by Maria Moyer, the founder of WINK Communications, its charter members also include Cathy Bailey, the creative director and co-owner of Heath; Natalie Chanin, the founder of the clothing company Alabama Chanin; Julie Gilhart, the fashion director of Barneys New York; and Nicole Mackinlay Hahn, a digital artist and the founder of Reap What You Sew, which promotes awareness of trade and sustainability issues. The members of the bureau like to get together and invite people to talk about their projects, ideas and ideologies. But what made this meeting - the second of three in the bureau's "Making and Meaning" series -- particularly memorable was that everybody sewed.

Even in this cheek-by-jowl town, the realm of other people’s apartments remains resolutely mysterious. Sure, New Yorkers share walls, overhear fights, inhale the sweet-spiced victories (and, all too often, failures) of sundry kitchen experiments. But the odd, unholy secrets of our neighbors’ homes remain hidden — and some of these secrets are very odd indeed. Voices whisper, spirits hover, stereos scream and stuffed animals rearrange themselves on beds. While we enjoy cozy, sleep-filled nights in our shoebox-sized sanctuaries, our neighbors toss and turn in the Gotham equivalent of Whaley House or Bly. And why not? New York is a city built on the dead, on mass graves and potter’s fields, old battlefields and spiffed-up shooting galleries. Surely some spirits are hanging around.

LEVITT--Norman, age 66, died on Saturday, October 24 of complications related to heart failure. Graduate of Bronx High School of Science and Harvard University, he earned a Ph.D. in mathematics from Princeton. As a faculty member of Rutgers University from 1969-2006, Levitt made significant contributions to the field of topology. Since the early 90s, he authored several books and articles in defense of science against its post-modern critics. Norman Levitt is survived by his wife Renee Greene; children Steven Levitt (Oradee) of Brooklyn, NY and Heather Levitt Doucette (Jason) of Manchester, CT; and four grandsons. A memorial will be held at 1:30pm Sunday, November 1, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue / 91st Street, Manhattan. No flowers. Donations to the National Center for Science Education, 420 40th Street, Oakland, CA 94609.

8 P.M. (Travel) GHOST ADVENTURES LIVE! The ghostbusters -- Nick Groff, Zak Bagans and Aaron Goodwin, from left above -- journey to Weston, W.Va., where they will lock themselves into the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum for a seven-hour report on any ghostly activity to be found in this supposedly haunted landmark, built from hand-cut stone during the Civil War and closed in 1994. Among the more gruesome procedures performed at the hospital in the 1930s and '40s was the ''ice pick lobotomy,'' perfected by Dr. Walter Freeman, who, after rendering patients unconscious by way of electroconvulsive therapy, would insert an ice pick between the eyeball and eyelid and hammer it into the frontal lobe of the brain through the eye socket. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Ms. Winfrey interviews Lisa Niemi, the widow of Patrick Swayze.

Born in East Orange, New Jersey on August 21, 1917 to Meta (McClelland) and Louis DeVoursney Day, he grew up in Summit, New Jersey and graduated from Deerfield Academy, Wesleyan University and The University of Pennsylvania Medical School. GALSTON--Clarence E.,lawyer and insurance executive, died at 100 on October 27, 2009 at his home in Westwood, MA. The son of a federal district judge, he was raised in Woodmere, Long Island. He attended Woodmere (now Lawrence Woodmere) Academy, which his father had founded. After a year at Exeter, he went to Harvard, earning the BA magna cum laude in 1930 and LLB (later JD) in 1933. He joined the law firm of Spence Hopkins & Walser in New York and became a partner in 1940. He served in 1942-44 in the Army Air Force in England as Combat Intelligence Officer under Col. Curtis LeMay in the 305th Bombardment Group, 8th Air Force, directing strikes on targets in Germany and France; afterward he joined the Pentagon staff of Gen. Trubee Davison and was assigned to assess the postwar potential of corporations that supplied airframes and engines. He was discharged as Colonel in the U.S. Air Force Reserve. In 1948 he became president of the Motor Haulage Company in NYC and oversaw its merger with U.S. Trucking Company, which he served as vice president. In 1960 he joined Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and College Retirement and Equity Fund (TIAA-CREF) as general counsel and secretary and later became executive vice-president. After his retirement in 1974 he directed the Life Insurance Council of New York (LICONY), an industry association based in Albany. Mr. Galston was married in 1937 to Constance Matthiessen. The couple lived in Huntington, Long Island, and had three children. They were divorced in 1952. Three years later Mr. Galston married Nina Moore Shields, a lawyer and member of the faculty of the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia University, who died in 1997. He was a former treasurer and member of the executive committee of the Association of the Bar of New York City. He was a founder in 1946 of the East Woods School in Oyster Bay NY and served as its president. He was treasurer of the Cold Spring Harbor Biological Laboratory from 1974 to 1980. An active supporter of Phillips Exeter and Harvard, he received the John Phillips Award from Exeter in 1997, the highest honor given by the school to an alumnus. He was president of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club in 1960-62 and of the Ausable Club-Adirondack Mountain Reserve in St. Huberts NY from 1984 to 1988. A tournament bridge player, tennis player, and racing sailor, Mr. Galston remained a serious golfer into his late 90s. He was a regular at U.S. Seniors golf events and at the annual Father-Son Tournament in Garden City, where he competed until last year. He is survived by his son, John Galston, of Colorado Springs, CO; two daughters, Jill Galston Walsh, of Santa Monica, CA, and Linda Galston Fates, of Ipswich, MA; and a stepson, William Shields, of Hamilton, MA. He leaves 12 grandchildren and 20 great-grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Ausable Club Preservation Foundation, St. Hubert's, NY 12943. The funeral will be held at 2pm on Monday, November 2, at Trinity Episcopal Church, Concord MA.

Her older sister, Esther Sperling, Greenport, LI survives. Pearl's charm, intelligence, thoughtfulness and strength of character will be missed by all who knew her.

Phil Hughes prides himself on composure, and for most of his young career, he has stayed stoic on the field. But when Hughes left the field after walking his only two hitters in Game 1, he barked at the plate umpire, Gerry Davis. He said he doubted he had ever done that before. ''I probably haven't,'' said Hughes, 23, the Yankee right-hander. ''I definitely regret it. It was just the emotions of the moment. I went back and looked at the pitches, and they probably weren't as close as I thought they were. So that falls on me.''

Japan set the stage for a huge bailout of Japan Airlines on Thursday, telling the struggling carrier to turn to a state-backed body for assistance. The move signaled that the new left-leaning government in Tokyo would not take a tougher stance against the country's powerful corporations. The government said JAL, Japan's largest carrier by revenue, had been instructed to apply for funds from a state-backed turnaround body, after a special task force said that saving the airline was ''definitely possible'' but would require a substantial injection of public money.

The Obama administration gave the green light for construction to begin on the Mall for a long-delayed memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. At a ceremony on the memorial's site, across the Tidal Basin from the Jefferson Memorial, Ken Salazar, the interior secretary, signed the construction permits. ''It is time to honor Martin Luther King Jr. right here in the nation's front door,'' Mr. Salazar said. Harry E. Johnson, the project's chief executive, said planners had raised $106 million of the expected $120 million cost of the memorial ( model is above), which is expected to be completed in August 2011.

ROBIN--Albert. The law firm of Cowan, Liebowitz & Latman, P.C. mourns the death of our esteemed colleague and law partner Albert Robin. A powerhouse in the intellectual property field, he served in leadership and advisory positions in nearly every trademark bar association, including the commission responsible for recommending important legislative changes to the federal trademark statute. Although his five years with us at Cowan formed only a brief part of a remarkable career spanning more than four decades, he will long be remembered here for his sharp intellect, his unfailing loyalty to his clients and his daily zest for the practice of law. We will endeavor to honor him as he would have wanted with our continued commitment to the trademark bar in the US and worldwide. Our thoughts are with his entire family.

FRAZIER--Michael, passed away October 23 after a courageous battle with Parkinson's disease near the Tyringham, MA farm he shared with Charles Mirotznik for the past 30 years. He was 72. A resident of New York City, he headed Human Resources for Grey Advertising and Gulf and Western before becoming a Broadway producer in 1973 with the revival of "The Women." His greatest success was "Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music." He ran the Charles Playhouse in Boston for many years and founded The Halstead Theater Center in Chicago. In addition to Mr. Mirotznik, he is survived by a brother Paul, three nieces and countless friends and associates. Michael's glass was never half-filled - it was always overflowing. He is greatly missed. Memorial services are planned for NYC and the Berkshires.

ROHRBACH--Peter A. The law firm of Hogan & Hartson LLP mourns the passing of our esteemed partner and colleague, Peter A. Rohrbach, 56, who died October 25 of complications from lymphoma. He was one of the top U.S. communications lawyers, a leader at the firm, and a deeply-loved father, husband, brother, son, and friend. Mr. Rohrbach was an important member of Hogan & Hartson's management team. He had been Director of the firm's Communications Practice Group since 1998 and served two terms on the firm's Executive Committee. His many accomplishments included handling major telecommunications mergers and related regulatory approvals at the federal and state levels. He shared with his family a deep appreciation for culture of all kinds. He drew great satisfaction from his work as a volunteer teacher with the outreach program of Thurgood Marshall Academy, a successful D.C. public charter school. Mr. Rohrbach is survived by his wife Linda Gail Alperin and their two sons, James and Andrew. He will be greatly missed.

As health care legislation advances in Congress, the provisions most likely to become law are those that are identical or nearly so in the House and Senate measures. One such provision would require insurers to allow young adults to remain on their parents' policies -- until their 27th birthdays, under the House bill unveiled on Thursday, and at least until age 26 under the Senate version.

At Thursday's rally for the House health care bill, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, hauled out the gavel he had used when he was in the speaker's chair on the day in 1965 when the House passed the Medicare bill. ''I'm going to lend it to whoever gets to preside over this legislation, because a good piece of wood doesn't wear out with one great event,'' Mr. Dingell declared, waving the mallet.

SCHURE--Dr. Alexander, on October 29, 2009, learning theorist, inventor, educational and technological visionary. He shaped the world for the better as founding President of New York Institute of Technology and Chancellor of Nova University. Dr. Schure was a pioneer of technology enhanced learning, off campus education and computer graphic animation. He believed passionately in the ability of all students to learn, creating teaching machines in the 1950s. He also produced one of the first computer-animated films, Tubby the Tuba. Graduating from high school as a young teen, he went to work to support his family and later attended City College. After military service, he received doctoral degrees in engineering and education from New York University. He was the recipient of numerous awards, including seventeen honorary doctoral degrees and numerous other awards, both academic and athletic. Dr. Schure was the beloved husband of Gail Schure (Strollo), and the late Dorothy (Rubin) Schure, as well as the proud parent of Dr. Barbara Weinschel (Alan), Dr. Matthew Schure (Judy), Louis Schure (Denise), and Dr. Jonathan Schure (Marianne) and proud stepfather of John Impellizeri (Liz). He was also the grandfather of Lawrence, Adam, Naomi, Jared, Deborah, Joshua, Juliana, Dianne, Daniel, Samantha, Michele, Johanna, and Allison, and great-grandfather of Zachary, Henry, Phoebe and Leah. He is also survived by sister Esther Gilbert, and sisters-in-law Bette Bronstein and Ellen Rubin, as well as numerous cousins, nieces, and nephews. Services will be on Sunday, November 1st, 2:30pm, at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, New York. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or American Cancer Society.

And Then There Was One | You never want to ignore Jerry Brown. With the departure of San Francisco's mayor, Gavin Newsom, from the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, the 71-year-old state attorney general becomes the presumptive nominee, explains Daniel Weintraub. Perhaps it's not a surprise: Every California governor in the past half century has been either a veteran state officeholder or a celebrity. Mr. Brown is both.

Matchup to Watch: Eli Manning vs. The BlitzEli Manning takes a lot of time to adjust plays at the line of scrimmage, and that has caused some delay penalties and miscommunication. Coach Tom Coughlin has expressed his concern about too much "chess game." Coughlin and the offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride said the Eagles blitz even more than before, and that was plenty. Should Manning dither further when presented with such challenges, the Giants could lose again to their N.F.C. East rival.

What is the hottest thing in music right now? A pair of video games ─ Guitar Hero and Rock Band. Anyone can play. The games allow you to become a member of the band. Each game offers a range of pop music hits on game controllers that look and feel like guitars and drums. What makes these video games so much more impressive than "air guitar" is that through the use of something called the instrument game controller the player actually experiences the visceral feeling of performing music. You can even improve if you practice.

The Friday deadline passes at U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix without a filing of objection from Wayne Gretzky to the sale of the Phoenix Coyotes to the N.H.L. Gretzky, who is seeking $8.2 million in deferred salary by the bankrupt Coyotes, refrains from filing even though there is no provision in the tentative sale for repayment of what he is owed. The Arizona Republic sees it as another selfless move by Gretzky, who resigned before training camp as the Phoenix coach and director of hockey operations; the newspaper reveals that Gretzky asked Ford Motors to restructure his $6.5 million endorsement deal because of the auto industry's financial difficulties, and next year he will receive roughly one-third that amount.

The lineups are in for Game 3 of the World Series, and Nick Swisher is back in right field for the Yankees, batting seventh. Manager Joe Girardi reiterated that Swisher had been his regular right fielder all season and that he went to Jerry Hairston Jr. in Game 2 because of Hairston's good numbers against Pedro Martinez.

During its 11-year history, The National Post of Toronto has never shied away from using its news pages to present bold opinions, either for self-promotion or to challenge critics. It happened again on Saturday, with a front-page editorial assailing other news outlets for their coverage of the newspaper's financial troubles after a Toronto court prevented the paper's closing.

Forgive us in a headline for using the first name of Republican candidate Dede Scozzafava, who -- apparently in tears -- suddenly dropped out on Saturday of the special election in New York's 23rd Congressional District. What a development on a slow weekend heading into trick-or-treating.

PHILADELPHIA -- It has been raining intermittently here on a classic fall Saturday, warmish and gray. Although the forecast has improved slightly, it still calls for a 40 percent chance of showers over Citizens Bank Park around the 7:57 p.m. start of World Series Game 3, increasing to 70 percent by 10 p.m. So, at this point, anything is in the realm of possibility, including delays, a postponement or the worst-case scenario, a suspended game.

Scientists at CERN have sent a beam of protons into the Large Hadron Collider, and ran them part way around the giant underground ring successfully before dumping them. This work, conducted during the past week, was the first time protons have traveled in the giant particle accelerator since last September when the first attempts to turn on the $6-billion machine ended in a fury of sparks and smoke. The engineers also ran lead ions around part of the machine for the first time; they will eventually be collided in hopes of producing a so-called quark-gluon plasma.

Very interesting this idea of a twilight race. During qualifying the game plan, the playing field, the goal posts, all seemed to be shifting and moving all the time. Starting in daylight, the sun setting and shining down low on the track, into the drivers' eyes in spots, and then the darkness of night. Along with all that, the shifting times of the drivers and right to the last minute no idea who might end up on top. For the final seconds, it looked as if it was Mark Webber - who just surfaced out of nowhere - but then he was pushed aside by Sebastian Vettel, and then, with more than half a second's margin, Lewis Hamilton.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about real estate investments by the Retirement Systems of Alabama misspelled the surname of a developer who commented on the impact of the organization’s developments in Montgomery. He is Jerry Kyser, not Keyser.

An article on Friday about the Obama administration’s recommendation of asylum for a Guatemalan woman who suffered domestic violence described incorrectly a statistic cited by an expert witness who testified for the woman. The witness said that more than 4,000 women were killed violently in Guatemala in the last decade, not that more than 4,000 women were killed in “domestic violence” cases. The article also misstated the year that Guatemala adopted a law providing special sanctions for such crimes. It was passed in 2008, not 2004.

An article on Oct. 22 about Pope Benedict XVI’s recruitment outreach to disaffected Anglicans, which raises the prospect that groups of married Anglican priests could join the Roman Catholic church, misstated the Eastern Orthodox church’s celibacy policy for priests. While married men can become priests in the Eastern Orthodox church, it does not allow priests to marry.

The House and Senate on Thursday passed budget increases for the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities. The Interior Appropriations Bill for fiscal year 2010 set budgets for each agency at $167.5 million, up $12.5 million from last year. President Obama is expected to sign the bill into law shortly. The White House had requested an increase to $161 million for each agency. The N.E.A. received an additional $50 million through the stimulus bill. The final budget, decided in conference this week, passed by a vote of 247 to 178 in the House and 72 to 28 in the Senate.

Uninsured children who wind up in the hospital are much more likely to die there than hospitalized children covered by private or government insurance plans, according to one of the first studies to assess the impact of insurance coverage on children receiving hospital care. Researchers at Johns Hopkins Children's Center analyzed data on more than 23 million children's hospitalizations in 37 states from 1988 to 2005, in which nearly 39,000 children died. Uninsured children had a 60 percent higher risk of death than insured children, the researchers found.

WORTHMAN--Gertrude. November 17, 1929 - October 29, 2009. Daughter, sister, wife, aunt, mother, grandmother, friend. Forever in our hearts. We will miss you. Funeral services: Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Sunday, November 1st at 12 noon. Donations to: Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407.

RONIS--Michael. My dear friend and partner of twenty years, Michael Ronis, passed away on October 29th. Michael was the founding chef of Carmine's Family Style Italian Restaurant and Virgil's Real Barbeque. His passion for food coupled with his exquisite palate will be long remembered by all who knew him. Michael got so much pleasure feeding people and creating new recipes for them. His zest for food was evident in how much he loved to eat! He was devoted to the restaurants and considered them his second home. It was an honor to have known him. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife Elle and his family. Alice Cutler, President Alicart Restaurant Group

KREISELMAN--Julius. Died suddenly August 15, 2009 in Florida. He was the loving husband for fifty years of his childhood sweetheart Sandy; adoring father of Penni (David) and Jeffrey (Fran); cherished grandfather of Brittany, Briana and Jaime, Justin and Jake; devoted brother of Dorothy. He taught for forty years at P.S. 16 and I.S. 71 in Brooklyn. Known for his warm and inviting smile, compassion, good humor, respect and sensitivity. He was well loved by his school families, neighbors and friends in the Brooklyn, Staten Island and Floridian communities in which he lived. We love you. We miss you. Donations in his memory may be made to Papanicolaou Cancer Research c/o Sheila Levitt, 11565 Alana Terrace, Boynton Beach, Florida 33437.

Sony, the electronics maker, posted its fourth consecutive quarterly loss on Friday, hurt by a strong Japanese yen and sluggish sales. But the company trimmed its loss forecast for the year, citing an aggressive cost-cutting drive and a brightening outlook for the global economy.

The Securities and Exchange Commission sued a former California-based private-equity executive and six friends and relatives for reaping more than $8 million by trading Tempur-Pedic International and Acxiom Corporation shares based on secret information. King Chuen Tang, 39, also known as Chen Tang, learned nonpublic information about the companies as chief financial officer of a private-equity fund and from illegal tips from his brother-in-law, Ronald Yee, the finance head of a venture-capital fund, the S.E.C. said Friday. Attorneys for Mr. Tang and Mr. Yee denied the allegations.

LEVY--Michael B. The lawyers and staff of the law firm Bryan Cave LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Michael B. Levy, partner for over 30 years at Bryan Cave and our predecessor firm Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman. A nationally prominent real estate and banking lawyer, Michael touched every constituency of the firm, lawyers and staff alike. He was a valued counselor to his many clients in the finest and most complete sense of that term. Michael was diagnosed with lung cancer seven years ago and given six months to live. Typical of his passion as a lawyer, he simply refused to surrender to his illness, showed consistent courage and determination and would not allow the disease to interfere with his career and life. His will to live was a source of enormous inspiration to his friends and colleagues. Michael was extraordinarily proud of the accomplishments of his two children - Stacey and Spencer - and was close to them both. He loved golf, his practice, his clients, his friends and life in all its parts. To be in his presence was never a passive experience, and we will miss him greatly. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023, at 11am on Sunday, November 1. The Levy family has asked that donations be directed to Lung Research Center, c/o Dr. Mark Stoopler, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, 9th Floor, Room 936, New York, NY 10032. Bryan Cave LLP.

A New York toy salesman who admitted hiding $8 million in assets at UBS was sentenced to three months in prison by a judge who credited his cooperation in a widening investigation of offshore tax evasion. The salesman, Jeffrey Chernick, will serve six months' house arrest with electronic monitoring followed by six months' probation after leaving jail. The judge did not fine Mr. Chernick, noting that he would pay more than $4.5 million in civil penalties. Mr. Chernick, 70, pleaded guilty on July 28 to filing a false tax return. He was sentenced by Judge James Cohn of United States District Court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Chernick, of Stanfordville, N.Y., owns Jeff Chernick Inc., which represents Hong Kong and Chinese toy manufacturers.

By the middle of next year, Internet surfers will be allowed to use Web addresses written completely in Chinese, Arabic, Korean and other languages using non-Latin alphabets, the organization overseeing Internet domain names announced Friday in a decision that could make the Web more accessible. In a decision billed as one of the biggest changes in the Web's history, the board of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers -- or Icann -- voted Friday at its annual meeting in Seoul to allow such scripts in Internet addresses.

John Kenley, a Midwest theater impresario renowned for taking large-scale productions to small towns and cities and festooning the shows with headliners like Mae West, Gloria Swanson and Burt Reynolds, died on Oct. 23 in Cleveland. He was 103 and had homes in Cleveland and Florida. The cause was complications of pneumonia, a friend, Anita Dloniak, said. No immediate family members survive.

(HBO) AUSTRALIA (2008) Nicole Kidman, above, plays a weary Englishwoman in search of her husband, a cattleman, in the outback, and Hugh Jackman is the itinerant herder who helps save her ranch in this yarn from Baz Luhrmann. The film ''isn't the greatest story ever -- it's several dozen of the greatest stories ever told, 'The African Queen,' 'Gone With the Wind' and 'Once Upon a Time in the West' included,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''A pastiche of genres and references wrapped up -- though, more often than not, whipped up -- into one demented and generally diverting horse-galloping, cattle-stampeding, camera-swooping, music-swelling, mood-altering widescreen package, this creation story about modern Australia is a testament to movie love at its most devout, cinematic spectacle at its most extreme, and kitsch as an act of aesthetic communion.'' 10:30 A.M. RONIS--Michael. In deep sadness we mourn the death of our beloved friend, Chef, restaurateur, and partner, Michael Ronis. As the founding Chef of Carmine's Family Style Italian Restaurant in 1990 and on many subsequent projects, including Virgil's and Gabriela's Restaurants, Michael passionately pursued culinary excellence. For the past twenty years, he has been a constant presence in our kitchens, tasting food and developing recipes. We recently celebrated with him the successful release of the Carmine's Family Cookbook, which Michael authored. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Elle and the family. The Kitchener Rangers rookie Ben Fanelli remains in the intensive care unit at Hamilton General Hospital in critical but stable condition with a skull fracture after falling heavily into the boards during an O.H.L. game on Friday night. Fanelli, 16, went face-first into the boards after being checked from behind by Erie's Michael Liambas. He was airlifted to Hamilton General after medical personnel tended to him on the ice for half an hour. Liambas was given a boarding major and a game misconduct on the play. O.H.L. An article last Sunday about the Medill Innocence Project, in which students at Northwestern University’s journalism school scrutinize the work of prosecutors and the police, misstated part of the name of a group at the university’s law school that has worked with the students. It is the Center on Wrongful Convictions, not the Center for Wrongful Convictions.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the use of historical news events to drive plot developments in the television drama “Mad Men” misspelled the surname of the president of the Ossining Historical Society, who is an unofficial props and location consultant for the show (the main character lives in Ossining, N.Y.). He is Norman MacDonald, not McDonald.

An obituary last Sunday about the sculptor Ruth Duckworth omitted part of the name of one of the colleges for which she completed monumental bronze sculptures in the last decade. It is Lewis & Clark Community College in Godfrey, Ill. — not Lewis and Clark College. (There is a Lewis & Clark College in Portland, Ore.).
The “Living In” article and a map last Sunday about Castleton Corners, Staten Island, misstated part of the local name for Interstate 278. It is the Staten Island Expressway, not Parkway.
Tim Tebow had a hand in four touchdowns as top-ranked Florida defeated Georgia for the 17th time in their last 20 meetings.
A report last Sunday about the marriage of Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner misstated the bride’s relationship to Melania Trump. She is a stepdaughter, not the stepdaughter.
An article last Sunday about electric-motorcycle racing misstated the cost to compete with one racebike, the KillaCycle. It is $20,000 a year, not $120,000.
An article on Oct. 11 about the revival of “Bye Bye Birdie” misstated the age of Lee Adams, who wrote the music. He is 85, not 75.

SHEERS--Harriet Marling, 89, of New York City and Dennis, Massachusetts, died in her sleep on October 23, 2009 at her home on West 92nd Street in Manhattan. After graduating from Smith College in 1941, she served in the United States Navy during the Second World War as a Lieutenant in the Waves. Living in Paris after the war, she met and married J.C. Sheers, a writer and producer of documentary films. Harriet raised her family in North Stamford, Connecticut and, for three years, in Rome and London, before moving to Waltham, Massachusetts following her husband's death in 1970, and then to New York City, where she worked for many years as Director of Intake and Referrals at the Ackerman Institute of Family Therapy. A constant student of literature and passionate lover of music and the arts, Harriet was a longtime supporter of many cultural organizations in New York City, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the 92nd Street Y and the New York Society Library. She is survived by her sons, James Campbell Sheers III, Nicholas Minor Sheers and Alexander Marling Sheers, her sister Melinda Maclean, nine grandchildren and an extended, much loved family.
Art Nicolai Ouroussoff

I came to Iraq three days after Saddam Hussein fled Baghdad. It was April 12, 2003. At the time, Iraqis bristled when asked if they were Sunni, Shiite or Kurd. It made no difference, they said, they were brothers. And, in the heady aftermath of the war, for a short while it almost seemed true. That mood seems to be upon the country again, and it is most welcome after the last six years of bloody murders between Shiites and Sunnis; between Arabs and Kurds; between Muslims and Christians. Will it last? Or are Americans, as they have been in Kosovo and Bosnia and perhaps now in Afghanistan, turning away from the inconvenient realities of ethnic and religious differences, the depth of animosities, of struggles for power and territory? As the country's attention turns east to Afghanistan, I too have made the journey to Kabul, as my new assignment. It is tempting to make analogies between the two troubled places, and there are some, but there are at least as many differences.

''Are we going to give up in South Vietnam?'' That was the question President Kennedy posed, then tried to answer, in what would be his final news conference in 1963. ''The most important program, of course, is our national security. But I don't want the United States to have to put troops there.'' Kennedy was killed eight days later, giving rise not just to 40 years of grassy-knoll conspiracy theories but also to a lingering debate over whether he might have averted his successor's tragic plunge into the jungles of Southeast Asia. Kennedy came to public life as a staunch anti-Communist, but his experiences as president -- most notably the failed invasion of Cuba and the perilous standoff over Russia's missiles there -- reinforced in him a natural skepticism of go-get-'em generals and armchair extremism. In a 1995 memoir, a repentant Robert McNamara at last concluded that Kennedy most likely ''would have pulled us out of Vietnam.'' For liberals of a certain age, this is a comforting version of history, because it places some reassuring distance between the president who first inspired their idealism and the war that shattered it. The left would prefer not to believe that modern American liberalism, defined by an unshakable faith in the social justice and antiwar movements, derived from a martyred hero whose commitment to both causes was, in fact, considerably more nuanced.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Umpires Find Themselves Back in Center of Dispute,'' Oct. 30: In the bottom of the seventh inning of Game 2 of the World Series, with Yankees runners on first and second and one out, Johnny Damon hit a low line drive to Phillies first baseman Ryan Howard, who caught it on one bounce or caught it on a fly, as the umpire ruled. Jorge Posada, thinking it was a ground ball, ran from first to second.
Film Mike Hale

NEWBLATT--Marilyn (nee Blockton), 62, passed away at her home on October 30th after a courageous 14-month battle with esophageal cancer. She was surrounded by her family: Robert, Brett and Colby, Lindsay and Jon. Her strength, love and generosity will be an inspiration to all. She will be missed. Funeral service will be held at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY, Monday, November 2nd, 11am.

Many seaside towns make much of their location. Their shops are gussied up with nautical décor -- rigging, buoys, mounted fish -- and their restaurants often have the word ''captain'' in the name. The Brooklyn enclave of Sheepshead Bay avoids this waterfront kitsch. Yes, there are boats and bait shops and plenty of fishing, but there are also historical monuments and retro restaurants, all played out against the backdrop of the neighborhood's sometimes grimy, sometimes gorgeous bay. NOON Exit the B or Q train at the Sheepshead Bay station and eat lunch the way Benjamin Wolk, a local nonagenarian, has nearly every day for the past nine years: with a roast beef sandwich ($4.45) from Roll N Roaster, 2901 Emmons Avenue, (718) 769-6000. Although the restaurant has had five expansions over its four decades, its tent-covered eaves still sport the brown and tan palette popular in the 1970s. Its cuisine seems of another era, too. A sign reads: ''You can have cheez on anything you pleez'': in a cup (90 cents) or on top of your sandwich (45 cents). Felipe Marin, 24, a manager, said some customers have requested the bright yellow cheese sauce on their apple pie.

OVER the past 80 years, the United States government has engineered not one, not two, not three, but at least four rescues of the institution now known as Citigroup. In previous instances, the bank came back from the crisis and prospered. Will Citigroup rise again from its recent near-death experience?

''I do not want a documentary or sociological statement,'' Roy DeCarava once wrote. Mr. DeCarava, the great photographic chronicler of Harlem life who died last week at age 89, found his own way toward painful revelation. This 1956 Harlem photograph tormented him. The two male dancers, he said, reminded him so much of ''the real life experience of blacks in their need to put themselves in an awkward position before The Man, for The Man; to demean themselves in order to survive.'' Yet, he said, ''there is something in the figures not about that; something in the figures that is very creative, that is very real and very black in the finest sense of the word.'' A slideshow of his work: nytimes.com/lens

Of all the elements of a health care bill that the Senate and House will have to reconcile, one of the thorniest is the issue of the so-called employer mandate. To what degree will Congress require employers to provide health insurance for their employees? The three operative bills in Congress -- one unveiled in the House on Thursday, and two in the Senate that are being merged into one -- take different approaches.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''N.F.L. Data Reinforces Dementia Links,'' Oct. 24: It would be interesting to compare retired rugby players to those in the N.F.L. Rugby players wear very little protection (no helmets), and tackling is part of the sport. Nevertheless, the injuries in rugby are far less severe than those in football. John Jaros

For Vivienne Pacquette, being a combat veteran with post-traumatic stress disorder means avoiding phone calls to her sons, dinner out with her husband and therapy sessions that make her talk about seeing the reds and whites of her friends' insides after a mortar attack in 2004. As with other women in her position, hiding seems to make sense. Post-traumatic stress disorder distorts personalities: some veterans who have it fight in their sleep; others feel paranoid around children. And as women return to a society unfamiliar with their wartime roles, they often choose isolation over embarrassment.

We are all children when it comes to Halloween. I might even trade in my bike for a broomstick and take in the festivities and decorations around Manhattan from the sky. Last year, the Victorian town houses in Chelsea were wonderfully spooky: No inflatable plastic witches. Instead, residents lined stoops with candlelit pumpkins. At one house, a man lay in a coffin, which he would open to the shrieks of children. This year, a crystal spider web glitters in one of Bergdorf Goodman's Fifth Avenue windows, and pumpkins fill the wrought-iron balconies of a Gramercy Park town house. Last week, guests wigged out for the Central Park Conservancy's Twilight ball. Among the prizewinners were the couple at left; she's in a custom-designed spider-web gown and headdress.
This interview with Drew Gilpin Faust, president of Harvard, was conducted and condensed byAdam Bryant. Q. Do you remember the first time you became somebody's boss or supervisor?

All Roads Gather No Moss. A Rolling Stone Leads to Rome. Last weekend hundreds of readers of the Times blog Schott's Vocab participated in a competition soliciting disarranged proverbs. Some of the very best were these: Curiosity never grows old. True love killed the cat. -- brian Trust in God, but get even. Don't get mad, tie up your camel. -- Robert MacLeay Beware of Greeks bearing statistics. Th ere are three types of lies: lies, damn lies and gifts. -- Ken Absolute power is a joy forever. A thing of beauty corrupts absolutely. -- Nik Too many cooks spoil the kitchen. If you can't stand the heat, get out of the broth. -- Dave Goldenberg Living well makes the heart grow fonder. Absence is the best revenge. -- Mark In a battle between elephants, angels fear to tread. Fools rush in where the ants get squashed. -- Alexander Love is 20/20. Hindsight is blind. -- Samantha Shokin Truth is good for the gander. What's good for the goose is stranger than fi ction. -- alanyst Revenge is a fl ower that grows on graves. Gratitude is the idiot's weapon. (Translated and transposed from the Romanian) -- Lucia Make hay while the iron is hot. Strike while the sun shines. -- Judy S. Only fools sink ships. Loose lips rush in where angels fear to tread. -- Teige Nature abhors a home. Th ere's no place like a vacuum. -- JBS A little knowledge is a friend indeed. A friend in need is a dangerous thing. -- D. Feiertag, Denver Honesty is no excuse. Ignorance of the law is the best policy. -- bjergins Youth is wasted on a winner. Everyone hates the young. -- Simon Simons If God had meant us to fl y he'd have given us big ears. Little pitchers have wings. -- jim It is better to have loved and lost than to die by the sword. He who lives by the sword shall never have loved at all. -- Mark Lebow Misery doesn't grow on trees. Money loves company. -- Stan All's fair in love and lemonade. If life gives you lemons, make war. -- Frank Empty vessels smell after three days. Fish and guests make the most noise. -- catpro54 Familiarity makes good neighbors. Good fences breed contempt. -- Janice Huth Byer Th at which does not kill us keeps the doctor away. An apple a day makes us stronger. -- craig Th ere is no honor among the meek. Th ieves shall inherit the earth. -- Stephan, Cambridge If at fi rst you don't succeed, bring May fl owers. April showers try, and try again. -- Teige Each to an island. No man is his own. -- brian Seeing is in the eye of the beholder. Beauty is believing. -- Hondawitz It isn't over until you're having fun. Time fl ies when the fat lady sings. -- Aaron Embry You win some, and eat it, too. You cannot have your cake and lose some. -- Gracie If at fi rst you don't succeed, leap. Look before you try, try again. -- Hillel Life is the soul of wit. Brevity is short. -- spartacus It takes two to raise a child. It takes a village to tango. -- jfa Th is competition was inspired by the experimental Parisian literary movement Oulipo Ouvroir de Littérature Potentielle (''the workshop of potential literature''). In the coming weeks, in addition to its quotidian task of exploring words and phrases in the news, Schott's Vocab will be featuring more weekend Oulipian capering. (For example, this week's competition asks co-vocabularists to stack the shelves of imaginary libraries.) For more Schott's Vocab: nytimes.com/opinion

Nicholas Hoult: 'A Single Man' The English actor Nicholas Hoult has been working in film and television since he was 6. American audiences may know him for his role as Marcus, the put-upon, round-cheeked 12-year-old who tenderized Hugh Grant's heartless playboy in the 2002 romantic comedy ''About a Boy.'' Since then, thanks to snagging the alpha male role in the hugely popular teenagers-gone-wild British television series ''Skins,'' he has become a certified heartthrob at home. A midnight skinny-dipping scene in the designer Tom Ford's drama ''A Single Man'' (Dec. 11) suggests one reason why. Mr. Hoult is now a lithe, graceful 6-foot-3, and along the way that formerly chubby face has acquired dramatic cheekbones, a lush lower lip, sparkling deep-blue eyes and thick eyebrows that shoot up so sharply that he looks a bit like an alien, albeit a very handsome one.
UPPER WEST SIDE TWO-BEDROOM $1,350,000

When C. C. Sabathia started on three days' rest in the American League Championship Series, he was still throwing 95 miles an hour in the eighth inning. Sabathia earned the victory for the Yankees in Game 4 that night, and he has a chance to repeat the feat in the World Series on Sunday at Citizens Bank Park. Manager Joe Girardi named Sabathia as his Game 4 starter on Saturday, after making sure Sabathia came through Friday's workout with no problems. Sabathia, the Yankees' ace, will face the Phillies' No. 4 starter, Joe Blanton.

BREITBART--Kevin Harrison. August 30, 1966 - October 28, 2009. Born on Long Island, New York, Kevin graduated from the State University of New York at Stonybrook and the Scottsdale Culinary Institute. His soul matched his movie star good looks, but was even more superlative. Lover of all things living, he believed that all sentient beings deserved and require our respect and care. A kind and gentle soul whose passion was to educate people both on their health and the health of the planet. Cherished son, loving brother, one of a kind uncle, loving nephew and cousin. Survived by his parents, Barbara & Sheldon Breitbart, sister, Stacey Breitbart-Napp, nephew, Sam Napp and Niece, Alison Napp. He would want all who grieve for him to transform that grief into an elixir of promise and hope for humanity. Donations may be sent to the American Heart Association in Kevin's memory.

STEAK frites and coq au vin. Calf's liver, sautéed sweetbreads, escarole salad with lardons. Jackie and Bill Von Ahnen are selling these and other French bistro basics at their restaurant in Deep River, du Glace Bistro and Patisserie (the patisserie being next door to the restaurant). Such hearty, traditional food is particularly welcome as we slide into fall, and du Glace does a fair job with a short menu in a hospitable ambience that sometimes includes dancing. The Von Ahnens opened du Glace in January. (Glace is the French word for the reduced stock that forms the base of many classic sauces.) Despite a somewhat cavernous feel (dress warmly -- it was cold one night I ate there), the restaurant has a neighborly atmosphere, as if Deep River has embraced it happily. The walls are painted with murals that imitate Toulouse-Lautrec. The bar area at the front of the restaurant is busy and darker and cozier than the dining room.

IN fermentation, enzymes produced by microorganisms (yeast, bacteria) transform complex molecules into simpler ones. That beer is fermented might explain the proliferation of campus clubs celebrating this process. Friends of Fermentation started four years ago at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass. Each week a dozen students meet in a borrowed farmhouse to make fermented foods like kimchi or sauerkraut. They each get a batch to take home.
