IN ISTANBUL, one hot, sun-soaked day this past summer, the novelist Orhan Pamuk leaned back in his chair, a writerly throne in an overfull study, and looked out the window. He trained his eyes on the unblemished vista before him, where the Bosphorus, the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn run into one another and emerge as a perfect muddle of turquoise. Today, he announced, he was depressed. ''I am a writer. I have books to write. What am I doing building a museum?'' His voice rose in a crescendo to escape being drowned out by folkloric music coming from a passing cruise ship. A stuffed bird, perched to his left, peered down at the bookish debris below, giving the impression that the writer was addressing the handsome, ill-fated gull. Scattered around the room was the raw material of the museum-to-be: salt shakers, porcelain figurines, irregularly shaped doorknobs, lottery tickets, a quince grinder. The words ''never forget the objects as you write'' were written in Turkish in capital letters across a little yellow Post-it. He looked stressed. He had lectures to deliver at Harvard in the fall. He hadn't gotten far into his next novel. He had dreamed of taking a vacation with his new love, the novelist Kiran Desai. The music from the Love Boat got still louder. He winced.

The Whitechapel Gallery (77-82 Whitechapel High Street, E1; 44-20-7522-7888; www.whitechapelgallery.org) presents the first British retrospective of Sophie Calle, France's most eminent conceptual artist. The show starts with the English-language premiere of ''Prenez Soin de Vous'' (''Take Care of Yourself''), first exhibited at the 2007 Venice Biennale. In this multimedia installation, the artist asked over 100 women from different professional backgrounds -- lawyers, actors, accountants, singers -- to interpret an e-mail message in which Ms. Calle's partner ends their relationship.

LEVITT--Norman, age 66, died on Saturday, October 24 of complications related to heart failure. Graduate of Bronx High School of Science and Harvard University, he earned a Ph.D. in mathematics from Princeton. As a faculty member of Rutgers University from 1969-2006, Levitt made significant contributions to the field of topology. Since the early 90s, he authored several books and articles in defense of science against its post-modern critics. Norman Levitt is survived by his wife Renee Greene; children Steven Levitt (Oradee) of Brooklyn, NY and Heather Levitt Doucette (Jason) of Manchester, CT; and four grandsons. A memorial will be held at 1:30pm Sunday, November 1, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue / 91st Street, Manhattan. No flowers. Donations to the National Center for Science Education, 420 40th Street, Oakland, CA 94609.

Florida State's mediocrity is affecting its ticket sales. the Seminoles' smallest home crowd since 1993 -- 67,712 -- saw Jermaine Thomas, left, score twice in a 45-42 win over North Carolina State. Wisconsin beat visiting Purdue, 37-0, the Badgers' first shutout of a Big Ten opponent since 1999. It was the worst shutout loss for the Boilermakers since losing, 48-0, to Notre Dame in 1992.

IN a speech last year, Drew Faust, the president of Harvard, congratulated seniors who had gone the extra mile to get their R.O.T.C. training. She meant it literally, and the extra miles they had gone were the least of it. Harvard has not had a Reserve Officers Training Corps program on campus since antiwar protests in the 1960s shut it down. The handful of Harvard students determined enough to join R.O.T.C. must travel to Boston University and across Cambridge to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for their training, under a system developed by the military that allows host universities to serve nearby campuses.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Plodders Have a Place, but Is It in a Marathon?'' Oct. 23: We at New York Road Runners stress the strenuous, demanding nature of the marathon. We don't say that it's for everyone. We conduct more than 50 events a year -- from the mile to the marathon -- and hold beginner clinics and classes.

Early snowfall, colder temperatures and perhaps a sprinkle of P.R. have led ski resorts in North America, Europe and elsewhere to open early. Loveland Ski Area, above, a small, family-oriented resort about 50 miles west of Denver, opened on Oct. 7, about the same time that Las Vegas Ski & Snowboard Resort, about 45 minutes from the Las Vegas Strip, welcomed skiers. They were followed closely by Arapahoe Basin in Colorado and Boreal Mountain Resort on Lake Tahoe in California.

With this city's limited open spaces, many parents find themselves struggling to keep children and teenagers busy. Still, if you want to teach your children more about Mumbai's history and culture, there are plenty of good options. At Mani Bhavan (19 Laburnum Road, Gamdevi; 91-22-2380-5864; www.gandhi-manibhavan.org), once Gandhi's home, children can see the room where the leader worked -- along with his sandals, spectacles, spinning wheel, bed and drinking bowl. A good way to get younger children interested might be to go straight to the top floor, which displays intricately crafted dioramas depicting scenes from Gandhi's life.

As the New York City mayor's race enters its final, combative stretch, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his opponent, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., have unleashed a flood of advertisements that contain distorted, misleading and, in some cases, outright false claims about everything from the creation of jobs to plans for tax increases. With many New Yorkers just beginning to tune in to what has been a late-blooming campaign, the truth-stretching -- in TV commercials, Web advertisements and mailed brochures -- could be the primary exposure they have to the two candidates.

Aaron Taylor's career at Nebraska was successful by any measure. He helped the Cornhuskers win three national titles, was an all-American as a center and a guard and won the Outland Trophy as the nation's best interior lineman in 1997. It took about 30 minutes Saturday for him to lose possession of some of the tangible evidence of his accomplishments. Taylor's Outland Trophy and his seven championship rings were sold at a court-ordered auction, after the failure of his Cornhuskers-themed restaurant in Omaha and his subsequent bankruptcy. According to The Associated Press, the trophy sold for $6,800, and the diamond-encrusted rings sold for $2,000 to $5,900. Bids were accepted in person and online. The auction brought in $28,500, the A.P. reported.

The Dalai Lama said Saturday that the Chinese government was wrong to attribute political motives to his travels, including a planned trip soon to a Buddhist mountain enclave in northeastern India that China claims as its territory. ''The Chinese government considers me a troublemaker, so it is my duty to create more trouble,'' he said jokingly, according to The Associated Press. ''The Chinese government politicizes too much wherever I go. Where I go is not political.''

'I was like, I've been here before. Just kick the ball. It's not rocket science.' California kicker Giorgio Tavecchio on what he was thinking before he made a 24-yard field goal with 21 seconds left to beat Arizona, 23-21.

WHAT does a swimming tiger suggest about public policy, or a pricked finger say about your goals? The Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University is showing applicants two dozen conceptual photos, and giving them the option of basing an essay on one of them. The photo album was created by the Center for Creative Leadership, a nonprofit group that produces visual tools to prompt conversations at leadership training seminars. Wagner is putting the concept to unusual use as an admissions tool. ''It allows us to get a deeper sense of the applicant's passion for/commitment to an issue, and unlocks the depth of interest in a way that is not always achievable in a standard admissions essay,'' says Tracey Gardner, Wagner's chief of staff. Another benefit: no more essays rehashed from other applications. About 970 applicants for this fall's class, more than half, wrote on an image. The importance of having a clear focus, purpose and strategy, and of combining theory and practice.

To check or not to check? It's a question that is becoming tougher to answer for airline passengers. The latest salvo in the complicated issue: Virgin America is testing a policy that allows passengers without carry-on items to be seated first. The idea behind the policy, which is being tested on select flights out of San Francisco International Airport, seems to be that unburdened passengers can seat themselves quickly and not clog the aisles trying to fit their luggage in overhead compartments. (Personal items, like laptops, are not included.)

COMMUNING WITH THE ELEMENTS, JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK, IN CALIFORNIA, MARCH 14, 2009 Nancy Sherwood, 62, center, a spiritual teacher from Upper Vaughan, Nova Scotia, dances at the Interspiritual Conference at the Joshua Tree Retreat Center. ''I'm not a member of the Sacred Fire Community, which hosted the conference. But I practice meditation from the Shambhala Buddhist tradition, and when this thing came up, I thought, 'I need to go and connect with this part of the world.' They keep the fire going the whole time because, in the practices of traditional, indigenous and even contemporary people, the fire keeps the energy moving. And I'm just drawn to that energy. I'm really nervous about using flaky language, but I really believe that we can connect so deeply with the elements that we can merge with them in spirit. It's like a communion is happening. And in that place, I felt safe enough to be able to express that. I didn't have to worry about anybody watching me. When it fills me up, that's when I start to move. Because it's almost telling me how to move.'' As told to Austin Considine

CONSUMER REPORTS has released results from its annual car reliability survey, which will be published in the December issue of the magazine. According to the survey, Honda and Toyota continue to have the most reliable vehicles, but Ford is very close behind. The magazine said Ford's performance in the survey ''dispels the notion that only Japanese manufacturers make reliable cars.''

LINDA RODIN, a former model and longtime fashion stylist, doesn't claim her decadent skin oil will reverse the signs of aging. Talk like that, she has come to realize, is cheap. But she does insist that Rodin Olio Lusso, which was concocted in her kitchen from 11 essential oils, ''will make your skin the best it can be naturally -- whether you're 20 or 90.'' And, well, fashion insiders are sold: The models Kate Moss, Claudia Schiffer and Eva Herzigova are all big fans; the makeup artists Diane Kendal and Tom Pecheux carry it in their bags. (Mr. Pecheux, below, used it backstage at Balmain to give the models a fresh-faced glow.) And her dermatologist, Dr. David Colbert, stands so firmly behind the products (aside from the face oil, there is a body oil and, in December, a lip balm), he sells them at his Fifth Avenue office. ''Bottom line: it works,'' he said.

WHEN Katie Jarvis was first approached in a British train station to audition for the lead in Andrea Arnold's ''Fish Tank'' (Jan. 15), she didn't believe it for a minute and refused to give the casting agent her number. For one thing, she had never acted before, and for another, she was busy having a shouting match with her boyfriend on the opposite platform. She couldn't know it, but that's what caught the casting agent's eye. Mia, the 15-year-old girl Ms. Jarvis ultimately agreed to play, has been expelled from school and is at war with the world. Within moments of the movie's opening, she's in a screaming fight with her mother (Shrieking mum: ''What is wrong with you?'' Shrieking Mia: ''You're what's wrong with me!''), and minutes later answers the taunts of an ex-friend with a head butt worthy of a hired goon.

THE DEMOCRATIC PARTY should not ''allow itself to be embarrassed by old formulas formulated for another age, which had other and very different questions to settle. Take the old ideal of 'as little government as possible.' It is no longer possible with the modern combinations of industry and transportation to discriminate interests of the states as they could once be discriminated. Interests once local and separate have become unified and national. They must be treated by the national government.'' WOODROW WILSON, president of Princeton University

MARGOLIS--Henry Melville , born New York City 1909, died on his 80th birthday, 2 November, 1989 in black tie. Fought his way up from the Lower East Side. City College law school. Owner of hotels. Served in the US Marines at Iwo Jima. Co-owner of the city's famed Cafe Chambord. Produced plays Broadway and London, starring Orsen Wells. Industrialist: chairman Elgin Watch Company, SI Industries, Jamieson Labs. Founding director, International Center for Photography, Strang Clinic, Pritkin Institute. Noted philanthropist. Married Nexhmie Zaimi. Second wife, Irene Broza. A great spirit who loved New York. His light still shines. Eric Margolis

LICHTENBERG--Herbert S.,USMA 1955, was a founder and the treasurer of the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund. In the mid 1960s, together with his brother Alan, USMA 1951, he formed a group of West Point graduates and nongraduates, Jews and nonJews, who raised the necessary funds and in 1984 completed the construction of the Jewish Chapel at West Point. No Jewish cadet in the last 25 years knew what it was not to have a Jewish chapel at West Point. He was generous to a fault and supported cadet athletics and all religious programs. The Licthenberg Tennis Center and Class of 1955 Coaches Housing area, as well as the Jewish chapel at West Point, will remain a timeless tribute to his love for his alma mater. In recognition of his outstanding accomplishments, Herbie was sited by the West Point Association of Graduates in 2006 as a Distinguished Graduate of the United States Military Academy. He will be sorely missed. We mourn our loss. Burial at West Point Cemetery at 2:30pm, Friday, October 30, 2009. West Point Jewish Chapel Fund. Louis Gross, Chairman

THE world, as Tamara Taichman, a contributing editor of French Elle, sees it, has enough overly beautiful accessories. It could, however, do with more simple stuff. Such is the philosophy behind Tila March, her bag-and-shoe line, which, this season, includes some of the best-looking weekend boots around. In a rugged taupe suede, with a solid stacked wooden heel, they strike that perfect balance of laid-back chic. ''I tried to make shoes that are elegant and, at the same time, easy to wear,'' Ms. Taichman said. ''I think people are coming back to that.'' Tila March suede boots, $485 at Mick Margo, 19 Commerce Street; (212) 463-0515.

During his lifetime he was proprietor of H. Eckstein & Sons, a dry goods store and Lower Eastside institution. He will be sorely missed.

THE documentary photographer Bruce Davidson insists that style was never part of his vocabulary. Even so, his work, which is now the subject of two gallery shows and a three-volume box set published by Steidl, contains a haphazard elegance that has captivated the fashion industry from the very start. Alexander Liberman, Vogue's legendary art director, offered Mr. Davidson assignments after seeing his 1959 ''Brooklyn Gang'' series, portraying a gritty and rather gorgeous crew called the Jokers. ''There was an emotion and energy that Alex picked up on,'' Mr. Davidson recalled. ''He figured if I could shoot gangs, I could shoot fashion.'' Which he did for several years, despite his heart not being in it. ''The models were too tall and sophisticated,'' he said. ''It wasn't real. It was like cotton candy.''
NORWALK COLONIAL $995,000

Election officials compare them to a 1963 Studebaker (''it's a very good car, but it's very old'') and on Tuesday 7,000 squat voting booths, many manufactured almost 50 years ago by the Shoup Voting Machine Company of Canton, Ohio, will be stationed across the city. In addition to the ballot in each voting machine and sample ballots displayed at polling sites, the city's Board of Elections prints -- for each of the city's 6,000 election districts -- about 600 emergency ballots, 200 absentee ballots and 500 ballots that the disabled can mark with special devices. The printing is done by private companies and costs about $10 million. Ballots are printed in three languages besides English -- Spanish, Chinese and Korean -- depending on the demography of individual election districts. City election officials say they cannot remember major glitches on the ballots, like a spelling error, that required a recall. In 2008, one upstate district was said to have sent out absentee ballots listing ''Barack Osama.'' State legislation from the late 19th century requires each party to be listed on the ballot with a symbol as well as a name to make it easier for illiterate voters. Republicans use an eagle and Democrats a star, rather than the more familiar elephant and donkey, which began as political cartoons. The Libertarians use an arm of the Statue of Liberty, while the Conservatives took her torch. The parties are listed in the order of the number of votes they received in the last election of a governor; those that got fewer than 50,000 votes (Libertarian, Socialism and Liberalism, Socialist Workers, Green and Rent is Too Damn High) land in the order their petitions were filed with the Board of Elections. The Jobs & Education Party, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg created, is listed under his name on the Independence line because the city does not want candidates to monopolize the ballot by inventing new parties. Voters can also write in any name, including their own. In 2005, at least one vote was recorded for nearly 150 individuals, among them Daffy Duck, God, Jesus Christ and Howard Stern. DEMOCRATIC For a brief, dramatic moment, Mr. Bloomberg considered seeking the party's nomination, an unheard-of gamble for a non-Democrat. But the party's five county chairmen stuck with William C. Thompson Jr., now the comptroller.

IN the grand scope of automotive history, Graham Nearn's accomplishment may seem small. The focus of his ambitions was the Lotus Seven, a niche sports car that he had sold as a Lotus dealer in 1959. The dealership was in Caterham, England, and called Caterham Cars. ''I fell in love with the car then,'' Mr. Nearn said in 1993. ''I was a young man then. It was a two-seater open car that would do anything you could want a two-seater open car to do. You could go away in it for the weekend or you could race it.''

(13, 49) PLACE OF EXECUTIONJuliet Stevenson stars as Catherine Heathcote, a television journalist and single mother bent on solving the 1963 disappearance of a 13-year-old girl whose body was never found -- despite a murder conviction in the case. In flashbacks more than 40 years earlier, Lee Ingleby plays George Bennett, a high-level police official whose career took off with the case and who is now the subject of Catherine's latest documentary. Philip Jackson is George as an older man. Greg Wise, above with Ms. Stevenson, plays the girl's arrogant stepfather; Tony Maudsley is George's garrulous sergeant; and Elizabeth Day is Catherine's rebel daughter, who can't stand her mother but is fascinated by her project. Then there are the suspects: a schoolmate (Mikey North) who had secretly kept photographs of the victim, and the victim's uncle (Ryan Anthony-Jones), a known sexual offender. But most troubling are the local villagers, who for more than four decades have withheld information. This two-part ''Masterpiece Contemporary'' production is based on a thriller by Val McDermid (''The Wire in the Blood''); David Tennant (''Dr. Who'') is host. Part 2 will be broadcast on Nov. 8 at 9. 8 A.M. (NBC) MEET THE PRESS Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner discusses the economy, jobs and health care; David Plouffe, President Obama's campaign manager, talks about his new book, ''The Audacity to Win: The Inside Story and Lessons of Barack Obama's Historic Victory.''

JOHN HILLCOAT's post-apocalyptic drama ''The Road'' (Nov. 25) is based on Cormac McCarthy's most parablelike novel, with its leading characters, a father and a son, known only as The Man and The Boy. It's a challenge for any actor to infuse an emblematic figure with specific, detailed life, but the astonishingly sure-footed Kodi Smit-McPhee, who was 11 at the time of shooting, makes it look effortless -- or as effortless as this grueling story allows. Playing alongside Viggo Mortensen, as the loving father who persists in instilling in his son a sense of ethics in the face of savagery, he becomes the moral pivot on which the movie turns. Father and son make their way across a ruined landscape where civilization and nature itself seem long dead and gangs of predators live off the flesh of less hardy or rapacious survivors, including children. This is the only world The Boy has ever known, and it's terrifying. And yet, although the movie opens with his high, panicked cry, ''Papa, Papa,'' as the earth rumbles under their feet, Kodi keeps melodrama at bay with a clarity and restraint that make The Boy a fascinating paradox. He is at once the steadiest and most vulnerable figure in a setting so wildly violent it makes social Darwinism look like a minuet.

The regional rivalry will cross two cities and three leagues this weekend. 76ers at Knicks Saturday night, Madison Square Garden The first round of the weekend's intercity duel was played in New York, where the Knicks hosted the 76ers in their home opener. The Knicks rallied from a 23-point deficit but fell in overtime, 141-127. The Knicks, now 0-3, lost in double overtime Friday, so they have played 11 periods in two days without a win to show for it. We are all children when it comes to Halloween. I might even trade in my bike for a broomstick and take in the festivities and decorations around Manhattan from the sky. Last year, the Victorian town houses in Chelsea were wonderfully spooky: No inflatable plastic witches. Instead, residents lined stoops with candlelit pumpkins. At one house, a man lay in a coffin, which he would open to the shrieks of children. This year, a crystal spider web glitters in one of Bergdorf Goodman's Fifth Avenue windows, and pumpkins fill the wrought-iron balconies of a Gramercy Park town house. Last week, guests wigged out for the Central Park Conservancy's Twilight ball. Among the prizewinners were the couple at left; she's in a custom-designed spider-web gown and headdress.

The great American holiday is Thanksgiving, and the great Thanksgiving movie is ''Planes, Trains and Automobiles.'' After writing and directing the '80s comedies my generation can still quote from memory (''Sixteen Candles,'' ''The Breakfast Club,'' ''Weird Science'' and ''Ferris Bueller's Day Off''), John Hughes turned his camera away from the adolescents of suburban Chicago and onto their fathers. The story here could not be simpler: Steve Martin is Neal Page, a successful marketing man trying to make it home for the holiday. Everything conspires against him, from God to Kevin Bacon. Neal is a Job with no patience. Every slight is a mortal wound. Every piece of bad luck brings on a new round of grimaces, eye rolling and impotent fury. Every scene contains some fresh insult, but whenever he tries to defend himself he ends up in worse straits. After he drops 18 F-bombs on an unhelpful rental car agent, she smiles sweetly and destroys him with a 19th. When he comes up with a decent retort for an equally unhelpful cab dispatcher, he's punched out and hoisted off the pavement by his scrotum.

KREISELMAN--Julius. Died suddenly August 15, 2009 in Florida. He was the loving husband for fifty years of his childhood sweetheart Sandy; adoring father of Penni (David) and Jeffrey (Fran); cherished grandfather of Brittany, Briana and Jaime, Justin and Jake; devoted brother of Dorothy. He taught for forty years at P.S. 16 and I.S. 71 in Brooklyn. Known for his warm and inviting smile, compassion, good humor, respect and sensitivity. He was well loved by his school families, neighbors and friends in the Brooklyn, Staten Island and Floridian communities in which he lived. We love you. We miss you. Donations in his memory may be made to Papanicolaou Cancer Research c/o Sheila Levitt, 11565 Alana Terrace, Boynton Beach, Florida 33437.

THE NEWS The government's ambitious vaccination program to combat swine flu is off to a slow start as the H1N1 virus spreads quickly across the nation. BEHIND THE NEWS Federal officials predicted last spring that as many as 120 million doses would be available by now. But early last week, only about 16 million doses were on hand. Why the lag? Production problems have plagued the companies making the vaccine. All use a technology that involves growing the vaccine in a fertilized egg; at most of the companies, the seed strain has grown more slowly than expected.

LEVY--Michael B. The lawyers and staff of the law firm Bryan Cave LLP mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague Michael B. Levy, partner for over 30 years at Bryan Cave and our predecessor firm Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman. A nationally prominent real estate and banking lawyer, Michael touched every constituency of the firm, lawyers and staff alike. He was a valued counselor to his many clients in the finest and most complete sense of that term. Michael was diagnosed with lung cancer seven years ago and given six months to live. Typical of his passion as a lawyer, he simply refused to surrender to his illness, showed consistent courage and determination and would not allow the disease to interfere with his career and life. His will to live was a source of enormous inspiration to his friends and colleagues. Michael was extraordinarily proud of the accomplishments of his two children - Stacey and Spencer - and was close to them both. He loved golf, his practice, his clients, his friends and life in all its parts. To be in his presence was never a passive experience, and we will miss him greatly. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023, at 11am on Sunday, November 1. The Levy family has asked that donations be directed to Lung Research Center, c/o Dr. Mark Stoopler, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, 9th Floor, Room 936, New York, NY 10032. Bryan Cave LLP.

Nov. 9 marks the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, and Rail Europe is offering 20 percent off German Rail Passes and a free Berlin sightseeing tour. The pass includes four days of travel within one month along any route in the German rail network, including stops in Munich, Cologne, Hamburg, Frankfurt and, of course, Berlin.

COHN--Peter J.,engineer and philanthropist, died peacefully on October 25. He is survived by his wife Bernice, his sons David and Claude, David's wife Carmela, his beloved grandchildren, Silvia, Sabrina, and Max, as well as by his brother Michael and his wife Sue. He was born in Leipzig, Germany on September 27, 1921 and emigrated to the United States with his family shortly after the Nazi take-over. During the Second World War he served in the China-India-Burma theatre. After the war he finished his studies at the University of Colorado. On retirement he became active in many philanthropic causes both here and abroad. Services private.

MUCHMORE--Virginia Harrison, 90, of New Vernon, NJ died peacefully at home on October 28, 2009. Born in Livingston, NJ, she was the daughter of Rufus Freeman and Elsie Wood Harrison. The Harrisons were one of the original settlers of Newark, NJ and were a prominent New Jersey political and business family from the 17th century to the 20th century. She was a graduate of College St. Elizabeth. During World War II, she was one of the first 23 women ever permitted to enroll in a course at Princeton University. Interested in preserving the rural nature of her community, she was the founder and President of Residents for Rural Harding and spearheaded the successful effort to put the Silver Lake District on the National Register of Historic Places. Her husband of 66 years, Henry George Muchmore, predeceased her earlier this year. Survived by sons, James H. of Morristown, NJ; and John W. of Pottersville, NJ; daughters, Joan M. Roach of Greenwich, CT; Jean M. McCleary of Wakefield, RI and Juliana M. Cooney of Kintnersville, PA; thirteen grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Donations may be made in her memory to the Harding Land Trust, P.O. Box 576, New Vernon, NJ 07976.

I WOULD like to take this opportunity to make a public apology to R. Creigh Deeds, the Democratic candidate for governor of Virginia: Creigh, I'm sorry for not returning your calls.

DURING a celebrity-packed party at the Hamptons International Film Festival last month, Anna Kendrick responded modestly to a question about the musical talent that brought her a Tony nomination for her work in the Broadway production of ''High Society'' when she was 12. Five years later, it won her the part of Fredrika in the New York City Opera's ''Little Night Music.'' Now 24, Ms. Kendrick has been concentrating on her film career, although in her biggest movie yet, Jason Reitman's ''Up in the Air'' (Dec. 4), she gets to sing too, after a fashion. In person Ms. Kendrick is tiny and adorable-looking, but on-screen she's no softy. In Mr. Reitman's dark-edged new comedy, which plays out amid the ravages of the current recession, she is hilarious and scary as Natalie, a ferociously perky young professional so hellbent on success that her game plan resembles an obsessive-compulsive disorder. As Ryan and Alex, business travelers who like spending more time in airport hotels than in their homes, George Clooney (below with Ms. Kendrick) and Vera Farmiga are the suave, witty headliners. They put the romance in this film, but it's Ms. Kendrick's job to supply the belly laughs.

AS the recession drags on, the ads that subway riders tend to ignore suddenly seem more compelling: ''For over 30 years, 90% of all DeVry graduates had careers within six months.'' ''Earn your degree in information technology at Monroe College and you become a crucial asset to every company in every industry.'' And people aren't just reading the ads; they're enrolling. In New York State, for example, the number of students at for-profit colleges in the last decade has jumped 61 percent (by contrast, the State University of New York took in 15 percent more students).

''The Ice Storm'' is the sort of holiday film that makes you never want to go home again. Though Thanksgiving is the reason for the return of the young protagonist (Tobey Maguire) from boarding school to suburban Connecticut, where his stilted parents (Joan Allen and Kevin Kline) and ironist younger sister (Christina Ricci, near right, with Mr. Kline and Ms. Allen) wait for him in their nest of noncommunication, the meal itself is a desultory affair. The real nourishment in this 1997 film is not what's bringing two families linked by adultery and teenage lust together, but what's pulling them apart: alienation, selfishness and spiritual bankruptcy. This doesn't sound like a barrel of laughs, I know, but it's deeply satisfying to watch characters drawn with such excruciating vividness get lost in the 1970s, ushering in the holidays with a ''key'' party where wives (Sigourney Weaver is unforgettable as a bored adulteress) and husbands gamely swish off in each others' Oldsmobiles as their children fumble naked and unsupervised under duvets, wander around in Nixon masks, whip rosebushes and electrocute themselves while observing natural phenomena. In fact, this film is not just set in the '70s, its deadpan tone echoes that great nonmanipulative period in American filmmaking when ''Taking Off'' and ''Shampoo,'' among others, embodied a warm satire, which is now very rare. Yet ''The Ice Storm,'' directed by Ang Lee, has an edge, an irony, a sharpness, that belongs to our own, more jaded time. Ice is a motif used throughout, not just in the weather: turkeys, ice cubes and hearts all need thawing in this strangely eerie film. I went to see it at the Angelika twice in two days when it came out. I thought it was pitch-perfect, just the right balance of pleasure and pain -- all you can ask of any holiday.

A nail salon opened around the corner from my house on Monday. Normally, this fact would barely register. Nail salons open every few minutes in New York City, and there were already three within two blocks. But on Monday morning, the sight of cheery women in surgical masks hanging up plastic pennants was big news: I was in Lap 17 of 75.4, on a quest to walk a marathon around my block, so the prospect of a $16 pedicure with foot massage seemed a good omen.

IN the five years since he assumed the position of Givenchy's artistic director, Riccardo Tisci has become one of Paris's most influential designers, initiating a brand of hard-core chic that entails lots of metal and no eyebrows. (Hey, it's a look.) Now he's bringing back some of the house's best hits, with a small collection of iconic pieces, at lower prices. The premier edition, which just arrived in stores, is based around the Bettina, a romantic white blouse designed by Hubert de Givenchy in 1952, and studs, which Mr. Tisci introduced in his breakthrough fall 2007 collection and hasn't yet grown tired of. For this collection, he has adorned pants, blouses, jackets, a dress and handbags in the stuff.

SPURR--Cynthia Holmes, 82, of Stuart, FL and Moultonborough, NH, formerly of Short Hills, NJ, died October 18, 2009. Born in Boston, MA and raised in Cleveland, OH, she graduated from the Laurel School, Abbott Academy and Smith College, where she was a member of the Smiffenpoofs. While raising a family she managed to pursue her many interests and talents for design, architecture and genealogy. Cynthia was preceded by her husband Gregory Waterman Spurr, Jr. in 2007, and twin brother Peter 11 years ago. Survivors include her children, Gregory W. Spurr, III, Jeffrey H. Spurr, Cynthia D. Spurr and Pamela S. Poole; five grandchildren and a sister, Jean H. Babson of Wilmette, IL. Memorial contributions may be made to Treasure Coast Hospice, 1201 SE Indian Street, Stuart, FL 34997.

Life as a Labradoodle may sound free and easy, but if you're Jet, who lives in New Jersey, there is a lot of work to be done. He is both a seizure alert dog and a psychiatric service dog whose owner has epilepsy, severe anxiety, depression, various phobias and hypoglycemia. Jet has been trained to anticipate seizures, panic attacks and plunging blood sugar and will alert his owner to these things by staring intently at her until she does something about the problem. He will drop a toy in her lap to snap her out of a dissociative state. If she has a seizure, he will position himself so that his body is under her head to cushion a fall.

The Jets have run the ball at a blistering pace. They amassed more than 300 yards rushing in each of their last two games -- the second time in N.F.L. history a team has done that in consecutive weeks; the first was in 1975. The Dolphins rank fourth in the league in run defense (86.3), and the Jets will be without Leon Washington, who is out for the season. The Jets will be counting on the rookie Shonn Greene, above (144 yards rushing against the Raiders), Thomas Jones (602 yards, fourth in the N.F.L.) and an offensive line that has started 23 straight games together, the most in the league.

JONES--Patricia Bleecker died October 27. Mrs. Jones was born in New York City August 29, 1930 to Ruth Hall and Benjamin DeWitt Bleecker. Married for 38 years to the late Edward Sprague Jones, she is survived by three children, Susanna Jones, Abigail Jones Feder, and Thomas Jones; sons-in-law, Robert Beguelin and Andrew Feder; daughter-in-law, Soraya Chemaly; and six grandchildren, Andries and Catalina Feder; Aaron Beguelin; and Isabelle, Caroline, and Noel Jones. At her death, she was the Senior Warden at Christ Church in Oyster Bay, NY. From 1988 to 1991, she served as President General of The Colonial Dames of America where she led the effort to transform the Society's New York museum into the period appropriate Mount Vernon Hotel; she remained active in the Society until her death. For decades, she led her Abbot Academy Class of 1949 as president and class agent. A talented development professional, she worked at General Theological Seminary and also volunteered, most recently on the Campaign Steering Committee, at East Woods School in Oyster Bay, NY. Donations, in lieu of flowers, to the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum, 421 East 61st Street, New York, NY 10065.

REGIONAL dishes are always exciting because they most often involve ingenuity. It seems that the more isolated an area, the more likely it is that what's outside the kitchen door is what goes into the pot, and sometimes it takes a lot of effort to turn these ingredients into something delicious, or even palatable. But Sardinia is lucky. Just beyond this island's door lie the bounty of the Mediterranean and the grazing lands of its mountainous interior. It is flush with fish, lamb and game.

DARLING--Charles M.,III, of New York City. Son of Charles M. Darling, Jr. and Alma (Healy) Darling; born in Rutland, VT on October 31st, 1924; husband of Marilynn W. Darling, recently deceased. Naval veteran of World War II, he received his BA from New York University, after which he served in the Korean War. After several years as a Naval officer in the Office of Naval Intelligence, he joined the State Department where he served in posts throughout southeast Asia. He was co-founder and Strategic Director of the Senior Executives Council of The Conference Board, where he was a facilitator in the creation and early operation of the Institute for the Future. Subsequently, he was a Principal in the Executive Search firm of Baeder International Group, which was headquartered in New York City, and was a long-time member of the Eighth Church of Christ, Scientist, where he served in many capacities, including as Reader and Chairman of the Board. He is survived by two sisters, Alice Darling Heyer and Mary Darling-Damas, and a brother, Charles M. Darling, IV, brothers-in-law Fred Heyer and Warren Weller, sisters-in-law Vivian Darling and Leslie Weller, and nephews Scott Heyer, Charles M. Darling, V, Christopher B. Darling, Douglas W. Weller and David J. Weller. In lieu of flowers, remembrances of him in the form of a contribution may be sent to Eighth Church of Christ, Scientist, 103 E. 77th St., New York, NY 10075, or PBS, Channel 13, 450 E. 33rd St., New York, NY 10001. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed for his contribution to us all.

The current exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art -- ''Bold, Cautious, True: Walt Whitman and American Art of the Civil War Era'' -- is a didactic sort of show, centering on representations of historical events in American art and about the literature of Walt Whitman in and around the Civil War period. The exhibition is a collaborative venture with the Dixon Gallery and Gardens in Memphis, where it was displayed earlier this year. It is enjoyable to look at, but rather difficult to understand, because the curator, Kevin Sharp, seems to have been too ambitious by half: With fewer than 60 works, he has sought to convey the story of American art and society during the Civil War era.

The Cleveland Browns announced late Monday night that the first-year general manager George Kokinis was no longer working for the team, following a day of reports that he had been fired. The Browns denied the juicy part of the reports that Kokinis had been escorted out of the building. Kokinis was Coach Eric Mangini's hand-picked choice to be the G.M., and the order of their hiring indicates who had the real power in the franchise: Mangini, not Kokinis. It was Kokinis who took the fall for the Browns' 1-7 start. For this he left the Ravens and Ozzie Newsome's well-oiled scouting and personnel machine?

Today's puzzle features a clever quote by a governor whose name tucks neatly into opposite corners of the grid. Crossword constructors like a name like that. Designers of campaign placards do too, being able to neatly stack one name atop the other. In presidential races, FORD DOLE was a good pairing. EISENHOWER NIXON wasn't, but using IKE and DICK solved that problem.

In the spring of 2004 I took a flight from my home near Greenville, S.C., to New York to visit my dying step-grandmother. We had been close, and it would be one of the last times I would get to see her. As the flight was about to land, it abruptly ascended and headed toward the Empire State Building. The passengers on the plane became quiet; the aura of 9/11 was hanging in the air.

This is a busy week for design exhibitions. Opening on Tuesday at the Wright auction house in Chicago is "Timeless," a collection of objects by Constantin and Laurene Boym. For the show, the New York-based Boyms, who won a 2009 National Design Award for their quirky, witty products, render everyday objects like tables and bottles in bronze, giving them a permanence they might not otherwise have.

Trader Joe's will have its grand opening Friday at the new Millburn location at 187 Millburn Avenue. The building was the site of Whole Foods, which has moved to Union, and will be the ninth Trader Joe's in New Jersey, the second one opening this year, after Princeton. There will be a ceremonial lei cutting at 9 a.m. by Mayor Sandra Haimoff and store manager (called "Captain") Linda Moffa, who comes from the Trader Joe's in Florham Park. There will be free prizes, taste samples, face painting and live musicl throughout the day. Trader Joe's is also accepting applications on its Web site. According to Trader Joe's spokeswoman, Alison Mochizuki, more than 70 percent of the employees hired are locals. -- Jean-Pierre Mestanza

In response, a number of U.S. servicemen wrote in with their own stories about education as an effective counterinsurgency measure. One of the most detailed came from Lt. Col. Michael Fenzel. This week, A. O. Scott looks at Sidney Lumet's 1982 film "The Verdict." It follows a tarnished lawyer (Paul Newman) who seeks to redeem his reputation by winning a malpractice case. The standard courtroom drama story is given a dark twist with a screenplay by David Mamet. "The Verdict," Mr. Scott says, "leaves you with the sense that justice can prevail, but when it does, it's too little, too late, and it can't compensate for the harm that's already been done." Please share your thoughts on "The Verdict" and other favorite courtroom dramas.

The AMC show "Mad Men" certainly seems to have an affinity for the travel industry. Last year's plotline involved an attempt by the Sterling Cooper agency to win an airline's lucrative business. This year, the famed hotelier, Conrad Hilton, turns up as a key character - one who approaches Don Draper about taking Hilton Hotels on as an account and then slowly insinuates himself into the adman's life.

I have a stash of business cards that I've collected over the years at networking events, meetings, happy hours, etc. At this point, I could probably build a house out of all of the cards I've saved. I'm not typically a hoarder (well, maybe a little), but I just can't bring myself to throw them out.

We invited readers to share their stories of how they became fans of the Yankees or the Phillies, and we will highlight entries as the World Series continues. Below, Lee Barber, 48, of Leesburg, Va., writes that the Phillies' 1980 World Series victory over the Kansas City Royals, which she celebrated while attending college in Missouri, was worth the wait.

With its benefit dinner Friday night, Performa 09, the performance art biennial that gets underway in earnest Monday, definitely established a hard act to follow. Perhaps not for itself, but at least for the event planners of the world. Organized by Jennifer Rubell, the daughter of the collectors Donald and Mera Rubell and an experienced event planner herself, the evening was modestly titled "Creation." It melded installation art, happenings and performance art with various Old Testament overtones, while laying waste to the prolonged ordeal that is the benefit-dining experience.

Carl Hulse, our chief Congressional correspondent, reported just a short while ago on our sib-blog, Prescriptions, that remarks made on Monday by a North Carolina lawmaker may signal the tenor of a rumble looming when Republicans and Democrats in the House debate the health care overhaul later this week.

Morgan Stanley's agreement to lend $2.5 billion to back CF Industries Holdings' hostile bid for Terra Industries, a rival fertilizer maker, is the biggest leveraged loan commitment by a single bank this year, Bloomberg News reports.

David Nutt, a professor of pharmacology who was forced to resign on Friday as the head of an independent panel of experts set up to advise the British government on drug policy, accused Prime Minister Gordon Brown of overstating the dangers of cannabis and ecstasy to impress voters and suggested that drug laws should be written by scientists, not politicians.

Yesterday we gained an hour, thanks to the end of daylight saving time. I love this transition out of daylight saving time during the fall, but I hate the transition into daylight saving time during the spring, when we lose an hour. And new research shows there is good reason for this preference: people are much less likely to get hurt at work when they "fall backward" than when they "spring forward."

It's a scene stolen from the nightmares of New York commuters: Thanksgiving Day, the evening rush, and you're trying to catch a train for dinner in the suburbs. You make it to Grand Central Terminal with 10 minutes to spare (phew!) - but no ticket.

Catch up with the latest in downtown comedy-nerdery tonight, when WitStream, a funny-people-Twitter-aggregate, sponsors a show at Comix. (Yes, Twitter-aggregating is one part of what it takes to make it in comedy these days.) The lineup includes <b>Michael Ian Black, Michael Showalter, Morgan Murphy</b> (a writer for Jimmy Fallon), <b>Pete Holmes</b> and more. If you’re truly humor-besotted, check out Leo Allen’s show Whiplash at the UCB afterward; it’s where all the local talent and executives who love them go.

To celebrate Día de los Muertos — the Mexican Day of the Dead (today is All Souls Day) — head to St. Mark’s Church-in-the-Bowery for music and other performances. Or to Mayahuel, the dark, sexy tequila bar, for a special menu of all-you-drink cocktails and small plates for $50. Bring a date.

Pimps, prostitutes, crackheads, criminals and weirdos — that’s what tonight’s readings have in common. At Bluestockings, Eric Ferrara, a fourth-generation New Yorker, shares his “Guide to Gangsters, Murderers and Weirdos of New York’s Lower East Side,” about the origins of mafiosos like Bugsy Siegel. And at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square, Augusten Burroughs offers his tales of perverse holiday woe in “You Better Not Cry: Stories for Christmas.” Thanksgiving’s right around the corner, after all.

After a long-running proxy battle, the activist shareholder Warren Lichtenstein said Monday that his hedge fund, Steel Partners II, had amassed enough support to remove Adaptec's chief executive, Sundi Sundaresh, from the board of the data storage company.

A fire sale of artwork that once belonged to Lehman Brothers, the investment services company whose bankruptcy in September 2008 augured months of worldwide economic turmoil, raised $1.35 million at an auction Sunday, which is, at least, a start toward the billions in debt that the company left behind. In a news release, the auction house Freeman's, which conducted the sale in Philadelphia, said that all of the 280 lots offered, consisting of works from Lehman Brothers offices in New York, Massachusetts and Delaware, were sold. Among the top sellers were a Roy Lichtenstein "I Love Liberty" print, which sold for $49,000; a set of 10 prints by Louis Lozowick that sold for $94,000; and a Georges Schreiber painting of the Financial District, which once hung in the company's New York boardroom, for $20,000. (All sales figures include a 25 percent buyer's premium on the first $20,000 hammer price and an additional 20 percent on the balance.) Freeman's plans future sales of Lehman Brothers artworks on Dec. 6 and Feb. 12.

UTRECHT | One of the great exports of Utrecht, a historic city well worth a day trip from Amsterdam, is a cartoon character: the Dick Bruna-drawn Nijntje the Rabbit. She's known as Miffy in English, and in Utrecht a statue stands in a square named after her, the Nijntjepleintje.

Over at the Momversation this week, Heather Armstrong of Dooce.com is leading a candid talk about depression. She has been extremely open over the years about the postpartum emotional crash that led her to a psychiatric hospital. Her fellow bloggers on the video - Alice Bradley, of finslippy.com, Mindy Roberts of themommyblog.net and Danny Evans of DadGoneMad.com - have been somewhat less public about their suffering, and their conversation about what Bradley calls "being filled with crushing despair" is a moving one.

A new study from PointCarbon, a carbon market research firm, indicates that ExxonMobil would face an annual outlay of $5.9 billion to purchase carbon allowances under the terms of the Kerry-Boxer cap-and-trade bill, while electricity giants like Exelon and Pacific Gas and Electric would emerge as financial winners, because they rely heavily on diversified, low-emission fleets that include nuclear reactors and hydro dams.

In the United States, "30 Rock" is regarded as a rapid-fire comedy whose ratings haven't yet caught up with its awards and critical accolades. In Germany, it's just another show that nobody watches. On Sunday night, the debut showing of "30 Rock" on the German channel ZDFNeo earned a 0.0 rating, The Hollywood Reporter said, meaning it was watched by fewer than 5,000 people. The channel, which is owned by the German broadcaster ZDF, was recently given a makeover in an attempt to attract more young male viewers, and its showings of "30 Rock" (along with series like "Miami Vice" and "The Sentinel") were central to that mission. It was unclear if viewers there would be more or less receptive to a "30 Rock" episode in which Liz Lemon accidentally sells NBC to a group of German investors.

Despite some recent activity, the figures for mergers and acquisitions in October are not particularly good. According to Dealogic, M.&A. activity in the United States was down 46 percent from September to October. In their new book "Soccernomics," to be published in the United States on Tuesday, the author Simon Kuper and the economist Stefan Szymanski do for soccer what "Moneyball" did for baseball. By the time a local council in south London completed its vote on the preservation of a mural by the street artist Banksy, the majority decision to keep the artwork was a moot point: vandals had already covered the mural in graffiti. BBC News reported that 93 percent of the 250 local residents who participated in the vote, which ended on Saturday, said that the Sutton Council should keep the work: a painting of a punk with spiky hair trying to assemble a slogan from the contents of an Ikea-style box, which appeared on a wall earlier this fall. Though the council generally has a zero-tolerance policy on graffiti, Councilor Colin Hall told the BBC: "We believe in democracy and wanted local people to decide what should happen to the Banksy. Sadly someone decided to take it into their own hands." He added: "The image actually criticized mindless graffiti so perhaps it isn't surprising that the sort of people who do that sort of thing should attack it."

Mate selection. Perhaps the most difficult choice that we have to make in our lives: one that affects our future happiness more than any other. What young person has not had fantasies of finding his or her perfect life-partner? How does that translate into making a perfect or even good choice amongst the real potential mates available to you? Wouldn't it be nice to have a technique, a magic bullet, that guaranteed you the highest probability of making your best choice?

Throughout her career, the Swedish designer Ann Sofie Back has embraced bad taste. Her ripped, stitched, tattered and generally askew aesthetic has been inspired by everything from Wildensteinesque plastic surgery to Lindsay Lohan's lack of underwear. As a result, the designer is no stranger to "worst dressed" lists. "My stuff has ended up on the Fashion Police site a few times," says Back, who recently moved back to Stockholm after 12 years in London. To pay for her style transgressions - and to boost her hometown profile - Back has introduced a new take on the guerrilla store concept: a hostage store.

The novelist and playwright Marie NDiaye became the first woman in a decade and the first black woman ever to win the Prix Goncourt, the annual literary prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. NDiaye, who is of French and Senegalese descent, was awarded the prize on Monday for her book "Trois Femmes Puissantes" ("Three Powerful Women"), a three-part novel about various characters who struggle with transitions between Europe and Africa. In an interview with Agence France-Presse, Ms. NDiaye, who is 42, said that she did not see any symbolism in her victory. "I have never thought of it in those terms: 'black woman' and 'Goncourt'. I find it impossible to see things that way," she said. The author, who was raised by her mother in Pithiviers, a town south of Paris, and did not travel to Africa until she was in her 20s, added: "I grew up in a world that was 100-percent French. My African roots don't mean much, except that people know of them because of the color of my skin and my name." The prize comes with a ceremonial award of about $15.

For its next season of Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater plans to attract audiences -- one hopes without perplexing its performers -- by staging two of the Bard's plays in repertory with the same company of actors. On Monday, the Public said that it would mount productions of "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale" that would run from June 9 through Aug. 1. Daniel Sullivan (who recently directed the Public's production of "Twelfth Night") is to direct "The Merchant of Venice," about a moneylender's notorious bargain, and Michael Greif ("Next to Normal," "Grey Gardens," "Rent") will direct "The Winter's Tale," the courtly romantic comedy containing the stage direction "Exit, pursued by a bear." The Public has previously staged repertory Shakespeare productions, including "Henry IV" Parts I and II in 1991, and a condensed version of the "Henry VI" plays and "Richard III," called "The War of the Roses," in 1971. Casting for the company that will perform "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale," including the bear, was not announced.

LONDON | In July 1961, on London's South Bank, Gustav Metzger put on a gas mask, rubber gloves and a hard hat and proceeded to spray hydrochloric acid in elaborate patterns all over three large screens of white, black and red nylon. Filmed up close, the quick melting and tearing away of fabric is beautiful, disturbing and captivating. Seen from 10 feet away, it looks like a hazmat worker messing around with tattered, ripped sheets.

It is a good thing for the N.F.L. that parity died the year before the salary cap does, or everyone would blame the absence of the cap for the parody of parity. Three undefeated teams entered the weekend, along with 11 teams that had two or fewer victories. But near the midpoint of the season, the N.F.L. took a few tentative steps toward reverting to form. What we learned from Week 8: TITANS UNSETTLED DESPITE WIN The Tennessee Titans finally won Sunday, and even if their season is beyond saving, at least Vince Young, the former third overall draft pick, may have been salvaged. The Titans have a pricey decision to make after this season about Young's future -- and the team's owner, Bud Adams, has a decision to make about Coach Jeff Fisher. After Sunday, Young's future might be brighter than Fisher's. Adams essentially ordered Fisher to start Young, who completed 15 of 18 passes for 125 yards and a touchdown. He also rushed for 30 yards on 12 carries. As much of a boost as that is for Young (Adams has always been a fan), it is an indictment of Fisher, who resisted the move and wanted to keep Kerry Collins at quarterback.

Sotheby's of London has sold a collection of racy letters written by Lord Byron, below, for $455,466, more than $150,000 above the estimate and a record price for letters by a British Romantic poet. According to BBC News, an anonymous bidder bought the 71 pages of letters and fragments, dating from 1808, which include details of an affair with a servant girl and a disparaging reference to William Wordsworth. The documents came from the library of Archibald Primrose, prime minister from 1894 to 1895. Gabriel Heaton, a Sotheby's specialist in British literature and history, told the BBC that the letters, to Byron's close friend the Rev. Francis Hodgson, ''offered a wonderful opportunity to reveal aspects of Lord Byron's character that were either unknown or long forgotten.''

Nate Robinson of the Knicks could be sidelined for up to two weeks after he sustained a sprained right ankle in the fourth quarter of Saturday's overtime loss to Philadelphia. Robinson may get X-rays on Monday. His injury probably means more playing time for Toney Douglas, one of the team's two first round selections over the summer. Douglas did not play in Saturday's loss. HARRINGTON FINED $25,000 The N.B.A. fined Al Harrington $25,000 for criticizing the referees after the Knicks' double-overtime loss to Charlotte on Oct. 30. Harrington blocked a shot by Charlotte's D. J. Augustin with 2.5 seconds left in the second overtime, but was whistled for a foul. Augustin made both free throws to seal the game for Charlotte. ''It was a block,'' Harrington said afterward. ''The ref knows it was a block, everybody knows it was a block.'' He added, ''That's a terrible call.''

The Looking Ahead column last Monday erroneously included one company among those reporting quarterly earnings last week. Liz Claiborne is scheduled to report earnings this Wednesday; it did not report them on Thursday.

Elton John, 62, has postponed more concert dates because of E. coli and influenza, Agence France-Presse reported. After canceling the final dates of his Red Piano world tour in Britain and Ireland, Mr. John delayed concerts with Billy Joel scheduled this week in Seattle and Portland, Ore., as well. The two performers had already postponed concert dates on the American leg of their tour when Mr. Joel, 60, was ordered to rest after reporting flulike symptoms and fatigue. Mr. John is reportedly recovering in a London hospital, with no word on when he might return to work.

The $33 million spent on broadcast television ads this year by Michael R. Bloomberg in the New York City mayoral race dwarfs the other candidates. He also has set a personal campaign spending record, with $85 million spent through Oct. 23. Spending breeds spending in very competitive races, like that in New Jersey between Christopher J. Christie, left, and Gov. Jon S. Corzine, right, and in Virginia between Robert F. McDonnell and R. Creigh Deeds for governor.

TAESUNG FREEDOM VILLAGE, Korean demilitarized zone -- Kim Han-seul, a fifth grader, has the most heavily armed crossing guard in the world. Each morning, his school bus picks him up at a bustling town outside the demilitarized zone that separates South and North Korea. It drives through wire fences, tank traps and military checkpoints along a road flanked by minefields.

One year after the election of President Obama, a handful of off-year political contests -- including governors' races in New Jersey and Virginia and a Congressional race in upstate New York -- offer some clues about how Americans are viewing Mr. Obama, as well as an early measure of the landscape for next year's midterm elections. But precisely what kind of clues? How much significance should be read into contests that will be determined by a small pool of voters in two states and one Congressional district?

President Obama signed into law on Friday a bill increasing the budgets of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities by $12.5 million each. The increase, passed in the House and Senate on Thursday, set the budgets for each agency at $167.5 million. ... The 59E59 Theaters will feature the playwright Alan Ayckbourn in a discussion Nov. 15 about his career and the intricacies of his writing. Details and tickets are at 59e59.org.

For Brett Favre, revenge is a dish best served with a side of denial. Favre raised his arms to celebrate another victory at Lambeau Field -- just as he had done many times over 16 seasons with the Green Bay Packers. Only this Sunday, he threw four touchdown passes to lead the Minnesota Vikings to a 38-26 victory that resonated painfully with Packer die-hards.

SALZ--Jay, on October 30, 2009 at the age of 82. Husband of the late Fran Salz; father of Richard Salz, Reading, MA and Wendy Salz, Los Angeles, CA and Jill Wolf of New York City; brother of Albert Salz and Carol Nowak. Mr. Salz is also survived by six grandchildren. Services Monday November 2, 5:30pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

American Ballet Theater has received a $500,000 matching grant from the Arison Arts Foundation, the ballet company has announced. The grant will help cover a fellowship for one dancer each year as part of a new partnership between ABT II and YoungArts, a national organization that supports 17- and 18-year-olds in the visual, literary and performing arts. Since 1996 eight American Ballet Theater dancers have been supported through the YoungArts program, Rachel Moore, the company's executive director and herself a YoungArts scholarship winner, said in a statement. ''Continued support is crucial to the future of young artists.'' The grant will also be used to support American Ballet Theater's other preprofessional programs, including the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School and apprentices in the corps de ballet.

At seven places along the New York City Marathon course, just past someone holding a large sign reading ''Professional Athlete Fluids,'' a Sunday morning's calm was briefly interrupted by chaos. The top 40 men and top 40 women in the marathon are allowed a perk that does not exist for the other 42,000 participants. They can mix their own liquid concoctions, place them in seven self-decorated bottles, hand them to race organizers the day before, and be assured that each energy boost will be waiting for them at an assigned spot on an assigned table every 5 kilometers or so.

MONDAY NIGHT FASTBALL And changeup and curve, too. When Cliff Lee shut down the Yankees in Game 1, he kept them off guard by using all three of those pitches. Now he'll try to do it again, on full rest, with the Yankees just one victory from their 27th championship. Facing him will be A. J. Burnett, who was having a bumpy postseason until he overpowered the Phillies in Game 2. In that game, Burnett relied on two pitches -- a fastball and an almost unhittable curve -- and Philadelphia was lucky to scratch out a run. This time around, Burnett will be pitching on three days' rest, which may affect his performance. After all, he's A. J., not C. C. Still, this seems to be the Yankees' year, and it would not be surprising if they find a way to get just enough runs off Lee to win. 7:57 p.m. Monday at Citizens Bank Park TV: Fox

Two avatars, Leto Yoshiro and Enchant Jacques, met in the virtual world of Second Life in 2005. They married online the same year and built a house together on an island. In real life, Leto was a film producer from Michigan, Enchant an accountant from England. In 2008, Leto died of liver failure while awaiting a transplant.

''By their nature people are talkers,'' says Breda, one of three sisters presiding over a mad, mostly tea-less tea party in ''The New Electric Ballroom,'' a comedy written and directed by the singular Irish playwright Enda Walsh that opened on Sunday night at St. Ann's Warehouse. ''You can't deny that,'' she continues in an agonized, breathless mumble. ''You can, but you'd be affirming what you're arguing against, and what would the point of that be? No point.'' This irrefutable bit of logic is among the more clear-eyed moments in this mordantly funny, weirdly transfixing play. And while the need to speak may be a natural inheritance, for some people it is much more. Breda and her sister Clara chatter away to convince themselves they are alive, but also to avoid truly living. ''There's a terrible lull in the conversation,'' Clara says with a squirm when the chatter stops. ''The sort of lull that can get you worrying about other things.'' It's an observation Samuel Beckett would surely approve.

Lincoln Center's LCT3 initiative, devoted to producing the work of new artists and developing new audiences, has filled out its 2009-10 season with the New York premiere of ''Graceland,'' by Ellen Fairey and directed by Henry Wishcamper (May 3 to 29) and the premiere of ''On the Levee,'' a musical play conceived and directed by Lear deBessonet, with a book by Marcus Gardley and music and lyrics by Todd Almond (June 14 to July 10). The works will be presented at the Duke on 42nd Street.

It may be an off year for elections, but there are still a lot of races on Tuesday. The big contests are the governors' elections in New Jersey and Virginia, but there will be voting for mayors in several big cities, some states have referendums or ballot initiatives and there are a couple of vacant Congressional seats to be filled. In New Jersey, the race between Gov. Jon S. Corzine and Christopher J. Christie, his Republican challenger, appears to be very tight, according to the latest polls. When an independent candidate, Christopher J. Daggett, is included, he receives 8 percent to 20 percent of the support of likely voters. All differences between Mr. Corzine and Mr. Christie fall within each poll's margin of sampling error of plus or minus three or four percentage points on each candidate.

9 P.M. (13, 49) CIVILIAN CONSERVATION CORPS In March 1933, just two months into his first term, President Franklin D. Roosevelt sent legislation to Congress intended to provide relief for one in four unemployed American workers through the conservation of natural resources. Over the next decade more than three million young men went to work in the nation's forests and parks, planting trees, building flood barriers, fighting fires and maintaining roads and trails. Corps workers lived like enlisted military personnel in camps and received $30 per month, $25 of which they were required to send to their families. This ''American Experience'' presentation, above, combines archival images with personal accounts from corps veterans to tell the story of this New Deal experiment. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA The cast of ''Ally McBeal'' reunites.

Charlize Theron, below, will join the British actor Tom Hardy in the fourth installment of the ''Mad Max'' post-apocalyptic franchise, according to Variety. Filming is scheduled to begin in August in Australia, but whether Mel Gibson, who played the title character in the first three films, will return or if Mr. Hardy will take over as Max is unclear. And the film's producer-director, George Miller, who is also serving as screenwriter, is keeping details of the script close to the leather vest. ... Anthony Hopkins has been cast in Kenneth Branagh's ''Thor,'' the film adaptation of the Marvel comic book, Variety reported. Marvel Studios expects to begin production in January, with Mr. Hopkins playing Odin, Thor's father; Natalie Portman as Thor's beloved, Jane Foster; and Chris Hemsworth in the title role.

Loving father of two children, Gwen Lichtstein and Stephen Camhi, a son-in-law, Stephen Lichtstein, a daughter-in-law, Dr. Judith Silverman, four grandchildren, Jeffrey Lichtstein and his wife Stefanie, Jacqueline Smith and her husband William, Michael Camhi and Rachel Camhi, and three great-grandchildren, Samantha and Michelle Lichtstein and Anders Smith. Donations to the Sephardic Nursing Home and Rehabilitation Center, 2266 Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11214.

The choice of jersey had not been entirely Meb Keflezighi's, but in one triumphant surge in Central Park on Sunday, he became the perfect person to be wearing a U.S.A. shirt at the New York City Marathon. He was one of several Americans striving to break the 27-year men's drought in the race, but he represented the American dream more than any of them. A child immigrant from war-torn Eritrea, and one of 11 siblings in a village with no electricity, Keflezighi traveled an arduous journey to the finish line here and carried decades of American hopes with him.

The $33 million spent on broadcast television ads this year by Michael R. Bloomberg in the New York City mayoral race dwarfs the other candidates. He also has set a personal campaign spending record, with $85 million spent through Oct. 23. Spending breeds spending in very competitive races, like that in New Jersey between Christopher J. Christie, left, and Gov. Jon S. Corzine, right, and in Virginia between Robert F. McDonnell and R. Creigh Deeds for governor.
Philadelphia's big sports day came and went Sunday, and with it, most likely, the Phillies' hopes of repeating as World Series champions.

NEWBLATT--Marilyn. We will treasure your fierce friendship, loyalty and love. We will miss your exuberance and joy. We honor your spirit and we were blessed to know you. Nancy, Allan, Kimberly and Solar

GRANOFF--Jeannette, age 94, passed away on November 1, 2009. Born in Brooklyn, the beloved daughter of the late Martha and Gabriel Trum. Devoted wife to the love of her life, the late N. Henry Granoff. Adored mother of Paul D. Granoff MD, Dan M. Granoff MD and Gary C. Granoff, Esq. Cherished mother-in-law to Leslie and Suzanne. Dearly loved grandmother to seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Survived by her sister Beatrice Trum Hunter (Dearing NH). Loved by her devoted caregiver, Lunette Hamilton. Jeannette Granoff graduated summa cum laude from Brooklyn College at age 20, taught French and, later, worked as a librarian. Married her high school sweetheart, Henry in 1935 and together they embarked on a journey of 67 beautiful years. Jeannette was involved in charities in New York, Palm Beach, and Israel. She was interested in languages, art, opera, ballet, golf and traveling. Warmly loved and admired by all who knew her, she will be remembered for her warmth, beauty, and caring nature. Funeral services will be private.

Inside the imposing British Crown Court here, Phillipa Curtis, 22, and her parents cried as she was remanded for 21 months to a high-security women's prison, for killing someone much like herself. The victim was Victoria McBryde, an up-and-coming university-trained fashion designer. Ms. Curtis had plowed her Peugeot into the rear end of Ms. McBryde's neon yellow Fiat, which had broken down on the A40 Motorway, killing Ms. McBryde, 24, instantly.

The Israeli police said Sunday that they had arrested a 37-year-old American immigrant, a West Bank settler, and charged him in an array of killings and terrorist attacks over the last 12 years, including the murders of two Palestinians, the bombing of a leftist Israeli professor's home and the maiming of a 15-year-old boy who belongs to a community of Jews who believe in Jesus. The suspect, Jack Teitel, a father of four and a computer technician and Web site designer, was born in Florida, the son of a military dentist. He went back and forth between Israel and the United States starting in the 1990s, immigrating here in 2000. His parents followed a year later and live in a different West Bank settlement.

In the weeks before the New York City Marathon, as he grappled with shin splints and a sore Achilles' tendon, the actor Edward Norton fixated on a mantra he had plucked from a book by the Japanese author Haruki Murakami: ''Pain is inevitable,'' the passage reads. ''Suffering is optional.''

FREEMAN--Stanley, on October 30, 2009. Died peacefully with his friend by his side. Born in New York City, he studied at Parsons and went on to be a creative director of advertising for many years. He enjoyed his art and his friends. Cherished brother of Edith Packard and uncle to Dr. William Packard. He will be gratefully missed.

HASEN--George Milton, on October 31, 2009 in Burlington, VT. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte Binger Hasen, loving father of Louisa Mattson, John Hasen and Elizabeth Hasen. Also survived by four grandchildren and his brother, John E. Hasen. Born in San Jose, CA, he graduated from Berkeley and Harvard Law School, and served as Lieutenant JG in the Navy in WWII. A partner at Morgan, Lewis and Bockius, he also chaired the New York City Bar Association's Civil Rights Committee. He served as Senior Warden and Superintendent of The Day School at Church of the Heavenly Rest. Donations in his memory to Greensboro Free Library, Greensboro, VT, 05841 would be appreciated. A memorial service will be held in Greensboro next summer.

With the White House's reluctant embrace on Sunday of Hamid Karzai as the winner of Afghanistan's suddenly moot presidential runoff, President Obama now faces a new complication: enabling a badly tarnished partner to regain enough legitimacy to help the United States find the way out of an eight-year-old war. It will not be easy. As the evidence mounted in late summer that Mr. Karzai's forces had sought to win re-election through widespread fraud to defeat his main challenger, Abdullah Abdullah, administration officials made no secret of their disgust. How do you consider sending tens of thousands of additional American troops, they asked in meetings in the White House, to prop up an Afghan government regarded as illegitimate by many of its own people?

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.04 percent. There are all sorts of obstacles to moving the nation's health care system, choking on paper records, into the computer age. The cost and complexity of making the transition are daunting, though the government's $19 billion in incentives for doctors and hospitals to adopt electronic health records should help. But the desired benefits of digital health records -- better care and reduced spending -- will not really materialize unless information flows seamlessly and securely among labs, clinics, hospitals, doctors' offices and patients. General Electric's big health care division is introducing on Thursday a new unit, eHealth, to pursue the business opportunity presented by this challenge.

Next month, the nine million American owners of Sony's PlayStation 3 game consoles will have another entertainment option available: streaming movies and TV shows from Netflix. The long-awaited announcement gives Netflix another distribution channel for its ''Watch Instantly'' service, which is already available via the Microsoft Xbox 360, a variety of Blu-ray players and HDTVs, TiVo, and the Roku box. (And Netflix streaming content can already be viewed via PS3 using third-party software like PlayOn.)

When Alberto Salazar crossed the finish line to win his third straight New York City Marathon 27 years ago, he did not think about who was coming behind him. He just assumed that runners from the United States would always be there -- until the sound of their footsteps grew fainter and fainter year after year.

SCHOENBACH--Morton J.,81, of Hewlett, NY died peacefully at home surrounded by family on Sunday, November 1 after a valiant battle with melanoma. Born June 5, 1928 to Sophia (nee Wolf) and Louis Schoenbach, Morty was a 1945 graduate of the Bronx High School of Science and a 1949 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. Morty was a passionate golfer and enjoyed an almost 60 year career as an architect and general contractor most recently as President of M&R Schoenbach and formerly of Edward Robbins and Co. He will be sorely missed and mourned by his beloved wife of 55 years, Francine, his children Michael and Marci of Westfield, NJ, Robert and Gail of Warren, NJ, his sister Jill Schoenbach of NYC and his six grandchildren, Billy, Dana, Elizabeth, Eric, Jamie and Jake. Services will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel 1450 Broadway, Hewlett NY. 516-295-3100 on Tuesday, November 3 at 11:30am. The family will be receiving visitors, please call the Chapel for details. Donations in his memory may be directed to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital 1275 York Ave., NYC 10021 where Morty received stellar care.

MARGOLIES--Gertrude. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Gertrude Margolies, Trustee and Honorary Trustee for the past 40 years, President Emeritus (1987-1988), staunch benefactor and friend. Her influence on the Foundation - from concept to present research and educational programs - is unequalled. She was a sophisticated ally with insight, conviction and tenacity - a pragmatist whose dedicated efforts were fundamental in advancing and expanding chemotherapy research and clinical science for the control, cure, and prevention of cancer through innovated medical therapies. Her commitment, driving force, loyalty and loving spirit will be remembered always with affection and gratitude. Barry Richter, President Chemotherapy Foundation

Accounts United Parcel Service, Atlanta, chose Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, part of WPP, to handle its worldwide account, with spending estimated at $200 million. The assignment had been divided among various agencies that included the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, for work in the United States, and several that are part of another Interpublic unit, the McCann Worldgroup, for work in other countries.

Cisco, the computer networking giant, has spent the last decade acquiring rivals and buying back stock. It's time to acknowledge that this strategy isn't working. Investors who bought Cisco's shares a decade ago have received no return on their investment. Results this week should give Cisco another chance to profess its optimism. Technology markets are rebounding. And John Chambers, Cisco's chief executive, will talk about the 26 new product areas that he thinks can each generate $1 billion in sales in the near term.

Everything was upside down. The favored Kenyan and the preferred American were both out of contention. And now an afterthought, a last-second replacement, was at the front of the New York City Marathon. Robert Cheruiyot of Kenya had won the Boston Marathon four times and Chicago once, but he was 31, and many thought he had too many miles in his legs for another important victory. Plus, he was not fully recovered from the world championships in August in Berlin. Even his own coach did not give him much of a chance on Sunday.
