Appreciation to Preston Tisch Brain Tumor Center at Duke University.

My review this week is of a newish French place on Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street called Le Relais de Venise L'Entrecôte. It's the first American outpost of a Paris institution (some would say tourist trap) that serves nothing but salad and steak frites. This is its great charm. The restaurant fights mightily against the tyranny of choice that so infects the world of restaurants in New York City. As David Carr - a media monster and Diner's Journal consigliere - said in the place one night, leaning back in his chair and just getting started on the subject: "There are zero conversational hideyholes in this menu. I'm glad we're friends and have something to talk about." Have you been to the restaurant? Do you want to go? Tell us what you think below. Keep it clean. There are children present.

Kathy Leventhal and Jerry Ryan, the Democrat incumbents, were re-elected to the Maplewood Township Committee tonight, according to their Twitter feed. The count, according to their tweets, was Ms. Leventhal 4,771, Mr. Ryan 4,712, Bob Perez 1,980, and Bart Albini 1,912. With polls closing at 8 p.m., the pair updated the vote count 65 times via Twitter, sometimes every three minutes. (The results are in line with preliminary results posted by the Essex County Clerk.) With all 21 districts reporting, Gov. Jon S. Corzine took Maplewood handily, with 5,497 votes,to Republican challenger Chris Christie's 1,565; 407 votes went to Chris Daggett, the independent candidate. Stay tuned for results from Millburn. --Tina Kelley

There will be dual hosts at the next Academy Awards. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences just announced that Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin will co-host the event.

Layoffs have begun at Time Inc. Approximately 15 to 20 sales and marketing employees were dismissed from Time Inc.'s news group tonight, largely from Sports Illustrated, according to a Time Inc. executive who asked not to be named as the company had not given authorization to discuss the matter.

Cru is lowering prices on its famous wine list by 30 percent across the board, said Robert Bohr, a partner in the restaurant. The prices will be cut by the end the week. And in two weeks the restaurant will have a menu from its new chef, Todd Macdonald.

Despite Robert Capa's statement that the "war photographer's most fervent wish is for unemployment," war continues to serve as a proving ground. Diving into the line of fire, photographers reveal its ravages. And many become casualties of the stark brutality of the conflicts.

Struggling to finish their big health care legislation, House Democratic leaders signaled Tuesday that they were prepared to make several changes to the bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who had threatened to block it.

Chrysler is scheduled to detail its five-year sales plan Wednesday during a six-hour conference call with reporters. (Will bathroom breaks be permitted?) The automaker is getting ready to reinvent itself with a fresh look, and the first tweak could come in the form of a sleek new logo.
A duplex apartment in Krakow's city center is on the market for 1.4 million Polish zloty ($478,000).
Getting TV news on your phone is a tricky business, as most mobile broadcastrs require a Wi-Fi connection. That's not really mobile TV, that's hot spot TV.

The My Pictures folder on my Mac notebook holds a whopping 47.39 gigabytes of images. It's nice to have so many photos of people, places and trips -- except for the unfortunate fact that they consume about one quarter of my total hard drive space. And I am running very short on storage these days.

The House on Tuesday approved a nonbinding resolution rebuking a United Nations report on last winter's conflict in Gaza, after architects of both the U.N. report and the House resolution recently criticized the other's work as inaccurate.

Update | 6:34 p.m. General Motors has confirmed that it will keep Opel and restructure the business itself, reports The Times's Bill Vlasic. "This was deemed to be the most stable and least costly approach for securing Opel/Vauxhall's long-term future," Fritz Henderson, G.M.'s chief executive, said in a statement issued Tuesday evening.

Update | 5:57 p.m. The new board of General Motors reversed course late Tuesday afternoon on the anticipated sale of the Opel division in Europe and decided that G.M. would retain the business and restructure Opel itself.
Cliff Freeman & Partners, one of the most successful New York advertising agencies of the 1980s and 1990s, is no more.

A remarkable conclave of leading figures from nine of the world's major religions is under way at Windsor Castle in Britain, under the auspices of Prince Philip and the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon. Called "Many Heavens, One Earth," the meeting is intended to generate commitments for actions by religious organizations, congregants and countries that could reduce emissions of greenhouse gases or otherwise limit the human impact on the environment.
Voters are voting today, and most pundits are punditing about what the races mean, especially what the big three -- in New Jersey, Virginia and upstate New York -- will say about Obama.

The next tenant for Broadway's Nederlander Theater was announced late Tuesday afternoon: The new musical "Million Dollar Quartet," based on a 1956 recording session that brought together Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, and Elvis Presley.

One year ago, we asked NYTimes.com readers for a single word to describe their mood about the presidential election. The response was overwhelming (73,400 words) and varied widely, with "hopeful" and "anxious" as the top choices.

Last Thursday's print and online article on tech solutions for older adults struck a chord with many readers, a number of whom wrote that the suggestions proved helpful in their quest to get their parents connected to the Internet.

But the Italian collective of Alterazioni Video and Ragnar Kjartansson offered something at least nominally classifiable in its free performance for a packed audience at Performance Space 122 on Monday evening: a concert. Specifically, "Symphony n. 1," billed as "a live and multimedia piece based on joy, infinite profound joy."

After Game 3, Hamels said, "I can't wait for it to end. It's been mentally draining." And all sorts of people - including, perhaps, his teammate Brett Myers - have interpreted that as Hamels quitting on the season.

At the Manhattan training office of the Board of Elections, judges on Tuesday heard very few cases by voters unable to vote at their polling place.
There were plenty of people in the Manhattan training office of the New York City Board of Elections. There was lots of chatting and reading of newspapers and eating of chips and playing of Scrabble.

On Tuesday in The Hague, my colleague Marlise Simons reports, the wartime leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, finally appeared at his trial -- but only "to argue once again that he needed more time to prepare his defense against a list of grave charges, including genocide."

After a difficult start to the season, A.C. Milan has begun to climb the Italian Serie A table and earn impressive results in Europe, restoring the faith of the Rossoneri supporters and the confidence of the players.

My colleague Dwight Garner kicked off this blog two and a half years ago with a slide show of advertisements that he'd discovered in old copies of the Book Review. After that, his posts on vintage book ads became a semi-regular feature in Paper Cuts. And today his book on the subject hits stores: "Read Me: A Century of Classic American Book Advertisements."
AT&T, the giant company with $124 billion in annual sales, has filed a federal lawsuit against its rival, Verizon. The issue: coloring, of the sort that you do in kindergarten.

Today's show opens with the tangled mess of a deadly train crash in Pakistan (Slide 1). In neighboring Afghanistan, American troops rushed for cover in the Pech Valley of Kunar Province amid an ambush by Taliban fighters (Slides 2 and 3). Back in the United States, public officials joined their constituents at the polls in New York (Slides 10 and 11), New Jersey (Slide 12) and elsewhere. And we end the presentation with the puzzling case of hair loss among two bears at a zoo in Germany (Slide 14).

In my article today about Freecreditreport.com and its credit monitoring service, I told of how the Federal Trade Commission had been trying for years to get the company to improve its disclosures. The commission (and, it turns out, many New York Times readers who commented on the article) believe that the company doesn't make it clear enough that before you get your free credit report from the site, you first have to sign up for the monitoring service at $14.95 a month.

Baghdad: To get another perspective on the debate about the reliability of the American military's M-16 assault rifle, we asked some Iraqi soldiers in Baghdad. They have recently been issued M-16s to replace their old AK-47s.

The magazine Time Out Kids this month is all about sex and your children. Called "A Comprehensive Guide for Progressive Sex Ed for Kids 12 and Under," it starts with the assumption that we all want to raise children who will be so comfortable with their sexuality that they won't need how-to-guides like this one.

Warren E. Buffett's investments in railroads are relatively recent. In fact, it was not until 2006 that Mr. Buffett's holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, began building a stake in the industry. Despite the economic downturn, Mr. Buffett continued to build his position in many of the major railroads in the United States - concentrating most of his investment in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, which he agreed to acquired fully on Tuesday for $26 billion in cash and stock.

In 1914, after falling out of favor with Freud, C.J. Jung lost his mind. Some scholars say he lost it by design, cultivating a psychic crisis to plumb the depths of his unconscious. The "Red Book," an illustrated manual of the Swiss shrink's inner world, is the product of all that plumbing.

Former Vice-President Al Gore is both an advocate of measures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and a prominent investor in green technology. In his role as a partner at Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Mr. Gore is in a position to hear from entrepreneurs coming up with ideas to solve the very issues that he has helped to identify.

Into U.S. Speedskating's bleak financial picture, a hero appeared from out of the blue. About a week ago, Stephen Colbert, host of Comedy Central's "Colbert Report," read about the team losing its major sponsor when the Dutch bank DSB went bankrupt. That left a $300,000 hole in U.S. Speedskating's budget just a few months before the Olympics.

In the world of political blogs, today's most important election is the one being played out in New York's 23rd Congressional District. It's probably no exaggeration to say that this is the race that belongs to the blogs and to the Internet more than any other taking place around the country today.

How quick is Spurs guard Manu Ginobili? Well, now we know he's quick enough to swat a bat out of midair. On Saturday night the Spurs-Kings game had just been delayed for the second time because of a bat swooping across the floor when Ginobili slapped the bat out of midair, picked it up and handed it to an arena worker for disposal. The video of the incident has become an Internet hit and PETA weighed in with its displeasure.

In this lesson, students consider a proposal to build more schools in Afghanistan rather than sending more troops to secure the struggling nation, then conduct research and present their policy recommendations in a debate.

Viewers may have leaped intermittently to their feet at the finale of "Symphony n.1" at Performance Space 122 on Monday night, but it was mostly to fend off dozens of careering soccer balls. Part of Performa 09, the performance art biennial, the piece was a collaboration between the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson and Alterazioni Video, an Italian collective. Mr. Kjartansson was present only on video while he continues to represent Iceland in an extended painting performance at the Venice Biennale. The Alterazionistas turned out to be five young men wearing tuxedoes of erratic fit.

Frédéric Malle's new Upper East Side store - his first free-standing location in the states - is much like his fragrances: refined and multilayered. Nestled in a former doctor's office at 898 Madison Avenue, the jewel-box boutique was designed by the French architect Patrick Naggar, who drew inspiration from the building's storied Art Deco exterior. Malle first spotted 898 Madison while studying art at New York University 25 years ago. "I've always loved the swirling facade," he says. "It's reminiscent of Hoffmann's Viennese pavilion." Alongside 1930s French art, objets and furniture from Malle's own collection (including a desk and chairs his grandfather commissioned from the atelier of Jules Leleu) are elements common to all of the perfumer's shops, including futuristic-looking smelling columns, refrigerated display cases, photographs of his "noses" and bookshelves containing Malle's archive of 18 fragrances. Also available: his new home collection, comprised of candles, rubber incense (sheets of recyclable rubber infused with scent) and the Fleur Mécanique, a red-cube wonder that diffuses the aroma of fresh flowers into the air. A specially designed venting system ensures that shoppers don't experience olfactory overload.Editions de Parfums Frédéric Malle, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941.

The notion that parents cherish all their children equally - or at least say they do - is so entrenched in our culture that colleagues warned Karl Pillemer, a gerontologist at Cornell University embarking on the first of many studies of family favoritism, that his research would prove futile. No mother, they insisted, would admit to caring more for one son or daughter than another.

President Obama's budget director said in a speech on Tuesday that the White House economic team is considering "a range of options" so the president can keep his promise to reduce federal budget deficits by the end of his term to half of the level he inherited.

With the H1N1 pandemic raging across the nation, public health experts are voicing concern that many American workers do not receive paid sick leave - and may feel economic pressures to report to work even when they have the flu. This, public experts fear, might help spread H1N1, which is also known as swine flu.

Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer who holds the title of master of the queen's music, said that he was "delighted" after his former manager was sentenced to 18 months in prison for defrauding him of more than $800,000, The Times of London reported. Michael Arnold, who managed Mr. Davies's business affairs for more than 30 years, was arrested in 2007 and charged in October 2008 with false accounting; he admitted last year to having stolen the money, much of which is believed to have been spent on online gambling. Mr. Davies, who has been honored this year with a global series of concerts celebrating his 75th birthday, said he had stopped composing for a few weeks and had to borrow money from friends after learning of the fraud. On Monday, after the sentence was announced, he said he was glad the episode was over, adding: "I may even set it all to music. Who knows? That would be the ultimate revenge."

Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, who founded the Classical Theater of Harlem and made it a home for the likes of Samuel Beckett, Euripides, Shakespeare and Melvin Van Peebles, will leave that Off Broadway theater company this month. In a news release, Mr. Preisser, who served as its artistic director, and Mr. McElroen, who has been its executive director, said they created the Classical Theater of Harlem in 1999 to "nurture a new, young and culturally diverse theater audience, and to produce theater that truly reflects" the diversity of New York. During that time, the company has staged acclaimed productions of "Waiting for Godot," "Marat/Sade," "Medea," "King Lear" and "Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death," Mr. Van Peebles's 1971 Broadway musical. It has won several Audelco, Obie and Lucille Lortel Awards as well as a Drama Desk Award, and has featured actors like André De Shields and Wendell Pierce. In a statement, Mr. Preisser and Mr. McElroen said they were confident the company would "continue to thrive," but did not name their successors.

City Room asks readers to share what concerns them most in their neighborhood on Election Day.

In the days before the election, reporters for The New York Times went to the five boroughs to talk to people about the concerns they want City Hall to address. The issues they raised were big and small, like soaring rents, congested streets, parking tickets and a lack of garbage cans. Voters in Port Richmond said that Staten Island felt like the "forgotten borough," and they lamented the lack of public transportation options. In Flushing, Queens, residents complained about congestion and trash. And in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, there was a chorus of complaints that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is running the city like a business.

In a city of $750-per-hour lawyers and sophisticated criminals, Russell Paisley was the everyman's attorney. He roamed the halls of New York courthouses, taking on any and every type of case, often representing clients without thick pocketbooks. He was a well-respected and well-liked figure among judges, court officers, his colleagues and many others working in the city's courthouses. To them, he was one of the faces of an important, yet all too often overlooked cog in the city's criminal justice system.

You see the same thing in the poll numbers and hear it in water cooler conversations.

Someday, as the movie and television series predicts, the Terminator robots will become powerful enough to reduce the world to a pile of scrap metal and ash. But for now, they just need new owners. Variety reported that the Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the "Terminator" movies and related assets, plans to sell the franchise at an auction in January as it goes through bankruptcy. When Halcyon purchased the "Terminator" property for $30 million in 2007, it became the latest in a series of owners that previously included the producer Gale Anne Hurd and the now-defunct production company Carolco. Though the latest entry in the film series, "Terminator: Salvation," grossed $369 million worldwide on budget of $200 million, Halcyon filed suit in August against a hedge fund that had provided the money to buy the series rights, saying that a backer at the fund engaged in fraudulent dealings, and filed for Chapter 11 in September. The company's founders, Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek, told a bankruptcy court that the "Terminator" franchise was worth $70 million. In a satirical blog post, Joss Whedon, the creator of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," said he would pay $10,000 for the series, proposing such new ideas as a "Terminator of the Rings" fantasy film and a "Terminator" musical.

When Dolphins Coach Tony Sparano decided to go for a 2-point conversion after Miami took a 30-19 lead against the Jets on Sunday, it didn't seem to make sense. With 8:48 left, an extra point would have forced the Jets to score two touchdowns to take the lead. When Miami failed to convert, the Jets had the chance to tie the score with one touchdown (with a 2-point conversion) and a field goal.

An eclectic roster of artists and entertainment industry figures were named to the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the White House announced on Monday evening. Among the 25 people who were named by President Obama as members to the committee were the talent agent Bryan Lourd, the managing director and co-chairman of Creative Artists Agency; the actors Sarah Jessica Parker and Edward Norton; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma; and Teresa Heinz Kerry, the philanthropist and wife of Senator John Kerry. Also named were the actors Kerry Washington, Forest Whitaker and Alfre Woodard; the director George C. Wolfe; Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue magazine; Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer; and the architect Thom Mayne. In September, the committee, which works with federal cultural agencies and in the private and public sectors to further the White House's cultural objectives, named George Stevens Jr. and Margo Lion its co-chairs and Mary Schmidt Campbell its vice chairwoman.

Al Gore's new book finds the core of the climate challenge, and solutions, in the human brain.

Former Vice President Al Gore's third book centering on global warming is out. Titled "Our Choice: A Plan to Solve the Climate Crisis," it centers on the same mantra at the core of his message for years now - that the only missing link holding back action is political will. The book is mainly a heavily illustrated guide to the technologies and policies that could, in Mr. Gore's view, limit climate dangers. Nuclear is largely out, capturing and burying carbon dioxide is somewhat in. Gains in energy efficiency are a vital stepping stone, he says, along with vastly expanded deployment of renewable energy sources and improved storage and grid components to make sure the power is available where and when it's needed.

Why credit freezes may help protect against identity theft better and more cheaply than credit monitoring and other services.
In Tuesday's paper, I wrote about FreeCreditReport.com and its credit monitoring service. Several critics and consumers see its up-to-the-minute reports on changes in your credit report as overkill.

ABC, already the network of "Lost" and "FlashForward," adds another speculative drama to its schedule with "V" (8 p.m.), an updated version of the 1980s show about allegedly friendly aliens who appear in the sky over earth's major cities. In a concession to the high cost of interstellar fuel, they bring 29 ships this time, instead of 50 as they did in the original.

"I went to see Madonna's dress rehearsal at the O2 arena in London. It was so boring because she didn't make any mistakes," announced Casey Spooner, one part of the electroclash (remember that?) duo Fischerspooner onstage at MoMA on Sunday evening as part of Performa 2009. "Between the Worlds," the group's three-hour performance supporting their newest album, "Entertainment," celebrated the imperfections and rawness of a dress rehearsal. The audience literally entered through the back stage, getting a close-up of the dancers shimmying into their different D.I.Y. showgirl outfits: leotards accessorized with colorful knee pads, ripped-up gowns and silver running suits that looked liked they were issued from NASA.But it was Spooner who stole the show with his getups - from corsets to Kabuki - and his snarky running commentary. The singer arrived onstage in a bolero jacket and slicked back platinum hair - for a band that seems stuck in the '80s, this seemed to be a subtle homage to Adam Ant. As he serpentined through his dancers, a veritable hall of mirrors and racks of clothes, he faced the room full of arty hipsters as if he were making his debut to a crowd of 50,000 at the Meadowlands. In fact, the whole performance, snafus and all, was about superstardom. There was the de rigueur talk of the current queen of all things pop, Lady Gaga, and of course the former king of pop, Michael Jackson - at one point Spooner changed into a silver sequined suit and black hat, looking like he stepped out of the "This Is It" documentary.

I just celebrated my 30th anniversary. One wife, three kids, 10 business start-ups, five business successes, five business misfires. I started my company the year before I got married, right out of school. I have come to realize over the years that I have not had a normal life. That's because I am not normal; I am an entrepreneur.

By the time a council in South London completed its vote on the preservation of a mural by the street artist Banksy, the decision to keep the artwork was beside the point: vandals had already covered the mural in graffiti. BBC News reported that 93 percent of the 250 local residents who participated in the vote, which ended on Saturday, said that the Sutton Council should keep the work that appeared on a wall this fall: a painting of a punk with spiky hair trying to assemble a slogan from the contents of a box branded with an Ikea-like name. Though the council generally has a zero-tolerance policy on graffiti, Councilor Colin Hall told the BBC: “We believe in democracy and wanted local people to decide what should happen to the Banksy. Sadly someone decided to take it into their own hands.” He added: “The image actually criticized mindless graffiti, so perhaps it isn’t surprising that the sort of people who do that sort of thing should attack it.”.

A fire sale of artwork that once belonged to Lehman Brothers, the investment services company whose bankruptcy in September 2008 augured months of worldwide economic turmoil, raised $1.35 million at an auction on Sunday, which is, at least, a start toward the billions in debt that the company left behind. In a news release the auction house Freeman’s, which conducted the sale, top right, in Philadelphia, said that all 280 lots offered, consisting of works from Lehman Brothers offices in New York, Massachusetts and Delaware, were sold. Among the top sellers were a Roy Lichtenstein “I Love Liberty” print, which brought $49,000; a set of 10 prints by Louis Lozowick, which went for $94,000; and a Georges Schreiber painting of Manhattan’s financial district for $20,000. (All sales figures include a 25 percent buyer’s premium on the first $20,000 of the hammer price and an additional 20 percent on the balance.) Freeman’s plans future sales of Lehman Brothers artworks on Dec. 6 and Feb. 12.

The New York Public Library said on Monday that it was acquiring the papers of the author E. Annie Proulx, whose works include “The Shipping News” and “Brokeback Mountain,” and that the writer and artist Hilary Knight, who illustrated the “Eloise” series of children’s books, had donated his papers to the library as well. The announcement was to be made officially at the 2009 Library Lions gala, which was paying tribute on Monday night to Ms. Proulx and Mr. Knight, as well as David Smith, a reference librarian; Julia Chang, its supervising librarian for children’s programs; and Janice Moore-Smith, a career specialist at the library.

The novelist and playwright Marie NDiaye became the first woman in a decade and the first black woman ever to win the Prix Goncourt, the annual literary prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. NDiaye, right, who is of French and Senegalese descent, won on Monday for her book “Trois Femmes Puissantes” (“Three Powerful Women”), a three-part novel about characters who struggle with transitions between Europe and Africa. In an interview with Agence France-Presse, Ms. NDiaye, 42, said that she did not see any symbolism in her victory. “I have never thought of it in those terms: ‘black woman’ and ‘Goncourt.’ I find it impossible to see things that way,” she said. The author, who was raised by her mother in Pithiviers, south of Paris, and did not travel to Africa until she was in her 20s, added: “I grew up in a world that was 100 percent French. My African roots don’t mean much, except that people know of them because of the color of my skin and my name.” The prize comes with a ceremonial award of about $15.

For its next season of Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater plans to attract audiences — you hope without perplexing its performers — by staging two of the author’s plays in repertory with the same company of actors. On Monday the Public said it would mount productions of “The Merchant of Venice” and “The Winter’s Tale,” to run from June 9 through Aug. 1. Daniel Sullivan, top right (who recently directed the Public’s production of “Twelfth Night”), will direct “The Merchant of Venice,” about a moneylender’s notorious bargain, and Michael Greif, right (of the Public’s “Romeo and Juliet,” as well as Broadway’s “Next to Normal”), will direct “The Winter’s Tale,” the courtly romantic comedy containing the stage direction “Exit, pursued by a bear.” The Public has previously staged Shakespeare in repertory, including “Henry IV” Parts 1 and 2 in 1991, and a condensed version of the “Henry VI” plays and “Richard III,” called “The War of the Roses,” in 1971. Casting for the company that will perform “The Merchant of Venice” and “The Winter’s Tale,” including the bear, was not announced.

The health care bill that the full House may take up later this week is much tougher on the drug industry than what the Senate is considering. And that could prove one of the challenges for lawmakers when the legislation eventually reaches a House-Senate conference committee. The Senate health committee did not address drug pricing, but the Senate Finance Committee's version includes a deal, supported by the White House, that aims to save Medicare enrollees and the government $80 billion over 10 years.

Giants defensive end Justin Tuck was blunt Monday when he expanded on comments made Sunday by middle linebacker Antonio Pierce about how the defense had a communication problem during a 40-17 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. Pierce refused to elaborate, but Tuck said he knew it was true ''when a guy scores a touchdown and guys are looking at each other like 'I thought this' and 'I thought that.' ''

Joe Torre thought his nervousness would subside, but it hounded him for hours. Needing one win with the Yankees to secure his first World Series ring in 1996, Torre remembered sitting in his office and being unable to relax. He had not been antsy about managing in the postseason, so he was surprised at how jittery he was. ''All of a sudden, you realize you have this opportunity,'' Torre said. ''It was the first time that I was actually nervous because we were on the verge of clinching.''

On television it's hard to miss the wildly popular band of slackers singing ruefully from a shabby apartment or while waiting tables in pirate regalia. The ruined credit that led to their financial misfortune might have been sparkling if only they'd tracked their status on freecreditreport.com. The Federal Trade Commission is not amused. It has long believed that the company that owns freecreditreport.com is deliberately diverting people from a government-mandated site where consumers can get free credit reports by law, and using the reports as a lure for a $14.95 monthly service that alerts subscribers to important changes in their credit status.

Throughout the Jets' locker room Monday, the answers did not match the record. The rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez sounded giddy. Linebacker Bart Scott remained defiant. Player after player expressed satisfaction with his respective individual or unit performance halfway through this season. None of that changed the bottom line, the string of uneven play, fixing one leak to find another, the 4-4 record those scattered performances produced. The Jets head into their bye week with the N.F.L.'s top-ranked rushing attack and a defense that stands second in fewest yards and fourth in fewest points allowed per game, before Monday's game.

Pauline McAreavy voted for President Obama. From the moment she first saw him two years ago, she was smitten by his speeches and sold on his promise of change. She switched parties to support him in the Iowa caucuses, donated money and opened her home to a pair of young campaign workers. But by the time she received a fund-raising letter last month from the Democratic National Committee, a sense of disappointment had set in. She returned the solicitation with a handwritten note, saying, ''Until I see some progress and he lives up to his promises in Iowa, we will not give one penny.''

In their new book ''Soccernomics,'' the author Simon Kuper and the economist Stefan Szymanski do for soccer what ''Moneyball'' did for baseball -- put the game under an analytical microscope using statistics, economics, psychology and intuition to try to transform a dogmatic sport. ''The heart of the matter is that the thinking in soccer is outdated, backward and tradition-based,'' Kuper said in a telephone interview. ''It needs a fresh look based on data. There's a new global map, with countries like the U.S. and Japan already rising. And they will continue to rise at the expense of Europe as knowledge gets dispersed. And it's happening very quickly.''

HERDER--Addie. Widely known as an "artist's artist," the Collagist, Addie Herder died on August 13. Her friends and family will gather in New York for a private celebration of her life and accomplishments on November 4. While many of her contemporaries were filling enormous canvasses with the barest minimum of pictorial adornment, she went her own way creating complex worlds and outlandish machines in spaces often no larger than 12 by 10 inches. The art critic John Russell declared her small spaces and all of the pictorial interests of a Georgione. He wrote in the New York Times: "There is something addictive about the collage constructions of Addie Herder. Once under their spell, we can't see enough of them."

GRANOFF--Jeannette, age 94, passed away on November 1, 2009. Born in Brooklyn, the beloved daughter of the late Martha and Gabriel Trum. Devoted wife to the love of her life, the late N. Henry Granoff. Adored mother of Paul D. Granoff MD, Dan M. Granoff MD and Gary C. Granoff, Esq. Cherished mother-in-law to Leslie and Suzanne. Dearly loved grandmother to seven grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Survived by her sister Beatrice Trum Hunter (Dearing NH). Loved by her devoted caregiver, Lunette Hamilton. Jeannette Granoff graduated summa cum laude from Brooklyn College at age 20, taught French and, later, worked as a librarian. Married her high school sweetheart, Henry in 1935 and together they embarked on a journey of 67 beautiful years. Jeannette was involved in charities in New York, Palm Beach, and Israel. She was interested in languages, art, opera, ballet, golf and traveling. Warmly loved and admired by all who knew her, she will be remembered for her warmth, beauty, and caring nature. Funeral services will be private.

BECTON--Henry Prentiss, former Chairman of Becton Dickinson & Co. and a lifelong singer and sailing enthusiast, died of heart failure in Blue Hill, Maine, on October 25th. He was 95 years old. Known as "Hank", he spent his professional life working for BD. During his tenure, BD went public, and grew from sales of $2.5 million to $7 billion, becoming one of the Fortune 500 and a member of the Dow Jones Sustainability and World Indexes. He served as Vice Chairman of Fairleigh Dickinson University, where the School of Nursing is named after him. He was also Vice Chairman of National Community Bank, now part of Bank of New York/ Mellon, a Founding Director of the United Way of Bergen County, a Founding Commissioner of New Jersey Public Broadcasting, President of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, and a founder of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Hank was born in Rutherford, NJ, on September 15, 1914, to Maxwell and Valerie Becton. He attended Yale University and was a member of the Yale Glee Club and the Whiffenpoofs. The Becton Center for Engineering and Applied Science at Yale bears his name. He served in the Army Air Force during WWII. He married Jean Sprague Coggan, and together they raised five children: Henry, Jean, Jeffery, Cynthia and Lizabeth. They resided for many years in Rutherford and Englewood, NJ and more recently in Vero Beach, FL. They spent their summers on the Maine coast where they loved to sail and spend time with family. In addition to his five children, Hank is survived by his fourteen grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. Contributions in his name can be sent to the Henry P. Becton School of Nursing & Allied Health, 1000 River Road, H-DH4-02, Teaneck, NJ 07666.

The U.S.S. New York reached New York City Monday morning, sweeping under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, pausing at the World Trade Center site and pushing along the Upper West Side before circling around, like a contestant in a beauty pageant, to dock in Midtown Manhattan. It was the end of an inaugural five-day voyage from Norfolk, Va., for the ship's official commissioning into the Navy fleet on Saturday, as well as an emotional ''homecoming'' for a vessel that was named for the state after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and has 7.5 tons of steel from the twin towers cast into its bow.

Unless there is a drastic change in approach, the AIDS epidemic will still be out of control on its 50th anniversary in 2031, a panel of AIDS experts predicted in an analysis being published Tuesday in the journal Health Affairs. The lead author, Robert Hecht, an economist and former policymaker at the United Nations and the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative, predicted that by that time, poor countries would need $35 billion a year -- three times what is spent now -- to treat AIDS patients, care for orphans and do prevention work.

At the heart of baseball's beauty is that anything is possible until the final out. There is no clock, no ticking away of the season. In theory, it could last forever. Nothing proves this better than the end of the World Series. ''There seems to be such a finality in baseball that doesn't exist in other sports,'' said Tim McCarver, a Fox broadcaster who has made the final out as a hitter and caught it as a catcher.

Starters became reserves, veterans were dusted off and everything was new again. The Knicks, in search of another fresh start, tried one more new look Monday night: winners. It took four games to find a combination that worked, or at least one that would not spot the opponent a 20-point lead before exerting some effort. Even before the first pitch of Game 5 on Monday, the Yankees' defining moments of the World Series had already been written. They were not so different from the hallmarks of their last championship. In 2000, the Yankees strangled the Mets from the start, capitalizing on a Game 1 base-running blunder by Timo Perez and using a 10-pitch walk by Paul O'Neill to spark a tying rally in the ninth. In Game 4 against the Phillies on Sunday, Johnny Damon created two similar moments that could also have a lasting place in Yankees lore.

A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Monday that Maher Arar, a Canadian man who claimed that American officials sent him to Syria in 2002 to be tortured, cannot sue for damages because Congress has not authorized such suits. The case has been widely watched because Mr. Arar claimed to be a victim of extraordinary rendition, the government policy of sending terrorism suspects to other countries for detention and interrogation.

Here we go again. Another study raises questions about the benefits of mammograms, and another set of confusing statements issue forth from experts. Last month, Dr. Otis Brawley, the American Cancer Society's chief medical officer, told The New York Times that the medical profession had exaggerated the benefits of cancer screening, and that if a woman refused mammography, ''I would not think badly of her, but I would like her to get it.''

The ice atop Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania has continued to retreat rapidly, declining 26 percent since 2000, scientists say in a new report. Yet the authors of the study, to be published Tuesday in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, reached no consensus on whether the melting could be attributed mainly to humanity's role in warming the global climate.

Ryanair, the Irish airline that has come to symbolize the rapid growth of low-cost European travel, said on Monday that it was considering easing back on a decade-long expansion as it struggles to keep a lid on operating costs while maintaining its rock-bottom fares. The news came as the airline -- Europe's largest by number of passengers carried -- reported a 35 percent jump in profit to 250.5 million euros ($370 million) for the three months ending on Sept. 30, a result of a 42 percent drop in oil prices from a year ago. The reduced fuel bill helped to mask a steep 17 percent decline in fares for the period, which pared revenue by almost 4 percent, to 992 million euros ($1.5 billion).

For centuries, the jailers at the Tower of London known as Beefeaters had a grim reputation. Guarding three Tudor queens who were beheaded and dispatching numerous others who had fallen afoul of royal favor to the gallows or the scaffold, they helped make the tower's bloodstained history. After about 500 years of service, the last century as a ceremonial yeomanry, that bill of attainder must now be expanded to include the more modern offense of misogyny, according to a report published in the Sun newspaper on Monday and confirmed, in part at least, by Scotland Yard.

RINZLER--Milton. The partners and staff of Hartman & Craven note with sadness the passing of our client and colleague Milton Rinzler, for over 50 years an active member of the New York State Bar and a leader in the New York real estate mortgage industry. He will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to the Rinzler family.

For all of Meb Keflezighi's preparation and strategizing, his bid to win the New York City Marathon almost came undone before he reached the starting line. As he went to dress for the race Sunday in the athletes' village at Fort Wadsworth, he found his singlet, sleeves and socks sopping wet because he had inadvertently laid them on a damp surface. No matter how well he understood his opponents or how fit he felt, starting the race in drenched gear would be a handicap.

FREEMAN--Stanley, on October 30, 2009. Died peacefully with his friend by his side. Born in New York City, he studied at Parsons and went on to be a creative director of advertising for many years. He enjoyed his art and his friends. Cherished brother of Edith Packard and uncle to Dr. William Packard. He will be gratefully missed.

BARNETT--Judith Lang, on November 1, 2009. Beloved wife of Norman Barnett and the late Hon. Irving Lang, mother of Tammy Hartel and David Lang, daughter of Regina and the late Samuel, sister of Yolanda and Ross. Services Tuesday, 12:45pm at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Public health experts worried about the spread of the H1N1 flu are raising concerns that workers who deal with the public, like waiters and child care employees, are jeopardizing others by reporting to work sick because they do not get paid for days they miss for illness. Tens of millions of people, or about 40 percent of all private-sector workers, do not receive paid sick days, and as a result many of them cannot afford to stay home when they are ill. Even some companies that provide paid sick days have policies that make it difficult to call in sick, like giving demerits each time someone misses a day.

The championship was in the Yankees' grasp on Monday night, and a reminder loomed over their heads at Citizens Bank Park before Game 5 of the World Series. As they lounged in their clubhouse, rolls of protective plastic wrap hung above their lockers. As party planners, the Yankees were prepared for a celebration. But the Philadelphia Phillies did not let it happen. They overwhelmed A. J. Burnett and survived a late Yankees charge for an 8-6 victory, sending the World Series back to the Bronx for Game 6 on Wednesday.

As the House moved toward climactic votes on legislation to remake the health care system, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday that middle-income families might be required to pay 15 percent to 18 percent of their income on insurance premiums and co-payments under the proposal. Democrats cited the figures as evidence that the legislation would reduce premiums for many low- and middle-income families who currently lack affordable coverage.

Aided by his bat and an astute apology, Alex Rodriguez is ending the baseball season not as a former steroids user but as a home run hero. In the process, he may be clearing a path forward for himself and his much-maligned sport. This may go down as the season that the fans forgave baseball -- or perhaps just grew tired of worrying about performance-enhancing drugs. Rodriguez and Andy Pettitte, two high-profile Yankees stars who were exposed as past users, are shining in the 2009 World Series.

The two major candidates vying in Tuesday's mayoral election have spent tens of millions of dollars flooding television, radio and mailboxes with ads and fliers, many of them attacking each other's record and integrity. But voters across New York City say they care less about the attacks between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his Democratic opponent, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., and more about issues big and small, like soaring rents, congested streets, parking tickets and a lack of garbage cans. In the days before the election, reporters for The New York Times went to three neighborhoods to talk to people about the concerns they want City Hall to address. Online: Voters from all five boroughs discuss their choices for mayor and what issues matter most at nytimes.com/nyregion.

Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. threw the heft of the White House behind the Democratic candidate on Monday in a race for a vacant Congressional seat that both Democrats and Republicans view as significant tests of their political fortunes. In the final hours before the polls open on Tuesday, Democrats made a plea for the votes of moderate Republicans who have become disillusioned with their party's backing of a deeply conservative candidate in the 23rd Congressional District. The race erupted after a more moderate Republican candidate, under pressure from conservatives, abruptly ended her campaign over the weekend.

MARGOLIS--Sylvia, 95, beloved wife of the late Joseph Margolis, mother of Ira (Andrea) and Henrietta (Larry), grandmother of Wayne, Lara, Jonathan and Jessica, and great-grandmother of Zoe, Micah, Aaron and Gabrielle. Funeral services November 2, 11:15am, Riverside, Amsterdam Ave. and 75th St.

READ--Alexander "Sandy", on Thursday, October 29th, died happily at The Equinox Terrace in Manchester, Vermont. Sandy enjoyed the whole thing, starting with his birth in Boston in 1928. One of nine children of Vice Admiral William A. Read USNR and Edith Fabyan Read, he grew up in Purchase, New York, attended The Browning School in New York City, and graduated from St. Pauls's and Yale, majoring in Hockey. After a few weeks of active duty in the United States Marine Corps, he spent 18 years as a member of the New York Stock Exchange, eight with DeCoppet and Doremus and ten as a partner in Spear, Leeds and Kellogg. During this time, he played hockey on the side for the St. Nicks and Beaver Dam teams. He retired in 1971 and moved to Peru, Vermont full time from Mill Neck, New York, with his wife Signa Lynch, whom he married in 1950. There he raised sheep, drew cartoons, and was a serious hunter and fisherman. He continued his interest in hockey as a part owner of The Buffalo Sabres and coaching the Brattleboro squirt team for several years. He took an active interest in politics and served Winhall as a Grand Juror, planner and selectman. After his divorce in 1986, he moved to Landgrove and then East Dorset, where he continued cartooning with his second wife, Patricia Wood Read, who predeceased him in 2005. He perpetuated his political career in Dorset by serving as a selectman for a number of years. In 2007, he remarried his first wife, Signa Lynch Read, who survives him. He is also survived by four of his seven brothers, Peter B. Read of Jaffrey, NH, Donald, B. Read of Old Lyme, CT, William A. Read, Jr. of Palm Beach, FL, Frederick H. Read of Malibu, CA, his sister, Jean R. Knox of Williamsville, NY, and his children, Sandra Read of Dorset, VT, Susan Read Cronin, of Manchester, VT, and Stewart W. Read of Bellows Falls, VT, two step-daughters, Marci MacNeur of Manchester, VT and Mindy Schwartz of Silver Springs, MD, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, as well as a large assortment of nieces and nephews, distributed nationally. He was a member of a whole pile of fancy clubs, where he drank copiously, and at his death was still a member of The Brook in New York City, and Mory's and Delta Kappa Epsilon at Yale. He was the author and illustrator of several books, including The Bear with the Orvis Rod and was a scrimshawer of note, with over three hundred pieces of work. His cartoons are found all over the world, and he will be remembered for his humor and his favorite saying, "There's a buck in every disaster!" Following his cremation, his ashes will be hauled to his favorite places. There will be no service at his request. "Bear" says goodbye to all.

Even before the first pitch of Game 5 on Monday, the Yankees' defining moments of the World Series had already been written. They were not so different from the hallmarks of their last championship. In 2000, the Yankees strangled the Mets from the start, capitalizing on a Game 1 base-running blunder by Timo Perez and using a 10-pitch walk by Paul O'Neill to spark a tying rally in the ninth. In Game 4 against the Phillies on Sunday, Johnny Damon created two similar moments that could also have a lasting place in Yankees lore.

The critically praised Off Broadway production of "The Temperamentals," a play about the early gay rights movement in America that had two sold-out runs this year, will transfer this winter to New World Stages, the producers announced on Wednesday. The production stars Thomas Jay Ryan ("Henry Fool") as Harry Hay, who helped build the Mattachine Society gay rights organization in the 1950s, and Michael Urie (Marc St. James on "Ugly Betty") as his lover Rudi Gernreich, who became a prominent fashion designer. Both men will reprise their roles at New World Stages, on W. 50th St. The producers are talking to the three other actors from the original production about returning as well. Previews are scheduled to start Feb. 18, with an opening night on Feb. 28. The specific theater to be used at New World Stages is still under discussion. Daryl Roth and Stacy Shane are producing the new play, which is by Jon Marans and directed by Jonathan Silverstein.

If, when the Beatles released the remastered versions of their albums in September, you withstood the pressure to buy the stereo and mono boxed sets that contained their entire catalogs, your patience is about to be rewarded, sort of. Apple Corps Ltd. and EMI Music said that they were releasing a limited edition USB drive that contains the stereo versions of the Beatles' albums, as well as the bonus materials that were included in their re-release, including short documentary films about the creation of the studio albums, photos and expanded liner notes. For the tech heads, the companies said that the audio files on the 16-gigabyte drives were in FLAC 44.1 Khz 24 bit and MP3 320 Kbps formats, and compatible with PC and Mac. For the people holding the credit cards, they said the drives would be sold at the Beatles' online store for $279.99 and would be released in North America on Dec. 8. The USB drive's design is presumably intended to evoke the Apple Corps. logo, and not the rotten fruit tossed by the villainous Apple Bonkers in "Yellow Submarine."

The papers of the poet Siegfried Sassoon are likely headed to Cambridge University following a grant from a British national fund for emergency acquisitions, BBC News reported. On Wednesday, the National Heritage Memorial Fund in Britain said that it would give about $900,000 toward the purchase of Sassoon's archives, which includes notebooks he kept on the Western Front during World War I, as well as correspondence, poetry books, photographs and love letters to his wife, Hester. Sassoon, who dealt with the human toll of war in poems like "They" and "Suicide in the Trenches," volunteered for military service just before Britain's entrance into World War I, and was a decorated soldier before he refused to return to duty in 1917. (A manuscript of his statement of refusal is among the items contained in the archive.) In June, several authors including Sebastian Faulks and Sassoon's official biographer, Max Egremont, started a campaign to acquire the poet's papers following the death of Sassoon's son George in 2006. With the grant, Cambridge is about $180,000 short of the estate's asking price of about $2 million for the archive.

The current Broadway production of "Hamlet" no longer needs to concern itself with borrowers or lenders -- the play has fully recouped its costs, its publicists said on Wednesday. In a news release, press representatives for "Hamlet," which began previews at the Broadhurst Theater on Sept. 12 and opened on Oct. 6, said that it had earned back its initial Broadway capitalization of $2.5 million as of the week ending Nov. 1. The play, directed by Michael Grandage, is the latest in a series of hits that have transferred to Broadway from the Donmar Warehouse in London, which also yielded "Frost/Nixon" and "Mary Stuart." The success of "Hamlet" might also have something to do with its star, Jude Law, who plays the melancholy Danish prince, and who has admirably held his own in a celebrity-filled season of Broadway neighbors like Daniel Craig and Sienna Miller. The limited run of "Hamlet" is to end on Dec. 6.

After dominating record sales for four months, Michael Jackson is finally at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. "Michael Jackson's This Is It," the companion album to the new movie -- Epic, the label, is being careful not to call it a soundtrack, since it is mostly made up of old hits -- sold 373,100 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Although Jackson has sold more than 5.6 million albums since his death in June, most of those titles have been too old to count on the Billboard 200, the standard album chart. But "This Is It" is a new title, and it becomes Jackson's sixth No. 1; the film was the top box office draw last week, taking in $32.5 million in its first five days in the United States.

On yesterday's post about whether we should support nonpartisan efforts to get people to vote, some comments accuse me of "elitism" (No. 52), of being "against universal suffrage" (No. 26) and disdaining "the poor, young and nonwhite" (No. 99) - charges I repudiate utterly. But the way to muster those with whom we have fellow-feeling is not by some vague admonition to vote, not by some airy appeal to good citizenship, but by proposing ways to make their lives - our lives - better, or, as I wrote early in yesterday's post: by rallying "support for a person or a policy you esteem."

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's strikingly thin margin of victory in Tuesday's election could affect his influence. He ended election night in possession of a surprisingly modest margin of victory, five percentage points -- far narrower than pollsters had predicted and with 100,000 fewer votes than he won in 2005. Voters seemed irritated by the term limits extension and his vast campaign spending.

What at most hotels is a dirty (and lucrative) little secret, Ace Hotels has turned into another opportunity to explore the zeitgeist. The Portland-based chainlet recently announced it has struck a deal with Butt magazine, the pink-papered gay quarterly, to curate 16 homoerotic films for the video-on-demand service at its New York and Palm Springs, Calif., properties. Selected by the Butt staff writer Adam Baran, the video selections will include a range of rare and historic adult movies - some in 3-D! - that are in keeping with the magazine's mission: to make titillation a cultural experience. A fixture in shops like Opening Ceremony, Butt regularly features the notable (Edmund White, Gus Van Sant) and the anonymous (Angel the Dominican carpenter) in various states of undress, which makes the Ace partnership no surprise. Since its start, the brand has aligned itself with independent tastemakers: Pearl's Plus, Surface to Air, Arkitip, Doc Martens and Crush Fanzine are a few current collaborators keeping Ace among the avant-garde.

For some time, researchers have been finding that people who exercise don't necessarily lose weight. A study published online in September in The British Journal of Sports Medicine was the latest to report apparently disappointing slimming results. In the study, 58 obese people completed 12 weeks of supervised aerobic training without changing their diets. The group lost an average of a little more than seven pounds, and many lost barely half that.

Curious about the history of the New York chophouse? <b>William Grimes</b>, a former restaurant critic of The New York Times, breaks it down — along with other tidbits like the oyster stalls and lobster palaces that were once dining mainstays — in his new book, <b> “Appetite City: A Culinary History of New York.” </b> “This vivid and vastly entertaining history,” Dawn Drzal writes in her review, chronicles the city’s “transformation from a Dutch village at the edge of the wilderness to what he sees as the most diverse restaurant city in the world.” Mr. Grimes reads from it tonight at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. For more arcana, head to the Union Square Barnes & Noble for a reading by <b>John Hodgman</b>, the veteran resident expert.

The English band Noah and the Whale closes out its three-night run at Mercury Lounge tonight. “They prize the stoicism of the British folk tradition, along with its fiddle tunes and vocal harmonies, without ruling out rock possibilities,” writes Jon Pareles. “Aching, unresolved, unironic heartbreak is at the core” of their songs, but it’s not overly emo: the singer, Charlie Fink, can sound like Lou Reed or Conor Oberst, and when they let loose, there’s psychedelic jamming and Springsteen-like antheming. Go Brittania.

Easy meals are what you want in this complicated time, right? Sam Sifton has one solution: Le Relais de Venise L’Entrecôte, “an assault on the tyranny of choice,” because it serves only a few things: salad, steak and fries. “The beef is fine,” he writes, the fries rate high on “the crazy-good scale” and the whole experience is “a perfect midweek dinner with a friend.” For more casual outings, visit the sandwich shops that Oliver Strand scouted out: Barros Luco for Chilean monsters like the beef empanada al horno; the Crosby Connection for classic New York monsters like the meatball hoagie; and the tiny Saltie in Williamsburg for outsize ambition. Run by three veterans of Marlow & Sons and Diner, it’s a high-achiever: the bread is baked in-house, the ice cream is made from scratch, and the sandwiches, like the vegetarian Clean Slate — quinoa and hummus with pickled vegetables, sauerkraut and yogurt in blistered naan — are culturally fearless.

A chart on Sunday with an article about academics on Facebook misspelled the given name of a Princeton professor with 1,938 Facebook fans (at the time the article went to press). He is Cornel West, not Cornell.

The Second Opinion column on Tuesday, about new findings that raise questions about mammography, omitted part of the affiliation of Dr. Otis Brawley, who said the medical profession had overstated the benefits of cancer screening. He is chief medical officer of the American Cancer Society — not just “the society.”.
Procedures in which dogs choose a suspect’s smell out of a group are under fire.

An article on Tuesday about creationism and evolution in the Islamic world included an erroneous example for how views on these subjects might differ between countries with Shiite and Sunni majorities. The population in Iraq is majority Shiite, not Sunni, so that country is not a proper contrast with Iran, which also has a Shiite majority.

An article on Tuesday about the success of the best-selling novel “The Help,” which included a comment from a co-owner of Rainy Day Books, an independent bookstore in Kansas, misidentified the town in which the store is located. It is Fairway, Kan., not Fairview.

A music review on Tuesday about “Daryl Glenn and Jo Lynn Burks Play and Sing Robert Altman’s ‘Nashville,’ ” at the Metropolitan Room, misspelled the surname of a singer and songwriter who performed some of her own songs in the film “Nashville.” She is Ronee Blakley, not Blakely.

An article on Saturday about a decision by federal health officials to release the last of the national stockpile of liquid pediatric Tamiflu misstated the amount of time it would take the Indian company Cipla Ltd. to offer the United States a generic replacement. It is three to four months, not four to six weeks. (While Cipla has finished testing the powder used in capsules to ensure that the generic and brand-name versions are equivalent, its tests on the powder used in liquid suspensions are expected to take several months.).

An article on Friday about a third-quarter expansion in the nation’s gross domestic product defined G.D.P. incorrectly. It is the government’s broadest measure of total goods and services produced — not the broadest measure of the government’s goods and services produced.

An article on Saturday about an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission inspector general, H. David Kotz, into Bernard L. Madoff’s decades-long Ponzi scheme erroneously included one former S.E.C. chairman on a list of ex-chairmen interviewed by Mr. Kotz as part of his inquiry. Although he interviewed Arthur Levitt, William Donaldson and Christopher Cox, he did not interview Harvey Pitt. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the continuation of the article.

Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, who founded the Classical Theater of Harlem and made it a home for the likes of Samuel Beckett, Euripides, Shakespeare and Melvin Van Peebles, will leave that Off Broadway theater company this month. In a news release, Mr. Preisser, who served as its artistic director, and Mr. McElroen, who has been its executive director, said that they created the Classical Theater of Harlem in 1999 to “nurture a new, young, and culturally diverse theater audience.”.

An eclectic roster of artists and entertainment industry figures were named to the President’s Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the White House announced on Monday evening. Among the 25 committee members selected by President Obama were the talent agent Bryan Lourd, managing director and co-chairman of Creative Artists Agency; the actors Sarah Jessica Parker (top right) and Edward Norton; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma (top left); and Teresa Heinz Kerry, the philanthropist and wife of Senator John Kerry. Also named were the actors Kerry Washington, Forest Whitaker and Alfre Woodard; the director George C. Wolfe (above right); Anna Wintour (above left) of Vogue; Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer; and the architect Thom Mayne.

Someday, as the movie and television series predicts, the Terminator robots, above, will become powerful enough to reduce the world to a pile of scrap metal and ash. But for now, they just need new owners. Variety reported that the Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the “Terminator” movies and other related assets, plans to sell the franchise at an auction in January as it goes through bankruptcy. When Halcyon purchased the “Terminator” property for $30 million in 2007, it became the latest in a series of owners that previously included the producer Gale Anne Hurd and the production company Carolco, now defunct. The most recent entry in the film series, “Terminator: Salvation,” grossed $369 million worldwide on a budget of $200 million. The company’s founders, Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek, told a bankruptcy court that the “Terminator” franchise was worth $70 million.
A California appeals court in Los Angeles has scheduled oral arguments for Dec. 10 in its review of Roman Polanski’s three-decade-old sex-abuse case.

The online price war that broke out last month among Wal-Mart, Amazon and Target took a new turn on Tuesday with Wal-Mart continuing to play the penny game. At first, Amazon appeared to be the low-price player when it extended its $9 price tag to three hardcover books that were officially released Nov. 3. Amazon had originally offered that price in response to price-cutting by Wal-Mart on its Web site for preorders of 10 titles that included the three that were released Tuesday: “Ford County” by John Grisham, “The Lacuna” by Barbara Kingsolver and “Kindred in Death” by J. D. Robb. As of Tuesday morning, Amazon still had those titles priced at $9 while Wal-Mart, which had offered them on preorder at $8.98, and Target, which had offered preorders for $8.99, had raised their prices. At Walmart.com, for example, “Ford County” was selling for $12, while “The Lacuna” was $13.50. At Target.com, “The Lacuna” was on sale for $18.89 and “Kindred in Death” was $17. But by late morning, Amazon had raised its prices — “The Lacuna” and “Kindred in Death,” for example, were offered for $13.50 — while Walmart.com had cut them again. All three novels that went on sale Tuesday were on sale at Walmart.com for $8.99, but by the afternoon, Walmart.com had raised its prices to just one penny lower than the price for the three titles on Amazon. In an e-mailed statement, a spokeswoman for Walmart.com said that it would “continue to adjust our pricing accordingly and as needed on these books.”.

Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer who holds the title of master of the queen’s music, said that he was delighted after his former manager was sentenced to 18 months in prison for defrauding him of more than $800,000, The Times of London reported. Michael Arnold, who managed Mr. Davies’s business affairs for more than 30 years, was arrested in 2007 and charged in October 2008 with false accounting; he admitted last year to having stolen the money. Mr. Davies, who has been honored this year with a global series of concerts marking his 75th birthday, said that he had stopped composing for a few weeks and had to borrow money from friends after learning of the fraud. On Monday, after the sentence was announced, he said he was glad the episode was over, adding: “I may even set it all to music. Who knows? That would be the ultimate revenge.”.

Richard Moe, the president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, is stepping down after 17 years in the post, the trust announced on Tuesday. Mr. Moe, 72, said he would stay on until a successor was named, which he expects will be by spring. During his tenure, the trust helped prevent Disney from building a theme park in the historic Northern Piedmont region of Virginia; championed the restoration of Lincoln’s cottage in Washington; encouraged the purchase at auction of the threatened Farnsworth House by Mies van der Rohe in Plano, Ill.; and focused on preserving the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina. “I think we broadened the mission here significantly,” Mr. Moe said in a telephone interview, adding, “Preservation is much more on the American agenda than it was several decades ago.”.

FREMANTLE--Adam, born March 18, 1934, died October 30, 2009, peacefully after a long illness bravely borne surrounded by his family. The funeral will be in London at 1:30pm on Monday, November 9 at St. Mary's Battersea, Battersea Church Road, SW11 3NA. No flowers. All enquires to Evershed Bros., 180 Battersea Park Road, SW11 4nd + 44(0)20 7622 4935. Donations may be made to Smile Train.

A VINTAGE LOOK Andy Pettitte versus Pedro Martinez summons up old battles between the Yankees and the Red Sox. But now Martinez is a Phillie, in a different shade of red, and he and Pettitte are going head-to-head with the World Series on the line. Pettitte is 37; Martinez is 38. Pettitte's career record is a superb 229-135; Martinez's is an even better 219-100. Both have an arsenal that increasingly relies on grit and guile. The temperature is expected to be in the 40s, with only a small chance that rain will get in the way of the game. And when it's over, the Yankees will have a 27th championship, or a Game 7 on Thursday night.

She is also survived by her son, Paul (Insook) Pensig, and a grandson, Charles Pensig. The family will hold a private service.

HANNAN--Kenneth H. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and Life Trustee Kenneth H. Hannan. One of our most longstanding and enthusiastic supporters, Mr. Hannan made numerous outstanding contributions to ensure the health of our Hospital and its patients for more than half a century. Elected to the Board of Governors of The Society of the New York Hospital in 1957, he served as President from 1966 to 1974 and chaired the Joint Administrative Board of the Medical Center for several years during this period. He was elected Life Governor of The New York Hospital in 1980 and continued to provide expertise as Life Trustee following the creation of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in 1998. A gentleman in every sense of the word, he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Hannan family. John Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Vice Chairman Charlotte M. Ford, Vice Chairman Peter A. Georgescu, Vice Chairman Jerry I. Speyer, Vice Chairman Herbert Pardes, M.D., President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

Claude Lévi-Strauss, the French anthropologist who transformed Western understanding of what was once called ''primitive man'' and who towered over the French intellectual scene in the 1960s and '70s, has died at 100. His son Laurent said Mr. Lévi-Strauss died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Paris. His death was announced Tuesday, the same day he was buried in the village of Lignerolles, in the Côte-d'Or region southeast of Paris, where he had a country home.

The Department of Medicine of the NYU Langone Medical Center is saddened by the passing of our retired colleague, Milena Lewis, M.D. Dr. Lewis was affiliated with NYU and with Bellevue Hospital since 1954. She was especially proud of her service as Chief of the Pulmonary Section of the Manhattan VA Medical Center. She will be missed by many colleagues. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

House Democratic leaders signaled Tuesday that they were prepared to make several changes to the health care bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who have threatened to block it. The opponents insist that tax dollars not pay for health insurance that would cover abortion. That could be tricky, given that the bill would provide hundreds of billions of dollars in federal subsidies to help moderate-income Americans buy insurance.

The Yankees needed two, so Feliz should just go back to the infield shift the Phillies used with Mark Teixeira at the plate batting left-handed.

Gunmen ambushed a government motorcade in the eastern province of Hadhramaut on Tuesday, killing three top provincial officials and three guards in an attack that had all the hallmarks of Al Qaeda's regional arm. The ambush was the deadliest attack on government officials in years in Yemen, where Al Qaeda has been building up a regional base with the aim of overthrowing the state.

HAGERTY--Mary Ann (Coleman), passed away peacefully on November 1, 2009, a few weeks short of her 72nd birthday. With the love and care of family and friends, she endured a long period of infirmity beginning in 2004; a sudden bout of pneumonia was her body's last battle. She was born on November 20, 1937 in New York City, the youngest child of John A. Coleman and Ann Meehan Coleman. Her brothers, John A. Coleman, Jr. and Thomas A. Coleman, predeceased her. A precocious student, she graduated at age 15 from the Convent of the Sacred Heart at 91st Street in New York and at age 19 from Manhattanville College. In 1959, she married Harry C. Hagerty, Jr. They lived in the New York City area for 35 years before moving to Sea Island, Georgia in 1994, where they enjoyed many happy years. After her husband passed away last year, she enjoyed the love and support of the many close friends and caregivers that they had been fortunate to meet in their time at Sea Island. She is survived by her children Harry C. Hagerty III, Elizabeth H. Dessen, and John C. Hagerty, and by nine grandchildren. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held at St. Williams Catholic Church, St. Simons Island, Georgia on Saturday, November 7 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that gifts in her name be made to Hospice of the Golden Isles, Inc., 1692 Glynco Parkway, Brunswick, Georgia 31525. Services have been entrusted to Edo Miller and Sons Funeral Home and Oglethorpe Crematorium in Brunswick, Georgia.

Esther Hautzig, an author of children's books whose true-life tale of surviving World War II in the labor camps of Siberia, told in a guileless teenager's voice, became a classic of young people's literature, died on Sunday in Manhattan. DAGLIAN--Ara, 83, of NYC and Fire Island, his Shangri-la, died peacefully on Sunday, November 1st surrounded by family and friends. He graduated from GWHS before receiving degrees from Columbia University and the Cornell School of Hotel Administration. He proudly served in the US Navy during WWII and in the Korean War. He had a 50 year hospitality industry career and devoted 25 years of service to the DPFD, where he rose to the rank of Chief. He was beloved father of Lisa and Ara Paul, "Poppie" to Ara Paul Jr. and Katie. He was predeceased by his former wife Barbara. He leaves his brother and sister-in-law, Kourken and Marliese, sister-in-law Georgia, nieces, nephews and many dear friends. A memorial service will be held on November 7th from 2-5pm at the Cornell Club of New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider sending donations to the Cornell Hotel School Scholarship Fund.

As many as 46 million adults and children in the United States lack health insurance, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. In an audio slideshow, ''Patient Voices,'' posted this week on the Prescriptions blog, one man describes his strategy for living without coverage. That man, Carl Arrington, 58, a freelance writer and chef in New York, was insured under an employer's group plan, but his company closed shop nine years ago. For a while, Mr. Arrington paid for extended coverage under the federal Cobra law, but eventually the high premiums forced him to make a difficult decision. He dropped his insurance.

Jon S. Corzine, and striking a blow against the Democratic party on a national stage. Mr. Christie, who accused Mr. Corzine of leading the state into economic turmoil, edged out Mr. Corzine by about four percentage points.

WOOD--William Lawrence. On October 30th, 2009, four months after the death of his wife of 66 years, Marion "Missy" Geer Wood, William Lawrence Wood, 91, of Hilton Head, SC, died in the arms of their daughter, Marion Canfield Wood. He is survived by his son-in-law M. Farrag "Frank" Ahmed, grandson William Lawrence Farrag Ahmed, of Mill Neck, NY, brother John Cotton Wood (Denise) of Kennett Square, PA, nephew John Masten (Marcia) of NYC, niece Elizabeth Hammill (Tom) of England, and cousin Penelope Wood (Mike Bain) of Brooklyn. Born in Santa Barbara, CA, Bill lived in Cambridge, MA, New York City, and Oyster Bay, NY. He attended Belmont Hill School '36 and Harvard College '40, and piloted 25 B-17 bomber missions over Germany, miraculously without a single injury to any of the men in his crews. He was awarded an Air Medal, 3 Oak Leaf Clusters, and a Distinguished Flying Cross. Sure that he'd used up all his luck in that brief period in his life he paid fanatical attention to the inner workings of every car he subsequently owned, including the Bentley he brought home from England after a two-year stint with First National City Bank (later Citibank) in London. He was a member of the Harvard Club of New York, where he played squash and was on the board. Puns, golf, and tennis were his great passions, and he was a fixture on the doubles courts of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and the Cove Neck Tennis Club, where he made ample use of his diabolical slice. For the last four-and-a-half years of Missy's life, when her Alzheimer's kicked in, Bill visited her every day, determined that she should not feel abandoned. At the end of their life together, their greatest pleasure was to sit in their wheelchairs holding hands, an example, as one aide observed, "of what Love looks like." Memorial Service date TBA. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Belmont Hill School, 350 Prospect Street, Belmont, MA 02478-2662. The Island Funeral Home and Crematory is in charge of services.

Indochine has proven that a true fashion restaurant never goes out of style. The palm-leaf wallpaper of the Lafayette Street boîte, opened by Brian McNally in 1984, has been the background for 25 years of beautiful faces, from the supermodels to the Roitfeld-Restoin clan. The new book "Indochine: Stories, Shaken and Stirred" (Rizzoli) serves as both eye candy and social document: there's a photo of Andy Warhol, Jacqueline and Julian Schnabel, Kenny Scharf and Jean-Michel Basquiat at the opening; there's a quote from Anna Wintour on the model-fest that was Grace Coddington's 50th birthday party in 1991. The index alone, organized by first name, reads like a downtown primer, hopping from Arthur Miller to As Four, Susan Sontag to Suzanne Bartsch.

Now that she's gotten her sea legs, Mary Mattingly, an artist who spent her summer living on an eco-art-barge floating around the city, is looking to move on up (to the sky). Ms. Mattingly has proposed that her next project, called "Air Ship Air City," be installed atop the Metropolitan Exchange Building, a seven-story design and research cooperative in downtown Brooklyn, whose members have given the initial green light to the idea, according to the Brooklyn Paper. The plans for the structure include a chicken coop - the barge, the Waterpod, was home to four chickens - a research lab, hanging gardens, potential living quarters (called the Flock House) and a communal area featuring outdoor couches that Ms. Mattingly envisions as a sort of human nest.

Update | 9:15 p.m. At a news conference outside Fort Hood the base commander, Lt. Gen. Robert Cone, just revealed that earlier reports that the suspected gunman, Major Nidal Hasan, had been killed were incorrect. Major Hasan was wounded but remains alive, Lt. Gen. Cone said, adding that he is in custody and "his death is not imminent." He added that 12 people, not 11, had been killed by whom the military authorities now describe as a single gunman.
