My husband, Andy, and I went to Poland in September to visit some of his relatives, and they took us to the mountain region of Zakopane to a guesthouse that includes both breakfast and dinner. Traditionally, Poles eat simply for breakfast and dinner, often a spread of bread, cheese and meat to make sandwiches. Lunch is the large, hot meal. But at this guesthouse, dinner is more akin to lunch, with a first course of soup followed by a main meat dish served with potatoes and either a slaw of carrots or cabbage.

Glen Davis, the Celtics forward also known as "Big Baby," has always had a larger profile than his on-the-court production has warranted. That was one of the things that made it so interesting to see him play a vital role during Boston's playoff push last season. Averaging 15.8 points a game in Kevin Garnett's absence, Davis showed that he could be a viable N.B.A. player despite being on the short side (he's at 6'9") for a power forward.

With three rounds of playoffs, one of them a best-of-five series, the modern postseason is designed to ensure that the best team in baseball only wins the World Series a small percentage of the time. This randomness inherent in the playoffs is the game's built-in remedy for its competitive balance woes, and has felled four different Yankee squads this decade that posted the game's best record but fell short of a title. Yet while the last Yankees club to bring home a championship, the 87-win 2000 team, reinforced the notion that the postseason is a crapshoot, the 2009 edition offers a different lesson: sometimes, just being really, really good is indeed good enough to win it all.

Today we are showing the trailer for Michael Haneke's latest film, "The White Ribbon." The drama, set on the eve of World War I, examines a group of families living in a village in northern Germany and a series of crimes that shake up the community. Manohla Dargis called the film, which won the Palme d'Or at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, "a meticulous examination of patriarchal domination." On Wednesday afternoon, TD11 formed just off the northern coast of Panama. It doesn't appear to have come from an easterly wave, but rather a persistent area of convection that sat and festered for a week or so. At such a low latitude, it takes quite a while for the Coriolis effect to influence the circulation of a low pressure. Later on Wednesday, an aircraft found that it had sustained winds high enough to warrant upgrading it to Tropical Storm Ida. On Thursday morning, it was again upgraded to Hurricane Ida (3rd hurricane of the season), with sustained winds of 65kts and a central pressure of 987mb. It's presently located right on the east-central Nicaraguan coast and looks well-organized for being so close to land.

On Thursday, the producers of "Billy Elliot the Musical" said two more actors would be joining its Broadway cast to portray the title role. Dayton Tavares, 13, who has played the character in the musical's Sydney and Melbourne casts, will become the sixth member of the Broadway Billy club, and Liam Redhead, 14, a student of the National Ballet School in Toronto, will become the seventh, the show's publicists said in a news release. Additionally, Tommy Batchelor, who is leaving the Broadway cast to play Billy in the show's Chicago production, will play his final New York performance on Dec. 11. The Broadway role was originated by David Alvarez, Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, who won Tony Awards for their performances. Starting dates for Mr. Tavares and Mr. Redhead were not announced.

Before the Berlin wall came down in 1989, the two Germanys each had their own culinary history. Spicy Russian stew in the East, maultaschen and sauerkraut in the West. This weekend, a couple of international gourmands are pitting the two sides against one another, inviting the culinarily curious to engage in a little exercise of gastro politics. Saturday, Sunday and Monday - the three nights leading up to the 20th anniversary of the fall of the wall - the writer and part-time Berlin resident Caroline Hobkinson, along with the Cordon Bleu-trained pastry chef Rachel Khoo, are hosting 30-euro, five-course dinners in an apartment just 50 yards from the old wall.

Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, told The Detroit Free Press that he felt lucky to be alive after having emergency surgery on Sunday to unblock a clogged artery. Mr. Slatkin, 65, the former music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, had a heart attack while conducting the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands, and is now resting in a hospital there after undergoing an angioplasty and stent procedure. In an e-mail exchange with The Free Press, Mr. Slatkin wrote that he experienced chest pains earlier in the week but dismissed them as indigestion. At the Sunday concert, he wrote: "I started having trouble with chest pain and I was sweating more than usual. Again, I thought it would go away but it stuck around. I sort of collapsed in the dressing room and a medical team from the hall was sent in. Five minutes later I was in an ambulance on the way to the hospital." He added that he was scheduled to fly to Prague later that night, "and it is very possible that I might not have survived that long." The Detroit Symphony Orchestra told The Free Press that Mr. Slatkin is still scheduled to conduct the orchestra in Detroit this month, but contingency plans are being made in case he is unable to perform.

Choosing one's next movie project after winning Academy Awards for best director and best film doesn't always come quickly -- just ask James Cameron -- but Danny Boyle, whose film "Slumdog Millionaire" won eight Oscars in February, has figured out his follow-up. Variety reported that Mr. Boyle (whose films also include "Trainspotting" and "28 Days Later") will next direct "127 Hours," a biographical film about the mountaineer Aron Lee Ralston. Mr. Ralston made headlines in 2003 when, in his exploration of Robbers Roost in southeastern Utah, an 800-pound boulder fell on his right hand and crushed it; after being trapped for several days, he sawed off the trapped arm and hiked to his rescue. The project is expected to reunite Mr. Boyle with his "Slumdog Millionaire" screenwriter Simon Beaufoy and producer Christian Colson. Production is expected to begin next year; no casting has yet been announced.

“Idiot Savant,” the latest from the long-running downtown auteur Richard Foreman, stars Willem Dafoe in the title role, and allows its actors to speculate at length about what it means to be in a play about an idiot savant, and whether they’re idiots for even talking about it. Classic Foreman, writes Ben Brantley, but amped up by Dafoe, who wears a costume that is “unequal parts samurai warrior, 17th-century French courtier and contemporary businessman,” and brings “a star’s bright idiosyncrasy” to the part. “It raises the humor and humanity to heights rarely felt in a Foreman work,” Brantley writes. Get your tickets now; it’s at the Public.

The Canadian band ****** Up , led by a bearded, jowly — and surprisingly jolly — singer named Pink Eyes, builds “an ecosystem of gorgeous guitar harmony and ambient texture inside the gray rhythmic world of stomping eighth-note punk,” writes Ben Ratliff. So: they’re lovelier than they may seem. This will be especially true tonight, when they play the entirety of their latest, critically-beloved album, “The Chemistry of Common Life,” at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple with the help of special guests Andrew W.K. and Vivian Girls. Come early for the openers Titus Andronicus.

The latest hotly-anticipated “app phone” — a term David Pogue Twit-sourced — is the Motorola Droid. It runs on Verizon and Google’s Android operating system (the 2.0 version) and the design, Pogue writes, “screams ‘Star Wars,’ if not ‘Darth Vader.’ It’s jet-black, all sharp angles and industrial-looking edges.” It’s super-fast, with good audio quality, a pull-out screen and a stellar GPS. The Droid may not be an iPhone killer, Pogue writes, but it is “a killer phone.” Get it starting tomorrow for $200 after a $100 rebate (Pogue’s tip: “Get it at Best Buy, where you get the rebate on the spot”) and play with it in your man cave.

Frank A. D'Amelio may be worth the $6 million of compensation he received last year as chief financial officer for Pfizer. But, Breakingviews says, it's questionable for the drug company to also pay him a $1.2 million bonus - half in cash and half in stock - for his role in acquiring its rival Wyeth. Rewarding executives for going shopping is crazy, the publication suggests.

The world needs another fashion exhibition like Valentino needs another pug. But "Dysfashional," which opened this week at the Passage du Désir in Paris, gives hope that despite the surfeit of recent shows, the subject matter may still have some bite. Although the show's curators, Luca Marchetti and Emanuele Quinz, have tapped designers like Raf Simons, Hussein Chalayan and Gaspard Yurkievich to contribute, the pair has chosen not to exhibit clothing, preferring instead to focus on the ideas and spectacle that surround fashion. Explains Marchetti, "Dysfashional tackles the seemingly frivolous yet vital realm of fashion by examining the approach of designers and artists from various backgrounds, bringing us closer to a world in which the protagonists are not the objects but the creative process itself."

An article on Monday about the legal problems of Raj Rajaratnam, a hedge fund manager charged with trading on inside information, misstated an arbitration panel’s damage award to Mr. Rajaratnam and Gary Rosenbach, another Galleon executive, on their claim that they were misled by the creators and promoters of a tax shelter later disallowed by the Internal Revenue Service. Although the panel found that $10 million in damages and interest was due and that John Schrier, a lawyer and accountant who recommended the shelter, was 50 percent responsible, it did not award damages from Mr. Schrier, who was not a party to the arbitration. Mr. Schrier and KPMG, his former employer, had already settled a related lawsuit on undisclosed terms, denying wrongdoing. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Schrier’s role in the tax shelter. He helped market the tax shelter to Mr. Rajaratnam and Mr. Rosenbach; he did not create it.

An article on Aug. 27 about the preservation of Modernist houses on Cape Cod referred incompletely to the restoration of the Kugel House, built in 1970 in Wellfleet, Mass. Besides the work done by Peter McMahon, who designs and builds houses, Fox Diehl Architects of Manhattan was also involved in the restoration. Elizabeth Kolbert, a writer at The New Yorker, has sold a new book about mass extinctions to Henry Holt & Company. Holt paid a mid-six-figure advance for the book, which began as an article in The New Yorker and is scheduled for publication in fall 2012. Stephen Rubin, the new president and publisher of Holt, announced the acquisition on Wednesday, just two days after he started his job. Mr. Rubin was most recently publisher at large at Random House. Ms. Kolbert moves to Holt from Bloomsbury, which published her previous book, “Field Notes From a Catastrophe,” in 2006. Her editor, Gillian Blake, is now at Holt and acquired the new book, “The Sixth Extinction,” an intellectual and natural history of various species. Ms. Blake said she had been talking to Ms. Kolbert about the subject of extinctions for years. “The idea of mass extinctions as the next step after talking about the perils of global warming is the most crucial subject,” Ms. Blake said.

After dominating record sales for four months, Michael Jackson is finally at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. “Michael Jackson’s This Is It,” above, the companion album to the new movie, sold 373,100 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Although Jackson has sold more than 5.6 million albums since his death in June, most of those titles have been too old to count on the Billboard 200, the standard album chart. But “This Is It” is a new title, and it becomes Jackson’s sixth No. 1. The film was the top box-office draw last week, taking in $32.5 million in its first five days in the United States. Also on this week’s album chart, Creed’s comeback, “Full Circle” (Wind-Up), opened at No. 2 with 110,000, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), rereleased in a deluxe package, jumped four spots to No. 3 with 109,000. Rod Stewart’s new album, “Soulbook” (J), a collection of covers of classic soul songs, bowed at No. 4 with 84,000 copies sold. Trans-Siberian Orchestra’s latest holiday album, “Night Castle” (Atlantic), opened at No. 5 with 83,000, and Sting’s new Christmas-themed album, “If on a Winter’s Night ...” (Deutsche Grammophon), sold 80,000 copies to debut at No. 6.
ABC’s new science-fiction series, “V,” a remake of the 1983 mini-series, opened to strong ratings on Tuesday.

The next tenant for Broadway’s Nederlander Theater was announced late Tuesday: The new musical “Million Dollar Quartet,” based on a 1956 recording session that brought together Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins and Elvis Presley. Preview performances are to begin on March 13, and opening night will be sometime in April. The show, now running in Chicago, will be directed by Eric Schaeffer and includes a book by Colin Escott and Floyd Mutrux. Casting is underway.

If, when the Beatles released the remastered versions of their albums in September, you withstood the pressure to buy the stereo and mono boxed sets that contained their entire catalogs, your patience is about to be rewarded, sort of. Apple Corps Ltd. and EMI Music said they were releasing a limited-edition USB hard drive that contains the stereo versions of the Beatles’ albums, as well as the bonus materials that were included in their rerelease, including short documentary films about the creation of the studio albums, photos and expanded liner notes. For the tech heads, the companies said that the audio files on the 16-gigabyte drives were in FLAC 44.1 Khz 24 bit and MP3 320 Kbps formats, and compatible with PC and Mac. For people holding credit cards, the drives will be sold at the Beatles’ online store for $279.99 and will be released in North America on Dec. 8. The USB drive’s green apple design, above, is presumably intended to evoke the Apple Corps logo and not the rotten fruit tossed by the villainous Apple Bonkers in “Yellow Submarine.”.

The current Broadway production of “Hamlet” no longer needs to concern itself with borrowers or lenders — the play has fully recouped its costs, its publicists said on Wednesday. In a news release, press representatives for “Hamlet,” which began previews at the Broadhurst Theater on Sept. 12 and opened on Oct. 6, said that it had earned back its initial Broadway capitalization of $2.5 million as of the week ending Nov. 1. The play, directed by Michael Grandage, is the latest in a series of hits that have moved to Broadway from the Donmar Warehouse in London, which also yielded “Frost/Nixon” and “Mary Stuart.” The success of “Hamlet” might also have something to do with its star, Jude Law, who plays the melancholy Danish prince (above with Geraldine James), and who has held his own in a celebrity-filled season of Broadway neighbors like Daniel Craig, Hugh Jackman and Sienna Miller. The limited run of “Hamlet” is to end on Dec. 6.

The papers of the poet Siegfried Sassoon are probably headed to Cambridge University thanks to a grant from a British national fund for emergency acquisitions, BBC News reported. On Wednesday the National Heritage Memorial Fund in Britain said that it would give about $900,000 toward the purchase of Sassoon’s archives, which include notebooks he kept on the Western Front during World War I, as well as correspondence, poetry books, photographs and love letters to his wife, Hester. Sassoon, who dealt with the human toll of war in poems like “They” and “Suicide in the Trenches,” volunteered for military service just before Britain entered World War I, and he was a decorated soldier before he refused to return to duty in 1917. In June several authors, including Sebastian Faulks and Sassoon’s official biographer, Max Egremont, started a campaign to acquire Sassoon’s papers after the death of his son, George, in 2006. With the grant, Cambridge is about $180,000 short of the estate’s asking price of nearly $2 million for the archive.

SPIEGEL--Jerry, 84, of Kings Point, NY on November 3rd. We are heartbroken by the loss of our extraordinary father. A pioneer in his field and a man of honor and substance, he led his life with integrity, courage and a sense of humor. His remarkable journey from potato farmer to successful businessman inspired us all. He taught us many life lessons including generosity, hard work and the importance of family. Born on the Fourth of July, he was the ultimate "All-American guy." He loved simple pleasures and enjoyed all that life had to offer. Our father shared an incredible marriage to our mother, the love of his life, and now joins his beautiful Emily for eternity. Our hero, he will remain forever in our hearts. He is survived by his daughters Pamela Sanders and Lise Wilks; sons-in-law Arthur Sanders and Jeffrey Wilks; and grandchildren Jordan, Remy and Erin Sanders and David, Andrew and Jack Wilks. Services will be held on Friday, November 6th at 11:30am, Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, Five Old Mill Road. The family will be sitting on Friday at 2:30pm and on Saturday from 4:30pm to 7:30pm at the home of Jerry Spiegel, 10 Broadlawn Avenue, Kings Point.
FRIEDMAN--Susan. Beloved and loving mother. Your winning personality, vibrant spirit, enthusiasm for life, and caring ways will always be in our thoughts and hearts. Melissa and Alexandra, Warren

WEINSTOCK--Solomon, 84, died peacefully at home in New York after a brief illness. A devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. Sol was the beloved husband of Barbara Antell Silber who survives him. His first wife Marianne Bayer died in 1998. He is also survived by his beloved children Sonia (Jean Francois) Hamel, Eric and Ellen and grandchildren Dasha, Hannah, and Benjamin. Cherished by Barbara's children: Drs. Andrea (Philip Dickey), Jeffrey, Laura (Dr. Dusan Knezevic), and Michael Silber and grandchildren Schuyler "Jack", Olivia, Aaron, Mila, Iva and Ana. Retired from Brooklyn College after more than two decades as professor of Psychology, Sol was a distinguished teacher and devoted to his research. He served in the Army during World War II. Majoring in Math and Physics, Sol graduated from City College of New York, he received his doctorate in Psychology from Indiana University. He was a strong advocate for civil rights and environmental issues. He enjoyed nature, chamber music and art. Sol loved to travel and was a nationally ranked chess player. Services Thursday, 11:15 at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. Contributions in Sol's memory may be made to: The International Crane Foundation, PO Box 447, Baraboo, WI 53913. http://www.savingcranes.org/

NAKHLA--Fayek, born in Egypt, January 4, 1933, died October 29th. After medical school in Egypt, he pursued a psychiatric residency in Denver, Colorado, and worked in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. He then trained in psychoanalysis at the London Institute of Psychoanalysis. He came to New York City in 1968. In addition to his private practice, he was on the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and then became the director of psychiatric residency training at Brookdale University Hospital. He was a member of the British Psychoanalytic Society and the International Psychoanalytic Association. He is survived by his wife, Yvette, two children from his first marriage, Tarek and Nevine, and three grandchildren. Service private. Donations may be made to Cancer Care.

Israeli Navy commandos seized a cargo ship early Wednesday in the Mediterranean Sea that Israeli officials said was carrying rockets and ammunition bound for Hezbollah militants. News reports quoted the Israeli president, Shimon Peres, as saying that the ship had been carrying the arms from Iran to Hezbollah forces in Lebanon. Iran, Lebanon and Hezbollah had no comment, according to The Associated Press. In September, at least two rockets were fired at Israel from southern Lebanon, the first in more than six months to be launched across the border. The capture of the ship comes as Iran is equivocating on a deal that was meant to delay Tehran's ability to build a nuclear bomb -- and to persuade Israel not to attack Iranian nuclear facilities.

In times of economic hardship, small businesses are among the first to feel the effects. As income declines and costs for employee coverage rise, health insurance is often one of the first expenses to be cut. In an audio slideshow on the Prescriptions blog, a business owner, Zoraida Reyes, tells her story. Ms. Reyes, 48, owns a check-cashing business in Bridgeport, Conn. She has never been able to afford to offer health insurance to her few employees. Recently, she and her husband dropped their own insurance policy.

An off-year election night of Republican victories in New Jersey and Virginia proved to be a big winner for the Fox News Channel, Nielsen ratings showed Wednesday. Perhaps still high off the fumes of last year's presidential contest, the news media covered the elections as if they were prize fights -- with extra coverage and countdown clocks to poll closings on cable channels. MSNBC called it a ''mini-Super Tuesday.''

WHEN it comes to women's underwear, cotton is the most comfortable fabric -- and the most breathable and the one most often recommended by doctors -- but it also can cause unsightly panty lines. Sadly, cotton tends to bunch up and sag, which means that panties made from it may require thick elastic. Underwear makers, however, have stepped up to the challenge. There is a growing selection of lingerie meant to combat the dreaded V.P.L. (visible panty line) and designed to be worn with pants by women who are working out, working it or not working at all. Some of the panties have spandex woven into the cotton for greater elasticity and smoothness. Others rely on pima cotton, which is particularly dense and soft, or raw-cut cotton, a patented weave with ends that do not curl or fray. The underwear is often tag-free and seamless, for the smoothest possible surface.

Three key members of the Giants' defense reported progress in their recoveries from injuries and expressed hope that they could play soon. Chris Canty, a defensive lineman, said he practiced fully and has recovered from a calf injury. He said he expected to be available Sunday when the Giants (5-3) try to break a three-game losing streak; they host the San Diego Chargers (4-3).

CUNNEEN--Sally S.,long-time professor of English at Rockland Community College, died in her sleep Saturday after a long fight against cancer. A prolific writer, she was the author "Sex: Female Religion: Catholic," "In Search of Mary: the woman and the symbol," "Mother Church: what the experience of women is teaching her," and "The Icon Reborn" (with Frederick Franck). She was also the translator of Kurt Klinger's "The Poet Laughs: stories of John XXIII." In 1950 she and her husband Joseph Cunneen founded "Cross Currents," an ecumenical quarterly which published many of the thinkers who were to be influential at Vatican II, and she remained an active editor until both retired in 1998. A long-time resident of Rockland County, she was well known for leading discussions of important contemporary fiction at the Spring Valley and Sparkill Public Libraries. After her four sons (John, Michael, Peter and Paul) seemed well launched, she completed her doctorate in psychology and English at Teacher's College/Columbia University. Born in Providence, RI, Sally attended Classical College. She attended Smith College but transferred after two years to the University of Rhode Island from which she graduated in 1947. She worked in New York until her marriage in 1949.

GOLDFIELD--Alfred. The Board of Directors and staff of New York Foundation for Senior Citizens deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Board Member and Treasurer, Alfred Goldfield, and express our sympathy to his wife, Joan, daughters, Alexis and Amanda. Alfred helped the Foundation pioneer its first senior citizen building in 1981. Throughout the last three decades, Alfred has provided invaluable expertise and support that has been of major assistance to the Foundation in successfully bringing many more senior citizen buildings and social service programs to fruition. Alfred was a genuinely caring, jovial gentleman and true friend. He will be sorely missed.

DAGLIAN--Ara, 83, of NYC and Fire Island, his Shangri-la, died peacefully on Sunday, November 1st surrounded by family and friends. He graduated from GWHS before receiving degrees from Columbia University and the Cornell School of Hotel Administration. He proudly served in the US Navy during WWII and in the Korean War. He had a 50 year hospitality industry career and devoted 25 years of service to the DPFD, where he rose to the rank of Chief. He was beloved father of Lisa and Ara Paul, "Poppie" to Ara Paul Jr. and Katie. He was predeceased by his former wife Barbara. He leaves his brother and sister-in-law, Kourken and Marliese, sister-in-law Georgia, nieces, nephews and many dear friends. A memorial service will be held on November 7th from 2-5pm at the Cornell Club of New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider sending donations to the Cornell Hotel School Scholarship Fund.

SCHWARTZ--Ida C.,died peacefully on November 3rd, 2009 at 100 years of age. She was born in 1909, daughter of Dora and Israel Garfinkel, wife of Bernard S. Schwartz (d. 2005), mother of Valerie B. Schwartz (d. 2000). She is survived by her son, Jonathan P. Schwartz, daughter-in-law, Marcella Fischer, and grandson, S. Alexander Schwartz. Mrs. Schwartz graduated from New York University. She was on Law Review, and one of five women in the NYU Law Class of 1934. She helped to found the New York Women's Bar Association. She practiced matrimonial and real estate law. With her husband, she was a founder of the Schizophrenia Foundation of New York. She was a valued counselor to her friends, many of whom she supported ardently in their hour of need and in their aspirations. A philanthropist, she supported New York charities. She will be sorely missed. Private Service.

General Motors provoked an uproar Wednesday in Germany after the company decided to keep its European business, Opel, rather than sell a majority stake to a consortium that had promised to try to safeguard jobs and factories. The sudden decision, after months of high-level negotiations, reflected a new degree of confidence at G.M. after its rebirth through a United States bankruptcy court. Opel was a strategic asset that G.M. had been prepared to jettison as it fought for its own survival.

ELVOVE--Elies, P.E.,Lt. Col. USAF Ret.; born April 26, 1917, Paris, KY; died November 3, 2009, Scarsdale, NY. Beloved husband of Barbara and the late Marjorie Rosmarin; Devoted father of sons Jay, Roy and Joshua Elvove and stepsons Robert and William Abrams; grandfather of Allison, Samantha, Elisa, Zachary, Brian and Ethan; brother of the late Sara, Ethel, Kadie and Louis; uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. PAKULA--Randall H.,died at the age of 85, a resident of Boca Raton, Florida. He fought a long-hard battle with Alzheimer's disease and succumbed to its ravishes on November 3, 2009. Randall was born in Brooklyn, New York on April 28, 1924, son to Benjamin and Mary Pakula and brother to Doris Meyerson. He attended Carnegie Tech at the age of 15, was a guard on their basketball team, and graduated with an engineering degree. In the Navy, Randall was promoted to Captain of his own merchant ship transporting men and equipment to the Pacific Islands. After the war, Randall joined Bryant Inc., a printing, marketing, advertising and consulting company founded by his father and Paul Pakula in 1918, where he was President and CEO for forty-nine years. A specialist in the floor covering industry he was a featured keynote speaker at industry conferences throughout the span of his career. Randall also served as a member of the Board of Directors of Utica Mutual Insurance for fifteen years. He was an avid golfer, a great story teller, and true confidant. Randall was a man of integrity highly respected by his peers. He gave not only to his family but to his community and was a supporter of the UJA-Federation. Randall, a loving husband and father, is survived by his wife Joan Pakula, his daughter Teri Pakula, his son Michael Pakula, Michael's wife, Alba Pakula and his grandchildren Benjamin Steven Pakula and Jacqueline Faye Pakula.

HECHT--Marie Louise Engel, in Stockbridge, MA, November 1st, 2009. Native of New York City, beloved wife of Dr. Manfred H. Hecht, Ph.D. (d. February 4, 2006). Avid artist and travel enthusiast. Mother to Andrew Hecht (d. December 1996) and grandmother to Deborah Ann and Howard M. Hecht, with three great-grandchildren as well as friend to numerous caregivers and her beloved dog, Basil.

House Democrats are bracing for a potential invasion of protesters in the Capitol complex on Thursday after Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, urged opponents of the Democrats' health care legislation to come to Washington to make their voices heard. Ms. Bachmann, in an appearance on Fox television Tuesday morning, invited opponents of the health care bill to join her for a news conference at noon Thursday on the steps of the Capitol. And she urged them to visit the offices of individual lawmakers to tell them to vote against the bill.

RICHLAND--Jerold B. 70, President of Richland Design of NYC, died October 31. A graduate of School of Industrial Arts and CCNY, he enjoyed multiple careers in Stage, Hospitality and Interior Design. His passion for travel throughout Europe and Russia energized his design visions with authenticity and integrity. An avid student of historical periods his stage and hospitality designs bestowed magical transformations for the viewer. His joys for life, keen wit and goodness have left an imprint on all who knew him. A graveside ceremony will be held at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, November 6, 11am.

HEY, I thought there weren't going to be any paparazzi!'' Armand Milletari, objected genially as a visitor entered the room. Mr. Milletari, a guitarist with Crazy Mary, a psychedelic rock band (above), was one of several dozen musicians practicing on a recent Thursday at Smash Studios in Midtown. The 20-year-old rehearsal hall was host to a crazy assortment of players, their garb as varied as their sound. ''People come in their everyday dress,'' said Clay Sheff, the studio's founder, their looks ''an absolute expression of their musical styles.'' Anthony (Romeo) Santos (below left), of the Latin band Aventura, was languidly seductive in chinos and a buttery leather jacket; Idris Elba, the actor, D.J. and musician (below right) worked a moody look; and Lydia Caesar (top right) played the seasoned flirt in a yellow sash and shrilly pink tank top.

CRABTREE--Amy Marie, resident of Pound Ridge, NY, died on November 3, 2009 at home, with her family beside her, after a 19-month battle with brain cancer. Amy was devoted to her profession as an oncology and surgical nurse for more than thirty years at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City and then at Stamford Hospital. Recently, Amy also worked alongside John, her husband of 27 years, at their family restaurant, Crabtree's Kittle House Inn, in Chappaqua, NY. She was committed to her community, and was a shining example as an active philanthropist. Amy dedicated herself to raising funds and awareness for a multitude of charities helping the poor, hungry and sick, with countless local organizations. Above all, Amy was a devoted, beloved mother and wife. She is survived by her husband John, and four daughters, Kathryn, 25; Chrissy, 24; Lizzy, 21; and Maddy, 18. Each has inherited her wit, strength of spirit, compassion for fellow creatures, intensity for life and unwavering family values. Her infectious laughter, her brilliant smile and her vitality for life will live in them, and with them, forever. Services will be made by Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home. Visitation Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass will be Saturday, 11am at St. Patrick's Church, Bedford Village, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution to one of Amy's favorite charities: Boys & Girls Club of Northern Westchester, Make-A-Wish Foundation of the Hudson Valley and Northern Westchester Hospital.

As the dust settled from Tuesday's elections, one of next year's potentially bruising campaigns came into focus on Wednesday as Carly Fiorina, a former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard and a Republican, declared her candidacy for the Senate seat long held by Barbara Boxer, a Democrat. Almost immediately, Ms. Fiorina was criticized by several national Republicans for being insufficiently conservative.

An article on Aug. 27 about the preservation of Modernist houses on Cape Cod referred incompletely to the restoration of the Kugel House, built in 1970 in Wellfleet, Mass. Besides the work done by Peter McMahon, who designs and builds houses, Fox Diehl Architects of Manhattan was also involved in the restoration. The firm acted pro bono as the architects of record, doing research and reviewing the restoration drawings with the first owners of the house to ensure that the work was faithful to the original. This correction was delayed for research.

DAVIS--Larry. Adored husband of Carolyn, passed away November 3rd at home surrounded by his children Richard (Cindy), David, Deborah (Orrin), Donna (Fred); stepchildren Wendy (Lewis), Donna (Luca), Stacey (Steve); sister Helen; and ten loving grandchildren. Memorial service Sunday, November 8th at Noon, Temple Shaaray Tefila, Bedford Corners, NY. Donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida.

HARRIS--Shirley. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Shirley Harris, beloved mother of Jeffrey Harris and mother-in-law of Jamie Harris. Jeffrey and Jamie, respected for their exceptional philanthropy and leadership in the Jewish community, are devoted to social and humanitarian causes, enriching the lives of many in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our sympathies to Shirley's beloved husband, Merle; to the couple's children, Jeffrey and Jamie, Steven and Gina Harris, and Julie Harris; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

FRIEDMAN - Susan M. nee West, 59, adored wife of Martin Eder, proud mother of Allie & Melissa, beloved daughter of Bette West & the late Mort West, cherished sister of Rob West & sister-in-law Mindy, & aunt to Ross, passed away peacefully in San Diego, on Sat., Oct. 31, after a very brave battle with brain cancer. She will be remembered by her family, her co-workers at Sun & Moon, & her very close network of friends as an adventurous, independent & determined woman who lived her life to the fullest every day. She will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched. A special ceremony in celebration of Susan's life will be held on Nov. 6, at 11 AM at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79th St. Bette, Rob, Mindy, Ross, Martin, Melissa & Allie

Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, November 8 at McLaughlin and Sons, Inc., Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn, NY. 718-238-3600. Donations can be made to Maimonides Cancer Center or the Metropolitan Museum.

GOLDFIELD--Alfred S.,on November 4, 2009, at the age of 70. Cherished husband of Joan, adored father of Amanda (David) Sarno and Alexis (Seth) Leven, loving grandfather of Olivia and Chloe Sarno, devoted son of Anne and the late Max Goldfield, son-in-law of Marian and the late Frank Strassburger, beloved brother of Michael (Ronnie) and H.P. (Kristin). Precious uncle and nephew, treasured friend, esteemed colleague and generous mentor. Graduate of Yale University ('61), Columbia University Law School ('64), and partner in the New York law firm of Balsam, Felber and Goldfield. To have known Alfred is to be truly blessed. Funeral Friday, November 6 at 1:30pm, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Alfred's memory to The National Kidney Foundation, 30 East 33rd St., New York, NY 10016 or www.kidney.org

McNEELA--Ita McGeady, 92, born in Derry City, Ireland, passed away on November 3. Predeceased by husband Martin. Beloved mother of Anita (Charles) McLoughlin, Martin (Nancy) McNeela, Seamus (Geraldine) McNeela, Brian (Kevin Cooper) McNeela, Moira (Jude) Hayes. Loving grandmother of 21 and great-grandmother of 16. Adored aunt to many in Ireland, England and the U.S. She was the belle of Derry and remains the belle of our hearts.

I've written before about the surprising patterns in pay during this recession. Those patterns continue in today's report: hourly wages accelerated in October. The average hourly pay of rank-and-file workers, who make up about four-fifths of the work force, rose 5 cents, to $18.72 an hour.

Actors' Equity Association said Friday that an actor who was fired from a Hartford Stage theater production after attaching reminders of his dialogue to his costume has been compensated for pay he says he was owed. The actor, Matt Mulhern, was appearing in Horton Foote's "Orphans' Home Cycle," a nine-hour series of three plays, and was fired on Sept. 22 after he peeked at bits of dialogue that he had taped inside his character's hat. In a statement, Actors' Equity said that it had filed for arbitration with the League of Resident Theaters, which includes Hartford Stage, and that the claim would be resolved. Mr. Mulhern said in a video posted on YouTube that he had been paid the week's salary that he said he was owed. Hartford Stage, which has not said why it fired him, said Friday in a statement that it "confirms that it made a business decision to resolve a dispute with Matthew Mulhern by paying him an additional week's salary. That decision does not constitute or imply agreement that Mr. Mulhern had a valid claim."

To visit the Archipelago of the Bijagós - a spattering of 88 palm-fringed and thinly populated islands off the coast of West Africa - is to enter another world and another century. Adam Nossiter, the West Africa bureau chief for The New York Times, made the voyage last June and found a magical and beguiling place.
A silver stove pipe now pokes through the cabin's green roof. Ah, what a sight!

The college football season has hit a bit of a late mid-season lull, at least on paper. With only two games that are top-25 matchups, this Saturday may seem like a bit of a yawner. But Louisiana State presents a significant challenge for its old coach Nick Saban and his undefeated Alabama team. Will the Crimson Tide be able to get past the Tigers and remain in the middle of the Bowl Championship Series conversation, or will a win by the Tigers brighten the chances of another team, perhaps even an upstart like Cincinnati or Boise State? And then there's Terrelle Pryor's first trip to Penn State with Ohio State. Joe Paterno certainly wanted Pryor to join the Nittany Lions, but he chose the Buckeyes and his career has been a little rocky thus far. Would a marquee road victory help turn things around? Perhaps the most unexpected matchup comes from Tobacco Road, where the fierce basketball rivals, Duke and North Carolina, find themselves in the middle of the A.C.C. race. Might there be a last-second finish, reminiscent of so many men's basketball games between the Blue Devils and the Tar Heels? Our prognosticators have their thoughts but, as always, if you agree, disagree or merely feel their picks out laughable, feel free to chime in.

The killing of five British soldiers on Tuesday at a checkpoint in Helmand Province by one of the Afghan police officers they were training was a reminder of how lonely death is in a foreign place and how intractable this part of the world has been for outsiders passing through. In Kabul there is a British cemetery, which in truth has only a few visible British headstones these days and mostly is filled with Europeans, but it stands as a statement of how poorly the West has done in this part of the world.

With the group we have right now, and the injuries we have, we have to grind out games like this. We have a veteran core here that understands that."

Lost any luggage recently? If you've flown through Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, you may have your answer. The Phoenix police have found nearly 1,000 pieces of luggage, along with plenty of other personal property, in the home of one couple, The Arizona Republic is reporting.

Waris Ahluwalia is the latest to explore the allure of India and its long history of sparking creativity with his book "To India With Love" (Assouline). India's star has shone in film, literature, music, photography and fashion. Ahluwalia attempts to capture these experiences with contributions from creative types who have found inspiration on the country. The result is a scrapbook of sorts, with each page highlighting the jeweler-slash-actor's friends' experiences with India in prose, photography, drawings or a combination thereof. Highlights include Wes Anderson's picture of teeth and dental instruments for sale (see Anderson's India-infused Profile in Style here), James Ivory recounting the turning point that was his meeting Ismail Merchant - complete with a photo of Merchant's first Indian passport - and a strange story about a beauty parlor and carnivorous dogs by Natalie Portman (see her T Screen Test here). Proceeds from the book, which was inspired in part by last year's attacks on Mumbai, will benefit the Taj Public Service Welfare Trust.

In every other sport you have to wait for the playoffs. As the regular season winds down teams with leads rest starters and begin to prepare for the postseason. Not in college football. As the season winds down the pressure on the top teams grows. The better you've been through the course of the season the more pressure is on you. You need to perform week in and week out. No resting anyone. In college football, the regular season is the playoffs. Think about this weekend's Alabama/L.S.U. game. A 3:30 p.m. game on a November Saturday at Bryant-Denny Stadium with the SEC West on the line definitely has a playoff feel about it. Ohio State/Penn State at Beaver Stadium is basically an elimination game in the Big Ten. At this point in the season, every week is a playoff game for teams like Iowa, Texas, Florida, Boise State, T.C.U. and Cincinnati. The more teams that are undefeated the more important it gets not to lose. No one can afford a let down. The weather is colder, the stakes are higher and total chaos always seems right around the corner. Gotta love the college football.

Andre Saraiva, the Paris nightclub impresario and hotel entrepreneur behind Le Baron and Hotel Amour, has set his sites on another culturati playground: St.-Tropez. At his new Hotel Ermitage, a 27-room 19th-century villa in the heart of the seaside hot spot, Saraiva has commissioned the leading lights of design - Marc Newson, Jean Pigozzi, Christian Louboutin, Olivier Zahm - to individually create each room, and he's stocked the rest of the place with pieces by Mathieu Matégot, Jean Prouvé and Ettore Sottsass, among others. Jean Pigozzi's candid black-and-white snapshots of Hollywood stars line the walls of the downstairs Veuve Clicquot bar. And according to the guest book, Snoop Dogg takes up residence in the Belvedere Suite when he's in town. (It does, after all, come fully equipped with its own private bar and entertaining area.)

In a video that was recently posted on his official Web site, the tenor Rolando Villazón offered his fans a couple of surprises. The first, he said, was that he had grown his hair long; the second, he said, was that "my voice is back." In April, Mr. Villazón canceled several performances through the end of the year after announcing that he needed surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords; in July, a statement posted on his site, rolandovillazon.com, said that the surgery had taken place and gone "very well." In the new video message, Mr. Villazón said he was "polishing little details to be able to come back as soon as possible next year to the stage and to sing for you," and ended by singing the word "Ciao." Agence France-Presse reported that the tenor had withdrawn from a planned performance in "Carmen" next year at the Vienna State Opera, but had not yet announced his decisions about scheduled performances in "Idomeneo" in Paris and "Manon" in London.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: During his speech in Wisconsin yesterday, President Obama explained that he was upset with his daughter, Malia, after she got a 73 on her science test. When I heard that, I was like: "Seventy-three? I would have killed for a 73."

Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of New York, a fierce champion in Congress of a single-payer health system that would be fully run by the government, said Friday that he had agreed not to insist on a vote on that issue, in an effort to help Democratic leaders pass their plan.

"American Beauty: Aesthetics and Innovation in Fashion," the latest exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology (F.I.T.), opens today. Featuring 25 American fashion designers, the exhibit showcases the reigning bigwigs of yesteryear and the hot young things of today. Sponsored by 1stdibs, the exhibit includes some sizzling pieces like a Pauline Trigère evening coat and a sparkling Adrian gown once worn by Joan Crawford, as well as swishy numbers by Rodarte, Ralph Rucci and James Galanos. To learn a bit more about the exhibit, The Moment bent the ear of Dr. Valerie Steele, director of the Museum at FIT, about recession chic, hip-hop fashion and why the show isn't called "American Fierceness."

"You Never Give Me Your Money" isn't just a Beatles song -- it's also a compelling legal argument. A federal court in Los Angeles has issued a temporary restraining order against a Web site that the record label EMI said was selling the music of the Beatles without permission, Reuters reported. EMI, which releases the music of the Beatles, took legal action Tuesday against BlueBeat.com, which had been selling Fab Four tracks for 25 cents each. (The Beatles currently do not allow their songs to be sold online, individually or as complete albums, for any price.) In a statement, EMI said that it "did not authorize its content to be sold or made available on BlueBeat.com." In response, BlueBeat had argued that it "sold entirely different sound recordings" that were created through a process called "psycho-acoustic simulation," according to Reuters. The court is scheduled to hear arguments in the case on Nov. 20.

A German antiquities expert will attend talks next month to discuss Egypt's demand for the return of a 3,500-year-old bust of Queen Nefertiti, Agence France-Presse reported. Zahi Hawass, head of Egypt's antiquities council, said that a meeting planned in Egypt on Dec. 8 to discuss the possession of the statue would be attended by the director of the Egyptian antiquities department at the Berlin museum. The bust of Nefertiti, the wife of the pharaoh Akhenaten, is currently on display at the Neues Museum in Berlin; it was discovered by the German archaeologist Ludwig Borchardt in 1912, who said he had Egyptian approval to take it. But Egypt has been calling for its return since 1930, and Mr. Hawass said that at the December meeting he would present evidence that "proves the statue left in an illegal way," according to Agence France-Presse. Mr. Hawass also said that the Berlin museum official would make the case "that the statue left Egypt through legal channels."

Back in the first few months of the current administration, when I was writing piece after piece urging the new administration to adopt a more aggressive economic policy, what I had very much in my mind -- and wrote about on a few occasions -- was the possibility of a sort of political economy trap. If unemployment continued to rise, I feared, Congress wouldn't draw the right conclusion -- that we needed more stimulus. Instead, the verdict would be that Obama's economic policies weren't working, so we needed to do less. And high unemployment would also lead to Democratic electoral losses, further undermining the ability to act (since the fact is that today's GOP is the party of economic ignorance). The result would be a persistently depressed economy, and a fading out of Obama's promise.

AIDS Geography| San Francisco's public health department has taken the practice of mapping the prevalence of HIV/AIDS by neighborhood to the next level. Instead of simply locating infected individuals, the new maps pinpoint the locations of the sickest individuals. "These hot spots are perpetuating themselves," Dr. Julio Montaner, president of the International AIDS Society said, praising the city's effort. The ultimate goal is to provide treatment and prevent transmission of the disease.

An obituary on Thursday about Michael Ronis, who helped conceive the Manhattan restaurant Carmine’s, misstated the profession of Drew Nieporent, who said Mr. Ronis “made a big impact on our industry.” While he is indeed a restaurateur, he is not a chef.
A theater review on Oct. 22 about “Avenue Q,” which reopened Off Broadway at New World Stages, misstated the length of the show’s run in Las Vegas in 2005 and 2006. It was nine months, not five.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about J.P. Morgan Securities’ settlement of a bribery case involving derivatives contracts misidentified, in some copies, the state in which Larry Langford, who was convicted in the case, served as mayor of Birmingham. It was Alabama, not North Carolina. (There is no Birmingham, N.C.).

An article on Wednesday about the Oshkosh Corporation’s success in providing the Pentagon a new armored truck for use in Afghanistan’s rugged terrain misstated the truck’s hill-climbing capabilities. The trucks can drive up 60 percent inclines, not 60-degree inclines. (The grade of a slope is expressed as percentage of vertical distance over horizontal distance; a 60 percent incline translates to a slope of about 30 degrees.) The error was repeated in a picture caption.

A picture caption on Thursday with the Our Towns column, about anger over property taxes among voters in the New York suburbs, misstated the outcome of Thomas R. Suozzi’s race for re-election as Nassau County executive. Mr. Suozzi, a Democrat, has a slight lead over his Republican challenger, Edward P. Mangano, but the winner has not yet been determined; Mr. Suozzi did not lose the race.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about Michael R. Bloomberg’s narrow victory in the New York mayoral race referred incorrectly to a voter who said Mr. Bloomberg “ran a smear campaign against a nonexistent opponent.” The voter, Stav Brinbaum, is a woman. The article also misstated, in some copies, the age of a second voter, Gerni Oster, who called Mr. Bloomberg “egotistical and arrogant,” and misspelled, in some copies, the given name of a professor who said she voted for Mr. Bloomberg’s Democratic rival. Ms. Oster is 32, not 34; the professor is Kathryn Krase, not Katherine.

The unlikely darling of both Tyler Perry and Oscar watchers, “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” the story of an impoverished, overweight, illiterate teenager twice impregnated by her father, is part bootstrap drama and part lurid potboiler, A.O. Scott writes: “‘Precious’ is a hybrid, a mash-up that might have been ungainly but that manages to be graceful instead.” A lot of credit goes to its first-time star, Gabourey Sidibe, who unreservedly embodies the role. “‘Precious’ is unabashedly populist in its potent emotional appeal,” Mr. Scott writes, “and at the same time determined to challenge its audience’s complacency as only a genuine work of art can.”

The trade publication Publishers Weekly probably wanted to provoke discussion with its annual list of the year’s best books, but not like this. In its issue of Nov. 2 Publishers Weekly compiled its PW Top 10, a decidedly subjective ranking of the best fiction and nonfiction published in 2009, including the biography “Cheever: A Life,” by Blake Bailey; the novel “Await Your Reply,” by Dan Chaon; and the graphic novel “Stitches,” by David Small. But as The Guardian reports, the ranking has drawn protests from a women’s literary group that notes there are no female writers on the list. Cate Marvin, a founder of the group Women in Letters and Literary Arts, told The Guardian, “The absence made me nearly speechless.” In her introduction to the year-end list Louisa Ermelino, the reviews director of Publishers Weekly, wrote, “We ignored gender and genre and who had the buzz.” She added, “It disturbed us when we were done that our list was all male.”.

Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, told The Detroit Free Press that he felt lucky to be alive after having emergency surgery on Sunday to unblock a clogged artery. Mr. Slatkin, 65, right, the former music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, had a heart attack and collapsed just after conducting the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands and is now in a hospital there after undergoing an angioplasty and stent procedure. In an e-mail exchange with The Free Press, Mr. Slatkin wrote that he experienced chest pains earlier in the week but dismissed them as indigestion. At the Sunday concert, he wrote: “I started having trouble with chest pain, and I was sweating more than usual. Again, I thought it would go away but it stuck around. I sort of collapsed in the dressing room, and a medical team from the hall was sent in. Five minutes later I was in an ambulance on the way to the hospital.” The Detroit Symphony told The Free Press that Mr. Slatkin was still scheduled to conduct the orchestra in Detroit this month, but that contingency plans were being made.

The producers of the multimillion-dollar Broadway musical “Spider-man, Turn Off the Dark” have scheduled a meeting in Manhattan on Friday with the director Julie Taymor and other members of the creative team to discuss the show’s future, two executives involved in the project said Thursday. They said that the producers would update the creative team on the project’s cash-flow problems, and that Ms. Taymor would say that it would be difficult to begin rehearsals before January. Even if the musical’s financial difficulties are solved in time for rehearsals to begin this winter, the show is so technically complex — Spider-man’s acrobatics and possible mid-air flight for instance — that Ms. Taymor and the producers may not be prepared to open the show by April 29, the cutoff date for Tony Award nominations, said the executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly about the production. If the show is not ready to be considered for the Tonys this season, the reasoning goes, the production team and cast would be better off waiting to open later — assuming the producers aren’t faced with a huge financial penalty for delaying use of the Hilton Theater, which they have already ripped up to accommodate Ms. Taymor’s vision for the musical. The show is still scheduled to begin previews on Feb. 25 and open in March, but several people involved in the production said those dates would change.

Choosing one’s next movie project after winning Academy Awards for best director and best film doesn’t always come quickly — just ask James Cameron — but Danny Boyle, whose film “Slumdog Millionaire” won eight Oscars in February, has figured out his follow-up. Variety reported that Mr. Boyle (whose films also include “Trainspotting” and “28 Days Later”) will next direct “127 Hours,” a biographical film about the mountaineer Aron Lee Ralston. Mr. Ralston made headlines in 2003 when an 800-pound boulder fell on his right hand and crushed it while he was exploring Robbers Roost in southeastern Utah. After being trapped for several days, he sawed off the lower part of the trapped arm and hiked to his rescue. The project is expected to reunite Mr. Boyle with two “Slumdog Millionaire” colleagues: the screenwriter Simon Beaufoy and the producer Christian Colson. Production is to begin next year; no casting has yet been announced.

Poor Mrs. Elliot may be gone to heaven, but somehow she keeps reproducing. On Thursday the producers of “Billy Elliot the Musical” said two more actors would be joining its Broadway cast to portray the title role. Dayton Tavares, 13, who has played the character in the musical’s Sydney and Melbourne casts, will become the sixth member of the Broadway Billy club, and Liam Redhead, 14, a student of the National Ballet School in Toronto, will become the seventh, the show’s publicists said in a news release. Also, Tommy Batchelor, who is leaving the Broadway cast to play Billy in the show’s Chicago production, will play his final New York performance on Dec. 11. The Broadway role was originated by David Alvarez, Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, who won Tony Awards for their performances. Starting dates for Mr. Tavares and Mr. Redhead were not announced.

Courtney Love threatened to do it, but Gwen Stefani actually did it: Ms. Stefani and her band, No Doubt, have sued the makers of the Guitar Hero video game franchise, saying that their latest entry in the series misuses the likenesses of the group members, Reuters reported. In its lawsuit against the game publisher Activision Blizzard, No Doubt said it had agreed on Ms. Stefani and her band mates appearing in the new game Band Hero. But the rock group said that the game makers went too far by allowing Ms. Stefani’s virtual counterpart to perform songs that No Doubt never recorded, including “Honky Tonk Women” by the Rolling Stones. This “results in an unauthorized performance by the Gwen Stefani avatar in a male voice boasting about having sex with prostitutes,” the lawsuit says. In a statement Activision Blizzard said it “believes it is within its legal rights with respect to the use and portrayal of the band members in the game.” Ms. Love, the widow of the Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain, raised similar objections when she learned that a Cobain avatar could be used to perform other artists’ songs in the video game Guitar Hero 5.

CANTOR--Marjorie (Hoffman), 88 died peacefully on October 31st, 2009 in New York City. She is survived by her daughter Nancy and Nancy's husband Steve (Brechin), her son Richard and his wife Andrea (Lilienthal), her four beloved grandchildren Maddy, Archie, Andrew and Eliza, her sister, Muriel Brotsky and her sister-in-law, Ruth Bernstein. A lifelong New Yorker, a graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University Teachers College, Marjorie worked passionately and tirelessly to understand and aid individuals and organizations for whom she cared deeply. Beginning with her work with migrant farm workers in upstate New York, she continued doing pioneering research for diverse groups such as The Girl Scouts of America and Vista. Marjorie found her true calling during Mayor John Lindsay's administration as Director of Research and Evaluation of the New York City department for the Aging, where she was the principal investigator of the 1970 landmark cross-ethnic study ''The Elderly in the Inner City of New York'', as well as nine other large scale studies during her 40 years in the field of aging. A past president of the Gerontological Society of America, she was a nationally and internationally recognized leader in the field of aging. At her death, Marjorie was an Emeritus Professor and Brookdale Distinguished Scholar of the Graduate School of Social Service of Fordham University, where she had been Associate Director of the University's Third Age Center and Scholar in Residence at the Lighthouse International. Her most recent work with ACRIA, directly a groundbreaking study of older adults with HIV in New York City, continued her lifelong commitment to illuminating the lives of those she felt underrepresented in our society. As the author of more then seventy-five publications, Marjorie served as a consultant to numerous Federal, State and local agencies and boards, including the Council of Senior Centers and Services of New York and Elder Share the Arts. She participated in both the 1980 and 1995 White House Conference on Aging, The International Forum on Aging in Beijing and gave the keynote address on the Symposium on the Jewish Family at the First World Conference on Jewish Services for the Elderly in Jerusalem. She will be deeply missed by her family , for whom she served as a loving beacon and exemplar to her friends and by her colleagues in the field of aging. A memorial celebration of her life and work is planned for early December in New York City, date TBA.

NEMSER--Barbara F.,79, a longtime resident of Rye and recently of Mamaroneck, passed away peacefully on November 4, 2009. She was predeceased by her husband Stanley and son Jonathan. She was the daughter of Frederick P. and Mercedes Fisher and born in Quakertown, PA. She came to New York for school and graduated from Barnard College in 1951. She is survived by one sister, Araminta Cahn of Mountainhome, PA and several nieces and nephews. In addition to singing, having been featured on local radio in her youth, Barbara was an accomplished artist, winning several awards for her paintings, an opera enthusiast, an experienced traveler, and a spirited bridge player. She was active in the Women's Club of Rye serving as its president in 1995-1996. She will be interred in Valley Forge, PA with her family. Beloved husband of Barbara and the late Marjorie Rosmarin; Devoted father of sons Jay, Roy and Joshua Elvove and stepsons Robert and William Abrams; grandfather of Allison, Samantha, Elisa, Zachary, Brian and Ethan; brother of the late Sara, Ethel, Kadie and Louis; uncle of numerous nieces and nephews. A graveside service is planned for Friday, November 6th at 1:00pm at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

LEVI-STRAUSS--Claude. The New School remembers Claude Levi-Strauss, anthropologist, philosopher, one of the intellectual giants of the past century. The United States greatly benefited from his exile in New York City during World War II when he taught at The New School for Social Research. He was a major influence on several generations of scholars and students around the world, including many of our own faculty colleagues. His books continue to be an inspiration to students of social science everywhere. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Michael J. Johnston, Chair, Board of Trustees Michael Schober, Dean The New School for Social Research

HENDERSON--Richard. The Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture of The Cooper Union mourns the passing of Richard Henderson, Professor and Associate Dean Emeritus. Richard served as Associate Dean of the School with great dedication and grace, was a masterful teacher of sublime intelligence, and a distinguished architect. He wrote of his seminal "Analysis" studio project: "Neither the definitive exposition of fact nor the meticulous rendering of description can hope to evoke the mysterious life embodied in enduring architecture". We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his family. He will be deeply missed and long remembered.

The Yankees return to the Canyon of Heroes for the first time since 2000 on Friday morning, when they will float up Broadway in a ticker-tape parade and share their 27th World Series victory with fans in Lower Manhattan. The parade starts at 11 a.m. at Battery Place and will go north on Broadway to Chambers Street. The parade should end at 1 p.m. at City Hall, where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will give the Yankees the keys to the city.

A same-sex unions ballot measure nicknamed ''Everything But Marriage'' appeared on its way toward passing, even as election officials continued to receive ballots in the largely mail-in election. With more than 70 percent of ballots estimated to have been counted, 52 percent of voters had supported the measure, while 48 percent had opposed it. Ballots had to be postmarked by Tuesday. The measure, Referendum 71, asked voters to approve or reject a wide-ranging domestic partnerships bill passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature this spring and signed by Gov. Christine Gregoire, a Democrat.

If the health care system is overhauled, patients and practitioners alike will face a primary care bottleneck. An estimated 30 million newly insured people will begin making appointments for checkups and other routine care with physicians who are already stretched thin caring for existing patients. The increase in demand may well put an end to a simmering policy dispute over the circumscribed role of nurse practitioners in medical care. If tens of millions of new patients enter the health care system, it seems clear that nurse practitioners will be needed to perform many of the tasks now performed by physicians.

SPIEGEL--Jerry, 84, of Kings Point, NY on November 3rd. We are heartbroken by the loss of our extraordinary father. A pioneer in his field and a man of honor and substance, he led his life with integrity, courage and a sense of humor. His remarkable journey from potato farmer to successful businessman inspired us all. He taught us many life lessons including generosity, hard work and the importance of family. Born on the Fourth of July, he was the ultimate "All-American guy." He loved simple pleasures and enjoyed all that life had to offer. Our father shared an incredible marriage to our mother, the love of his life, and now joins his beautiful Emily for eternity. Our hero, he will remain forever in our hearts. He is survived by his daughters Pamela Sanders and Lise Wilks; sons-in-law Arthur Sanders and Jeffrey Wilks; and grandchildren Jordan, Remy and Erin Sanders and David, Andrew and Jack Wilks. Services will be held on Friday, November 6th at 11:30am, Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, Five Old Mill Road. The family will be sitting on Friday at 2:30pm and on Saturday from 4:30pm to 7:30pm at the home of Jerry Spiegel, 10 Broadlawn Avenue, Kings Point.

SPIEGEL--Jerry. Our loving Grandfather had a passion for family, life and business. His quick wit never ceased to amaze us, and we were an easy audience to his one liners. Born on the fourth of July was not just a coincidence, as he epitomized the American Dream. Some of the most important moments of our lives were shared with him. We will hold these memories close to our hearts and always look back on them with great fondness. We love you, Grandpa, and will always remember you. With love, Jordan, Remy and Erin

My Sunday column looks at chemicals that the government has been slow to regulate, even though they are suspected of pernicious effects on our bodies by disrupting the endocrine system. The results appear to range from malformed genitalia to premature puberty to obesity and diabetes. I focus on BPA, a chemical variant of estrogen that is often used in plastics and other consumer products. Two billion pounds are manufactured in the US each year -- and as a result it is found in 92 percent of us. It's one of a number of endocrine disruptors that appear to have adverse effects on the body's hormone system.

An article on Tuesday about a conference at Hampshire College in Massachusetts on creationism in the Islamic world referred incorrectly to a comment by the event’s organizer, Salman Hameed. In noting that researchers did not have much information about the teaching and perception of evolution in Arab countries, Dr. Hameed was citing the example of textbooks used by private Saudi schools in the United States, not in Saudi Arabia.
As the Yankees’ Nick Swisher put it, getting up at 6:30 a.m. was not hard because “you know someone is going to be cheering for you all day.”

An article on Tuesday about an experimental gene therapy procedure intended to improve vision misstated the name of a gene used in a treatment of five children and seven adults with a type of congenital retinal disease. It is RPE65, not REP65.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Schubert Ascending mini-festival presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center misspelled, at one point, the surname of a pianist who will perform. As noted elsewhere in the entry, he is Inon Barnatan, not Barnaton.

An article on Oct. 29 about a blog by Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misstated the given name of the bishop of Brooklyn, who does not have a blog. He is Nicholas DiMarzio, not Anthony (Anthony is his middle name).

An article on Friday about Fugitive Safe Surrender, a government program that promises leniency to those wanted for nonviolent crimes, misstated the name of the Newark church where officers ran computer checks on participants. It is Bethany Baptist Church, not Bethel Baptist Church.

A report in the Prescriptions column on Wednesday about civil rights groups’ unveiling a “war room” in Washington to push for a government-run health plan misstated the age of one of the groups, the Urban League. It is 99 years old, not 109.

An article last Saturday about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s sparring with the Pakistani press during a recent trip to Pakistan misstated, in some editions, Najam Sethi’s relationship to The Daily Times, an English-language paper. He is the former editor in chief, not the current editor. (As the article correctly noted in some editions he is the editor of The Friday Times, an English-language weekly.).

To take Synergenz’s Respiragene test, consumers swab the inside of a cheek to get DNA and send the sample to a laboratory in Kentucky. The Synergenz Web site says a physician is required to sign a form requesting the test. The Respiragene test looks at 20 spots in a person’s genome where DNA varies among people. It uses that data, as well as nongenetic information like the person’s smoking history, to compute a risk score.

SPIEGEL--Jerry, 84, of Kings Point, NY on November 3rd. We are heartbroken by the loss of our extraordinary father. A pioneer in his field and a man of honor and substance, he led his life with integrity, courage and a sense of humor. His remarkable journey from potato farmer to successful businessman inspired us all. He taught us many life lessons including generosity, hard work and the importance of family. Born on the Fourth of July, he was the ultimate "All-American guy." He loved simple pleasures and enjoyed all that life had to offer. Our father shared an incredible marriage to our mother, the love of his life, and now joins his beautiful Emily for eternity. Our hero, he will remain forever in our hearts. He is survived by his daughters Pamela Sanders and Lise Wilks; sons-in-law Arthur Sanders and Jeffrey Wilks; and grandchildren Jordan, Remy and Erin Sanders and David, Andrew and Jack Wilks. Services will be held on Friday, November 6th at 11:30am, Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, Five Old Mill Road. The family will be sitting on Friday at 2:30pm and on Saturday from 4:30pm to 7:30pm at the home of Jerry Spiegel, 10 Broadlawn Avenue, Kings Point.

Amid the long and complicated health bills in Congress, there is at least one simple idea. And it would directly affect anyone who uses a prescription drug: numerical charts that could make medicine labels resemble the nutrition panels on food packages. That proposal, tucked into the Senate health committee's overhaul bill, would require the Food and Drug Administration to study whether such charts, quantifying the risks and benefits of a drug, would help physicians and consumers make better health choices. On sleeping pills, for example, a chart might show how many hours of sleep a pill typically provided a night compared with a placebo.

SPIEGEL--Jerry. The employees and officers of Spiegel Associates mourn the loss of Jerry Spiegel their beloved founder and Chairman. Jerry was a dynamic Long Island developer who built an empire through vision and purpose. He was philanthropic and generously supported medical research, education, the art world and many other charities. He will be deeply missed by all of us and will remain in our hearts and minds. Our deepest condolences to his daughters, sons-in-law, grandchildren, nephews, nieces and his entire family.

In a video that was posted on his official Web site, the tenor Rolando Villazón offered his fans a couple of surprises. The first, he said, was that he had grown his hair long; the second, he said, was that ''my voice is back.'' In April Mr. Villazón canceled several performances through the end of the year after announcing that he needed surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords; in July a statement posted on his site, rolandovillazon.com, said that the surgery had taken place and gone ''very well.'' In the new video message Mr. Villazón said he was ''polishing little details to be able to come back as soon as possible next year to the stage and to sing for you,'' and he ended by singing ''Ciao.'' Agence France-Presse reported that he had withdrawn from a planned performance in ''Carmen'' next year at the Vienna State Opera but that he had not yet announced decisions about scheduled performances in ''Idomeneo'' in Paris and ''Manon'' in London.

''Survivor,'' ''CSI'' and ''The Mentalist'' lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday night, winning every hour of prime time. According to Nielsen's estimates, CBS's crime show ''The Mentalist'' delivered the largest audience, with 15.4 million viewers, outperforming competitors in the 10 o'clock hour, ''Private Practice'' on ABC (9.2 million) and ''The Jay Leno Show'' on NBC (4.7 million). The ''Mentalist'' numbers improved upon CBS's 9 o'clock showing for ''CSI'' (15.1 million) and the tally at 8 for ''Survivor: Samoa'' (12.7 million). ABC's ''FlashForward'' and Fox's ''Bones'' tied for second at 8, with 8.5 million viewers each, while ABC's ''Grey's Anatomy'' was runner-up at 9, with 13.6 million, despite delivering the night's top ratings in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49. ABC led the night in that age group, followed by CBS, and NBC and Fox in third and fourth place. NBC earned its highest ratings during the 9 o'clock hour with ''The Office'' (7.9 million) and ''30 Rock'' (5.9 million). NBC's comedies at 8 and 8:30, ''Community'' (5.6 million) and ''Parks and Recreation'' (4.9 million), were both up slightly, compared with last week.

EARLY START TO CELEBRATION By 9:30 a.m. there were already streamers in the trees and covering the base of the Woolworth building on Broadway. Air horns went off and everyone, it seemed, wore hats and scarves, all blue and white, of course.
