Fans of ''South Park'' are well aware that Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the creators of that Comedy Central animated series, are not exactly delicate about the language on the show. An episode broadcast on Wednesday elicited a call from the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation that Comedy Central and the ''South Park'' staff apologize for what the alliance called a ''slur-filled episode.'' On the episode, called ''The F-Word,'' the children of ''South Park,'' above, frequently say the word ''fag'' as they try to change the meaning of the word to a slur against inconsiderate motorcyclists instead of against gay people. In a news release officials of the advocacy group said that they recognized that the episode was trying to ''use edgy humor to provide commentary on current issues.'' They added: ''Yet despite what the 'South Park' writers may believe, the definition of the F-word remains one that is harmful and derogatory.'' In a statement, Comedy Central said that the episode ''has been both criticized and applauded within the gay and lesbian community.''''With all of that in mind,'' it continued, we will let this 'South Park' episode speak for itself.''

IT was an improbable sight: a slightly hunched man, with a gait that suggested either his age (72) or infirmity (a bad back and knees that required replacement surgery), beating up a taller opponent no older than 30.

PEDERSEN--Peer T.,a long-time resident of Rye, New York, died Thursday, November 4, 2009, at the New Canaan home of his youngest daughter, Lucy P. Hazard, with his children by his side. Peer was born July 31, 1924 at New Rochelle Hospital in New Rochelle, New York, to the late Eunice H. Terrill and Jacob Otto Pedersen. Peer was a graduate of New Rochelle High School, Dartmouth College where he was a Rufus Choate Scholar, and New York Law School. Peer was a Lieutenant Gunnery Officer of the USS Hyman, Destroyer Class, in the Pacific campaign from 1943-1946, and subsequent to the end of World War II served in the US Naval Reserve until 1956. Peer was married in 1955 to Lucy Katherine Schaefer (deceased 2007) from whom he was divorced in 1984. He practiced law for much of the past six decades at the law firm of Keenan & Pedersen located in New York, NY; he was a former Board member and General Counsel of East River Savings Bank, a former Board member of Apple Bank, both headquartered in New York City, as well as a former member of the Board of Trustees of The Rye Country Day School, in Rye, New York. A lifelong and avid all-around athlete, Peer played competitive basketball during the 1950s in New York City where he starred for several teams including the Solin Sports Club, and he played golf for most of his adult life at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, New York, where he was a member since 1946. Peer was loving father to his four children, Peer Jr., Donna Fenech, Lyn Elizabeth, and Lucy Hazard, and a loving grandfather to his eight grandchildren, Peer III, Paige, Madeline, Samantha, and Margaret Pedersen, and Nathan, Lorraine, and Kerri Fenech. Peer is also survived by son-in-laws Craig Fenech and Scott Hazard, and former daughter-in-law Mary Quick Pedersen. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY 10580 on Monday, November 9th from 5-8pm. A service in celebration of his life will be held at The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY on Tuesday, November 10th at 11am, immediately followed by a reception at the Westchester Country Club.

TEIG--Morris, 96 years old, of Stamford, CT died November 5, 2009 at Stamford Hospital. He was born on the Eastside of Manhattan July 13, 1913. He attended Brooklyn College, graduating from St. John's Law School in 1938. He filled his life with his legal profession, spending hours at the Stamford and Norwalk courthouses. At his death, he was Connecticut's oldest fulltime practicing attorney. He is survived by his daughter Phyllis Moss (Stephen) of Nanuet, NY and his sons Bernard Teig (Sheila) of Stamford, CT, Joel Teig (Marjorie) of Smithtown, NY, Howard Teig (Judi) of Jericho, NY, his sister Helen Teig of Bronx, NY, 10 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife Hilda, his parents, his brother Joseph Teig and sister Yetta Kriegel.

McNAMARA--Patricia, died November 5, 2009 in Lurgan, Northern Ireland at age 83. Survived by eight of her original 12 brothers and sisters, many nieces and nephews and by many others who loved her. A native of County Roscommon in Ireland, Patricia was a professional nanny and nurse who moved to America in March 1955. A big and handsome woman, she was loving, kind, wise, and fiercely principled and independent. She made a huge positive impact on the children whom she raised over a period of 50 years: Louis Gershon of North London; the children of the late Norman and Alice Newhouse when they lived in Great Neck, L.I., Robin, Mark, Peter, Jonathan and David Newhouse; Giles and Julian Eyre, and their two brothers, of New York City, and lastly, Charlie Stone, now living in North Carolina. It was Charlie who last year reached out to her former charges and reconnected them to Patricia after so many years without contact. She loved to travel in her free time and had many friends, especially in Ireland. She loved the cliffs of Donegal. Her intellectual interests ranged from architecture to the Russian language. But her great gift was the love she brought into the lives of the children she raised. For this one, it is a light which will never be extinguished. Jonathan Newhouse, London

DIALING UP THE INTENSITY Sean Felder, 42, a security officer from the Bronx, is a veteran when it comes to victory parades. He was there when the Yankees celebrated in 1996 and 1998 and he saw the Giants' parade in 2008. He even remembered being at the parade for the Mets as a young man in 1986. ''New York City's like no other city in the world when it's got a championship team,'' he said.

A German antiquities expert will attend talks next month to discuss Egypt's demand for the return of a 3,500-year-old bust of Queen Nefertiti, Agence France-Presse reported. Zahi Hawass, head of Egypt's antiquities council, said that a meeting planned in Egypt on Dec. 8 to discuss the possession of the bust, above, would be attended by the director of the Egyptian antiquities department at the Berlin museum. The bust of Nefertiti, the wife of the pharaoh Akhenaten, is on display at the Neues Museum in Berlin; it was discovered in 1912 by the German archaeologist Ludwig Borchardt, who said he had Egyptian approval to take it. But Egypt has been calling for its return since 1930, and Mr. Hawass said that at the December meeting he would present evidence that ''proves the statue left in an illegal way,'' according to Agence France-Presse. Mr. Hawass also said that the Berlin museum official would make the case ''that the statue left Egypt through legal channels.''

McDERMOTT--Marilyn McDermott, a longtime Greenwich Village resident, died in New York City on Monday, November 2, 2009, at age 47. Born in Queens in 1962, Marilyn was raised in Huntington, L.I. and attended Walt Whitman H.S. She is a graduate of FIT. A talented woman known for her radiant smile, exuberant laugh and dynamic personality, Marilyn channeled her creative flair and administrative gifts into a variety of fields, including fashion, interior design, and marketing. She was also a great lover of the ocean and spent much time in Montauk. Marilyn McDermott is the daughter of Thomas McDermott, Sr. and the late Ann McDermott, and the beloved sister of Catherine McDermott and the late Thomas McDermott, Jr. She will be dearly missed and forever remembered in the hearts of her father, sister and devoted friends. A private memorial service will be held on a picturesque beach to honor her memory and celebrate her life.

CUTLER--Alvin, of Jupiter, FL, died peacefully at home on November 6, 2009 with his family at his side. He was raised in Mt. Vernon, NY and was a longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY. TRUANT FOR A CAUSE Kristen Rivelli of Islip, N.Y., let out an ''uuuggghhh'' as she tried to lift her son, Anthony Lawrence, so he could see over the crowds lining the east side of Broadway at Reade Street. It was much easier to lift Anthony, born Oct. 10, 2000, the last year the Yankees won the World Series. ''I remember holding him while we watched the games together the last time,'' Rivelli said. ''We had him all decked out in Yankees stuff then.'' This time, to celebrate the second Yankees title of his lifetime (but the first he remembers), Anthony wore a Derek Jeter T-shirt over a gray hooded sweatshirt, happy to be celebrating in the cold instead of being in his fourth-grade classroom at Sherwood Elementary on Long Island. JEFFREY MARCUS

FANS IN UNIFORM Cindy Calcaño, Marilyn Corona and Daniela Reynoso made the trip from the Army base in Teaneck, N.J., leaving at 6 a.m. They were in Iraq with the National Guard before returning this spring. ''We're veterans, we spent many late nights watching games over there,'' Corona said, drawing nods from the others. She described getting up at 3 or 4 a.m. to catch a game before going on patrol.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) FROST/NIXON (2008) In May 1977 the British television personality David Frost (played by Michael Sheen, far right) faced off against Richard M. Nixon (Frank Langella, above left), three years after Nixon left the presidency in disgrace. Mr. Frost was gambling with his money and future; Nixon, with public perception (though he earned $600,000 and 10 percent of the program's profits). The result was blockbuster ratings to rival those of ''Happy Days,'' starring Ron Howard, who directed this adaptation of Peter Morgan's play. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis described the film as ''a soothing, agreeably amusing experience, more palliative than purgative,'' adding that Mr. Langella and Mr. Sheen, who originated their roles on the London stage and later repeated them on Broadway, were ''first-rate.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY In honor of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, Deborah Potter reports from the St. Nikolai Evangelical Lutheran Church in Leipzig, Germany, where Bach played the organ and where, starting in 1980, the pastor, Christian Führer, became involved in a ''peaceful revolution'' to bring down the barrier.

Camera crews have trailed the Jackson brothers this year as they have mourned Michael Jackson and prepared for a reunion of the Jackson 5. Now the cable channel that bought the rights to the footage, A&E, has set a premiere date. ''The Jacksons: A Family Dynasty'' will begin on Dec. 13 with two one-hour episodes, the channel announced on Friday. Four more episodes will be shown on consecutive Sundays. Jackie, Jermaine and above, center and right, Tito and Marlon Jackson (Randy Jackson is at left) are the stars and executive producers of the reality series, which stems from plans for a documentary about the brothers before Mr. Jackson's death in June. Some scenes shot before June will be shown, but most of the episodes will show the brothers at more recent moments: attending the premiere of ''This Is It,'' recording vocals for a new song on the film's soundtrack and rehearsing for a Jackson 5 anniversary concert.

POWERS--Francis Clement, Sr.,90, formerly of Honolulu, HI and of Cold Spring Harbor and Oyster Bay, NY, died peacefully in New York City on October 31st. Predeceased by his former wife, Helen Whitecotton Powers, and his beloved brothers Charles, A. Jay, Jr. and Edward, he was the enthusiastic father of six children: Diana, Francis Jr., Arthur, Brian, Elizabeth and Christopher, and grandfather of nine. A graduate of the Lawrenceville School, class of 1937, and Harvard College, class of 1941, he served with the 20th U.S. Army Air Corps, WWII Pacific Theater, on Guam. He became Vice President of Sales for Powers Chemco, Inc., and a founder of Photocircuits, Inc. in Glen Cove, NY, and was a member of The New York Athletic Club and Harvard Varsity Club-inducted into its Hall of Fame in the sport of swimming. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 12th, 3pm at St. John's Church, 1620 Rte. 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to St. John's Church, P.O. Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

SPIEGEL--Jerry. The Feinstein Institute for Medical Research is greatly saddened by the death of Jerry Spiegel, a long-time supporter of The Feinstein. Mr. Spiegel's generosity enhanced the innovative, cutting edge research performed by scientists at the Emily and Jerry Spiegel Laboratory for Brain Imaging in Parkinson's Disease and helped support new clinical trials and technology to investigate and cure disease. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Ralph Nappi, Chairman, FIMR Kevin Tracey, Director and CEO, FIMR David Eidelberg, MD, Head, Center for Neuroscience, FIMR

SPIEGEL--Jerry. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Jerry Spiegel, a great friend to our Department of Neurology and our Stem Cell Initiative. We are especially grateful to him and his late wife, Emily, for their generous support of stem cell research, and its applications to our understanding and treatment of Parkinson's Disease. All of us at Columbia offer our condolences to the Spiegel family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Timothy A. Pedley, MD Chair, Department of Neurology Michael Shelanski, PhD, MD Chair, Department of Pathology and Cell Biology

LINDY--Sanford "Sandy," 86, passed away Thursday, November 5, 2009. Born in Center Brunswick, NY, graduated Troy High School, joined the US Navy, stationed in Pearl Harbor during the Japanese attack. He was a passionate skier and enjoyed reading and gardening. An enthusiastic world traveler, he made lifelong friends with his wicked sense of humor. Besides his dear wife, Lillian, he is survived by his daughter Judy and her husband Dr. Alvin Ruthenberg of New York City, and daughter-in-law Marilyn Lindy of Niskayuna, NY. He dearly loved his grandchildren, Michael Trossman of Washington, DC, Joshua Lindy and his wife Nicole, Jeffrey Lindy, of New York City, and Kate Lindy of Boston, MA. He was predeceased by his son Joel Lindy. A commemoration of Sandy's life will be held at the Molloy Funeral Home, West Hartford, CT at 1pm this Sunday.
KILCREASE--Chas L. November 8, 2008 "NOT A DAY NOT ONE DAY GOES BY" All our love always, Kenny, Ivette & Miss Kitty

The Boston Scientific Corporation agreed to pay $296 million to settle a Justice Department investigation into its Guidant unit's handling of heart devices and restated third-quarter results to show a loss. Guidant will plead to two criminal misdemeanors for failing to properly alert the Food and Drug Administration about problems with some of its implantable defibrillators, Boston Scientific said Friday. The investigation concerned product advisories sent by Guidant before its acquisition by Boston Scientific in April 2006, the parent company said. As a result of the settlement, Boston Scientific said it had a third-quarter net loss of $94 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with net income of $200 million, or 13 cents, reported in October. Adjusted earnings remained 19 cents a share.

Actors' Equity Association said Friday that an actor who was fired from a Hartford Stage theater production after attaching reminders of his dialogue to his costume has been compensated for pay he says he was owed. The actor, Matt Mulhern, left, was appearing in Horton Foote's ''Orphans' Home Cycle,'' a nine-hour series of three plays, and was fired on Sept. 22 after he peeked at bits of dialogue that he had taped inside his character's hat. In a statement, Actors' Equity said that it had filed for arbitration with the League of Resident Theaters, which includes Hartford Stage, and that the claim would be resolved. Mr. Mulhern said in a video posted on YouTube that he had been paid the week's salary that he said he was owed. Hartford Stage, which has not said why it fired him, said on Friday in a statement that it ''confirms that it made a business decision to resolve a dispute with Matthew Mulhern by paying him an additional week's salary.''''That decision,'' it continued, ''does not constitute or imply agreement that Mr. Mulhern had a valid claim.''

Just had a few reasons for wanting to link to my F1 season review story. One is just to spread the news onto the blog - ie, alert you. The other is because I wanted to draw attention to the great quote contribution in the story from a frequent and enthusiastic reader and participant in the blog, Toof Brown, whose quote is the first in the story, and I thought it was very pertinent. And the third reason for drawing attention to the story in the weekend edition of the International Herald Tribune was for the WONDERFULLY odd and serendipitous event that meant that while my season review story mentions the Max Mosley sex scandal of last year and his subsequent battle with a British newspaper - the whole idea there were Nazi role playing connotations etc. - well, on page two of the print version of the same paper in which my story appeared was also a little piece from the same newspaper 75 years ago, in which a certain Oswald Mosley, Max's father, won a case against another British newspaper in a libel case, in the second item of the story. Wonderful how these things happen sometimes. Not so often seen in the new media, I think.

Devoid as they are of nostalgia, kids won't really appreciate that the mustache included in the new wooden block set PlayShapes was inspired by Sgt. Pepper, nor that the toy has echoes of Alexander Girard, Enzo Mari and midcentury advertising illustrations. But what will please the little ones is that unlike that era's blocks, which mostly encouraged the dutiful construction of towns and landscapes, the strange contours of the 74 PlayShapes will let them build whatever animal, vegetable or psychedelic '60s pop star they please. ''We spent ages looking at old toys and seeing what had been done before, how we could make it new,'' says PlayShapes' Brighton, U.K.-based co-creator Zoe Miller, who with her partner David Goodman also designs vintage-inspired kids' toys and books for the Tate. ''For us it became about open-endedness, the fact that every child should feel that they're an artist.'' $111; go to shhhop.com.

An expensive, six-month marketing push helped "Disney's A Christmas Carol" open at No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, selling an estimated $31 million in tickets. But the result was weak for a movie that cost about $175 million to make (not including marketing costs), starred Jim Carrey in a cluster of roles, and was given one of the biggest releases yet on higher-priced 3-D screens. Did families decide it looked too dark? Did the motion-capture filmmaking style lessen interest? Or did a lot of moviegoers figure they would catch the holiday movie in the weeks ahead? Disney, which noted that the film, directed by Robert Zemeckis, made an additional $12 million in 18 foreign markets, hopes the latter.

Children may not be able to recognize good design, but according to Jamie Gray (photographed with his girlfriend, Olivia Sammons, and their children, Cy and Levi), they can recognize beauty. Gray, who owns the less-is-more New York design shop Matter, recalls once waking up at 5:30 a.m. to find the 3-year-old Levi gazing through the window of their Brooklyn apartment. ''Look at the sky, Papa,'' Levi exclaimed. ''It's beautiful.'' The first piece Gray ever built was a three-legged chair. His teacher told him it would never stand up. ''But I made it anyway,'' he said. ''And it worked!'' (Gray is seated in a Victor armchair by Paul Loebach.) His company's Web address, MatterMatters.com, speaks to the challenge of creating objects in a world that's already glutted with them. ''That's the daily quandary: Do you create more?'' he asks. ''But, ultimately, if there's a want, somebody has to take responsibility for it. My intention is to create heirloom pieces that won't end up at the bottom of a landfill.'

“The Red Shoes,” a classic 1948 film directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, is a gorgeously haunting work of art.
Amid a global frenzy fed by hedge funds, speculators and governments all rushing to stock up, the price of gold briefly surpassed $1,100 an ounce on Friday, a record high.
In the recent downturn, Ruby Tuesday has tried to trade up. When people start to dine out again, the founder wants them to find his chain transformed.

Coach Joe Taylor presides over an continuing character makeover at Florida A&M: “If you can improve the person, you can improve the player.”

58: The number of private colleges that now charge at least $50,000 a year for tuition, fees, room and board.
According to Fire Department officials, the blaze started in the basement of an illegally subdivided home, and neighbors said the dead men were all from Bangladesh.

An article last Sunday about lessons a correspondent learned while reporting on the war in Iraq offered an incorrect contrast to the difficulties Iraqis face when crossing from Kurdish Iraq into their country’s Arab southern provinces. A comparison that illustrates the ease of traversing a state border in the United States would be a crossing from Michigan into Indiana — not into Illinois, with which Michigan does not share a land border.
In trying to understand the work of the French anthropologist, look for pairs of opposites common to all human societies.
To the Editor:.
Fear of injuries has led to fewer practices with pads and full-contact plays, causing a decline in defenders’ ability to contain the running game.
Maybe it’s time to rethink the business cycle. It no longer predicts when — or if — jobs will return.

Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. is proposing that education spending be cut and that Colorado charge sales tax on candy and soft drinks as well as online sales.
However, repairs at a flood-control reservoir have not eliminated the risk of flooding this winter in the Green River Valley near Seattle, the Army Corps of Engineers said.

Barack Obama’s speechifying once gripped the nation. Not so much now. He may need his salesman’s tools more than ever.

There are just over 100 people in the world in prison for life for crimes they committed as juveniles in which no one was killed; 77 of them are in Florida.
Germany is now more peaceful, more united and less turbulent than people had expected.
Peruvians pose what might be a final challenge to the ecosystem supported by the giant huarango tree, which is coveted as a source of charcoal and firewood.

President Obama, extending condolences to Fort Hood, Tex., reminded Americans that people of “every race, faith and station” serve in the military — an oblique attempt to prevent a backlash against Muslims.

When you think about it, the Rockwell Group has been in the business of playgrounds for years, creating a showy interior for a glamorous jeweler, a JetBlue terminal and Nobu restaurants from New York to Dubai. So the Imagination Playground at Burling Slip, which opens next summer in a former parking lot near South Street Seaport, is a logical next step. The peanut-shaped park is inspired by midcentury adventure playgrounds, where children used found objects and postwar debris. It features sand and water, Playground Associates to oversee the action, and more than 350 loose parts, including wheelbarrows, pool noodles and weather- and germ-resistant foam blocks (above, in Brooklyn). David Rockwell, the founder and C.E.O., has created a standard kit that can be deployed cheaply in open spaces across the country, but at Burling Slip he pays homage to its nautical past with pulleys, masts and periscope-like tubes through which children can talk from opposite ends of the park. “Each place encourages a kind of cooperative, self-directed fantasy play,” he says. “Or you can just run around like a maniac.” [?][?][?] JILL SINGER.
Faye Toodgood’s style leaps off the page.
A Southern California house makes room for three generations.
Design for all ages.

SWEET DREAMS Worried that your baby’s bed won’t match your midcentury modern décor? The Nest Collection bassinet, by Scott Wilson for Offi, is a sleek walnut-veneered design with a chrome base. $999. Go to minijake.com.
Bring out the beast — in a good way.
Architects design for education and get an A+.
Hold the chicken fingers. Kids’ menus are catering to increasingly sophisticated palates.
If the clothes are so small, why are the price tags so big?

If the initiatives that Project H Design has taken on seem largely geared toward young people — Learning Landscape playgrounds and sustainable food programs for public schools, to name but two — it may have something to do with the fact that Emily Pilloton, the founder of the not even two-year-old humanitarian organization, is herself only 27. With the help of nine volunteer-driven cells from Austin, Tex., to Johannesburg, Pilloton, who started the company with a laptop and $1,000 while living at home with her parents, aims to create local design solutions and apply them globally. (The playgrounds, for example, were conceived in Uganda and have since been installed in North Carolina and the Dominican Republic.) Pilloton is also the author of the just-released book “Design Revolution: 100 Products That Empower People” (Metropolis Books), which gives well-deserved shout-outs to everything from the Hippo Water Roller (a portable vessel that can carry a week’s worth of water for a family of seven) and Braille-based Lego-style building blocks to D.I.Y. soccer balls (left) and SkySails (which are large enough to help propel cargo ships). “If it’s any consolation,” she insists, “I’ve aged a lot over the last year.” [?][?][?] ALIX BROWNE.
When your parents are hard-core animalists, you grow up with nothing — and like it.
Living in a winter wonderland.

Children may not be able to recognize good design, but according to Jamie Gray (photographed with his girlfriend, Olivia Sammons, and their children, Cy and Levi), they can recognize beauty. Gray, who owns the less-is-more New York design shop Matter, recalls once waking up at 5:30 a.m. to find the 3-year-old Levi gazing through the window of their Brooklyn apartment. “Look at the sky, Papa,” Levi exclaimed. “It’s beautiful.” The first piece Gray ever built was a three-legged chair. His teacher told him it would never stand up. “But I made it anyway,” he said. “And it worked!” (Gray is seated above in a Victor armchair by Paul Loebach.) His company’s Web address, MatterMatters.com, speaks to the challenge of creating objects in a world that’s already glutted with them. “That’s the daily quandary: Do you create more?” he asks. “But, ultimately, if there’s a want, somebody has to take responsibility for it. My intention is to create heirloom pieces that won’t end up at the bottom of a landfill.’ [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN.

Warren Buffett is now a cartoon character. The Oracle of Omaha has a starring role in “Secret Millionaire’s Club,” a Web series produced by AOL and A Squared Entertainment that goes live in January. This is not a move to stanch his declining fortunes — the man’s still worth $40 billion, after all — but a pro bono effort to teach kids fiscal responsibility. (Adults, Buffett must think, are now beyond his help.) The “club” is made up of a group of young Nebraskans who sell baseball memorabilia online and use the profits to bankroll an investment business; an animated (and slenderized) Buffett serves as their adviser. Searching for a youth-friendly analogue, Andy Heyward, the show’s producer, says, “It’s a little bit like Monopoly.” Heyward first collaborated with Buffett on the animated introductions to Berkshire Hathaway’s annual shareholder meetings, in which the frugal tycoon has spoofed Batman and James Bond. “Warren is amazing,” Heyward says. “He does everything in just one take.” [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN.

Getting kids interested in eating good food is one thing. How about getting them interested in cooking? Phaidon, which published the translation of the Italian food bible “The Silver Spoon,” has chosen 40 bambino-friendly recipes from the original 2,000-plus to create “The Silver Spoon for Children: Favorite Italian Recipes.” The colorful, cleverly illustrated book teaches kids 8 and up kitchen fundamentals and provides step-by-step instructions for everything from a simple prosciutto and melon to spaghetti amatriciana. (“Ask an adult to help you drain the spaghetti.”) Making meatballs is apparently a great way to practice math and learn about fractions. And cooking your parents chicken breasts stuffed with mascarpone is a great way to make them happy. Buon appetito. [?][?][?] CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

London is known for top-quality design exhibitions, and this season doesn’t disappoint. Opening Nov. 18 at the Design Museum is a retrospective of the work of the German designer Dieter Rams, including his pioneering electronics designs for Braun, without which there might be no iPod (Apple’s Jonathan Ive is one of five designers who are interviewed for the show), and those for the furniture company Vitsoe. On Nov. 26, the Serpentine Gallery opens its first-ever contemporary design exhibition, “Design Real,” curated by the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic. His selection focuses on objects (like Carlotta de Bevilacqua’s Yang light for Artemide, below right) that have a practical function, are accessible to all and have made a significant impact on the world. Grcic’s own work will be the subject of “Konstantin Grcic: Decisive Design,” starting Nov. 20 at the Art Institute of Chicago. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.
The designer makes high-spirited fashion -- but that's nothing compared to her exuberant family life.
A Southern California house makes room for three generations.

Until now, the world of dollhouses has thrived on Tudors and Georgians filled with wicker, Windsor and chintz, forcing dolls — and the children who love them — to dwell in a land that time forgot. “They’re all furnished like my grandmother’s house, with terrible old brown chairs,” says Linda Stenberg, the creative director for the new Danish company Minimii (minimii.com). She and her partner Claus Hojer Hansen have come up with an antidote: a 1/16-size reproduction of Arne Jacobsen’s own 1929 house, approved by Jacobsen’s family and scheduled for release early next year. There are Egg and Swan chairs courtesy of Fritz Hansen, tiny Vipp trash cans and a working lamp by the Danish studio Design by Us. New pieces commissioned just for the house so far include a childlike scribble by the artist Poul Pava and prospective inhabitants by the dollmaker Maileg. Stenberg has already noticed a change in her kids since she let them play with the prototypes: “They recognize the furniture now,” she says. “When they see a Jacobsen, they say, ‘Oh, Mommy, those are your chairs, only bigger.’ ” [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Who doesn’t have a digital camera these days? Not to mention a million unviewed images, eating up the memory on the hard drive? With that in mind, Fujifilm has introduced the adorable and already successful (in Europe and Asia) Instax Mini 7S camera. With its matte-white, bubble-shaped body, the camera was conceived not so much for those who pine for Polaroid as for the design-savvy iPod generation. The super-color-saturated, credit-card-size photos satisfy the current obsession for all things miniature — in a flash, no less. $96; go to fujifilmusa.com. [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO.

Once upon a time, kids who showed an interest in culinary arts were given a packet of instant brownie mix and a miniature oven powered by a light bulb. But if your budding Jacques Pépin is begging for the latest Viking combi, indulge him instead with the latest cooking utensils from Curious Chef. The tools — including a whisk, spatula and rolling pin — are all bisphenol-A-free and scaled down to fit a child’s hands; the nylon serrated knives are effective for chopping a tomato, not your little sous-chef’s fingers. The 27-piece Foundation Set ($60; curiouschef.com) even comes with an apron and a chef’s hat. Anyone for petits fours? [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO.

In-Store Sweet William Bronagh Staley’s two-year-old shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is filled with stylish clothing, accessories and toys for the seesaw set. “I’m drawn to small labels, especially European ones, that make traditional kids’ items with a little bit of an edge,” says Staley, shown here with her son and muse, Fiontan. (112 North 6th Street; 718-218-6946; sweetwilliamltd.com) SANDRA BALLENTINE.

Devoid as they are of nostalgia, kids won’t really appreciate that the mustache included in the new wooden block set PlayShapes was inspired by Sgt. Pepper, nor that the toy has echoes of Alexander Girard, Enzo Mari and midcentury advertising illustrations. But what will please the little ones is that unlike that era’s blocks, which mostly encouraged the dutiful construction of towns and landscapes, the strange contours of the 74 PlayShapes will let them build whatever animal, vegetable or psychedelic ’60s pop star they please. “We spent ages looking at old toys and seeing what had been done before, how we could make it new,” says PlayShapes’ Brighton, U.K.-based co-creator Zoe Miller, who with her partner David Goodman also designs vintage-inspired kids’ toys and books for the Tate. “For us it became about open-endedness, the fact that every child should feel that they’re an artist.” $111; go to shhhop.com. [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Sitting on a shelf in the nursery at 2 Willow Road, in the leafy London suburb of Hampstead, is a wooden square containing cutouts of the 26 letters in the alphabet. It is slightly shabby, as if the letters have been pushed in and pulled out by lots of little hands over the years — which they have.

Frank Gehry is out of the house business, having moved on to bigger things. But it was a residential project — his radical revision of his own little Dutch colonial in Santa Monica, Calif. — that put him on the map in the late 1970s and allowed him to explore the ideas that came to define his architecture. This house and others are included in “Frank Gehry: The Houses” (Rizzoli), by Mildred Friedman, who in 1986, as the design curator at the Walker Art Center, mounted the first major museum exhibition of the architect’s work. (I contributed an essay to its catalog.) The book, which has an intimate, down-to-earth tone, features not only abundant visual material but also interviews with Gehry, his clients (including his wife, Berta), and current and former members of his firm. And seeing projects like his own home, the never-built extravaganza that he designed for the insurance magnate Peter Lewis or the guesthouse (right) that he completed in 1987 for Mike and Penny Winton in Wayzata, Minn., makes you hope Gehry still has another house (or two) in him. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.

Heather Walsh and Michael Menkes were married Saturday at the Blue Bay Grand Esmeralda, a resort in Playa del Carmen, Mexico. Alma Rosa Rosas, a municipal judge for the city of Playa del Carmen, officiated.

Karen Cheryl Levi, the daughter of Linda and Roy Levi of Old Bridge, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Mitchell Sack, the son of Jules Sack of New York and the late Dale Sack. Rabbi Avi L. Levine officiated at the Mission Hills Country Club in Rancho Mirage, Calif..

Bari Alissa Draznin, a daughter of Sharon R. Draznin and Arthur Draznin of Short Hills, N.J., was married there Saturday evening to Andrew Joseph Huber, the son of Lynn and Ralph Huber of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Bayar officiated at the Hilton Short Hills, and Cantor Lorna Wallach participated in the ceremony.

Laura Schöe Grosshans and Jordyn A. Buchanan were married Saturday at Per Se, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Jewelnel Davis, a Baptist minister and the chaplain of Columbia University, led the ceremony.

Cassie Beth Gabrielson, the daughter of Lisa R. Gabrielson and Charles M. Gabrielson of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Justin Lee Mayer, a son of Diane M. Mayer and Stanley A. Mayer of Morganville, N.J. Rabbi David E. Fass performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.
The director Roland Emmerich is at the helm of another disaster movie with “2012.”

Dr. Christine Angele Pace and Dr. Andrew Lee Ellner were married Saturday in New York. Dr. Jane S. Sillman, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Manhattan Penthouse.

One Madison Park, the soaring 600-foot glass condominium that towers over East 23rd Street, opened to its first residents in August, but since then only five buyers have closed, according to city records.

Heather Ilene Silber and Nicholas Nafis Mohamed were married Saturday evening in Boston in the Grand Ballroom of Taj Boston, a hotel. James C. Gibney, a justice of the peace in Massachusetts, performed the ceremony, which incorporated Hindu, Jewish and Muslim traditions.
Dr. Marisa Beth Jupiter and Jonathan Benjamin Miller were married Saturday evening at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Jeremy S. Morrison officiated.
Meghan Ann Moriarty and Christopher Max Colice were married Saturdayin Boston. The Rev. Susan Spector, an interfaith minister, officiated in the Abbey Room at the Boston Public Library.

The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies on Oct. 25, about residential pricing trends, misstated the length of time that a house at 88 Oxford Street in Glen Ridge was on the market. It was in contract after 18 days; it was not on the market for six months.
Dr. Ayanna Woltz and Talib Morgan were married Saturday at the Reeves-Reed Arboretum in Summit, N.J.

The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about brownfield redevelopment projects referred incorrectly to the role of Advance Realty at a project in Harrison that will include a new soccer stadium for the New York Red Bulls. It is the master developer of the area; it is not the company that is finishing the stadium. (The stadium is being developed by the Austrian soft-drink maker Red Bull G.m.b.H., which owns the team.).
Lori Robyn Toub and Zachary Oliver Pomerantz were married Saturday evening at the Cescaphé Ballroom in Philadelphia.
David Calle and Mark Burstein were married Friday in Darien, Conn.
Connecticut’s tourism commission now has a budget of $1 a year — down from $4.3 million.
Dr. Allyson Cushing Augusta and Dr. Gautam Vinay Shrikhande were married Saturday by the Rev. Steven J. Yagerman, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Church Parish in Plymouth, Mass.
To spur international investors, some real estate companies have started marketing a service that brokers have long provided informally.
A new park for students living at the York Hill campus of Quinnipiac University features an array of wind turbines intended to project serenity while producing energy.
About 40 percent of Croton-on-Hudson is set aside as parkland, and the area is known for its rivers.
Forget the first rule. On its 10th anniversary, people are still talking about “Fight Club.”
The federal government is poised to enact rules to combat discrimination on loans backed by the Federal Housing Administration.
Progress is being made in converting Newark’s empty lots and abandoned buildings into new housing, despite a crushing recession.
Mr. Michaels is the chairman and chief executive of the Carlton Group, a real estate investment bank that specializes in equity and debt placement.
For those who crave a historic house — along with all the charms and challenges it can entail — there are a few other architectural gems to be found across the Island.
Tere O’Connor, who has been creating dance since 1982, sees himself and his art form as only now entering an exciting time of mature possibility.

An article on Oct. 11 about the revival of “Bye Bye Birdie” misstated the age of one of its creators, Lee Adams, and a correction in this space last Sunday misstated Mr. Adams’s creative role. He is 85, not 75, and he wrote the lyrics, not the music.
Punk rocker Jemina Pearl and her bandmates hang out at a record store, go to a concert and eat fried chicken in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
An article last Sunday about the comedian George Lopez gave an outdated name for a golf tournament for which he is host. It is the Bob Hope Classic, not the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.
The rap star is shooting not only for popularity with his song “Empire State of Mind,” but also for a symbolic crown: the king of New York music.
More funky than flashy, a phalanx of doe-eyed fashion dolls are jostling for attention on toy shelves this season.

An entry in the holiday films listings last Sunday misidentified the author who wrote the historical novel from which the director Michael Hoffman’s movie “The Last Station” is adapted. The writer is Jay Parini — not Rose Tremain, who wrote the novel upon which Mr. Hoffman’s movie “Restoration” was based.
In three and a half years, Ludlow Bistro has built a word-of-mouth reputation for its food, style and service.

A picture caption on Oct. 18 with excerpts of an interview with Jeff Eastin, creator of the television show “White Collar,” misidentified the actress shown with Matt Bomer and Tim DeKay. She is Marsha Thomason — not Alexandra Daddario, who also appears in the series.
In the 19th-century manor house of a railroad baron, fresh baked goods, sandwiches and salads are available to Bayard Cutting Arboretum visitors.

At the Tap House, a new chef has refocused the menu on classic dishes at reasonable prices.
At Tuthilltown Spirits in Dutchess County, small-batch bourbon is made from locally grown field corn, and it’s called Hudson Baby Bourbon Whiskey.
Cafe Manolo opened recently, offering a simple menu, efficient service and terrific food that places a premium on freshness.
The Bridge, a tofu factory in Middletown, gives tours and sells tofu and related vegetarian and related items like seitan and amasake.
After six years of renovations, the Thomas Edison National Historical Park in West Orange has reopened and is showing people a much fuller portrait of the inventor’s world and work.

The Auto Ego feature last Sunday about the owner of a vintage Bentley, David Wilkinson, misidentified the racer that his mother’s uncle, Ralph DePalma, pushed to the finish line in the 1912 Indianapolis 500. That car, called the Grey Ghost, was a Mercedes, not a Mercedes-Benz. (The car’s manufacturer, Daimler, merged with Benz in 1926.).

This beautifully illustrated retelling of the classic fable has only seven words, all sound effects.
A book imagining trucks as dinosaurs, and other explorations of the primal place of machines in the lives of small children.
A duck discovers a huge speckled egg in “The Odd Egg”; readers free a frog by opening the pop-up book “Big Frog Can’t Fit In.”
An illustrated poem about the seasons; a story about a penguin searching for new colors; and a collection of classic fairy tales with vivid pictures.
This illustrated collection of surreal tales features water buffalo, stick figures and rivers of unread poetry.
Two young adult histories and a graphic novel about the worst ecological disaster in American history.
This lovely picture book tells a true story about Masai villagers who bestow a heartfelt gift after 9/11.

An American climber recounts some of the most dramatic attempts on the peak of K2.

A candid memoir from the multitalented wrestler Hulk Hogan.
The life of Robert Altman, told in interviews with nearly 200 of his friends, colleagues and family members.

An argument that can-do optimism has hardened into a suffocating force that bears little relation to genuine happiness.
Amy Gerstler’s poems — skillful in every kind of comedy, yet deeply serious — show a fondness for animals without sentimentalizing them.
John Irving’s new novel follows a father and son through 50 years in “a world of accidents.”
This official biography chronicles the parties, the games, the trips, the charitable causes — and the trouble thanks to Edward VIII.
This novel, about a boy’s consequential bonds with Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and Leon Trotsky, is a call to conscience and connection.
A valuable new biography of Samuel Johnson, the most eminent of all literary critics.
When an enormous transparent dome settles over a small town in Maine in Stephen King’s new novel, it’s just fine with Big Jim, the local tyrant-in-waiting, and his pet goon squad.

Ammunition may strike you as a commodity, but even bullets get branded.
As the gay-marriage debate plays out on the public stage, a more private debate is taking place in kitchens and bedrooms over who does what in a heterosexual marriage.
Between two adults (same sex, different cultures), a question of intent.

After surviving a heart attack on the New York subway, Michael Kiernan, 50, is trying to be a better partner to his longtime girlfriend and seize each day a little more.
Heather Locklear, who gave the original “Melrose Place” much of its intrigue and sizzle in the 1990s, will join the new version of the soap on Nov. 17.
With the average American spending almost two hours a day in a car, according to the Ecology Center, there is ample opportunity for exposure to toxic chemicals.
This week, answers to readers’ questions about dealing with a boyfriend’s mother, how long to wait to date after a spouse dies and thank-you notes at baby showers.
The Mercedes-Benz S400 BlueHybrid manages to improve fuel economy even as it offers the size and luxury typical of the S-Class.
For that price, a rare species of car owner gets a rocket that gleams across the planet’s surface faster than any true production automobile that has come before.
Melissa Johnson is known for her sardonic humor and love of dark, gory films. So no one was more surprised than she when she fell for Timothy Lagasse, an endlessly upbeat, puppet designer.
Wall Street may be a center of American finance, but it is also a neighborhood filled with shops, cafes and history.
Today’s highway intersections are getting more consideration, both as landmarks and utilitarian features of life.
A modern interpretation of bagna cauda, which means “hot bath,” involves a whole roasted cauliflower with black garlic and a parsley-anchovy butter.
A theme of Augustus Saint-Gaudens' life was his enduring friendship with the architect Stanford White.
A new breed of children’s movies play a kind of reverse dress-up, disguising adult anxieties in the costumes of innocent make-believe and fanciful spectacle.
On Nov. 17, 20 years to the day since the start of the Velvet Revolution, a nonprofit group is organizing a re-enactment of the student march.
There’s more to the city than country music, especially in once-sleepy neighborhoods that are now beating to a stylish, new rhythm.
Few hotels allow one to spend the night next to an architectural wonder of the ancient world. Fewer still are also architectural marvels themselves.
Painters, dancers and the young and hip are clustering in this working-class neighborhood.
The dining scene has evolved to match the romantic allure of the city, with its battered cobblestones and crumbling 19th-century mansions.

Carpeted with cork oaks, whitewashed villages and olive trees, this region in southeastern Portugal is emerging as a stylish backwater for the international set.

A map last Sunday with the Heads Up column, about new bars and clubs in the Dempsey Hill neighborhood of Singapore, misstated part of the name of one of the bars. As the article correctly noted, it is the White Rabbit, not the Wild Rabbit.

To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column “In Latin America, Luxe Costs Less” (Oct. 25): Even though Buenos Aires is not new on the “less expensive luxury” list, it still offers surprises. The last time I went, I found Miravida Soho, a recently restored 1930s mansion that has been turned into a small hotel and wine bar. It was probably the nicest hotel experience I have had in ages.
To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, “$855 a Night? Can We Talk?” (Nov. 1): The name of the game here is: It never hurts to ask.
Malcolm Gladwell’s “What the Dog Saw” enters at No. 3, while Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner land at No. 2 with “SuperFreakonomics.”

The 98th annual campaign of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has gotten under way. Every year since 1912, the fund has provided direct assistance to children, families and the elderly in New York. Articles will appear daily in the newspaper and online through Jan. 31, illustrating the difference that even a modest amount of money can make in easing the struggles of the poor. Last year, 10,838 donors contributed $6,964,031, which was distributed in 2009 directly to those in need through seven New York charities. The New York Times Company Foundation underwrites all administrative costs incurred by the fund.

JEBY--Barbara Diane, October 8, 2009. Loving mother of three, sister, grandmother of 12, and wife. Musician, educator, principal, and volunteer who never stopped learning and teaching. She is deeply missed.

The freshman Nick Florence, left, threw for a team-record 427 yards and 3 touchdowns and ran for a fourth to help Baylor defeat Missouri and end a 13-game Big 12 road losing streak. Rob Curley threw for a career-high 373 yards and a team-record 7 touchdown passes to lead Lafayette to a 56-49 victory over visiting Colgate. He completed 18 of 31 passes.

KOVAR--Dr. Leo, 86, on November 5, 2009 in Philadelphia. Survived by his wife Lillian Cohen Kovar, daughters Naomi and Rachel, son Joshua and his wife Deborah Andrus, sister Rhea Kovar Sossen and grandson Elijah Paul Kovar. Donations may made to Philadelphia Chamber Music Society. Memorial service at 3pm Sunday at Goldstein's, 3410 North Broad Street, Philadelphia.

BENOWICH--Edward B.,80, died peacefully November 4, in his home, surrounded by his family. A proud, generous and private person, he is survived by his adoring wife, Rita, his loving children, Leonard, Marc and Debi Levy, his daughters- and son-in-law, Ruth, Stacey and Andrew, and his grandchildren, Alena, Sarah, Haley, Scott, Shaun and Stephanie. He will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to United Hospice of Rockland or the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

To celebrate the 25th anniversary of Miami's White Party, a gay circuit party that bills itself as ''one of the world's oldest and largest HIV/AIDS fund-raisers,'' several hotels are offering special rates during the six-day event, which starts Nov. 25. The EPIC hotel, with 411 rooms in downtown Miami, is offering rates starting at $119 a night -- $5 from every night booked will be donated to Care Resource, an HIV/AIDS service organization in South Florida. To receive the rate, which is available from Nov. 25 to 30, enter the code WHITE when making reservations at www.epichotel.com.

I MET Angelika Wachs for only a few minutes of my life. But what moments they were -- our share of history in its most momentous shift since 1945. It was the evening of Nov. 9, 1989. I had arrived in Berlin the night before, convinced revolution was under way in East Germany, and had spent the day reporting in an East Berlin suburb. The mood there was grim -- all the suspicion, cynicism and stale shoddiness bred by 40 years of totalitarian rule on full display. Despite the exodus of 50,000 East Germans to West Germany via Czechoslovakia in the five days before that gray, freezing Thursday, despite the resignation of the East German Communist Party Politburo and growing street protests, hope was as scarce as coveted luxuries like bananas.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''To Some, American Winner Is Not American Enough,'' Nov. 3: Meb Keflezighi, the first American man to win the New York City Marathon since 1982, has received undue criticism contending that he is not a real American because he was not born here. But he, like many other immigrants, gained citizenship legally.

EDELMAN--James Neil, age 68, passed away on November 4, 2009. Loving son of the late Adele Edelman Becker and the late Milton Edelman. Beloved husband for 34 years of Diane Gersoni Edelman, proud, adoring father of Michael and Sara, devoted brother of Robert, brother-in-law of Carol, and uncle of Alexandra and Josh. He was a wonderful family man. Often called the dean of the men's clothing industry, Jim worked at A&S and then Macy's for decades. He was renowned for his merchandising skills, retail acumen, professionalism, integrity, loyalty, caring nature, humor, and mentoring of associates. Truly unique, a dynamic personality, legendary in his field, he will be sorely missed by family, friends, and colleagues. Funeral services scheduled for Friday, November 6, 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell.

The sleeveless topper, from vests to long sweaters, is the choice of many women who aren't ready for a winter coat. This popular style allows the wearer to put together her own layered look, and it was seen -- in fake fur, real fur and knits -- on the backs of many women watching the thousands of runners in the New York City Marathon last Sunday. That day there was also an unofficial marathon for the hundreds of pedicabs gathered around Columbus Circle to take exhausted runners back to their hotels. Their passengers disgorged, they sped back in order to pick up more footsore passengers on this one-day business bonanza.

Sunil Gulati, the president of the United States Soccer Federation, is an economics professor at Columbia University and one of the financial architects of Major League Soccer. He presides over a game that continues to grow and show promise in the United States on many levels, including the national team's berth in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. JACK BELL Q.The United States has qualified for South Africa. Mission accomplished?

DUANE--Winifred. The Hunter College community mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed State Senator, colleague and friend, Tom Duane. We know how proud Winnie was of Tom's commitment to public service and his successful career. Our heartfelt condolences to Tom and the entire Duane family. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College

SPIEGEL--Jerry. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Jerry Spiegel, a great friend to our Department of Neurology and our Stem Cell Initiative. We are especially grateful to him and his late wife, Emily, for their generous support of stem cell research, and its applications to our understanding and treatment of Parkinson's Disease. All of us at Columbia offer our condolences to the Spiegel family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University Timothy A. Pedley, MD Chair, Department of Neurology Michael Shelanski, PhD, MD Chair, Department of Pathology and Cell Biology

WOLPER--Gary Marc, November 6, 2009 passed away in Effort, PA surrounded by his loving family, wife Arnette, daughters Julie and Allyson, son Jonathan, brother Edwin, brother-in-law to Butch and Jeanette, father-in-law to Rob and Allison, and four grandchildren. Born April 29, 1942 in Brooklyn, NY. Gary was a successful businessman in the NYC garment industry, a loving husband, unconditional father, wonderful grandfather and genuine good soul to all. He was a man of humor, a true character and, a man of integrity. Services will be held November 10th 11:45am at Riverside Chapel 180 W. 76th St. NY, NY. Burial will follow at Mt Golda 500 Old Country Rd Huntington, NY.
To the Sports Editor: I'm a Mets fan who jumped on the bandwagon in 1986 and has been faithful ever since. The Yankees-Phillies World Series was my worst nightmare.

HELMAN--Florence, died peacefully on November 5th, 2009 after a long illness. Beloved and devoted wife of Alan, loving mother of Neil, Susan, Michael, Penny and the late Gordon. Adoring grandmother of Ariel, Benji and Eli. She will always be remembered for her extraordinary giving and caring ways, wonderful creativity, and refined elegance. Throughout her life she found joy in nature and filled her life with a love of art and music. She touched all who knew her and will always have a special place in our hearts.

HENDERSON--Richard. The Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture of The Cooper Union mourns the passing of Richard Henderson, Professor and Associate Dean Emeritus. Richard served as Associate Dean of the School with great dedication and grace, was a masterful teacher of sublime intelligence, and a distinguished architect. He wrote of his seminal "Analysis" studio project: "Neither the definitive exposition of fact nor the meticulous rendering of description can hope to evoke the mysterious life embodied in enduring architecture". We offer our heartfelt sympathy to his family. He will be deeply missed and long remembered.

In one of its core civic myths, New York prides itself as a street-smart city inured to blarney -- if only because of the sheer amount of it thrown around in millions of human interactions each day. So give Mayor Michael Bloomberg credit. His successful bid for a third term was a masterpiece of illusion. Using $90 million from his own fortune, he persuaded a good many people that it would be a sucker's bet to back his opponent, the Democrat William C. Thompson Jr. The close results left his opponents in a graveyard of what-ifs. State Senator Eric T. Schneiderman offered up this epitaph: ''Bill Thompson was always closer than people thought, and on our side, if people had been behind him more, there would have been more checks, more endorsements, more attention, and that might have made the difference.''

With three rounds of playoffs, one of them a best-of-five series, the modern postseason is designed to ensure that the best team in baseball wins the World Series only a small percentage of the time. This randomness inherent in the playoffs is the game's built-in remedy for its competitive-balance woes, and has felled four Yankees squads this decade that posted the game's best record but fell short of a title. The 87-victory championship team in 2000 reinforced the notion that the postseason is a crapshoot, but the 2009 edition offered a different lesson. Sometimes, being really, really good is indeed good enough to win it all.
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Coach Says Agassi's Admission Is Surprise,'' Oct. 31: Many believe that Andre Agassi hoped that confessing his use of illegal drugs would inspire others to recover.

NAKHLA--Fayek, born in Egypt, January 4, 1933, died October 29th. After medical school in Egypt, he pursued a psychiatric residency in Denver, Colorado, and worked in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. He then trained in psychoanalysis at the London Institute of Psychoanalysis. He came to New York City in 1968. In addition to his private practice, he was on the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and then became the director of psychiatric residency training at Brookdale University Hospital. He was a member of the British Psychoanalytic Society and the International Psychoanalytic Association. He is survived by his wife, Yvette, two children from his first marriage, Tarek and Nevine, and three grandchildren. Service private. Donations may be made to Cancer Care.

How do Romans get that extra kick between espressos? They hop on a Vespa, take a deep breath and plunge into the city's famously chaotic traffic. If you know your way around on two wheels back home, once you get going, you'll find there is an elaborate code of order on the roads. ''We get lots of Americans,'' said Bruno Zarlenga, the owner of Barberini Scooters for Rent (Via della Purificazione 84; 39-06-48-85-485; www.rentscooter.it), which opened in 1979. ''They are usually very enthusiastic when they get back.'' Maps are provided, guided tours can be booked in advance, and for 40 euros (about $60 at $1.53 to the euro), a small motor scooter is yours for the day. A few pointers. In Rome the scooter takes precedence over the car. A little toot of the horn means ''hi'' or ''thanks''; longer ones mean you aren't happy. Lanes? If you're driving a scooter, any space in the road is a lane -- use this to your advantage. It's expected. JESSICA DONATI

HASEN--George Milton, on October 31, 2009 in Burlington, VT. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte Binger Hasen, loving father of Louisa Mattson, John Hasen and Elizabeth Hasen. A memorial service will be held in Greensboro next summer.

Travelocity has upped the ante in the online battle for hotel bookings. Travelocity customers who find the same hotel room for less can now ask for a refund of the difference. The guarantee applies to any hotel booking site, with one exception: so-called opaque hotel booking sites like Priceline or Hotwire that offer unpublished discounts. Plus, until Dec. 31, customers will also receive a $50 discount toward future travel.

You've seen Rick Steves, Anthony Bourdain and, of course, Gwyneth Paltrow. Now meet Thomas Beug, 29, above at right, and Tim Kalafas, 30, two buddies from New York City who started a ''guerilla'' travel show for the Twitter generation. Called ''This Is My City,'' the travel show follows the two as they visit new cities and find colorful characters to show them around. The show is streamed on the Web site Vimeo -- part of a growing trend of D.I.Y. travel shows that take advantage of cheap video cameras, free video hosting and, in some cases, lots of free time.

An art review in some editions last Sunday about ''Bold, Cautious, True: Walt Whitman and American Art of the Civil War Era,'' at the Katonah Museum of Art in Westchester County, misidentified the institution that loaned two paintings by Sanford Gifford to the museum. It is the New York State Military Museum and Veterans Research Center, not the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

There's a powerful clandestine organization that secretly controls the world's governments and financial markets: the 1972 Miami Dolphins. They sip Champagne and pull strings from their headquarters beneath the Roman catacombs, transforming underachievers like Ted Ginn Jr. from first-round busts into touchdown machines with only a few words from their Greek chorus. Only a handful of individuals know the truth about this secret society: Dan Brown, Bob Kuechenberg's dry cleaner (he left the pregame script for Super Bowl XLII in a shirt pocket), and Bill Belichick, who rents out the adjacent catacomb.

TEIG--Morris, 96 years old, of Stamford, CT died November 5, 2009 at Stamford Hospital. He was born on the Eastside of Manhattan July 13, 1913. He attended Brooklyn College, graduating from St. John's Law School in 1938. He filled his life with his legal profession, spending hours at the Stamford and Norwalk courthouses. At his death, he was Connecticut's oldest fulltime practicing attorney. He is survived by his daughter Phyllis Moss (Stephen) of Nanuet, NY and his sons Bernard Teig (Sheila) of Stamford, CT, Joel Teig (Marjorie) of Smithtown, NY, Howard Teig (Judi) of Jericho, NY, his sister Helen Teig of Bronx, NY, 10 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife Hilda, his parents, his brother Joseph Teig and sister Yetta Kriegel.

LINDY--Sanford "Sandy," 86, passed away Thursday, November 5, 2009. Born in Center Brunswick, NY, graduated Troy High School, joined the US Navy, stationed in Pearl Harbor during the Japanese attack. He was a passionate skier and enjoyed reading and gardening. An enthusiastic world traveler, he made lifelong friends with his wicked sense of humor. Besides his dear wife, Lillian, he is survived by his daughter Judy and her husband Dr. Alvin Ruthenberg of New York City, and daughter-in-law Marilyn Lindy of Niskayuna, NY. He dearly loved his grandchildren, Michael Trossman of Washington, DC, Joshua Lindy and his wife Nicole, Jeffrey Lindy, of New York City, and Kate Lindy of Boston, MA. He was predeceased by his son Joel Lindy. A commemoration of Sandy's life will be held at the Molloy Funeral Home, West Hartford, CT at 1pm this Sunday.

Maggie Nesciur was 7 when she started exploring city streets on foot. Terrified of a man who was a fixture in her subway station, she would get off at a nearby stop and walk. After high school, she traveled widely, but returned to Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 2003, after being diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma, a rare cancer. Even during a year of chemotherapy and radiation, Ms. Nesciur took long walks; since regaining her health, she has walked as much as 43 miles in a day, and generally does 50 to 90 miles each week. ''I'm afraid of not being able to walk one day,'' she said. ''I walk like a madwoman because I know I can.''

FRÉDÉRIC MALLE'S new Upper East Side store, his first free-standing location in the United States, is much like his fragrances: refined and multilayered. Nestled in a former doctor's office at 898 Madison Avenue, the jewel-box boutique was designed by the French architect Patrick Naggar, who drew inspiration from the building's storied Art Deco exterior. Mr. Malle first spotted the location while studying art at New York University 25 years ago. ''I've always loved the swirling facade,'' Mr. Malle said. ''It's reminiscent of Hoffmann's Viennese pavilion.'' The interior includes, in addition to the refrigerated display cases, 1930s French art, objets and furniture from Mr. Malle's own collection (including a desk and chairs his grandfather commissioned from the atelier of Jules Leleu). Also available: a new home collection, including candles, incense and the Fleur Mécanique, a red-cube wonder that diffuses the aroma of fresh flowers into the air. C'est magnifique. (212) 249-7941. SANDRA BALLENTINE

McNAMARA--Patricia, died November 5, 2009 in Lurgan, Northern Ireland at age 83. Survived by eight of her original 12 brothers and sisters, many nieces and nephews and by many others who loved her. A native of County Roscommon in Ireland, Patricia was a professional nanny and nurse who moved to America in March 1955. A big and handsome woman, she was loving, kind, wise, and fiercely principled and independent. She made a huge positive impact on the children whom she raised over a period of 50 years: Louis Gershon of North London; the children of the late Norman and Alice Newhouse when they lived in Great Neck, L.I., Robin, Mark, Peter, Jonathan and David Newhouse; Giles and Julian Eyre, and their two brothers, of New York City, and lastly, Charlie Stone, now living in North Carolina. It was Charlie who last year reached out to her former charges and reconnected them to Patricia after so many years without contact. She loved to travel in her free time and had many friends, especially in Ireland. She loved the cliffs of Donegal. Her intellectual interests ranged from architecture to the Russian language. But her great gift was the love she brought into the lives of the children she raised. For this one, it is a light which will never be extinguished. Jonathan Newhouse, London

WEISS--Joyce, born May 25, 1933 died peacefully on October 19 after a brief illness. She was a graduate of Freeport High School and the Brooklyn Hospital School of Nursing. She attended classes at The Julliard School and Marymount Manhattan College. Joyce lived on E. 15th St for 33 years. A consummate New Yorker, she loved movies, theater, music and was a member of several choirs, including Voices of New York. She enjoyed exercise with her pals at the 14th Street Y. Her cheerful spirit will be missed by her family and her many friends. She is survived by her sister Patricia Estes of Nashville, TN.

ILAN RUBIN In Ilan Rubin's photographs, objects are never quite what they seem: a high heel looks like a full glass of chardonnay, a pile of swim trunks forms a scene straight out of a Chagall painting. Rubin, an Israeli-born New Yorker, pioneered the Must-Haves shoots for T's Get section, and shot this issue's cover story (''Just My Size,'' Page 60) with the set designer Gary Card to convey the idea that good design knows no generation gap. Rubin is in demand by magazines like Elle Decor, Allure and GQ for his dramatically lit still lifes, which require that the photographer cocoon himself inside his Manhattan studio for days on end. But don't feel too bad for him. ''I have a lovely terrace here,'' he says.

IN a highly unusual move for an agency that prefers low-profile discussions, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has publicly rebuked Toyota, accusing it of putting out ''inaccurate and misleading'' information about the unintended acceleration problem that could affect 3.8 million of its vehicles. The agency said a news release that Toyota issued Monday inaccurately stated that the agency had reached a conclusion ''that no defect exists in vehicles in which the driver's floor mat is compatible with the vehicle and properly secured.''

COOK--Daniel Carrington, a longtime resident of Greenwich, CT died on November 3, 2009 at the age of 101. Born in Waterbury, CT on August 19, 1908, he was the son of the late Clarence Parker Cook and Harriet Carrington Cook. He is predeceased by his wife of 55 years Katharine Skinner Warner Cook. He is survived by his children Daniel C. Cook, Jr. of Carlisle, MA, Katharine S. Cook of Wickford, RI, Alexander T. Cook of Philadelphia, PA and Christina Bates of Portsmouth, NH, five granddaughters and numerous nieces and nephews. Dan was a parishioner of Trinitarian Congregational Church in Concord, MA and previously of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, CT where he had been Treasurer and a vestry member. He later served as trustee of the Round Hill Community Church. He graduated from Hotchkiss School and Yale University, class of 1931. He was President of the Field Club, a member of the Round Hill Club and the West Chop Club on Martha's Vineyard. He was also President of the Yale Club of New York City. His business career started as a trainee for Chase Bank in New York which led to managing of a chain of 1,000 moving picture theaters, followed by a move to West Virginia where he became Treasurer of the Kanawha & Hocking Coal Company. During World War II he served as a Navy Lieutenant in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters, and later in Newport, RI, where he was in charge of anti-aircraft training. With the war at end he became Treasurer of the Thomas Y. Crowell Company and years later became Treasurer of the Walsh Construction Company which built the St. Lawrence Seaway. Finally, he returned to Wall Street where he managed the financial affairs of the Averill Harriman family trust and foundations for the next 20 years. He will be greatly missed by many family members and friends. A memorial service will be held for Dan at Trinitarian Congregational Church in Concord, MA at 1pm on Saturday, November 28, 2009. In lieu of flowers, Dan would want a donation made to either the Audubon Society, www.audubon.org or the YMCA of Greenwich, www.gwymca.org.

THE Australian blogger Jonathan Zawada turns the fashion formula on its head with his illustration blog, Fashematics.com. By reducing a runway look to a pair of mass-culture antecedents, Mr. Zawada thumbs his nose at the pretentious sources cited by designers and journalists (It's all about Buffalo Gals meet Marie Antoinette at the Mudd Club, darling). For example, a look from the high-tech high-concept spring 2010 Alexander McQueen show is hilariously summed up as an ostrich plus a jellyfish. Here, Mr. Zawada finds SpongeBob SquarePants and Grace Jones hidden inside a look from Viktor & Rolf's spring collection. Inspired. JONATHAN S. PAUL

MILLER--Dr. Theresa. The family of Dr. Theresa Miller with great sorrow report her death on October 27. Terry Miller at age 90, after a valiant struggle following a severe stroke in March, finally succumbed to its effects. Wife of Marvin Miller, mother of Peter Miller and Susan Miller, grandmother of Neil Miller, educator, psychologist, tennis player, swimmer, enthusiast of life, warm, considerate friend to many; she will be missed by all who were fortunate enough to know her, most of all by her immediate family.

NENDO, the Japanese design studio founded by Oki Sato in 2002, is known for designing products for companies like Cappellini, Moroso and Boffi that bring out the poetry in technology. ''Ghost Stories,'' an installation of four new Nendo creations, is now showing at the Museum of Arts and Design in New York. Mr. Sato says he treasures life's ''Aha!'' moments and wants to share them with others, and in that respect this exhibition will not disappoint. Among the pieces on display will be the Blown-Color lamps, made from a new, nonwoven polyester fabric that can be inflated like a balloon; and the acrylic Fade-Out Chair, with a faux wood finish that disappears toward the base of the legs, making it seem as if the chair is starting to vanish. ''Ghost Stories'' runs through Jan. 10, 2010. PILAR VILADAS

EDELMAN--Jim. The firm of George Weintraub and Sons mourns the loss of our dear friend. He will be remembered for his integrity, honesty and legendary knowledge of the men's clothing industry. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family.

HORTON--George Klaus, PhD, East Brunswick, NJ died Sunday 1 November 2009 at age 83. He was a professor of physics at Rutgers University for 50 years. In 1939, his family escaped from Nazi Germany to England where he attended Rugby School and Imperial College, London. In 1949 he received his PhD at the University of Birmingham with Rudolph E. Peierls. After a post-doctoral fellowship in Zurich he joined the faculty at the University of Alberta, where he served for 9 years, before beginning his career at Rutgers University. Dr. Horton was predeceased by a son, David S. Horton, and by a sister, Ursula Bowles. Surviving are his beloved wife of 60 years, Pamela Horton (nee Fairbrother); three children: Belinda Carstens-Wickham of Edwardsville, Il, Jonathan C. Horton of San Mateo, CA, and Lisa Richter of Canton, CT; and 10 grandchildren: Karoline, Michelle, Miranda, Hannah, Nathanael, Matthew, Christina, Paul, Mollie, and Pamela. Dr. Horton was an expert in solid-state physics, with a special interest in lattice dynamics and self-consistent phonons. He authored over 100 scientific papers, books, and chapters. He trained graduate students, post-docs, and taught basic physics to generations of Rutgers undergraduates. His work as a professor and scientist was the focus of his life as were a great love for his family and a deep appreciation for the arts. A memorial will be held at Rutgers University at a later date. Donations may be sent to the George K. Horton fund at the Rutgers University Foundation, Winants Hall, 7 College Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ 08901-1261.

ROSE--Israel H.,Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at Lehman College, died October 30 at the age of 92 of pneumonia. Born to Abraham and Dora Rose in New Britain, Connecticut, he received his B.A. and M.A. degrees from Brooklyn College and his Ph.D. from Harvard University. He held department chairmanships at Lehman and Hunter Colleges, played a seminal role in founding Lehman's math department, and authored numerous textbooks. IN a highly unusual move for an agency that prefers low-profile discussions, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has publicly rebuked Toyota, accusing it of putting out ''inaccurate and misleading'' information about the unintended acceleration problem that could affect 3.8 million of its vehicles. The agency said a news release that Toyota issued Monday inaccurately stated that the agency had reached a conclusion ''that no defect exists in vehicles in which the driver's floor mat is compatible with the vehicle and properly secured.''

GANTZ--John G.,of Greenwich, CT, died on November 1, 2009 at age 90. Remembered as an active man who traveled extensively, a dedicated New York fan and a fiery competitor in the sports he loved, John had a passion for American history, art and antiques. In business and social life he was respected for his loyalty, integrity, humor and generosity to many organizations and charities. Above all he enjoyed his family and made his home a place of love. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Muriel, daughter Barbara Klein, son John and Margot Gantz, grandchildren Jason and Judy Klein, Jennifer and Adam Levinson, Zoe and Jorge Henriquez and Brian Gantz and three great-grandchildren. A contribution to the Gantz Scholarship Fund of The Loomis Chaffee School or to Greenwich Hospital would be greatly appreciated.

POWERS--Francis Clement, Sr.,90, formerly of Honolulu, HI and of Cold Spring Harbor and Oyster Bay, NY, died peacefully in New York City on October 31st. Jay, Jr. and Edward, he was the enthusiastic father of six children: Diana, Francis Jr., Arthur, Brian, Elizabeth and Christopher, and grandfather of nine. A graduate of the Lawrenceville School, class of 1937, and Harvard College, class of 1941, he served with the 20th U.S. Army Air Corps, WWII Pacific Theater, on Guam. He became Vice President of Sales for Powers Chemco, Inc., and a founder of Photocircuits, Inc. in Glen Cove, NY, and was a member of The New York Athletic Club and Harvard Varsity Club-inducted into its Hall of Fame in the sport of swimming. BUSES are a frugal traveler's best friend -- cheap, ubiquitous and reliable. Except when they're not, and then they're a nemesis -- slow and unpredictable. Things get worse when you factor in a seatmate, who might intrude on your personal space, insist on chitchatting or, most horrific of all, scream, squirm and throw Cheerios on the floor. Yes, I was seated next to a baby, my 10-month-old daughter, Sasha, on a Megabus bound for Washington, D.C., from New York City. This was to be a simple day trip: four hours on the bus, six hours of frugal fun in our nation's capital and four more hours back home.

The Auto Ego feature last Sunday about the owner of a vintage Bentley, David Wilkinson, misidentified the racer that his mother's uncle, Ralph DePalma, pushed to the finish line in the 1912 Indianapolis 500. That car, called the Grey Ghost, was a Mercedes, not a Mercedes-Benz. (The car's manufacturer, Daimler, merged with Benz in 1926.)

You get a very different perspective on Hong Kong if you get out of the city -- and doing so is surprisingly easy. Indeed, hiking is a very popular pastime for Hong Kongers who want to substitute a bit of real jungle for the concrete. One of the best hikes for visitors runs down the spine of the peninsula overlooking Clear Water Bay, along the High Junk Peak Country Trail. To start, you can take the MTR (Mass Transit Railway) to Hang Hau station and then catch a taxi for the short ride along Clear Water Bay Road to the starting point at Ng Fai Tin. There's a signpost marking the trail, just past the village of Ng Fai Tin itself.

THE NEWS Republicans may have emerged from last week's elections in a position to turn back the political wave President Obama unleashed last year. BEHIND THE NEWS Victories in governor's races in New Jersey and Virginia highlighted the president's trouble in transforming his victory into a sustained advantage for Democrats. Independents who voted for him in those states shifted to the Republican candidates, who played down their conservative social views and focused on jobs and the economy. Michael Steele, the party's chairman, cast the victories as signs of a Republican renaissance.
