PEDERSEN--Peer T.,a long-time resident of Rye, New York, died Thursday, November 4, 2009, at the New Canaan home of his youngest daughter, Lucy P. Hazard, with his children by his side. Peer was born July 31, 1924 at New Rochelle Hospital in New Rochelle, New York, to the late Eunice H. Terrill and Jacob Otto Pedersen. Peer was a graduate of New Rochelle High School, Dartmouth College where he was a Rufus Choate Scholar, and New York Law School. Peer was a Lieutenant Gunnery Officer of the USS Hyman, Destroyer Class, in the Pacific campaign from 1943-1946, and subsequent to the end of World War II served in the US Naval Reserve until 1956. Peer was married in 1955 to Lucy Katherine Schaefer (deceased 2007) from whom he was divorced in 1984. He practiced law for much of the past six decades at the law firm of Keenan & Pedersen located in New York, NY; he was a former Board member and General Counsel of East River Savings Bank, a former Board member of Apple Bank, both headquartered in New York City, as well as a former member of the Board of Trustees of The Rye Country Day School, in Rye, New York. A lifelong and avid all-around athlete, Peer played competitive basketball during the 1950s in New York City where he starred for several teams including the Solin Sports Club, and he played golf for most of his adult life at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, New York, where he was a member since 1946. Peer was loving father to his four children, Peer Jr., Donna Fenech, Lyn Elizabeth, and Lucy Hazard, and a loving grandfather to his eight grandchildren, Peer III, Paige, Madeline, Samantha, and Margaret Pedersen, and Nathan, Lorraine, and Kerri Fenech. Peer is also survived by son-in-laws Craig Fenech and Scott Hazard, and former daughter-in-law Mary Quick Pedersen. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY 10580 on Monday, November 9th from 5-8pm. A service in celebration of his life will be held at The Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY on Tuesday, November 10th at 11am, immediately followed by a reception at the Westchester Country Club.

Stanford running back Toby Gerhart has the thick arms of a logger and they were covered with scratches and red welts Saturday after he toppled Oregon. Gerhart rushed for a team-record 223 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Cardinal's 51-42 upset of the seventh-ranked Ducks. It was the first Pacific-10 loss this season for the Ducks (7-2, 5-1), who are eighth in the Bowl Championship Series rankings. After opening with a loss at Boise State, Oregon reeled off seven victories, outscoring its opponents by an average of 22.7 points.

8 P.M. (13, 49) BLACK MAMBA The black mamba snake is known for being fast and furious, raising a third of its body, which can grow to 13 feet, above the ground to look a person in the face. With 10 times the toxins needed to kill an adult, its bite is called the kiss of death. This ''Nature'' episode journeys to Swaziland in southern Africa, where the black mamba can be found lurking in sugar cane plantations as well as in homes, gardens, schools and even hotel rooms -- and where the traditional response has been to kill the snakes before being killed by them. But recently, snake handlers like Thea and Clifton Litschka-Koen have been working to change public perception of what they believe is the world's most misunderstood creature. (Above, one of their employees handles a specimen.) And in doing so, they have inspired King Mswati III of Swaziland to donate land for a nature reserve on which relocated black mambas can live, and to build a clinic specializing in the treatment of snakebites, the first of its kind in the country. 10 A.M. BROCHIN--Dr. Malcolm, 78, of Woodbridge, CT, died suddenly on November 6. He is survived by his beloved wife, Elizabeth Resnik Brochin and his children, Lisa Rosner and Peter Brochin (Emerrita) and his son-in-law, Dr. Joseph Camilleri Jr. He was predeceased by his daughter, Dr. Martha Brochin and his brother, Merwin Brochin. He also leaves behind seven cherished grandchildren. Dr. Brochin, a longtime obstetrician and gynecologist in the New Haven area, graduated from Dartmouth College in 1952 and Harvard Medical School in 1956.

SCHWARTZ--Ida C.,died peacefully on November 3rd, 2009 at 100 years of age. She was born in 1909, daughter of Dora and Israel Garfinkel, wife of Bernard S. Schwartz (d. 2005), mother of Valerie B. Schwartz (d. 2000). She is survived by her son, Jonathan P. Schwartz, daughter-in-law, Marcella Fischer, and grandson, S. Alexander Schwartz. Mrs. Schwartz graduated from New York University. She was on Law Review, and one of five women in the NYU Law Class of 1934. She helped to found the New York Women's Bar Association. She practiced matrimonial and real estate law. With her husband, she was a founder of the Schizophrenia Foundation of New York. She was a valued counselor to her friends, many of whom she supported ardently in their hour of need and in their aspirations. A philanthropist, she supported New York charities. She will be sorely missed. Private Service.

RIVELA--Francisco Gutierrez, Chairman of the Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors, died suddenly at the age of 54 on September 29, 2009. Mr. Rivela was an icon in Spanish language media and arts for over two decades. Mr. Rivela was the premier Spanish language voice-over artist in New York City. His voice was in a myriad of commercials and narrations including the televised United Nations program the U.N. in Action. A consummate performer, writer and director, he founded the Theatre of (No)thing in SoHo, in 1995 for bilingual alternative performance art. Mr. Rivela was an extraordinary advocate for Latin-American and Spanish actors through the Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors (H.O.L.A.), the Screen Actors Guild (S.A.G.) and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (A.F.T.R.A.). His tireless efforts provided opportunities and representation for many artists that did not have a voice. Mr. Rivela came to New York City from his native Spain in 1980. He graduated from the University of Madrid with a Masters in Communications. He had a B.A. in Drama from the Cordoba Conservatory. He was an alumna from New York University where he obtained a Masters in Educational Theatre. Mr. Gutierrez Rivela is survived by his wife, Dr. Alina Segura-Bustamante, his daughter Raquel Amalia Gutierrez, his sister Angelines Gutierrez Rivela, his nephew Alex Segura and his nieces Christina, Luz and Coral. The family will be holding a memorial service to be announced at a later date. Donations in his name can be made to the Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors.

THE Belgian designer Natalia Brilli puts a new spin on that old saw, if you have to ask how much, you can't afford it. Among the items in her catalog of curiosities is this fake Rolex watch, called a Nolex, which she covers in soft buttery leather, suggesting that if you have to know the time, you also can't afford it. Ms. Brilli, who has designed accessories at Rochas, is hyper-sensitive to the conclusions people draw about the character and status of someone wearing a luxury product. So far, she's encased everything from skateboards to medical alert bracelets in black or silver leather. But sometimes, she'll pick a bright electric hue, further scrambling the object's original associations. Nolex, $312 at Barneys New York, (212) 826-8900, and at Project 8 (212) 925-5599. ANA FINEL HONIGMAN

These are excerpts from recent posts on the Globespotters blog, a travelers' guide to cities around the world. Full entries can be found at nytimes.com/globespotters. So subtle are the installations by the Belgian artist Joëlle Tuerlinckx in Madrid's Palacio de Cristal (Parque de El Buen Retiro; 34-91-574-6614; free admission), that on entering the gorgeous light-filled glass pavilion, you might not even notice them. Only after walking around a bit and getting close to the few objects that seemingly litter the floor -- compasses, a ladder and tools in one area; a jar and knife in another -- does it occur to you that perhaps they were not just haphazardly dropped by a construction crew heading off to lunch. (Granted, in the case of the ladder, your eye certainly will catch sight of the orange filament cords wrapped around it and running up to a glass panel in the ceiling above.)

When did grooming become a spectator sport? When I was growing up, back in the days when the express train beat the local, straphangers were content to pass their time in transit with a good book or a crossword puzzle. Occasionally, I'd encounter the loud talker, the nose-picker or someone who had to free himself of a wedgie. Hey, we've all been there.

Patricia Lay-Dorsey, 67, wasn't fond of the way she looked. Her wrinkles - the "dry creek bed" on her face - made her feel uncomfortable. So she made a series of close up portraits of her face. Ms. Lay-Dorsey wasn't fond of her belly or her sagging breasts. So she photographed herself nude. Ms. Lay-Dorsey felt some shame over falling down because of multiple sclerosis. So she documented her daily routine. And, while exposing herself, Ms. Lay-Dorsey noticed something unexpected. "Somehow," she said, "I began to feel more beautiful."

From coast to coast, House Democrats on Monday trumpeted their victory in approving the big health care legislation, even as they acknowledged with some trepidation that the fate of the legislation in the Senate is far from certain.
Americans are feeling more doubtful about an overhaul of the health care system than they were in September, according to a new Gallup poll.
Former President Bill Clinton will attend the Senate Democrats' weekly caucus luncheon on Tuesday to talk about the pending health care legislation, senior Democrats said.

When it comes to the Sunshine State, coastal cities like Miami, Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale usually hog the spotlight. That might explain why The Washington Post, in its Florida special issue, turned its attention to the lesser-known Gulf Islands.

The autograph seekers have been lurking on 42nd Street for quite some time already, one of the staffers at the theater informs me. This is no large gang, but rather just a trio of very eager-looking young men clutching envelopes we believe to be full of pictures of stars who are inside the theater. They stand obediently far enough from the door of the theater to seem nonthreatening, but the unblinking watching of the door is a little disconcerting anyway. Out of the blue, Emmy Rossum exits the theater to head back to her rehearsal studio next door and they bolt toward her (but not before she totally makes a point of saying hi to me!).

As expected, the N.H.L. announced Monday afternoon that it had suspended Calgary forward Curtis Glencross for three games for a blindside hit that gave the Rangers' Chris Drury a concussion on Saturday night.
The United States women's Olympic curling team won its first tour event of the season, beating Ontario's Lisa Farnell rink 5-2 at the OVCA Fall Classic in Kemptville, Ontario, Canada.

Jurors in the criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers have been deliberating less than a day, but they have already requested several pieces of evidence, the testimony of one witness and even a day off.

The Giants announced Monday that Gerris Wilkinson, a linebacker who plays mostly on special teams, dislocated his right wrist Sunday against San Diego and would be out six to eight weeks after surgery.

Last month, we explored the many extra costs that same-sex couples incur because their unions are not recognized by the federal government. But we'd like that story to serve as a conversation starter. Now that we know the issues -- extra health insurance costs, potentially higher tax bills, estate-planning hurdles, to name a few -- we plan on exploring them in more detail. Right here.
In this week's critics' pick, A. O. Scott asks what it takes to entertain a child. Does it take 3-D, talking animals or CGI?

The health care bill passed by the House of Representatives over the weekend eliminates a tax penalty for same-sex couples who receive health benefits from employers, but whether the final legislation will include the provision is another story.

The lobbyists who went to the White House on Monday to complain about the administration's policy of banning them from an international trade advisory board were all seasoned players in Washington. So it should hardly surprise them that the White House has used their meeting for its own purposes, as an opportunity to call attention to the virtues of its no-lobbyist ban.
The Senate on Monday voted 72-to-16 to confirm Judge Andre M. Davis to a seat on the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, which is based in Richmond.

Oracle's acquisition of Sun Microsystems would not be anticompetitive and consumers would have a variety of database products from which to choose, the Justice Department's antitrust division said on Monday, a move that conflicts with a position taken by the European Union.
City officials have chosen five more development projects, one in each borough, to receive tax-free financing through the federal stimulus program.

A curious fact -- one that I can attest to based on my own inbox, and is also borne out by more general observation -- is that "Nazi" is the preferred term of abuse from today's right wing. We get signs saying "Obama=Hitler", not Obama=Stalin. I get mail calling me a "dirty Nazi scumbag", not a Commie or pinko.
One of the first and best questions about "The House of the Dead," I think, is why Dostoyevsky wrote it as a novel, and not simply as autobiography.

Are we really discussing Thanksgiving? People, I'm not only talking about it, but I've already eaten it, and I've already slurped it down.

About 300 people received swine flu shots today at The Baird in South Orange, with more vaccine available tomorrow, health officials said today. There were minimal waits, usually under 20 minutes, after the first several patients came through. Tomorrow's will be held from 1:30 to 4:30 p.m., for people ages 10 to 24.

With the New York City Opera safely (one hopes) up and running again, the spotlight swings back to the Metropolitan Opera in a season unusually thick with new productions. Next up is Janacek's "From the House of the Dead," in a staging by Patrice Chéreau that had its dress rehearsal on Monday morning and opens on Thursday evening.

After the parties to the Google settlement requested an extension on the deadline to submit a revised agreement that would address the concerns of the Justice Department and others, Judge Denny Chin agreed to set a new deadline of Friday, Nov. 13.

The attempt to sort out the meaning of the murderous actions of Maj. Nidal Hasan has consumed numerous blog cycles since Thursday. Does Hasan's rampage signal an internal jihadi threat we're ill-equipped to thwart, or was it just another meaningless moment of American lone-gunman violence?
Electronic Arts, the video game company, announced Monday that it had acquired Playfish, one maker of the social-network-based games that have become so popular this year.

Walt Disney Pictures rarely does things small when it comes to marketing, but this piece of publicity material was as big as a house.

"Before I built a wall I'd ask to know / What I was walling in or walling out, / And to whom I was like to give offence." - Robert Frost, "Mending Wall" (1914).

Bonus time on Wall Street will be very hit or miss this year amid a growing divergence in incentive compensation across the financial services industry, according to projections from Johnson & Associates, a consulting firm.

When I found out my daughter's school was offering the H1N1 vaccine last week, I quickly signed up. Given the scarcity of the vaccine in my community, I felt fortunate it was finally available through the school. But I was surprised how many parents chose not to have their kids vaccinated.
In today's "Really?" column, Anahad O'Connor explores whether magnetic therapy can ease arthritis pain.

Clearly there was a table piled high with food, but not a lot of actors spent much time sitting around eating. Some passed through quickly and went off to continue rehearsing, one cast was having its sole chance to be on the stage proper before tech and worked through lunch and others, well, who knows if all of these people even eat lunch.

When I wrote about same sex parenting in the Times Magazine this weekend, one of the people I interviewed was M. V. Lee Badgett, who is both the director of the Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation Law & Public Policy at the UCLA School of Law and a professor of Economics at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. She is also the author of "When Gay People Get Married: What Happens When Societies Legalize Same-Sex Marriage," which focuses mostly on data from the Netherlands, where same-sex marriage has been legal for nearly a decade.

In the 1920s, Alfred Sloan, who was the president of General Motors at the time, committed the automaker to the annual model change. But today, model changes are far less frequent than annual, and a recently released economic research paper argues that Detroit automakers have suffered because of it. Detroit's share of the auto market fell from roughly 73 percent in 1996 to 47 percent in 2008.

American ice dancers Meryl White and Charlie Davis qualified for their second Grand Prix final by winning their second competition of the season.

PARIS | She is known for her unadulterated beauty, feisty temper and French je ne sais quoi. Brigitte Bardot first graced the cover of Elle magazine in 1950, at the age of 15, and has remained in the public's imagination ever since. "Brigitte Bardot: The Carefree Years," an exhibition dedicated to the French star, now 75, celebrates her lasting popularity -- which itself is a reflection of France's own obsession with passion, rebellion and idealization.

More than 200 commenters chimed in on Lion Calandra's complaints about grooming in public -- the argument that people should not make public spectacles out of private moments clearly hit a nerve. Most had their own horror stories to share (often involving nail clippings or tossed dental floss), though some even confessed to their own grooming indiscretions.

Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, said Monday that it was reviewing whether it would have to write off $5.2 billion in low-income housing tax credits after the Treasury Department rejected its request last week to sell the credits to Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reports.

The Belgian designer Natalia Brilli puts a new spin on that old saw: If you have to ask how much, you can't afford it. Among her catalog of curiosities is this fake Rolex watch, called a Nolex, which she covers in soft buttery leather, suggesting that if you have to know the time, you also can't afford it.Brilli, who has designed accessories at Rochas, is hypersensitive to the conclusions people draw about the character and status of someone wearing a luxury product. So far, she's encased everything from skateboards to medical alert bracelets in black or silver leather. But sometimes, she'll pick a bright electric hue, further scrambling the object's original associations. The Nolex is $295 at Project 8, (212) 925-5599.

Last week, when Mr. Feinstein said he was "very surprised to learn of the similarity of titles," perhaps he thought he'd have the last word on the matter. But no.

The first word came early last week, flashed to Manhattan from a British Army forward operating base in Helmand Province in a Facebook message. Then confirmation arrived in a phone call Friday at lunchtime. There was a short delay on the line, but the message was clear: The ultimate New York care package had arrived in Afghanistan.

Last week, we had you imagine yourself to be a perfect princess who had to choose from among the world's most eligible princes. This week's fictitious story, about the break-up of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, is a reminder that even unions between seemingly perfect people can go horribly wrong. And both stories perfectly illustrate another recent TierneyLab topic: why we love to gossip. We enjoy the first case by vicariously living our lives through people who seemingly have it all; in the second case, we just let our bottled-up envy loose and thumb our noses at them: "You're not so perfect, Mr. Celebrity. Nyah, nyah, nyah nyah nyah." It's something that we can enjoy with our baser instincts both going in and coming out.

Last week in Rome I walked through the Forum, parallel to the Via Imperiali, from the Colosseum to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I felt as if I were walking among the skeletal ruins of empire, one of history's vast museums. Huge Corinthian columns rose up in marble, holding nothing but the sky's blue sphere above, the buildings they once belonged to vanquished by centuries of dust, lime burners, thieves. Slabs of marble lay on the ground with the fragments of names and pronouncements chiseled into them.

The Club for Growth PAC, an anti-tax organization with considerable financial resources, announced on Monday that it is endorsing Marco Rubio in his Florida Republican primary battle with Gov. Charlie Crist for the United States Senate.
A man with a knife and wearing a Red Sox cap who robbed several young women on New York City's subway system was arrested on Friday in Rocky Mount, N.C., according to the police.
The president signed legislation last week that extended the tax credit for first-time home buyers and added a new credit for some existing homeowners.

The comedian Katt Williams has been charged with burglary and trespassing and remains held in an Atlanta jail after he was arrested on Sunday night for breaking into a home, The Associated Press reported. Major James Yarbrough of the Coweta County sheriff's department told The A.P. that the break-in occurred at a home in Newnan, about 38 miles southwest of Atlanta, where a homeowner called the police to say that Mr. Williams "gained entry by breaking into the home, and items were taken from the residence." The name of the homeowner was not given. In July, gun charges against Mr. Williams were dropped after an incident in New York in November 2008 when the police pulled him over for driving a car without license plates and discovered a gun in the car. The comedian sought medical care later that month after he was seen behaving suspiciously in Sumter, S.C., where his family lives. The A.P. said that a magistrate was expected to set bond for Mr. Williams at an arraignment Monday afternoon.

It's clear that no food publication is recession-proof. Culinary photography, however, is bubbling over, with a new annual festival kicking off this month in Paris called the Festival International de la Photographie Culinaire. Its founder, a former cookbook editor named Jean-Pierre Stephan, has noticed a revolution in the quality of food photos over the past decade, thanks to the boom in cookbooks and foodie mags. "I want to show that culinary photography has become a true art," he says, "one that can make its way in the marketplace the same as any other form of art or photography. You can hang it on the dining room wall like a 17th-century Dutch still life."

The magazine Metropolitan Home will be closing, Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S. announced today.Hachette will focus resources - and, presumably, try to concentrate ad pages - at Elle Décor, which it also owns. The company had shut down another design title, Home, in 2008.

By 8 a.m. the directors had finished submitting their choices (Lucie Tiberghien said she thought the scripts were all good, and all funny. "Nobody tried to do a dark drama," she said). It seemed only a few minutes had passed before Philip Naudé, one of the producers, gave the directors their assignments. Leigh Kilton-Smith is to direct Stephen Belber's play, "Ramen Noodle," and her reaction seemed unclear for a moment - was that pleasant shock or something more like horror that flashed across her face?

BlackBerry owners may be able to type circles around their iPhone-toting friends when it comes to speeding through e-mails. By the latest count, the Apple iPhone has 100,000 apps and the BlackBerry has just a few thousand.

Every year since 2000, the National Survey of Student Engagement has sought to take the academic pulse of tens of thousands of college students at several hundred colleges. To me, their answers are almost beside the point. I've always thought the questions themselves provided an especially detailed road map for high school seniors and their parents, as they try to take the measure of a particular college.

Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker staff writer who for five years has been doing double-duty as the editor of The Paris Review, will leave his editor's post in April, The New York Observer reported. In an interview with The Observer, Mr. Gourevitch (whose books include "We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families" and "The Ballad of Abu Ghraib") said that he wanted to focus more on his writing and a new book project about Rwanda. "I want to give that everything," Mr. Gourevitch said. "You can't take time off when you're in charge." A committee run by Antonio Weiss, the publisher of The Paris Review, and Terry McDonnell, the director of the Paris Review Foundation, and including Bob Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, and Peter Matthiessen, a founder of The Paris Review, will search for Mr. Gourevitch's replacement.

NBC's Tom Brokaw returns to Berlin for the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.  Brokaw was the only U.S. anchor in Berlin the night the wall fell.

Updated | 1:20 p.m. A long-running theatrical marriage has hit a major bump: a union that represents professional musicians has filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, saying that the producers of the show "Tony N' Tina's Wedding" fired its contracted musicians and replaced them with recorded music. The Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said that in 2008 it renewed a three-year agreement with the previous producers of that show, which covered its performers through May 2011, and stipulated that it must be honored if new producers came onto the show. The union said that the producers Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, which recently took over "Tony N' Tina's Wedding," paid the musicians for the show's Oct. 10 performance and asked them to learn a new song for Oct. 17. On that date, however, the union said the producers locked the musicians out of the performance space and have denied them access to their instruments and other property. A representative for Local 802 said a meeting had been scheduled for Monday afternoon to address the dispute. A message left at Broadway Entertainment was not immediately returned.

On Saturday, two streets in Harlem were named in honor of two civil rights leaders with ties to New York City: A. Philip Randolph and W. E. B. DuBois.

Street art in Auckland, New Zealand, is much more than just random acts of spray paint. Nearly every corner of the city is decorated with sophisticated graphic imagery, from stencil drawings (sharks, angels, aerosol-can characters) to murals (intergalactic space settings, muscle men portraiture) to "throw-ups" (elaborate, bubble-shaped letters forming the artist's signature). The city council has even allowed electrical boxes to be used as 3-D canvases for street art. While some of the artists and collectives have achieved a certain visibility in the graffiti world - a local crew called TMD (The Most Def) has won the "Write For Gold" international competition in Germany for the past two years - many of the taggers are anonymous. And if you want to see their handiwork, you'd better be quick. Most of the art (excluding the electrical-box mainstays) is either torn down or painted over within a few days. As Andrew Beck, from the Auckland collective Surplus Bargains, says: "That's what street art is - temporary."

The battle between CF Industries, Terra Industries and Agrium looks to be near a conclusion after the events of the past week. CF raised its hostile offer for Terra to $40.61 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected about 48 hours later by Terra's board. Meanwhile, Agrium raised its hostile offer for CF to $92.99 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected less than 24 hours later by CF's board.

The decade isn't quite over yet, but The Times of London made an early effort on Saturday at tying a bow around the last ten years with its list of the 100 best films of the decade. The Times's proudly opinionated lineup feels more provocative than definitive, though it does make an effort to represent all sides of 2000s cinema, from art-house fare ("The Diving Bell and the Butterfly" at No. 28; "Dancer in the Dark" at No. 25) to hit crowd-pleasers ("The Devil Wears Prada" at No. 100; "Wedding Crashers" at No. 90) to cult favorites ("Shaun of the Dead" at No. 58), with at least one authentic "Huh?" moment in there ("Bad Santa" at No. 54?).

The writers are nowhere to be seen at the moment, the room some of them used last night is empty. They have gone to bed.

Treasury inflation-protected securities -- bonds whose payouts are indexed to consumer prices -- are really useful for economic analysis: they give an objective, market-based measure of expected inflation. But you have to be a bit careful about using them to interpret recent events, because the same financial disruptions that wreaked havoc with many assets also did some funny stuff to TIPS.

A tilted plywood wall wraps around the northwest corner of Bainbridge Avenue and East 204th Street, where the air smells of smoke and the sidewalk glistens from broken glass. The wall tries to hide the ghastly sight of 10 storefronts burned to sooty brick and skeletal girders. But it only reminds all who pass of a local tragedy.

Early this decade, a drought in Brazil that cut water to the country's hydroelectric dams prompted severe energy shortages. The crisis, which ravaged the country's economy and led to electricity rationing, underscored Brazil's pressing need to diversify away from water power.

The celebratory mood of the first few hours of 24 Hour Plays activity at the American Airlines Theater Sunday night gave way to a more contemplative one shortly after 11:30 p.m. when only the writers, producers and a few others were left. After the actors took off, the writers had a chance to see the stage where their shows are to be presented Monday night. There is already a set on the stage, a big, English country house designed by Allen Moyer for "After Miss Julie," and the writers will have to work with it or around it. This is not a simple matter, given the absurdly long wooden table, the abundance of what looks like delicate china and a number of other items that are not likely to fit every play that is being cooked up. "It would be tricky to not use this set," Warren Leight said as the group of writers gapes at the big, crowded stage.

What happens in Vegas doesn't stay in Vegas in the beginning of a triple crossover on "CSI: Miami" (CBS, 10 p.m.). Ray Langston (Laurence Fishburne) of "CSI" travels to Miami when a leg found there turns out to belong to a woman who went missing in Las Vegas. The story plays out on "CSI: NY" on Wednesday and "CSI" on Thursday.

John G. Stumpf, the chief executive of Wells Fargo, objected vocally to the federal injection of rescue funds into banks, saying taxpayers were benefiting at Wells Fargo's expense. A year on, the government still owns $25 billion of Wells preferred stock. The bank's boss has cooled his rhetoric, but still wants to pay back the Treasury's Troubled Asset Relief Program investment "shortly." He also wants to avoid damage to his shareholders. Reconciling the two objectives is not easy, Breakingviews.com says.

Released just over a decade ago, Benjamin Anastas’s debut novel, “An Underachiever’s Diary”, about the lesser of a pair of twin boys, was a sort of precursor to the smart, funny slacker-hipsters of today. (See: Jonathan Ames and his alter-ego Jason Schwartzman in “Bored to Death.”) Now that it’s been reissued in paperback, Mr. Anastas, also a journalist, gets to overachieve in lit form. He reads from it tonight at the Half-King.

Dance movie fans are probably doing a pas de deux right now: two stellar examples of the genre are in theaters. A favorite of Martin Scorsese, the restored version of the classic “Red Shoes” “has been the inspiration for countless bleeding feet and soaring artistic passions,” writes Manohla Dargis, who calls it “essential viewing.” And the documentary “La Danse: the Paris Opera Ballet,” from the veteran vérité director Frederick Wiseman, “is one of the finest dance films ever made,” A.O. Scott writes — worthwhile even if you don’t know a plié from a tutu. “The substance of Mr. Wiseman’s particular genius is the way it transfixes you with the inner workings of an institution you may not otherwise care about.”

Nien Cheng, whose memoir, ''Life and Death in Shanghai,'' offered a harrowing account of the Cultural Revolution in China and her years of imprisonment and torture at the hands of the Red Guards, died on Nov. 2 at her home in Washington. She was 94. The cause was cardiovascular and renal disease, said Catherine Mack, the executor of her estate.

HEYMAN--Samuel. Our deepest condolences to Ronnie, Larry (Kim), Eleanor (Rodney), Jenny (David) and Liz (David). Sam was an extraordinary man who will continue to be an inspiration to all who knew him. May you find comfort in your many wonderful memories of him. With love, Susan, Benjamin and Alison Winter

Research in Motion, the company that makes the BlackBerry Storm phone, above, announced a share buyback last week, after weak third-quarter results led to a drop in the stock price. The Storm, and its successor, Storm 2, released in mid-October, work on Verizon's network and were meant to compete with Apple's iPhone. Some 23.8 million users owned touch-screen phones in August, an increase of 159 percent from August 2008. Still, it seems the iPhone, with a larger share than the next four competitors combined, has an insurmountable lead. SHELLY FREIERMAN

SPECIAL WEB REPORT A new Times Topics page, ''The Berlin Wall: 20 Years Later,'' collects dozens of photos from readers who were there when the wall came down, reactions by Angela Merkel and other political leaders, audio reports from Alison Smale and Serge Schmemann, and an archive of news articles and photographs documenting history as it happened. nytimes.com/berlinwall
Another Miracle for Snyder When Bill Snyder was hired for a second stint as the coach of Kansas State last year, the move was widely viewed as an act of desperation.

HEYMAN--Samuel. You were a mentor, a leader possessing great wisdom, strength and kindness. To me you were so very special. You believed in me and made me believe in myself. You taught me to work hard and maintain the highest ethics. You entrusted your family to me, each one I have grown to love so very much. To my good friend Ronnie you had the "best of the best" as a partner down life's path. To Larry and Kim, Eleanor and Rodney, Jennifer and David, Elizabeth and David, all the grandchildren and the Fuerstein family deepest condolences and love. Sam will be with us all forever. Nancy and Ralph Elias

Stacy Rowles, a jazz trumpeter, fluegelhorn player and singer who had been active on the Los Angeles jazz scene since the 1980s, died on Oct. 27 at her home in Burbank, Calif. She was 54. The cause was complications from a car accident on Oct. 13, said her sister, Stephanie Rowles.

Conquering armies of centuries past avoided this remote, mountainous area along the present-day border with China, once described by a British colonial official as ''an unpenetrated enclave of savage hills.'' Neither the British colonial overlords nor the Burmese kings who preceded them saw much point in controlling the area, inhabited by the Wa, an ethnic group once notorious for headhunting.

The government ''should have done a lot more in both areas'' in recent years, he said.

(HBO Signature) JOE'S PALACE (2007) Michael Gambon plays Elliot Graham, a billionaire recluse, and Danny Lee Wynter (above left, with Mr. Gambon) is Joe, the teenage caretaker of Elliot's grand but empty London house -- and his conduit to the outside world. When Elliot allows a philandering politician (Rupert Penry-Jones) to conduct an affair with his married mistress (Kelly Reilly) in the house, Joe becomes close to the lovers. But in time the house comes to feel more like a prison for all the characters, forcing Elliot to examine the dark secrets of his past. This drama, written and directed by Stephen Poliakoff (''Gideon's Daughter''), is the first of two set against the backdrop of this gloomy mansion and linked by Joe, a highly individualistic young man whose lower social status renders him invisible to those around him. ''Capturing Mary,'' the second film, starring Maggie Smith, will be shown Tuesday at 9. 8 P.M. (NBC) HEROES Claire (Hayden Panettiere) tries to get at the truth behind the sorority rush attacks. Which business model for watching movies online will be the winner? Paying upwards of $8 a month for unlimited and instant online access to an older catalog of films and TV shows from a company like Netflix? Or paying $2 to $3 a film for access to newer releases from a service like Amazon's Video on Demand? The Catalyst Group, a New York research company that studies how people use technology, looked into this question. The company conducted extensive interviews in August with 11 people they introduced to the $99 Roku player -- a device that connects to the TV and the Internet and gives owners access to both Netflix and Amazon Video on Demand.

The new issue of the Web journal Open Letters Monthly features a "cover" portrait of Marguerite Duras by the Swedish artist Carl Köhler, who died in 2006. It's a pretty cool image - a sketchy double exposure showing Duras both as an old woman and in the prime of her life, with blocks of color that make it appear as if she's emerging ghostlike from the gloom - but the main thing that caught my attention was the painter's name. I've been looking at a lot of Carl Köhler's author portraits lately. Earlier this year, the Brooklyn Central Library mounted an exhibition of them, which I missed, but after the show left Brooklyn for Washington, I heard from its curator (and the artist's son), Henry Köhler, who forwarded a batch of his father's work. Köhler was a neo-modernist who especially liked to paint writers and intellectuals: Kafka, Beckett, Joyce, Gide, Beauvoir, all in a rough, haunting style that captured their writerly moods as much as their physical appearances. The exhibition will travel early next year to Toronto and Vancouver, but you can peek at some of Köhler's paintings in a slide show, here.

In the second week of its three-week run, Performa 09 is unfolding at a fast and furious pace. Redefining the concept of over-booking, it is serving up more than any one person can see. The events I've managed to attend have ranged from great to less than, and run the gamut in terms of production values. It was production values to fore on Saturday in Tacita Dean's sleek, gorgeously majestic "Craneway Event," a 16mm color film that was unexpectedly hypnotic at St. Marks on the Bowery. Her second collaboration with the choreographer Merce Cunningham is a slow-moving documentary (100 minutes) of a rehearsal in the cavernous, many-windowed craneway of a refurbished factory in northern California. Ms. Dean's themes center on the ineluctable movement of light -- and to some extent the camera -- through time and space. A great artist still at work at the end of his career, surrounded by acolytes and ever-deepening shadows, is the perfect subject for her relentless, elegiac art.

No single piece of clothing says "neutered invertebrate" or "cult member" quite like the Snuggie ("the blanket with sleeves!"). For more than a year, these large, shapeless swaths of cheap fleece designed for lying on the couch and working the remote have inexplicably remained fixed in the kitsch cultural firmament. There are fan tribute sites, YouTube homages and pub crawls; Oprah, Ellen and Al Roker have worn them on camera. Most incredible of all, more than five million have been sold.

Today's idea: There are three types of fool, an essay says, and no one's immune: You're one, at one time or another. Sometimes it's even smart to play the fool.

The seemingly endless recession, the growing attraction of Kindles and the steady shuttering of bookstores gave the owners of one bookstore in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, even more reason to celebrate today. They're still open.

PARIS | Lucio Fontana was so handy with a knife he could probably have made a living as an old-school hit man. Instead he became an artist, and a pivotal one at that. Through what he called his "concetto spaziale," or spatial concept, he exerted a huge influence on 20th-century modernist art.

When the Oasis of the Seas, the world's largest cruise ship, departed Finland on its maiden voyage on Oct. 30, it barely squeezed under Denmark's Great Belt Bridge, with less than two feet to spare. There will be no such close calls when the Oasis, owned by Royal Caribbean International, docks in its new home, Cruise Terminal 18, a huge complex that opened Nov. 8, at Port Everglades, Fla.

When I was 26 years old, I chased a guy down an alley in San Francisco's Tenderloin district. It's a bit of a long story, but suffice it to say that it involved a free airline ticket, a flight filled with Deadheads, a friend of a friend of a friend who offered me a place to crash, being mistaken for a transvestite and warned not to walk down Tenderloin alleys after dark, even if it was only 7 p.m.

The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that it had entered into a five-year partnership with Egypt to help conserve and manage the tomb of Tutankhamen, whose striking wall paintings have been pocked with brown spots at least since the tomb's discovery in 1922.

If you want to relive the magic or trauma -- or both -- of childbirth, you might want to check out the live streamed (now recorded) birth of Solveig, who was born on a live streaming video. Lynsee, his mother, is a former teacher and she decided to have her baby on live web video as an educational gesture. (She is a saint during the whole process, which may explain her generous nature.)

After months of delays because of tangled vetting procedures, the Obama administration plans to name Rajiv J. Shah as the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, officials familiar with the appointment said on Tuesday.

The street artist Shepard Fairey has won the right to a new lawyer in his ongoing suit against The Associated Press over the image that became his celebrated Barack Obama "Hope" poster. In a pretrial hearing, U.S. District Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein also allowed that lawyers for The A.P. can depose Mr. Fairey and his outgoing lawyers before the end of the year, The A.P. reported. The agency and the artist are countersuing each other over the rights to the image, a photo taken in April 2006 at an event at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Fairey recently admitted that he had lied publicly and to his own lawyers about which image he had used, which caused them to abandon his case.

My colleague Steven Greenhouse wrote last June about the record for work-sharing programs. Under such programs, employers reduce their workers' weekly hours and pay. The government then pays workers some, or all, of their lost wages. The best-known work-sharing program is in Germany, but other developed countries have adopted it, as have many American states.

It's been an exciting fall for local sports, with Columbia High School football logging only one loss in the regular season and headed to the playoffs, the Millburn High School girls soccer team going to the state sectional finals Thursday, and, with any luck today, the Millburn boys soccer team heading to the semi-finals. But not all the glory belongs to the secondary schools. Here's a report on a local elementary school cross country program from James M. O'Neill, a reporter for The Record of Bergen County. The room is recreated with exquisite attention to detail: a scribbled price list for sexual services on a whiteboard. A large bowl with condoms spilling onto the end table. Half-used lipstick scattered among twisted thongs, high heels and toilet paper. A sickly perfume-type smell that clings to the torn wallpaper. A grimy stained bed designed to shudder under the weight of invisible, moving bodies. Men's voices that alternately issue commands and groans.

The creation of a Consumer Financial Protection Agency got another lift with its inclusion in a sweeping overhaul of the financial regulatory system proposed Tuesday by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and the chairman of the Senate banking committee.

The Broadway producers of "Alfred Hitchcock's The 39 Steps" have opened negotiations to move the quick-witted play to the Off Broadway venue New World Stages next year, according to the show's lead producer, Bob Boyett. "The 39 Steps" is scheduled to close on Broadway on Jan. 10 after almost three years.

As some of you will recall, I have been following the progress of (and offering advice to) Debbie Dusenberry, the owner of a home-furnishing and gift store in Kansas called Curious Sofa. You can read "When Passion Meets Math" to see how Ms. Dusenberry built her store, garnered lots of media attention for her merchandising, ran smack into the Great Recession and began the journey from artist to businesswoman. This small-business journey is far more common than most people understand. Ms. Dusenberry is so good at the artistry that she is envied by other owners, one of whom has called her "retail royalty." But as you will see in a moment, her retail reality is very different.

Even as the old "that's the way it is" model of mass media is increasingly tested by the Web, there are interesting experiments under way that show how far-flung, yet important, issues like marine pollution can still be effectively covered. One surfaced today in a Science Times article by Lindsey Hoshaw, known on Twitter as @thegarbagegirl. The feature is an up-close examination of the Pacific Ocean's vast patch of plastic flotsam, reported with travel money provided by readers of Spot.us.

Evelyn Hofer, 87, was a flawless technician and a much sought-after teacher, who searched for an "inside value, some interior respect" in the people she photographed. She favored carefully composed scenes with a still, timeless aura, William Grimes notes, in reporting her death on Nov. 2.

There is a small gem of a show at Danziger Projects right now, featuring a little-known trove of Polaroids by Andy Warhol of famous athletes. They were commissioned by one collector in the late 1970s and early '80s. The simplicity of Warhol's method - straightforward portraits shot with the Big Shot camera - gives the tiny images (4 1/4" x 3 3/8") a purity and sincerity that belies the radiance and aura of greatness coming from the sitters. Even today, there is something tingle-inducing about seeing Muhammad Ali, Dorothy Hamill, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Chris Evert, Pelé, Tom Seaver and Wayne Gretzky captured at the height of their youthfulness and fame. These portraits, made by the ultimate connoisseur of fame himself, have aged beautifully. The show is up through Dec. 12 at 534 West 24th Street.

Kathryn Gurland has learned about the intricacies of cancer through her work as a medical social worker and therapist. But Ms. Gurland's knowledge is also uniquely personal. Her older sister Judi learned that she had melanoma at age 46 and died eight months later. Her younger sister Peggy, who never smoked, received a diagnosis of nonsmall-cell lung cancer and died 14 months later, just shy of her 45th birthday.

How long does it take for the Next Big Thing to actually become a big thing? We've been hearing whispers about the London band the XX since late summer, when they released their superb debut album, "XX," in Europe - and a whisper is the appropriate register for this music, with its wispy vocals and sparse arrangements that echo a range of styles from old-school soul to modern-day trip-hop. The record's October release stateside brought more praise (including this from The New York Times); and a month-long United States tour, kicking off tomorrow in New York, may be just what the band needs to bring the whispers to a roar.The four-piece band already seems wise beyond its years (each member is barely 20 years old), and for the video for their first single, "Basic Space" (above), they made a clever choice in hiring Anthony Dickenson, an up-and-coming British director and photographer. Dickenson recently picked up a UK Music Video Award for this music video from Speech Debelle and is currently at work on a photo project that will be exhibited next year. The "Basic Space" video warrants watching in high definition - it's a cool experiment with light, speed and focus that fits perfectly with the XX's minimalist aesthetic.

The "climate divide" between countries that are rich and poor, insulated from climate impacts and vulnerable to them, was on vivid display in the Maldives over the last few days. Countries that consider themselves most threatened by human-driven global warming -- mainly places exposed to the sea or reliant on rainfall -- concluded a forum there and issued a declaration of their concerns and demands. Mike Shanahan of the International Institute for Environment and Development sent the text, which I have included below.

Eighty years ago, the United Workers Cooperative Colony in the Bronx was more than just a housing complex for an enclave of secular Jews -- many of them communists, socialists, anarchists and their sympathizers. "The Coops," as this community of two square blocks is commonly called, once housed their own restaurant, gym, youth clubs, grocery store and day care center. Built next to the spacious Bronx Park, the Coops still have lush gardens in their courtyards and the hammer and sickle adorning the doors.

For various reasons I've been doing a lot of walking around the past few days, in both Princeton and New York, visiting areas I haven't looked at for several months. And I'm not sure what to make of it, but casual observation suggests a stronger recovery than anything I see in published numbers. Lots of small-scale construction -- home remodeling, tear-downs replacing old houses. Many new businesses and restaurants filling storefronts that were vacant a couple of months ago.

With just over 70 operating plants offering capacity of around 3,100 megawatts, the United States is the global leader in generating electrical power from geothermal resources, according to a recent report from Islandsbanki, an Icelandic bank that provides investment and financial services to the sustainable energy sector.

The unemployment rate may top 10 percent, but there is an opening at the University of California, Santa Cruz, for a Deadhead. The library is advertising for an archivist to handle the library's Grateful Dead collection. A master's degree in archives management is required, as is "expert knowledge in the history of and scholarship of contemporary popular music, or American vernacular culture, preferably the history and influence of the Grateful Dead."

PBS's "Frontline" offers a timely repeat of a 2008 program called "Sick Around the World" (PBS, 9 p.m. on most stations). In one fast-moving hour, it examines the health care and insurance systems of five countries, including Britain, Japan and Germany, and makes the case that supporters of health-care reform in America have failed to make over the last year. A review of the program is here.

Our fun-for-all-ages winter issue of T Design and Living is out, but the great designs for the young, not to mention the young at heart, just keep coming. (Stay tuned for more later in the week.) Case in point: the four witty, whimsical rugs that the London designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have done for the Rug Company. Colorful and graphic, each rug depicts a different member of the animal kingdom and reflects its nature, from the solitary owl against its night-sky background to an acid-green snake that seems to slither off the edge of its rug. A pair of butterflies and an adorable school of fish round out the designs, which cost $3,285 or $4,725, depending on size. Barber Osgerby's designs have the playful simplicity of children's-book illustrations, but they're so sophisticated that you'll likely be seeing them in grown-up rooms, too.

FRONT PAGE.

A music review on Saturday about New York City Opera’s opening-night gala, using information provided by the company, misstated the title of one of the songs performed. It was “Soliloquy,” not “Billy’s Soliloquy,” from the musical “Carousel.”.

An article on Saturday about a newly published oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater misspelled the surname of a collaborator who helped Papp create the theater. He is Bernard Gersten, not Gerstein.

A picture caption on Saturday with a dance review about the Cave New York Butoh Festival misidentified the performer in “Furnace,” which opened the festival. She is Stephanie Lanckton — not Ximena Garnica, an artistic director of the festival.

An article on Saturday about a new lead producer for the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the troubled production that has ceased selling advance tickets, misidentified the firm that is handling those sales. It is Ticketmaster, not Telecharge.
LeBron James clarified a remark he made last week in which he said getting a maximum contract next summer was not that important to him.

Picture captions and credits in some editions on Monday with an article about the absence of a playoff system for college football were reversed in some copies. The top photograph showed Jordan Shipley of Texas and was by Brian Bahr of Getty Images. The bottom photograph showed Alabama’s Julio Jones after a 73-yard touchdown reception and was by Dave Martin of The Associated Press.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about Rent the Runway, an online dress rental company, reversed the identifications of the company’s founders in some copies. Jennifer Hyman is at the left and Jennifer Carter Fleiss is at the right.

An article on Saturday about a new stock option program for Citigroup employees misstated the total number of options to be dispensed. Citigroup granted between 200 million and 300 million options, not two million to three million. As a result, the article also misstated the value of the options as of the close of trading Friday. The options had an expected value of almost $1.1 billion, not $11 million.
An article on Sunday about the victims of the shootings at Fort Hood omitted the given name of the father of one victim. He is Juan Velez.
For many, last week’s carnage was another blow in an area that has been beset by violence since the Iraq and Afghanistan wars began.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the police officer who shot the suspected gunman at Fort Hood misstated, in some editions, the make of the sports utility vehicle she owns. It is a Chevrolet Tahoe; there is no Ford Tahoe.
Bill Simmons’s history of basketball stretches almost 700 pages because, he said, he wanted it to be memorable, and he wanted to do it once.

An article on Saturday about the large gains for Wall Street bankers on stock grants and options awarded last year in lieu of cash bonuses misstated, in some editions, the value of some anticipated compensation, which the Treasury Department mandated be almost entirely in the form of stock. If performance goals are met, 19 executives at Citigroup will split $113 million, not $133 million, in stock this year, and 12 executives at Bank of America will share in $75.6 million, not $78.6 million. The article also misstated, in some editions, the value of the Citigroup options should the share value, which was around $4 on Friday, rebound to $12. The shares would then be worth $340 million, not $400 million.

The writer Zachary Lazar is adept at mingling real-life characters — like the Rolling Stones, the director Kenneth Anger and Manson family acolytes — in slightly tweaked situations; “Sway,” his second novel, “reads like your parents’ nightmare idea of what would happen to you if you fell under the spell of rock ’n’ roll,” Charles Taylor wrote. In his latest book, “Evening’s Empire,” Lazar investigates his own life; it’s a memoir about the murder of his father. He reads from it tonight at the KBG Bar’s nonfiction night, alongside Sonja Livingston, the author of “Ghostbread,” about growing up poor in upstate New York.

In the downtown dance world, the choreographer Tere O’Connor is “an essential figure, adored for his exquisitely constructed works, his mentoring and his fiercely articulated beliefs about all things related to dance,” writes Claudia La Rocco. His newest work, “Wrought Iron Fog,” uses different movement styles and a “delicately layered score” to give a glimpse, the choreographer said, of the “beauty you pass by quickly in the day,” the iron in the fog. The show opens today at DTW.

Cue the farmboy extras: “Cedar City Falls,” a staged soap opera from the “Sex and the City” writers, is “the sassy, salty story of a Midwestern town,” writes Patrick Healy, “where neighbors fall in and out of friendship (and bed) with one another and squabble over extramarital affairs, church choir rivalries, missing goats, DNA paternity tests — you know the drill.” Produced by Liz Tuccillo (a writer of “He’s Just Not That Into You”) and three of her fellow SATC alums, it delivers snappy dialogue and special guest stars (like cast members from “Mad Men” and “Law and Order” ) live every Tuesday this month at Galapagos. Go knock back a few beer-tinis.

Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker staff writer who for five years has been doing double duty as the editor of The Paris Review, will leave his editor’s post in April, The New York Observer reported. In an interview with The Observer, Mr. Gourevitch, left (whose books include “We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families,” about the Rwandan genocide, and “The Ballad of Abu Ghraib”), said he wanted to focus more on his writing and a new book project about Rwanda. “I want to give that everything,” he said. “You can’t take time off when you’re in charge.” A committee to find Mr. Gourevitch’s replacement will be run by Antonio Weiss, the publisher of The Paris Review, and Terry McDonnell, director of the Paris Review Foundation, and include Robert B. Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, and the author Peter Matthiessen, a founder of The Paris Review.

A long-running theatrical marriage has hit a major bump: a union that represents musicians has filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, saying the producers of the show “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” had fired its contracted musicians and replaced them with recorded music. Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians said that in 2008 it renewed a three-year agreement with the previous producers of that show, covering its performers through May 2011 with the requirement that it must be honored if new producers came aboard. The union said that the producers Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, which recently took over “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding,” paid the musicians for the Oct. 10 performance and asked them to learn a new song for Oct. 17. On that date, however, the producers locked the musicians out of the performance space, the union said, and they have denied them access to their instruments and other property since then. A representative for Local 802 said a meeting had been scheduled for Monday afternoon to address the dispute. A message left at Broadway Entertainment was not immediately returned.
A face-off between the Dallas Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles was the No. 1 draw on Sunday as NBC’s football coverage easily led the night.

The sweet emotions that the members of Aerosmith once felt toward one another have apparently come to an end. In an interview with The Las Vegas Sun, the group’s lead guitarist, Joe Perry, near right, said the singer Steven Tyler, far right, had quit after a concert in Abu Dhabi. “Steven quit as far as I can tell,” Mr. Perry told The Sun. “I don’t know any more than you do about it.” Mr. Perry was responding to remarks that Mr. Tyler made in an interview with Classic Rock, a British music magazine, in which Mr. Tyler said he was preparing to focus on a solo career. “I don’t know what I’m doing yet,” he said, “but it’s definitely going to be something Steven Tyler: working on the brand of myself — brand Tyler.” Mr. Perry said he had had difficulty confirming this with Mr. Tyler because the singer had not returned his phone calls. “He’s notorious for that,” he told The Sun. “That’s one thing I’ve learned to live with. I try to overlook it.” Aerosmith canceled several concerts over the summer after Mr. Tyler fell from a stage on Aug. 5. A publicist for the band referred questions to its management, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The comedian Katt Williams has been charged with burglary and trespassing and remains in an Atlanta jail after he was arrested on Sunday night on suspicion of breaking into a home, The Associated Press reported. Maj. James Yarbrough of the Coweta County Sheriff’s Department told The A.P. that the break-in had occurred at a home in Newnan, about 38 miles southwest of Atlanta, where a homeowner called the police to say Mr. Williams, above, “gained entry by breaking into the home, and items were taken from the residence.” The name of the homeowner was not given. In July gun charges against Mr. Williams were dropped after an incident in New York in November 2008 in which the police pulled him over for driving a car without license plates and discovered a gun in the car. The comedian sought medical care later that month after he was seen behaving suspiciously in Sumter, S.C., where his family lives. The A.P. said a magistrate was expected to set bond for Mr. Williams at an arraignment on Monday afternoon.

BAZIGOS--Nicholas M.,distinguished engineer, passed away on November 7. He survived his adoring wife, the late Mary (nee Panagakos), and is survived by his sons, Michael, William, and John, his granddaughters, Ariadne and Alexandra, and Krystyna Krukar, a loving family friend who cared for him in illness. Viewing at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn from 2-5pm and 7-9pm Tuesday and Wednesday. Service at Holy Cross Greek Orthodox Church, 8401 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn, 9:30am Thursday.

From coast to coast, House Democrats on Monday trumpeted their victory in approving health care legislation, even as they acknowledged with some trepidation that the fate of the Senate measure was far from certain. Speaker Nancy Pelosi, above, visited Seattle to tour the Swedish Medical Center, which operates a ''medical home'' program to help coordinate patient care. The House bill establishes pilot programs to encourage the creation of such homes.

HEYMAN--Samuel. We are so saddened by the loss of a good and dear friend, so loving and so caring. We extend our deepest sympathy to Ronnie and the family that Sam loved so much. Marlene and Harold Strauss

Angela Ahrendts, in her three years as chief executive, has reshaped Burberry, pushing it closer to upscale rivals like LVMH and Hermès. Now Ms. Ahrendts, the 49-year-old American sitting atop one of the world's quintessentially British brands, hopes to adapt its trench coat to the age of the Internet.

The Senate on Monday voted 72 to 16 to confirm Judge Andre M. Davis to a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, based in Richmond, Va. Mr. Davis's appointment has been a long time coming -- nine years, to be exact. President Bill Clinton, a Democrat, nominated him in October 2000, but the nomination languished in the administration's final months, then basically died once President George W. Bush assumed office.

Many doctors are performing unnecessary Pap smears, ignoring guidelines issued by major medical organizations and adding to health care costs, a survey of physicians has found. Of 1,212 primary care doctors who responded to a survey about cervical cancer screening, about one-fifth described practices that were consistent with the latest recommendations from groups including the American Cancer Society and the United States Preventive Services Task Force, the study found. Most had overused cervical cancer screening.

A rare order filed last week by a federal judge in California appears to give prosecutors a sliver of hope that they will be allowed to keep the positive drug tests for more than 100 major league players. Judge Alex Kozinski of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in California, asked lawyers for the players union and the government to submit briefs by Nov. 25 regarding whether all 27 judges of the court should rehear the case. Since 1980, the court has used ''limited en banc'' panels, currently 11 judges.

HEYMAN--Samuel. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Samuel Heyman, and extends sincere sympathy to his beloved wife, Ronnie; his four children; grandchildren; his mother; and to his entire family.

STANG--Blanche Feder, died at home in Florida November 6, 2009. She was a beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Her husband, Arthur Stang, preceded her in 1995. Burial at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ, Wednesday November, 11, 2009 at 1pm.

HEYMAN--Samuel J. We are shocked and saddened by Sam's untimely death. Our thoughts are with Ronnie and the entire family during this terribly difficult time. We will miss Sam's dry sense of humor, profound intellect and thoughtful friendship. Linda and Peter Berley

KANE--Janet. (May 2, 1926 - November 7, 2009) died peacefully Saturday morning with her husband of sixty-one years, Stanley, and one of her three daughters by her side. She lived for eighty-three pleasure-filled years, eighty-one of which were enjoyed in perfect health, without even a minor surgery. The day before her passing, she worked on her beautiful orchids, which always filled her home, blooming year after year under her loving care. In the evening she enjoyed a dinner of grey sole, zucchini seasoned with cinnamon, and oven-roasted potatoes, all the while commenting on how delicious everything was. Janet was a devoted wife. Try as her daughters did to whisk her away on any number of girls' weekends, Janet would always reply, "Oh, I couldn't possibly leave your father." Janet first met Stanley when they were youngsters in New Rochelle, NY, but it was after Stanley returned home from the war that she stole his heart. They married and raised three daughters The Kane Girls in New Rochelle and then Bedford Hills, NY. Since then and forever after Janet would tout that her daughters were her greatest achievement. Janet and Stanley moved to Sarasota in 1984 where they quickly became pillars of Sarasota society. Equally known for their great parties and philanthropy, Janet was both the Belle of the Ball and YMCA First Citizen. She had an unrivaled zest for life. Wherever she went, people loved being near her. Her enthusiasm was infectious, her generosity enormous. She was brilliant, and could talk about everything from politics to literature, fashion to food. Always witty and insightful, she lit up every room with her glowing warmth and spirit. So much so that people often called her before scheduling their parties, so as to make sure that she'd be there. She was a thoroughly glamorous party girl who created fun everywhere she went. Delighted by the dresses, piqued by the gossip, and thrilled by everyone's plans, your joy was her joy, your sorrow her tears. She had the rare gift of making you feel entirely special, as though you were the most important person in the world. In her eyes you were beautiful, brilliant, and talented. She was everyone's greatest fan, which in turn made her everyone's favorite friend. Janet is survived by her husband, Stanley, her daughters, Katherine Kane, Betsy Kane-Hartnett, and Priscilla Kane Hellweg, her sons-in law, Olin West, John Kane-Hartnett, and John Hellweg, her seven grandchildren, Meghan Kane-Hartnett, Jesse Kane-Hartnett, Liza Kane-Hartnett, Jonah Kane-West, Daniel Kane-West, Jasper Kane Hellweg, and Brendan Ellis Hellweg, her twin brother, George Haas, four pugs, and one ringed-necked parrot. Lively, brilliant, generous, irreverent, a pistol, a firecracker, a Scrabble player and a flirt, Janet Kane was above all else, a cherished wife, an adored mother, a prized grandmother, and a friend to all. She was the heart and soul of Sarasota and will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Forty Carrots Family Center, 1500 South Tuttle Avenue, Sarasota, FL 34239 or Sarasota Family YMCA Foundation, 1 South School Avenue, #

Cmdr. H. B. Le, the first Vietnamese-American to command a United States Navy destroyer, had just stepped ashore on a formal port call, making an emotional return to Vietnam for the first time since he fled as a young boy on a fishing boat at the end of the war in 1975. A youthful and smiling man of 39, he bore on his shoulders the weight of the symbolism of cautiously warming military ties between Vietnam and the United States in the visit over the weekend.

Three American hikers who were arrested in Iran this summer after straying across its border with Iraq have been accused of spying, an Iranian state news agency reported on Monday. The Tehran prosecutor told Iran's official IRNA news agency that the Iranian authorities were pursuing espionage charges against the Americans, who were detained in late July after trekking through the Kurdistan region of Iraq and toward the Iranian border. News of the spying accusations drew a quick rebuke from the White House and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, with each reiterating calls for the Iranians to release the hikers, Shane M. Bauer, 27, of Emeryville, Calif.; Joshua F. Fattal, 27, of Cottage Grove, Ore.; and Sarah E. Shourd, 31, of Oakland, Calif.

ST. JOHN--Judson, of Naples, FL died on November 4, 2009. Born in Fort Wayne, IN on August 26, 1926 to Lillian Hazel (nee Judson) and Harold St. John. Judson married Grace Burke Doremus on August 6, 1951. They shared a wonderful and full life together until Grace's death in January 2006. They lived in Grosse Pointe, MI, Chappaqua, NY and Villanova, PA. They moved to Naples in 1989 when Jud retired from American Home Products (now Wyeth soon to be part of Pfizer). Jud's entire professional career of 38 years was spent at American Home Products (AHP) where he ultimately rose to the President of Ayerst Laboratories, and later Wyeth-Ayerst. His career path at Ayerst included: Sales Representative from 1951-1955; District Manager from 1956-1962; Assistant Sales Manager from 1963-1970; Vice President of Operations from 1971-1976; Executive Vice President from 1977-1982; and President from 1983-1986. AHP later combined its two pharmaceutical divisions to form Wyeth-Ayerst in 1987. Jud was named President of the merged organization and held this role until his retirement in 1989. After graduating from Pontiac High School, Jud enlisted in the United States Navy and served from 1944 to 1946. Early duty took him from a medical clinic in northern Idaho to a troop transport ship in the South Pacific. His sense of naval service permeated his life and was manifest in his personal collection of nautical art. After his discharge from the Navy in 1946, he attended Kenyon College for two years as a Pre-Med student and later received a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Michigan in 1950. He was a competitive diver on the Kenyon swimming team and a proud member of Delta Kappa Epsilon. Jud's love of the outdoors was reflected in his hobbies swimming, hunting, fishing and golf. A passionate naturalist, he was a member of the Purple Martin Society and a lover of animals dogs in particular. He shared his 83 years with over six dogs. His fondness for swimming and diving, along with his early experience as a lifeguard at Pine Lake Country Club in Pontiac, certainly influenced his decision to enlist in the U.S. Navy. Later in life, his passion turned to golf and his memberships included Whippoorwill Country Club, Merion Golf Club and Eagle Creek Country Club (where he was a Founding Member and former President). He was also a member of the Oscoda Yacht Club and the Naples Yacht Club. Judson is survived by his son, Burke and daughter-in-law, Lisa St. John of Chappaqua, NY; grandchildren Jennifer, Luke, Burke, Jr. and Dylan; and brothers, Harold St. John and Richard St. John. A private memorial will be held in late November. Memorials may be made to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL 60018 (www.abta.org) in the name of Judson St. John. Those wishing to contact the family are invited to do so at www.fullerfuneralhome.com.

Which local station did fans tune in to watch the Yankees' victory parade on Friday? No surprise that it was WNYW-Channel 5, which capitalized on being the Fox affiliate that carried the World Series, even though its sister station WWOR-Channel 9 carries about 20 regular-season Yankees games. From 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., 358,500 viewers watched the parade on Channel 5, followed by WCBS-Channel 2 (264,800), WABC-Channel 7 (251,800), WNBC-Channel 4 (229,200) and WPIX-Channel 11 (107,500).

WASHINGTON -- Intelligence agencies intercepted communications last year and earlier this year between Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, who is accused of shooting to death 13 people at Fort Hood, Tex., and a radical cleric in Yemen known for his incendiary anti-American teachings. But federal authorities dropped an inquiry into the matter after deciding the messages warranted no further action, government officials said on Monday. Maj. Hasan's exchanges with Anwar al-Awlaki, once a spiritual leader at a mosque in suburban Virginia where Maj. Hasan worshipped, indicate that the troubled military psychiatrist came to the attention of the authorities long before long before last Thursday's shooting rampage at Fort Hood, but left him in his post. It is not clear what was said in the exchanges, believed to be e-mail messages, and whether they would have offered a hint at the major's outspoken views or his declining emotional state.

The Club for Growth PAC, an antitax organization with considerable financial resources, announced Monday that it was endorsing Marco Rubio in his Florida Republican primary battle with Gov. Charlie Crist for the United States Senate. The club, a conservative group, last week pounced on Mr. Crist's most recent statements that he was not really endorsing President Obama's $787 billion stimulus package when he appeared with the president last February and promoted the effort. The group immediately produced an advertisement against Mr. Crist, replaying the embrace between Mr. Obama and the governor at a rally.

8 P.M. (BBC America) JAMES MAY ON THE MOON Mr. May, above, a host of ''Top Gear,'' fulfills a childhood dream by heading into space with a little help from technology. He takes a virtual excursion in some of the most impressive space vehicles ever devised, and recreates test drives and training routines in an interstellar version of his automobile series. He also uses computer-graphic imaging to add himself to archival film footage, where he buckles up with Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, lands the Eagle, and takes his very own space walk. The astronauts Charlie Duke, Alan Bean and Harrison Schmitt recount their experiences as well. This presentation is the first of three new documentaries related to the 40th anniversary of the moon landing, in July 1969. 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. HEIDE--Peter van Berlo, of Ringoes, NJ passed away of pancreatic cancer on November 7th at the age of 71. He died at his home with his family by his side. Born in New York City on August 24th, 1938, he was the son of the late Andrew and Eleanor Heide. He is survived by his wife of 42 years Mollie Lamkin Heide. His is also survived by his children Dean Hutchinson Heide of Ringoes, NJ and Diana Heide Fredericks of Locust Valley, NY, four grandchildren, brother, Philip Edward Heide of New York, NY, and numerous nieces, nephews and family members. He graduated from Allen-Stevenson School, Portsmouth Abbey School and the University of Pennsylvania. Peter was Chairman of the Board, President and CEO of Henry Heide, Inc., a candy company best known for its Jujubes, Jujyfruits, Red Hot Dollars and Gummi Bears, that was founded in 1869 by his great grandfather Henry Heide. Peter was President and Treasurer of the Pennsylvania Manufacturing Confectioners' Association (PMCA), awarded Dean of the National Candy Wholesalers Association (NCWA), Financial Committee Member of St. Hubert's Animal Welfare Center, President of the Mid-Atlantic Flat-Coated Retriever Club, President, Treasurer and Show Chairman of the Plainfield Kennel Club, Treasurer and Board Member of Lenape Tracking Club, and did hundreds of hours of pet therapy at local hospitals and nursing homes. Peter was a parishioner at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton in Three Bridges, NJ. He will be greatly missed by many family members and friends. The memorial service will be held for Peter at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton in Three Bridges, NJ on Wednesday, November 11th at 11am. There will be a visitation at the church before the service at 9:30am.

The pioneering editor of the top Chinese business magazine has left her post with plans to start anew, after a tussle for control involving much the same mix of political and financial intrigue that she made her mark uncovering. The editor, Hu Shuli, 56, resigned Monday from Caijing, the magazine she built into a thriving print and Web outlet that specialized in investigating government corruption and corporate fraud, said a Caijing spokeswoman, Zhang Lihui. Senior editors and most of Caijing's journalists either had already resigned or were preparing to do so as well, magazine employees said.
