FEIGL--Rosemarie Eva, born in Vienna, Austria July 2, 1926, passed away at Lenox Hill Hospital November 5th after a short hospitalization. Rosemarie was brought to the U.S. in 1940 from France by the Unitarian Service Committee (USC) with 24 other children thought to be endangered by the Nazi occupation. USC was later able to help both of her parents immigrate to the U.S. Rosemarie was trained as an artist and worked as a muralist and commercial artist for NYC department stores for many years. Rosemarie leaves behind a close circle of loving friends, who will miss her wit, vivacity, charm and style. A memorial is being held Wednesday, November 11 at 2:15pm, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th.

HEYMAN--Samuel. The Board and the entire community of Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University are deeply saddened by the death of Samuel Heyman, who with his wife Ronnie, has been a friend and benefactor of the Law School for thirty years. Sam served as a member of the Board from 1980-1990, becoming an honorary member in 1991. Ronnie continues her leadership on the board as an honorary member, having served her initial term on the Board from 1991-2006. They co-founded the Samuel and Ronnie Heyman Center on Corporate Governance. Sam was boldly prescient in establishing a center of legal education focused on corporate governance and securities regulation, a program that continues to inspire the careers of both students and practitioners. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ronnie, to their children Larry (Cardozo '97) and Kimberly Heyman, Eleanor and Rodney Propp, Jennifer and David Millstone, and Elizabeth and David Winter; to his mother Annette; and to the Heyman and Feuerstein families. Iran will execute the Kurdish activist Ehsan Fattahian on Wednesday, Kurdish and opposition Web sites reported on Monday.

Iran will execute the Kurdish activist Ehsan Fatahian on Wednesday, Kurdish and opposition Web sites reported on Monday. Nassrollah Nasri, Mr. Fatahian's lawyer, told the independent Kurdish Mokrian news agency that his 23-year-old client was sentenced on charges of ''armed struggle against the regime'' and that he had been informed by the court to attend the execution by hanging on Wednesday.

GELLERT--Ellen, fantastic wife of Joe Gellert, loving mother to Stephen and Molly Gellert and loyal fan of the New York Mets, surpassed the Yankees '27 World Championships with her 30 consecutive "World's Best Mom" titles. She passed away while surrounded by her devoted family on Saturday, November 7, 2009 in her home in Chappaqua, New York. Ellen battled lung cancer for two and a half years in the same manner as she faced all aspects of her life: with grace, courage and a great sense of humor. She was born in Brooklyn on July 7, 1948 to Gabriel and Jeanne Gelber and grew up in Great Neck. She received her Master's in Education from NYU and made a difference in many students' lives as a tutor in Pleasantville, NY. Ellen was highly active in the Chappaqua community where she served as a president of the PTA and also helped establish and lead the Mitzvah Committee at Temple Beth El, a group which provided meals and support to congregants in mourning. She will be greatly missed by all and to quote Ellen, "Peace, love and have a ball." Services will be held at 10am on Tuesday, November 10 at Beecher Funeral Home located at 418 Bedford Road in Pleasantville. Burial will follow in Great Barrington, MA. The family will be sitting shiva starting Wednesday at their home in Chappaqua.

One of the highlights of Performa 09 is Joan Jonas's "Reading Dante II," which began its five-night run (with one matinee) at the Performing Garage Tuesday night. It amounts to a 60-minute multimedia collage in the round with moving parts and a smorgasbord of audio accompaniment. This includes music, loud crashes, traffic noises, and voices reading fragments of the work's inspiration: the Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso of Dante's "Divine Comedy."

The South African artist William Kentridge was part of a successful puppet troupe before he became known as a visual artist who explored the painful legacy of apartheid in tragic-comedic stop-action animations. His films unfold in vigorously hand-drawn charcoal scenes that mutate as we watch, with images often emerging from and disappearing into small cyclones of sooty black. A frequent character in these tales was Soho Eckstein, a wealthy, sometimes guilt-ridden Johannesburg businessman with an active fantasy life who bears a striking resemblance to the artist.

In his first full season in charge of the Los Angeles Galaxy, Bruce Arena led the club back to the playoffs in Major League Soccer for the first time in three seasons. Amid the hoopla and distractions that come with having a guy named David Beckham on the team, Arena's club won the Western Conference and is one game from playing for the league championship. For his efforts, Arena, who also coached the University of Virginia, D.C. United, the United States national team and the Red Bulls, was named the league's coach of the year on Wednesday. Arena also won the award in 1997 and joins Sigi Schmid (Los Angeles in 1999; Columbus in 2008) and Bob Bradley (Chicago in 1998 and Chivas USA in 2006) as a two-time winner.

The H1N1 pandemic is raising concerns about people reporting to work sick and spreading the disease. The pandemic has given momentum to Congressional efforts to enact legislation that would guarantee paid sick days to tens of millions of workers - although it is far from clear that such legislation will be enacted. Those legislative efforts received added momentum on Tuesday when the Obama administration backed the Healthy Families Act, which would guarantee seven sick days a year to workers in companies with 15 or more employees.

Prada addicts, rejoice: a 708-page catalogue raisonné of the nearly century-old brand has just been published. "Prada," which was designed by Michael Rock and Sung Joong Kim of the New York firm 2x4, was fast-tracked over six months and orchestrated as a magazine would be, Rock said, in almost "cinematic" fashion.The book is slipcased in Prada's signature navy with an embossed logo and is divided into sections like Past, Inside, Stage and Product that outline the company's creative output from fashion design to runway shows, including Brigitte Lacombe's black-and-white photographs of factory workers sewing, and lovingly cataloged swatches of fabrics and ensembles from seasons past. The Campaign section focuses on aspects like advertising, which, Rock explains, is the "mediating factor between the fashion house and the public." The Place, Scene, Outside and Prada+ sections highlight the company's architectural "epicenters" in New York and Los Angeles that were designed by Rem Koolhaas/OMA, its iconic building in Tokyo by Herzog & de Meuron and branding strategies that encompass sailing regattas, nightclubs, exhibitions and the art-centric Fondazione Prada. The book has been painstakingly translated into Italian, English, Chinese, Korean and Japanese, though Miuccia Prada exclaims that "fashion is instant language."

The Scotiabank Giller Prize, the annual Canadian literary award, was awarded to Linden McIntyre for his novel "The Bishop's Man." The novel, narrated by a priest who is charged with suppressing evidence of sexual abuse of children by other priests, was one of five finalists. Mr. McIntyre, a co-host of "The Fifth Estate," an investigative journalism program on CBT, received an award of about $48,000. The prize garnered a flurry of attention in September when Alice Munro, widely considered a likely nominee for her short-story collection, "Too Much Happiness," said she was withdrawing the book from consideration because she had previously won the prize twice and wanted to give younger writers a chance to win.

The executrix for an opera lover in Edinburgh who willed much of her fortune to the Metropolitan Opera confirmed reports about the extent of the gift: around $7.5 million (less 40 percent in taxes), according to a Met official. The executrix said she did not have a precise amount but said that accounts in British papers about the bequest, left by Mona Webster, who died last summer at 96, were accurate. The Met official, Gail Chesler, the director of planned and special gifts, said she had dinner with the executrix, a lawyer from Edinburgh who was in New York, before Tuesday's performance of "Turandot."

Update | 5:09 p.m. That shudder you felt through your computer keyboard was the Internet responding all at once to the news that "Dollhouse" has been canceled. The Hollywood Reporter said that Fox was shutting down the series, created by Joss Whedon (of "Buffy," "Angel" and "Firefly" fame) and starring Eliza Dushku as an enigmatic special agent whose memories and identity can be completely altered from mission to mission. The series suffered low ratings following its debut in February, but Fox unexpectedly picked up the series for its 2009-2010 season, and the show seemed to be building an online fan base. Fox had pulled the show for its November sweeps period, but the network said it would broadcast the remaining episodes it had ordered. In a message posted on the Web site whedonesque.com, Mr. Whedon wrote that he was proud of the show and the people who worked on it, adding: "I'm grateful that we got to put it on, and then come back and put it on again."

Club Monaco has long been known for its no-frills basics, like affordable boyfriend blazers and men's-wear-inspired button-downs. Perhaps realizing that savvy downtown girls have been wearing Tom Binns jewelry with tees and jeans, Club Monaco is introducing a jewelry collaboration with Ligia Dias, who designed baubles for Lanvin for three years before starting her own line in 2005. (Rei Kawakubo snagged her to embellish the knitwear for the fall 2006 Comme des Garçons collection.) The line for Club Monaco will consist of five pieces, combining the utilitarian with the refined - Dias mixed rope and brass with pearls and crystals. It is available at select Club Monaco stores and ranges in price from $149 to $399.

Long before Lady Gaga, Beyoncé or even Madge, there was Betty Davis. Not the smoky-eyed "All About Eve" star, but the preternaturally funky 1970s diva whose high-voltage performances could melt the black off tar. She was light years ahead of her leisure-suited contemporaries, who didn't get Davis's piercing growl, far-out fashions and sexually charged funk-acid rock amalgam. But now, with Light In the Attic Records releasing two of Davis's long-lost albums, "Nasty Gal" (1975) and "Is It Love or Desire" (1976), the time is right for us late adopters to catch up to this sassy soul sensation.

It's not just Hank Pryor who's out of a job -- Kelsey Grammer, who played that unemployed executive on the new sitcom "Hank," will once again be seeking work. ABC has canceled the show, The Hollywood Reporter said. The network said it would halt production on the series after work is completed on a 10th episode. Five episodes have been broadcast, and ABC has not yet announced its plans for the five remaining episodes it will have on hand. "Hank" is the second short-lived series for Mr. Grammer, who played the unctuous Dr. Frasier Crane for 20 years on "Cheers" and "Frasier". His sitcom "Back to You," on which he and Patricia Heaton played rival television news anchors, ran for one season on Fox in 2007-8.

It seems that with every fashion season there is a new 1980s moment - it's become as predictable as a catfight between the strong-shouldered demon ladies on "Dynasty." Having said that, an interesting '80s revival is happening on Abbot Kinney Boulevard, the nerve center for West L.A. style makers. Garrett Leight, a native of Venice, Calif., and the 25-year-old son of the Oliver Peoples eyewear founder Larry Leight, has started A. Kinney Court, a specialized eyewear gallery and boutique for men and women. The store's centerpiece is a rare assortment of vintage Oliver Peoples frames, dating as far back as 1987. Classic clip-on sunglasses, as well as the famous O'Malley frame (based on retro shades from the 1950s), will be showcased along with a revolving selection of other rare finds rediscovered by Larry and Garrett after carefully sifting through boxes in multiple storage units. The frames come with original blue, green and brown vintage tint lenses to complete the period-perfect look; Garrett will soon complete his optician's license exams to make sure his customers' vision is as sharp as their look. The store, which opened this week and is situated around a vast courtyard hangout, carries other design-minded optical lines like Mykita, Thierry Lasry and KBL Eyewear, as well as shoes and apparel for men and women from Becca Moon and LnA, a casual sportswear line. I'm feeling for it!

Olafur Eliasson, the Danish-Icelandic artist who created the temporary waterfalls in New York's East River last year, is at work on a project that will give the residents of another city a different way of looking at a nearby body of water. On Wednesday, the city of Copenhagen said that Mr. Eliasson would create a bridge there, called Cirkelbroen ("circle bridge"), which would provide a winding path across the city's Christianshavns Kanal. In a news release, Mr. Eliasson said the bridge, whose design was inspired by the sailing ships that pass through the canal, would consist of five circular platforms with their own "masts." In a statement, he said he hoped the bridge would "reduce speed" and "turn focus." "Rather than offering the fastest possible passage across the canal," Mr. Eliasson said, "the bridge will create small variations in the way we see the city and open for a renegotiation of public space." The bridge is being given as a gift to Copenhagen from the Nordea-foundation, which promotes healthy living and outdoor activities. It is expected to be completed in 2012 and cost about $6.8 million; Copenhagen is contributing about $1.5 million.

After much delay, the Iraqi Parliament finally passed a law on Sunday allowing for national parliamentary elections - the third since the American invasion in 2003. Voting is scheduled to take place in the second half of January.

J. Alexander, better known as Miss J on "America's Next Top Model," is a well-loved figure. We were in Savannah, Ga., together a few months ago for the SCAD graduation fashion show, and when we sat down at a quaint little ice cream parlor at least 10 people came up to our table, fumbling for cellphones to get a picture with the modeling coach diva. (He does not allow pictures taken with phones, only with cameras, thank you.) With the debut of his first book, "Follow the Model," we are sure all those fans will be eager to learn a bit more about the man who modeled in drag in Japan, loves cake and hates the word "fierce."

Over the years, France has given New York everything from the Statue of Liberty to Daniel Boulud, and now, in its latest act of trans-Atlantic generosity, it plans to lend the city a pair of dancers from the the Paris Opera Ballet. The New York City Ballet said that Aurélie Dupont and Mathias Heymann, both Étoiles with the Paris Opera Ballet, would perform at City Ballet's opening-night benefit. Ms. Dupont and Mr. Heymann (who are among the dancers featured in the Frederick Wiseman documentary "La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet") are to perform the "Rubies" pas de deux from George Balanchine's "Jewels." The other half of the bargain (struck by Brigitte Lefèvre, the dance director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet) is that Paris gets to borrow Ashley Bouder and Gonzalo Garcia, principal dancers from City Ballet, who will dance the leading roles in "Rubies" for the Paris Opera Ballet on Thursday at the Palais Garnier. The City Ballet benefit will take place on Nov. 24 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

Overview | Why do scientists seek evidence to support cause-and-effect relationships that seem obvious to the casual observer? What is the value of studying environmental problems in depth before acting to address them? How do public awareness and economic factors affect what actions are taken with regard to waste and pollution? In this lesson, students reflect on the Pacific garbage patch and recent scientific voyages to study the effects of plastic and other debris on water quality and oceanic life.

The Tate Gallery said on Wednesday that it had appointed Penelope Curtis the director of its Tate Britain museum in London. In a news release, the Tate said that Ms. Curtis, who has served since 1999 as the curator of the Henry Moore Institute in Leeds, earned a masters degree and a Ph.D. at the Courtauld Institute of Art in London, and has overseen the acquisition of many works for the institute's sculpture collection, including pieces by Rodin, Epstein and Calder. Dr. Curtis also served on the the British Council Committee for the Venice Biennale in 2008 and the Turner Prize Jury. Of the four museums in the Tate Gallery's network, the Tate Britain is the oldest, with an emphasis on both historic and contemporary British art.

A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles made two longtime associates of Michael Jackson the executors of the singer's estate on Tuesday, dismissing a challenge filed by Mr. Jackson's father, Joe, Reuters reported. Judge Mitchell Beckloff named the lawyer John G. Branca and the music executive John McClain the executors of the estate, which is expected to take in $200 million this year in revenues from the Jackson concert documentary "This Is It," as well as the accompanying soundtrack album and other business deals. Mr. Branca and Mr. McClain were already serving as the administrators of the estate. Joe Jackson had petitioned the court to say that it should set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to the one established for the singer's mother, Katherine Jackson, but the judge said he had no standing to challenge his son's will.

The Steelers' 28-10 win over the Broncos on Monday night was their 100th in the regular season since the start of the 2000 season. The Steelers are the third team to surpass the century mark in the 2000s, joining the Colts (109) and the Patriots (108), but they will probably not be the last. The Eagles, who have 97 wins, should reach the milestone. But Philadelphia will most likely be the only member of the group to emerge from the 2000s without a Super Bowl title. (They would join the Bills of the 1990s, who had 103 wins but no titles.)Most Wins by Decade

In an era of digital manipulation and trickery, documenting something with a photo is a lot more complicated than it seems. The “New Photography” exhibit at MoMA explores this to great effect, writes Karen Rosenberg, evoking “the kind of debates about gesture, process and intent that used to coalesce around painting.” You can get good and liquored up and argue tonight, when the museum is open late for its PopRally series. Andrew Kuo, digital artist extraordinaire, supplies the beats; photo booths will be installed; creative dress rewarded.

Prime Meats may not have a full dining room or menu yet; it may be cash-only, and its vintage-y bar may have no seats. But you will stand, and you will like it, because it’s still an excellent little spot, writes Sam Sifton, “a happy extension” of Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli’s mini-empire (Frankies 457 Spuntino, Frankies 17 Spuntino, et al). Go for the sautéed wild mushrooms with a poached Amish egg, the fine hamburger or quality steak, the cured meats, cabbage salads and excellent house-made pretzel. Order up a “crazy Prohibition cocktail ginned up by one of the mustachioed fellows behind the bar, some guy with absinthe in his eyes and a flaming goblet in front of him,” and soon enough you’ll find yourself chatting with the cook, David Colston, about hippos and Canadian Thanksgiving till 3 a.m. Or maybe that’s just us.

Several weeks ago, The Journal of the American Medical Association published a study that should give pause to anyone who plans to live a long and independent life. The study looked at the incidence of hip fractures among older Americans and the mortality rates associated with them. Although the number of hip fractures has declined in recent decades, the study found that the 12-month mortality rate associated with the injury still hovers at more than 20 percent, meaning that, in the year after fracturing a hip, about one in five people over age 65 will die.

Ulysses Grant, 63, is a retired postal worker. Named after his father, he lives alone in an apartment on the Hudson River in Ossining, N.Y., next door to Sing Sing Correctional Facility. Sharing the name of the 18th president hasn't been easy, he said, as an alumnus of 12 anger management classes. His pride in the name has grown over the years. However, he added, "When somebody says a joke about Ulysses Grant or 'Do you know who's buried in Grant's tomb,' I just fly off the handle."

An article on Saturday about the planned Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the status of advance ticket sales. While there has been no general advance sale, tickets are still available through Ticketmaster to holders of American Express cards; it is not the case that advance tickets are no longer being sold. An article in some editions on Friday about the distribution of the swine flu vaccine to some major New York companies even as shortages continue referred incompletely, based on information from the city health department, to the 27,400 doses requested by Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Those doses are meant for patients, workers and volunteers — not just workers.

A Congressional Memo article in some editions on Sunday about the race for Congress in the 23d District in New York misstated the circumstances of an endorsement in The Watertown Daily News. The paper’s decision to endorse the Democratic candidate, Bill Owens, after the Republican candidate, Assemblywoman Dede Scozzafava, withdrew was based solely on internal discussions, according to the editor, John B. Johnson Jr. He said the paper was not “pressed for the endorsement” by Democratic officials. (Mr. Johnson also noted that the decision had been made by the time Mr. Owens asked for the endorsement.).

An article on Monday about difficulties for Muslims serving in the American armed forces described incorrectly the background of Michael A. Monsoor, a member of the Navy Seals. Mr. Monsoor was a Christian of Lebanese and Irish descent, not a Muslim. The article also described incorrectly the act that earned him a Medal of Honor. It was for falling on a grenade and saving at least three team members — not for pulling a team member to safety. (Saving a team member in an earlier incident earned him a Silver Star.).

The street artist Shepard Fairey has won the right to a new lawyer in his suit against The Associated Press over the image that became his celebrated Barack Obama “Hope” poster. In a pretrial hearing Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Southern District Court of New York also ruled that lawyers for The A.P. can depose Mr. Fairey and his departing lawyers before the end of the year, The A.P. reported. The agency and the artist are suing each other over the rights to the image, a photo taken in April 2006 at an event at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Fairey recently admitted that he had lied publicly and to his lawyers about which image he had used, causing the lawyers to abandon his case. Mr. Fairey later added that he still believed his work fell under fair-use guidelines and did not infringe on The A.P.’s copyright, an assertion that his new lawyer, Geoffrey Stewart, supported, and that the agency rebutted.

The Broadway producers of “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps” have opened negotiations to move the quick-witted play to the Off Broadway theater New World Stages next year, according to the show’s lead producer, Bob Boyett. “The 39 Steps” is scheduled to close at the Helen Hayes on Broadway on Jan. 10 after almost three years. “We’ve just started to have a conversation with them, but no decision has been made,” Mr. Boyett said on Tuesday. “The decision to move is going to be based on what kind of business arrangement we can come to. We think the show still has life in it.” “The 39 Steps” has been playing lately to houses that are only about two-thirds full, but the lower running costs off Broadway could yield lower-priced tickets — and potentially more customers. ... In other news, the Roundabout Theater Company, the producers of “Wishful Drinking,” Carrie Fisher’s wry one-woman show about the perils of growing up famous (and famously hair-bunned), said the production has been extended. It will run through Jan. 17 at Studio 54. ... The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that it had entered into a five-year partnership with Egypt to help conserve and manage the tomb of Tutankhamen, above, in the Valley of the Kings, near Luxor, whose striking wall paintings have been pocked with brown spots at least since the tomb’s discovery in 1922. “King Tut has magic that we must conserve for future generations,” Zahi Hawass, secretary general of Egypt’s supreme council of antiquities, said in a statement. The first two years of the project will involve studying the condition of the tomb and examining the spots, whose nature and origin have never been determined. Then a conservation plan will be carried out and documented, along with a plan for long-term monitoring of the condition and maintenance of the entire tomb, including policies for regulating the number of visitors, said Tim Whalen, director of the conservation institute.

FORT HOOD, Tex.President Obama took on the role of national eulogist on Tuesday for the first time since assuming office as he led the country in mourning 13 active and retired soldiers gunned down not on a foreign battlefield but here on their home post by one of their own. Standing in front of 13 sets of boots, rifles, helmets and photographs, Mr. Obama vowed that the memory of those slain in a rampage here last week would ''endure through the life of our nation.'' One by one, he listed the names of those killed and described their hopes and dreams and the families they left behind.

Two surprises are in store for those who tune in to ''Return to Duty'' on Wednesday night on MTV. One is that this hourlong special, an offshoot of the somewhat mindless ''Real World'' reality series, might be the most affecting of the Veterans Day programs this week. The other is that Ryan Conklin, an impishly charming young man who made a big impression in ''The Real World: Brooklyn,'' is actually upstaged by his own parents.

When his car repair shop's health insurance premiums doubled between 2000 and 2002, David White saw the problem as akin to a sputtering engine. So he got under the hood of the state's health system and tried to fix it. Seven years later, Mr. White is on seven health advocacy and improvement boards, has helped devise the state's public insurance plan and has a library of health care books and research papers. He spent so much time on the issue that his business suffered. But he still has no health insurance for himself or his lone remaining mechanic, an experience that is emblematic of his state's.

It has come to this: Germany will almost certainly have a bigger budget deficit next year than Italy will. Traditionally, Germany is the Continent's keeper of fiscal rectitude, perpetually fretting that the Italians and other free-spending Southern Europeans are about to undermine the euro and rekindle inflation by not reducing their red ink.

A taste of turkey to start Thanksgiving is not overkill. The smoked turkey I used to prepare this classic spread tastes more of ham than bird. I simmered the meat and skin stripped from a drumstick in broth and poultry fat until the broth evaporated, then shredded the meat with the fat in a food processor. It was just like making duck or pork rillettes, except that the meat was already cooked. Smoked turkey is sold by some meat purveyors. But a plain roasted drumstick, bought prepared or leftover, will also do the trick.
Time: One hour plus 24 hours for drying bread

The Steelers' 28-10 win over Denver on Monday night was their 100th victory in the regular season since the start of the 2000 season. Pittsburgh is the third team to reach the century mark in the 2000s, joining the Colts (109) and the Patriots (108), but they will probably not be the last. The Eagles, who have 97 wins, should reach the milestone. But Philadelphia could be the only member of the group to emerge from the 2000s without a Super Bowl title. (The Eagles would join a club with the Buffalo Bills of the 1990s, who won 103 but didn't win a title.) ANDREW DAS

With fertilizer bombs now the most lethal weapons used against American and NATO soldiers in southern Afghanistan, the bomb-making operation in Kandahar was something close to astonishing. In a pair of raids on Sunday, Afghan police officers and American soldiers discovered a half-million pounds of ammonium nitrate, a fertilizer that is used in the overwhelming majority of homemade bombs here. About 2,000 bomb-making devices like timers and triggers were also found, and 15 Afghans were detained.

One North Korean sailor was killed and three others were wounded as North and South Korean naval vessels exchanged fire in disputed waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday, according to MBC, a South Korean television station. The South Korean defense minister, Kim Tae-young, left, told Parliament that he could not confirm the report of the casualties. The two Koreas accused each other of violating territorial waters, provoking the fierce two-minute skirmish that left one North Korean vessel engulfed in flames. It was the first border fighting in seven years between the countries.

(49) THE WAY WE GET BY For the last five years, a group of retired people have placed themselves on 24-hour call to volunteer as greeters for the more than 900,000 American troops who have passed through Bangor International Airport in Maine on their way to and from Iraq and Afghanistan. This ''P.O.V.'' presentation follows, above from left, Jerry Mundy, Joan Gaudet and Bill Knight, three of the Maine Troop Greeters (Ms. Gaudet is the mother of Aron Gaudet, the film's director) as they confront growing old and, by showing their respect for the soldiers' willingness to make sacrifices for the country, discover a new reason to live. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said, ''Neither pro- nor antiwar (unlike many cable-news ideologues, Mr. Gaudet and his subjects easily distinguish between the troops and their mission), this fine, affecting film perfectly exemplifies Milton's famous claim: 'They also serve who only stand and wait.' '' 4 P.M. (ABC); 7 P.M. (55) THE OPRAH WINFREY SHOW Charla Nash talks to Ms. Winfrey in the first interview she has given since being mauled and blinded by a 200-pound chimpanzee; also, an appearance by some heroic sergeants from the shooting at Fort Hood last week.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton are coalescing around a proposal to send 30,000 or more additional American troops to Afghanistan, but President Obama remains unsatisfied with answers he has gotten about how vigorously the governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan would help execute a new strategy, administration officials said Tuesday. Mr. Obama is to consider four final options in a meeting with his national security team on Wednesday, his press secretary, Robert Gibbs, told reporters. The options outline different troop levels, other officials said, but they also assume different goals -- including how much of Afghanistan the troops would seek to control -- and different time frames and expectations for the training of Afghan security forces.

Liberal interest groups in favor of overhauling the health care system are taking different tacks in trying to advance their goals, at least as far as advertising goes. MoveOn.org is spending $500,000 on television commercials to criticize Democrats who voted against the House bill on Saturday night. The targets include Jason Altmire of Pennsylvania and Heath Shuler of North Carolina, both of whose districts voted for John McCain for president in 2008. (MoveOn, though, is also planning some ''thank you'' events this week for House Democrats who did support the bill.)

The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he expected to bring major health care legislation to the floor next week and to complete work on the bill before Christmas. But other Democratic leaders said it was unlikely that a bill could reach President Obama's desk by year's end. The House approved its version of the health care legislation late Saturday by a vote of 220 to 215. In a first procedural step toward Senate debate, Mr. Reid on Tuesday night moved to put the House bill on the Senator calendar, from which he could call it up any time after Tuesday.

With the Federal Reserve under more intense attack than at any time in decades, Ben S. Bernanke, the professorial chairman of the central bank, was schooled last month in how to handle the increased political demands of his job. For months, he had warned -- without anyone on Capitol Hill appearing to listen -- that a seemingly innocuous bill to let Congress ''audit'' the Fed would gravely threaten the central bank's independence.

HEYMAN--Samuel. Harvard Law School mourns the passing of Samuel J. Heyman, outstanding corporate leader, and invaluable advisor and great friend of the Harvard Law School. His visionary belief in the need to inspire the nation's best and the brightest to pursue careers in the federal government led to his creation of the Law School's Heyman Fellowship Program on Government Service. We are honored that Sam's legacy will live on through the extraordinary work of the Harvard Law School Heyman Fellows and all others inspired by his call to service. We at the Harvard Law School will never forget his stellar role on the Dean's Advisory Board, the Executive Committee of our recent fund-raising campaign, and in the rejuvenation of our public service community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Ronnie, his mother, Annette, his children, Lazarus Heyman, Eleanor Propp, Jennifer Millstone HLS '05, Elizabeth Winter, son-in-law David Millstone HLS '05, his grandchildren, and the entire Heyman family. Martha Minow Dean, Jeremiah Smith Jr Prof Harvard Law School

An article last Wednesday about Sam Kass, the assistant White House chef who is closely involved with administration food policy and oversees the White House garden, referred imprecisely to the financing of the American Council on Science and Health, a consumer-education group that has criticized Mr. Kass for saying he would not use pesticides in the garden. The group is financed by various sources, including the food industry, foundations and private individuals; it is not solely financed by big food makers.

After the Cardinals beat the Bears, Arizona Coach Ken Whisenhunt humorously invoked memories of Dennis Green's 2006 ''The Bears are who we thought they were!'' tirade. He finished his news conference by saying, ''The last thing I'll say is, we didn't let them off the hook!'' He was right, although it almost seemed as if the Cardinals tried. After the second touchdown by Bears tight end Greg Olsen, Whisenhunt, enjoying a 34-14 lead, called on Matt Leinart to perform mop-up duties. On his fourth snap, Leinart's only official pass attempt resulted in an interception by Zack Bowman. Less than a minute later, Jay Cutler hit Olsen for a third score, making it a two-possession game with 9:04 remaining.

The sole House Republican to vote in favor of the health care legislation, Representative Anh Cao of Louisiana, said Tuesday in a telephone interview that he had been getting some ''pretty nasty responses.'' The House approved the health care bill late Saturday night on a vote of 220 to 215. Mr. Cao was the only one of 177 House Republicans to vote for it. Afterward, he said he had studied the legislation and concluded that voting for it was the best decision for his New Orleans district, traditionally a Democratic stronghold.

VETERANS DAY began as Armistice Day, to mark the end of World War I. Though the conflict occurred nearly a century ago, the Great War has always seemed vivid and immediate to me -- thanks to my grandmother. She was born in 1909 to poor peasants in Limana, a small town in the Italian Alps. When I was a child, my grandmother would tell me about how the Italians fought the Austro-Hungarians and the Germans there, and about the hardships she and her family endured. I heard her stories so many times that now it seems they're my own memories. Here is how I imagine them.

Out of timeouts, Eagles Coach Andy Reid watched helplessly Sunday night as the Cowboys ran out the clock with three running plays, one short pass and a series of kneel-downs. Reid's decision to kick a field goal with 4:33 left and the Eagles trailing by 7 was not necessarily a poor decision, said Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats, but he needed to follow up with an onside kick. ''Chances were very good they wouldn't get the ball back, particularly because the Cowboys are one of the league's top running teams this year,'' he wrote. ''You don't even need to do the math. To win the game, Reid had to assume his defense would force a three-and-out, so an unsuccessful onside kick wouldn't really hurt that much.'' (NYT)

A report in the Prescriptions column on Saturday about a drug-labeling provision in the Senate health committee's legislation on health care misidentified the senator who drafted the provision. Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island, wrote the measure, which would require the Food and Drug Administration to consider adding statistics about risks and benefits to drugs' labels. It was not drafted by Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland. (She helped add the measure to a section in the legislation involving health care quality.)

This Sunday's Times Magazine features a story by Pete Wells with a recipe for spicy caramel popcorn from Karen DeMasco's first book, "The Craft of Baking." I was eager to get my hands on it; DeMasco is one of New York City's most celebrated and talented pastry chefs. She baked at Fore Street in Portland, Me., at Chanterelle in Manhattan and then under Claudia Fleming at Gramercy Tavern. In 2001, she relocated a block south, where she shaped her baking style as Tom Colicchio's pastry chef at Craft, Craftbar and 'wichcraft. After a brief hiatus from the restaurant grind, she is back in it, this time as the pastry chef at Andrew Carmellini's Locanda Verde.

Children between the ages of six months and three years will no longer be eligible for the Nov. 22 swine flu vaccine at the Maplewood Town Hall, as officials had previously advertised. Only children four and older can get the shots, which have trace amounts of the preservative Thimerosal, said Robert Roe, the health officer. The shots still will be available for children ages 4 to 24, pregnant women and post partum women, adults ages 25 to 64 with long term health conditions that the flu can complicate, parents with children less than six months of age, and health care providers. Pregnant women will need to bring a physician note advising that vaccination is needed. Registration is required and starts Monday. Call 973-762-8120, ext. 4400 to register, and send a blank email to reminder@twp.maplewood.nj.us for future updates. The township has ordered vaccines for children aged 6 months through 3 years, and some pediatricians may have doses available, Mr. Roe said. --Tina Kelley

Last Sunday the Sculpture Center in Long Island City, Queens, was the site of Burning Man East, if you will. The artists Mike Kelley and Michael Smith showed videos of their visit to last summer's hippie rave fest in Black Rock Desert. The case most commonly made against allowing some prosthetics into able-bodied competitions holds that I lack an imagination. It's not hard to imagine, so this argument goes, that we could invent prostheses that would give the runner an advantage. Actually, it is. Unless we are adding energy artificially (robotics, engines, etc.), these prostheses replace what isn't there. There are ways to test whether they enable competitors to run or to run better than they otherwise might (the unilateral test subjects were chosen precisely because their one natural leg provided a control). When I was a kid, anyone who owned a Guinness Book of World Records will remember the arresting photo of the football player who lacked part of a foot and, with a shoe shaped like a brick, kicked the longest field goal in pro football history. After he won the world record, the league adjusted the rules to say that everybody, including amputees, had to kick with the same-shaped shoes. That seems fair.

Update | 3:49 p.m. Ten years ago to the day, the government reversed one of the key elements of the Depression-era banking laws, knocking down the firewall between commercial banks, which take deposits and make loans, and investment banks, which underwrite securities. The repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 was seen at the time as a way to help American banks grow larger and better compete on the world stage.

There is a movement afoot to organize domestic workers and improve their working conditions even as many face unemployment because of the weak economy. On Friday morning, people advocating better working conditions for such workers will gather at the 24th Street BART station for a march to the Women's Building on 18th Street. The march kicks off the West Coast Congress of the National Domestic Worker Alliance, to be held at Oakland's Laney College this weekend. Twenty-eight organizations will discuss how to better organize on national issues and get a domestic workers bill of rights passed in California's legislature.

If anyone can make Parisians stand up for good food, it's the bistro maestro Yves Camdeborde, whose new L'Avant Comptoir has been packed to the rafters since it opened a week ago. Just steps from the Odéon, this short, narrow, standing-room-only space with white tile walls, a broad pewter counter and an open kitchen is what Camdeborde calls an "hors d'oeuvres bar," and it serves up an array of delicious small-plate Basque- and Béarnais-inspired nibbles and carving boards of superb charcuterie along with a great selection of wines by the glass (Lapierre's luscious Morgon, great Côtes du Rhone, offbeat whites like UBY Colombard Ugni Blanc).

Overview | How do authors depict the experiences of soldiers returning home from war? How do these literary portraits mirror reality? In this lesson, students explore literary depictions of veterans and compare them to the lived experiences of soldiers. They then use recent Times war coverage to create found poems that comment on the theme of returning from war.

Mercury, the only metal element that is liquid at standard room temperature, is notoriously hard to handle - in more ways than one. Until 2003, automakers used highly toxic mercury in switches that controlled trunk and under-hood lights, as well as antilock brake systems. Since then, carmakers have switched to benign alternatives, but an estimated 38 million mercury switches still remain in cars.

If the N.H.L. general managers wind up asking for stricter rules regarding checks to the head when they make their recommendations to members of the N.H.L. competition committee this March, much of the credit for influencing them to change their longstanding opposition will ultimately go to someone outside the league: Ontario Hockey League Commissioner David Branch. The rules he has imposed and strictly enforced in his league -- penalizing all hits to the head, enforcing stern and consistent suspensions for flagrant violations of all safety-related rules -- created a climate that changed the conversation in Canada, opening the way for traditional fans to begin thinking about a game that tries to reduce catastrophic injuries and promote mutual respect among players on the ice. The N.H.L. G.M.'s resisted that stance for a long time, but on Wednesday in Toronto they showed for the first time a willingness to consider adopting some of the principles Branch has championed.

Founded in 1912 as a Farm Colony of Brooklyn State Hospital, the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens became, by mid-century, a world unto itself. At its peak, it housed some 7,000 patients. They tended gardens and raised livestock on the hospital's grounds. The hospital contained gymnasiums, a swimming pool, a theater, a television studio, and giant kitchens and laundries where patients were put to work.

Monki and Weekday, the sister stores that are Sweden's answer to Topshop and H&M, continue their march through Europe, most recently arriving in the German city of Hamburg, where the shops opened last week. Based in Stockholm, the company achieved international status with its Cheap Monday jeans - skintight numbers that the co-founder, Adam Friberg, says at first "no one liked and then they suddenly became really popular." That kind of intuition is what led Friberg and his business partner, Orjan Andersson, to Hamburg: they just like the city's odd mix of grit and wealth, its asymmetrical architecture and its flea-market subculture.

From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

A ruling by a Nevada district court judge will allow a Las Vegas area high school to perform student productions of "Rent" and "The Laramie Project," despite the objections of parents who were seeking an injunction to prevent them, The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported. Students at Green Valley High School in Henderson will be allowed to perform both shows, starting on Thursday with "The Laramie Project," after Judge David Wall ruled against parents who objected to the productions' content. Lawyers for the Clark County School District who represented the students said in arguments that the parents could not prove that performing the shows would cause "irreparable harm." Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada filed a brief that supported the students as well, arguing that an injunction would violate the students' right to free speech. Amanda Smith, a 16-year-old student who has a lead role in the "Rent" production planned for next year, told The Review-Journal, "I'm ecstatic."

Scientists sifting for trends in record high and low temperatures across the United States have found more evidence of long-term warming of the climate, with the biggest shift coming through a reduction in record low nighttime temperatures. That is a pattern long predicted by climate scientists using computer simulations. The researchers said they sifted data carefully to avoid possible distortion of trends related to changes in instruments or conditions at and around weather stations. The World Cup ski racing season resumes this weekend with men's and women's slalom races in Levi, Finland. After her 4-year-old daughter failed to catch a handmade porcelain doll she had tossed into the air, Marlene Hochman went on a mission to have it repaired, setting her on an unexpected journey into the world of playthings. Thirteen years and three books later, she runs New York City's only toy museum.

Reacting to the news Wednesday that Fox had canceled its science-fiction adventure series "Dollhouse," viewers went through an abrupt grieving process. First, denial (see various blog comments and Tweets that take the form of "NOOOOoooo!!!"); second, hurling favorite expletives at the Fox network; third, a kind of acceptance, as if they had known from the start that "Dollhouse" was destined for a short run.

When Dr. Marc Chamberlain, a Seattle oncologist, was treating his brain cancer patients, he noticed an alarming pattern. But a number of his female patients were going it alone, ending up separated or divorced after receiving a brain tumor diagnosis.

A recent New York Times article on GPS Apps for the iPhone apparently got the attention of TomTom, the Netherlands-based navigation company. According to a company spokesman, the article was forwarded to the Amsterdam-based team of engineers to draw their attention to, among other things, the inability of its stand-alone units to properly pronounce place names, and the frustration of having the iPhone app announce an intersection after one has already driven through it.

Attention dandies and wannabes: you can outfit yourself and your man-cave on Thursday, just in time for, um, Call of Duty season. FRONT PAGE.

An article on Tuesday about an effort to collect seeds to save species, possibly by relocating them through a process known as assisted migration, misstated the surname of the plant conservation program manager at the Bureau of Land Management. She is Peggy Olwell, not Orwell.
Former President George W. Bush is starting a new institute to promote his domestic and international priorities.

The Mind column on Oct. 6, about the ability of nonsense to sharpen the mind, reported findings from a flawed statistical analysis. The authors of a study that was described in the column reported that subjects who read a Kafka-inspired short story were more accurate in seeing hidden patterns than people who had read a more coherent short story. After a reader questioned the analysis, the researchers repeated the experiment and found no significant difference between the groups. (A similar experiment reported in the same paper, in the journal Psychological Science, did hold up to re-analysis.).
The price rose at breakneck speed at Sotheby’s auction of “200 One Dollar Bills” as collectors vied for the classic.

A picture caption on the Itineraries page on Nov. 3 with an article about travel management companies’ negotiating rates for the coming year referred incorrectly to the Peninsula Hotel in Shanghai. It is a new hotel; it is not newly renovated.

An article on Friday about the election defeat of New Jersey’s Democratic governor misspelled his surname at one point and misstated, in some copies, the number of political campaigns in which he spent more than $130 million of his own fortune. As noted elsewhere, he is Jon S. Corzine, not Cozine, and that sum was spent over three campaigns, not two — one for United States Senate in 2000, and two for governor, in 2005 and this year.

A Political Memo article on Saturday about the effect of last week’s elections on the health care debate in Congress misstated the middle initial for the Republican who is the governor-elect of Virginia. He is Robert F. McDonnell, not Robert H.

An article on Wednesday about plans by the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan to present an exhibition of art owned by one of its trustees, Dakis Joannou, referred imprecisely, in citing similar arrangements, to a collector whose old master drawings were exhibited by the Metropolitan Museum of Art this year. The collector, Jean Bonna, is an honorary trustee of the Met, not a trustee.

An article last Thursday about a possible severe shortage of seasonal flu vaccine in the United States misattributed an assertion that Bush administration officials pressed Congress for money to develop vaccine technology but never got as much as they sought. The comment was by Michael T. Osterholm, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota — not by William Hall, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services.

A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles named two longtime associates of Michael Jackson as executors of his estate on Tuesday, dismissing a challenge filed by Mr. Jackson’s father, Joe, Reuters reported. Judge Mitchell Beckloff named the lawyer John G. Branca and the music executive John McClain executors of the estate, which is expected to take in $200 million this year in revenues from the Jackson concert documentary “This Is It” as well as the accompanying soundtrack album and other business deals. Mr. Branca and Mr. McClain were already serving as administrators of the estate. Joe Jackson had petitioned the court to set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to one established for the singer’s mother, Katherine Jackson, but the judge said he had no standing to challenge his son’s will.
An app combines social-networking sites, texts, a phone log and local search services with your contacts so you can respond from one screen.

Carrie Underwood’s new album, “Play On” (19/Arista Nashville), easily reached the top of the Billboard chart this week, outselling Michael Jackson and new releases by Andrea Bocelli and Weezer. “Play On,” the third album for Ms. Underwood, below, and her second to reach No. 1, sold 318,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The soundtrack to “Michael Jackson’s This Is It” (Epic), last week’s best seller, was No. 2 with 196,000 sales, a 48 percent drop, and the rest of the Top 5 was all new: Mr. Bocelli’s “My Christmas” (Sugar/Decca) opened at No. 3 with 149,000 sales; the soundtrack to the Fox show “Glee” (Columbia) reached No. 4 with 113,000; and Vol. 32 of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” opened at No. 5 with 102,000. Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), released a year ago and recently rereleased with more songs, fell three spots to No. 6 with 70,000 sales, for total sales of just more than 4.2 million. Weezer’s latest album, “Raditude” (DGC/Interscope), opened at No. 7 with 66,000.

The shortest rift in rock music history has been healed as the estranged Aerosmith band mates Steven Tyler, far left, and Joe Perry, near left, reunited on Tuesday night, and Mr. Tyler said he was not leaving the group. Last week Mr. Perry, the band’s guitarist, said Mr. Tyler quit, after Mr. Tyler gave an interview to a British music magazine saying he was preparing to focus on a solo career. Mr. Perry went so far as to announce on his Twitter feed on Monday that Aerosmith was looking for a new lead singer. But on Tuesday night, the British music publication New Musical Express reported, Mr. Tyler made a surprise appearance at a performance by Mr. Perry’s band, the Joe Perry Project, at the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza. There Mr. Tyler told the crowd, “I just want New York — New York, I just want you to know I am not leaving Aerosmith,” before a performance of “Walk This Way” with Mr. Perry and his group.
The audience for ABC’s “V” on Tuesday fell substantially from its premiere a week ago, attracting 10.6 million viewers compared with 14.4 million for its debut.

Over the years France has given New York everything from the Statue of Liberty to Daniel Boulud, and now, in its latest act of trans-Atlantic generosity, it plans to lend the city two dancers from the Paris Opera Ballet. The New York City Ballet said Aurélie Dupont and Mathias Heymann will perform at City Ballet’s opening-night benefit on Nov. 24. Ms. Dupont and Mr. Heymann (who are among the dancers featured in the Frederick Wiseman documentary “La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet”) are to perform the “Rubies” pas de deux from George Balanchine’s “Jewels.” The other half of the bargain (struck by Brigitte Lefèvre, the dance director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet) is that Paris gets to borrow Ashley Bouder and Gonzalo Garcia from City Ballet, who will dance the leading roles in “Rubies” for the Paris Opera Ballet on Thursday at the Palais Garnier. The City Ballet benefit will take place at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

The Tate Gallery said on Wednesday that it had appointed Penelope Curtis the director of its Tate Britain museum in London. The Tate said Ms. Curtis has served since 1999 as curator of the Henry Moore Institute in Leeds and has overseen the acquisition of many works for the institute’s sculpture collection. Elsewhere, Artinfo reported that the Japanese architect Kazuyo Sejima was named director of the Venice Architecture Biennale for 2010. Ms. Sejima, who with Ryue Nishizawa founded the Tokyo architecture firm Sanaa, has helped design buildings including the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan. She will be the first woman to oversee the architecture biennale, which is to run from Aug. 29 to Nov. 21.

First things first: Jerry and Ann Moss, and Jess Jackson, deserve enormous credit for the success of Zenyatta and Rachel Alexandra. They campaigned each boldly and brilliantly, and thoroughbred racing was better for it this last year. In a perfect world, the two would share the horse of the year honors. It is not a perfect world, however, and forced to choose, one would have to say that the undefeated Zenyatta made the most compelling case for being named the best horse of 2009.

It's not surprising that the health care legislation that the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy spent years fighting for has become a large issue in the campaign for his Senate seat. The unexpected part is that two candidates are fighting about whether or not to support the legislation. The Massachusetts attorney general, Martha Coakley, the current front-runner, said she opposed the health care bill that the House approved last weekend, because it contains an amendment prohibiting federal health care plans from covering abortions.

Cherished grandfather of Andy Tepper and Reuel and Wilder Daniels. A true renaissance man and avid skier. Services Friday, 12 noon at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Amid kidnappings and war rhetoric in Venezuela, the Mets may recommend that the catching prospect Josh Thole return home from his winter league team there. On Tuesday, the former Mets pitcher Victor Zambrano's mother, 56-year-old Elizabeth Mendez Zambrano, was rescued in a commando-style raid after being kidnapped Sunday from her home at her son's farm in Aragua. She is one of several relatives of baseball players who have been kidnapped for ransom in Venezuela in recent years.

LEVINE--Robert Sheldon, industrial designer, architect and astrophysicist of Manhattan, NY passed away on November 10th at the age of 85. Born in the Bronx on February 28, 1924, he was the son of the late Murray and Sylvia D. Levine. He is survived by his loving daughters Susan Levine-Chien, Pam Levine-Umans, Nina Levine and their husbands, Bruce, Marty and Simon. In addition, his three grandchildren Sarah, Abby and Cody and his sister Bette Israel-Kantor of North Carolina survive him. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel in New York City at 6:30pm on Thursday, November 12th. Shiva will take place at the Umans-Levine home in Brooklyn on Friday from noon-4pm and Sunday from noon-6pm.

NATHAN--Ira. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, deeply mourns the loss of this sweet, funny, sensitive, soft brown-eyed, two time Ph.D. Our love to his Rhoda, their three sons and families. Services Friday at Noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel.

The United States ambassador to Afghanistan, who once served as the top American military commander there, has expressed in writing his reservations about deploying additional troops to the country, three senior American officials said Wednesday. The position of the ambassador, Karl W. Eikenberry, a retired lieutenant general, puts him in stark opposition to the current American and NATO commander in Afghanistan, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who has asked for 40,000 more troops.

Funeral services Friday, November 13, 11am, Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 91st St.

I love my family and my family comes first, and my family means more than anything to me, but it hasn't been that way for me. PAUL BACHMUTH, an unemployed father of two. [A1]

Okinawans like Zenji Shimada, who have spent most of their lives under the thudding of helicopters from a busy American air base, are accustomed to disappointment. Decades of complaints about the base here and others on the island have gone largely unheeded, and a painstakingly negotiated plan to move the Marines from populated areas remains years from completion. This summer was no different. Hopes stirred by the election of a new Democratic Party government were quickly dashed after members of the administration of the incoming prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, backed away from the party's pre-election promises to move the base off the island.

LEISER--Burton M. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Burton M. Leiser, a National Commissioner and Vice-Chair of ADL's New York Regional Board. We will miss his sound counsel and leadership. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Janet, daughter Illana and the entire family. Robert G. Sugarman, National Chair Abraham H. Foxman, National Director Jeffrey M. Parker, NY Regional Board Chair Ron Meier, NY Regional Director

7:30 P.M. (SNY) METS YEARBOOK SportsNet New York turns back the clock to 1971 -- when Ralph Kiner could be found giving Ken Singleton hitting tips at Al Lang Field in St. Petersburg, Fla., and Satchel Paige pitched at an old-timers' game -- in the first of 27 recently unearthed half-hour films from 1962 to 1988 starring the New York Mets. Some of the vintage installments were created for television; others were intended as marketing tools to be shown at schools, churches and scout meetings. Highlights in this inaugural season include footage of Shea Stadium under construction and the final walk to the center-field clubhouse at the Polo Grounds by Casey Stengel, above, as well as interviews with Joan Whitney Payson, a founder and majority owner of the Mets, and the broadcasters Lindsey Nelson and Bob Murphy. A new round of ''Mets Hot Stove,'' at 7, serves up news and rumors surrounding the team. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The arrival of the Christmas tree at Rockefeller center.

WINGATE--William A.,at the age of 82, on November 11, after a battle with cancer, a longtime resident of Ocean Beach, Fire Island and Manhattan, husband to the late Adele and late Sondra. He is survived by a dear friend and companion, Judy Levy, his daughter Leslie Markert, daughter and son-in-law Jeri and Peter Licht, stepdaughter Susan Abrams, three grandchildren (Alyssa, Evan and Daniel), and great-grandson Will. A practicing attorney for more than 50 years (Wingate, Russotti & Shapiro), he also spent his time serving four terms as a Trustee of the Village of Ocean Beach on Fire Island. His loyalty, warmth and easy smile will be missed by his many friends and associates. Funeral services Friday, November 13 at 9:30am at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Shiva will be observed at the home of his daughter Jeri Licht. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the International FOP Association at www.ifopa.org.

Abortion will not be the only social issue dividing Congress as it seeks to construct a compromise health care bill capable of passing both houses. The bill the House passed on Saturday also sets up a confrontation with the Senate over how much access illegal immigrants should have to public resources. In this case, the public resource is a government-run health insurance exchange, or marketplace, intended to give consumers more affordable coverage by letting them comparison shop.

When President Obamadelivered a rare and public call last week for President Hamid Karzai to crack down on corruption in Afghanistan, there was one glaring omission from his remarks -- an ''or else.'' Mr. Obama's exclusion of the obvious threat -- that he will pull American troops out of Afghanistan if Mr. Karzai does not comply -- reflects a stark conundrum: How much leverage does the United States really have over the Afghan leader?

AS the long-reigning diva of ''Guiding Light,'' the soap opera whose 57-year run on television ended in September, Kim Zimmer found herself so busy that she could seldom browse her favorite stores. But while contemplating the future and planning a book on her life as a soap star, she now has time on her hands -- and a new apartment to furnish. Ms. Zimmer had played the tempestuous Reva Shayne Lewis since 1983, with one five-year break, while nesting more conventionally with her husband, the director A. C. Weary, and their three children in Montclair, N.J.

FRAGILE camera gear demands ample protection, particularly when shooting pictures outside. ''Cameras today and lenses are expensive investments,'' said Brian Markman, sales manager of the pro photo division of B & H, a large photographic equipment store in New York. ''You're not going to put it into a regular backpack or a sports bag.''

With signs that the effort to fill the two new high-profile positions at the European Union is in trouble, the bloc's leader, Fredrik Reinfeldt, issued a new message on Wednesday to his colleagues in hopes of breaking the deadlock. Mr. Reinfeldt, the prime minister of Sweden, which holds the current rotating presidency of the bloc, warned its 26 other leaders that they would be asked to back specific candidates at a special meeting he called for next Thursday. The Lisbon Treaty, which received final approval this month, creates a permanent president and increases the powers of the union's foreign policy chief. Previously, most decisions on top union jobs were made under rules that allowed any nation to block an appointment. That right disappears under the treaty.

No game this year will be more controversial and more easily misrepresented than Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. That is because it revolves around the most provocative, forcefully uncomfortable and emotionally disturbing scene yet built into interactive entertainment. Rather than survey the battlefield from a clinical distance, the game thrusts the player into the harrowing experience of modern terrorism. Yet, as each generation learns to its own horror, organized killing is in reality forcefully uncomfortable and emotionally disturbing. Modern Warfare 2 -- unflinching yet empathetic -- reflects that more clearly than perhaps any other game.

Graveside services Friday, November 13, 2009, 10am at the Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be directed to "The National Magazine."

MINOR--Emily Chadbourne, 94, died October 30 in Rye, NY. Survived by her son John and daughters Kathleen, Jane and Caroline, 14 grandchildren, 23 great-grandchildren. Service at Christ's Church Rye, NY, December 3, 11am.

The N.C.A.A. has joined a growing trend of sports organizations trying to find an answer for evaporating news media coverage of its events, contracting with a new business called Sports Media Exchange to generate stories to run on NCAA.com. The deal will kick off this weekend, with coverage of the N.C.A.A. field hockey championships, the kind of event that would draw little coverage. Sports Media Exchange, launched four months ago by three former newspaper sportswriters, draws from its database of about 250 freelance writers to cover events.

The horse of the year contest between Rachel Alexandra and Zenyatta can be reduced to basic math: Rachel Alexandra won three prestigious races against the boys in 2009, and Zenyatta won one. End of debate. Because the top horses do not run frequently or stick around very long these days, horse racing generally suffers from a lack of great moments. But Rachel Alexandra provided three of them this spring and summer. And a fourth, if you want to include her astonishing 20-length victory against fillies in the Kentucky Oaks.

HEYMAN--Samuel J. Sam was gifted with intellect and acumen. He used his brilliant mind and abundance of energy to improve the lives of many. Together, Sam and Ronnie sought solutions to problems and inspired others to contribute to the solutions. No challenge was too great. It was on challenge that he thrived. To Ronnie, to Mrs. Annette Heyman, and to the children, Larry, Eleanor, Jennifer and Elizabeth and to the Heyman family we extend our deepest sympathy. May Sam's memory inspire each of us to a more noble life. We mourn the passing of a friend with a soft manner and winning smile. American Friends of the Open University of Israel Ingeborg Rennert, President Baron Robert de Rothschild, Honorary Chairman Malcolm Thomson, Chairman

HEYMAN--Samuel. We mourn the shocking and untimely death of our dear friend Sam Heyman. A brilliant and kind man, he had a loving and generous heart, and an unwavering dedication to his precious family. We will miss his warm friendship, his lightness of spirit, his easy smile, and his embrace of life. Our thoughts and prayers are with Ronnie and the family. Linda and Arthur Carter

For the first time since the armistice that ended World War I with Germany's defeat in 1918, a German leader joined French officials here to mark the moment the guns fell silent on the Western Front after a war that killed millions. The German chancellor, Angela Merkel, and the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, laid a wreath on Wednesday at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier under the Arc de Triomphe in central Paris, erected in 1835 to honor the army of Napoleon.

O'CONNOR--James L.,88, of Jupiter, Florida, died November 9, 2009. He was born in Chicago, Illinois on August 24, 1921 to Leon P. and Marguerite McMahon O'Connor. He was a member of the Class of 1942 at the College of the Holy Cross, from which he withdrew in January 1942 to join the Army Air Corps. He flew 50 combat missions as a B-24 pilot in the Pacific theater. A 1949 graduate of Columbia Law School, Mr. O'Connor spent several years as a commercial litigator in New York City. In 1966, he moved to Weston, Massachusetts to become General Counsel of Ludlow Corporation. In 1978, he moved to Palm Beach County Florida and founded The Storage Place Ltd. Mr. O'Connor is predeceased by his wife Prudence and son James. He is survived by Prudence and Jeffrey Neubert of Norwalk, Connecticut, Andrew and Kelly O'Connor of Leawood, Kansas, Maureen O'Connor of Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, Florida, nine grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.
LERMAN--Omar. We cherished you Omar. All sympathy to Molly and Dion. Rhoda and Play It By Ear

AYVAZIAN--Dr. Levon Fred, died peacefully at home in Northampton, MA on Tuesday, November 3, 2009. He was born in Ordu, Turkey on October 3, 1919, the son of Dr. Haig Ayvazian and Shnorhig Ayvazian. He was graduated from Stuyvesant HS, Columbia University and NYU Medical School. He served during the Korean War as a Captain at the Fitzsimmons Army Hospital. From 1961 to 1971, Dr. Ayvazian was Medical Director of the Will Rogers Hospital in Saranac Lake, NY. He also ran the Pulmonary Services at both the Manhattan and East Orange VA Hospitals. Fred was the author of three novels and scores of medical articles, book reviews, essays, and poems. He also drew and painted. Dr. Ayvazian leaves his wife of 62 years, Gloria Bedikian Ayvazian, three daughters: Leslie, Andrea and Gina; their partners Sam, Michael and Marcelle; and two grandsons: Ivan and Sasha. A memorial service to celebrate Fred Ayvazian's life will be held on December 5th. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that his life be honored through donations to the Haydenville Congregational Church, UCC, Box 257, Haydenville, MA 01039.

After meeting for 90 minutes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France announced in a joint statement on Wednesday evening that they had agreed to work toward ''immediately reviving the peace process'' in the Middle East and discussed international efforts to stop Iran from enriching uranium. Mr. Sarkozy, a strong supporter of Israel who has sharply criticized Iran's nuclear program, has regularly demanded that Israel freeze all settlement activity in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem, a step the Palestinians now say is their requirement for renewing talks on a final peace settlement.

CRUMM--Anne T.,85, died peacefully, October 24, with family in attendance in Rye, NY. Her husband, Charles Crumm, predeceased her 13 years ago on Martha's Vineyard where they retired in 1988. Anne, raised in Scarsdale, NY, graduated from Smith Collage in 1945. She lived a full and energetic life working 30 years in Architectural Design. She had a deep appreciation of literature, painting, music, cooking and loved those Jack Russells. Anne and Charlie loved entertaining; their home was open to all. She will be missed. Anne is survived by her children, Peter of Revere, MA; Nick of Larchmont, NY; Chad, of Ithaca, NY; Nina of Brisbane, Australia, two grandchildren, Sam and Olivia. Her sister Nancy lives in Southbury, CT, her brother Alan in Pittsford, NY. A service will be held on Martha's Vineyard.

GREENMAN--Roger, born December 11, 1946, died November 6, 2009. For the past four decades, he worked in the private and public sectors as a technology and business consultant. He was preceded in death by his parents, Philip and Evelyn Greenman and is survived by sister, Linda Greenman. Funeral services will be held at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, New York, today at 10am.

SIEGEL--Irene L.,on November 10, died very peacefully. Beloved wife of the late Norman Siegel. She is survived by her beloved son Marshall and his wife AnnMarie, her daughter Susan, her brother Dr. Solomon Lanster, and grandchildren Victoria, Naomi and Akiva Reuveni. She was much loved and will be greatly missed. Services 11:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, corner Amsterdam Ave. and West 91st St.
WEITZMAN--Charles. Deepest condolences to Elaine and her treasured family. Charles was their hero. Estelle Cohen and Family

LERMAN--Omar K.,of Manhattan and Cape May Point, died peacefully at 82 after a long illness. Seabee, arts administrator, pyrotechnician, stargazer, wise elder, beachbum, friend to the world, beloved husband of Mollie Falk, father of Dion Lerman, brother of Leonard Lerman. You were our sunshine.

Ballots for horse of the year are taken from 282 voters from three categories -- racing secretaries and chart-callers, Daily Racing Form writers and members of the National Turf Writers Association. Voters rank the top three horses, with 10 points for first, 5 points for second and 1 point for third. These ballots establish the top three finalists and the winner, announced in January, is determined by first-place votes only.

LOS ANGELES - Petit-point embroidery plays an important part in the artistic career of Francesco Vezzoli: his best-known works are serigraphs in which details of the images are hand-stitched in shocking colors. His big media debut was presenting Veruschka and himself embroidering in a three-day performance at the Venice Biennale many years ago.

Update | Saturday | 2:35 p.m. ET Egyptian Win to Keep Hopes Alive for World Cup 2010. A remarkable last-minute goal for Egypt in Cairo, scored by Emad Moteab, gave the hosts the 2-0 victory they needed to stay in contention for a spot in next summer's World Cup. Egypt and Algeria end the qualifying period tied and will now face off in a one game playoff at a neutral venue (in Sudan) on Wednesday, to decide which country will go to the World Cup. The goal came in the fifth minute of added time, just seconds before the match was due to end.
"Ask an Expert" is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you'll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

For those of you itching to see a top team in action, you won't have to wait for Saturday. Undefeated Cincinnati takes the field Friday night against West Virginia, hoping that its high-scoring ways will be enough to topple the Mountaineers. The marquee game of the weekend comes from the Mountain West, where unbeaten Texas Christian takes on Utah, which was the lone undefeated team at the end of last season. Will the Horned Frogs be able to make that claim this season? Elsewhere, Iowa travels to Ohio State for a game that could decide Big Ten supremacy, Notre Dame tries to bounce back from a loss when it faces surging Pittsburgh and Arizona takes on California in a pivotal game in the suddenly wild Pac-10. Our prognosticators have made their choices. If you agree, disagree or just feel the picks are laughable, feel free to chime in.

In this Sunday's Caribbean issue, Matt Gross, who writes the weekly Frugal Traveler blog for The New York Times, sails the Caribbean on a shoestring budget. Without a boat to call his own or a budget to hire a yacht, he joins the crew of a 75-foot, two-masted schooner for a two-week immersion in the sailing world. For $55 a day, he learns the ropes, swims with sea turtles and, when all goes right, sleeps under the stars.

On Dot Earth, reader comments that are particularly intriguing or illuminating have sporadically been brought "out front" to this space for a fuller airing. As I wrote earlier today, that process will now become a regular feature, Your Dot, used to focus the discourse on constructive commentary by readers who prefer to stand publicly behind what they say. I'm not endorsing the views expressed in these comments, and hope they will reflect a wide range of stances. Also, the full range of views and levels of anonymity will persist in the standard comment threads.

I'm thinking about a trip to Central America next month, perhaps Nicaragua and Honduras and I don't know where else. I don't know the terrain and would welcome suggestions for columns. As always, I'm looking for a micro example of a macro problem. For example, I'm unlikely to write about Nicaragua as such, but might use a program in Nicaragua to illuminate a global development problem. If you have suggestions, post them below -- and thanks.

Well, Charles, your idea that the eagle is meant to be a toy did not occur to me and is intriguing. I thought that the toy-like look of the mechanical eagle was a pitiable image. It made the prisoners seem like eager children who manage not to fight over a toy because it is so wondrous and special. This, for me, is what prevented the moment from being sentimental.

Guys, I'd be curious to discuss the eagle. I may be being a bit literal-minded here, but it seemed to me the creature was so obviously mechanical that it was actually meant to be a toy rather than a living thing. Obviously this could just be a matter of stylization - you can't put a live bird onstage in an opera, let alone coach him to act wounded.

On Thursday, Time magazine published a package on its Web site that attempted to handicap the nation's "10 Best College Presidents.'' In response to our post on that feature -- in which we gingerly raised the question of how one could possibly establish an objective ranking of college presidents -- nearly 100 readers of The Choice submitted comments. Most of you sent nominations of your own, and others mirrored our skepticism about the value of such a list.
