Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the navy, "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart" will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night, the satirical news show is scheduled to host Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Comedy Central announced the booking Friday in a news release. It's the first time that Mr. Biden has appeared on "The Daily Show" since he was elected vice president; he previously appeared on the show as a senator and presidential candidate on Aug. 8, 2007, and on Jan. 31, 2007, the day that Mr. Biden announced he was seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. Barack Obama last appeared on the show on Oct. 29, 2008, before winning the presidential election.

Read it (and check out his other posts) at Politics of the Plate.

There are hints that Japan's review of government spending in a number of areas could diminish the billions of yen spent each year to sustain the country's annual whaling excursions to the oceans around Antarctica. Greenpeace sent an alert around about the budget review just before President Obama flew to Japan. For the moment, it's unclear whether the whaling program -- which Japan has long cast as important scientific research but many biologists and activists decry -- is in danger, according to our Tokyo reporters. There'll be updates here as needed. [UPDATE, 11/19: This year's hunt got under way as the fleet headed south. Presumably the chasers below are gearing up, as well.]

Gustavo Dudamel has received a blast of publicity like few others in classical music in the past several years. He rode into Los Angeles as its orchestra's music director last month on a wave of media and public relations hoopla. Mr. Dudamel, of course, is not the first classical musician to capture mainstream - read populist - attention. Yo-Yo Ma and Renee Fleming are exemplars now. Before them, we had Beverly Sills and Leonard Bernstein. Before them, John McCormack and Enrico Caruso. Before them, the castratos of Italy and superstar opera composers of the Viennese and Italian courts.

The fabled crossroads where Robert Johnson is supposed to have sold his soul to the devil in exchange for his guitar prowess has not been definitively located, but the musician's birthplace has been determined and plans are in the works to restore it as a tourist attraction, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Johnson, the blues guitarist of "Sweet Home Chicago" and "Love in Vain," who influenced artists from Muddy Waters to Eric Clapton, was born in 1911 in Hazlehurst, Miss., in a home built by his stepfather. The birthplace was verified in a letter from his half-sister, according to the cultural affairs office of Copiah County, which is seeking to raise $250,000 to restore the home as a destination for music fans and Johnson acolytes. "He was so good that he would literally turn his back when they were recording him," said the screenwriter Jimmy White ("Ray"), who is working on a script about Mr. Johnson's life. "He didn't want the other musicians to see his fingering technique."

This weekend's cover story, "Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way," has been a long time coming-three years, to be exact. Back in September 2006 I visited Jost Van Dyke, a tiny island in the British Virgin Islands, for another Frugal Traveler story, and it was there, while staying on White Bay, that I met a Florida family of four who'd rented a sailboat and invited myself and a friend aboard for gin and tonics. Impressed by both their generosity and their freedom-with the boat, they could go wherever they liked, whenever they wanted!-I began to try to figure out how I, a non-sailor without sailboat-rental funds, could live their luxurious lifestyle.
Updated Could the conservative candidate who conceded on election night in one of the country's most intensely watched races really still squeak to victory?

Holiday decorations seem to go up earlier every year, but in this case we don't mind: the shopping blog Racked NY reports that as of Friday morning, Barneys has filled its windows with papier-mâché effigies of characters and cast members from "Saturday Night Live." The display spans the 35-year history of that late-night show: we spotted versions of Roseanne Roseannadanna; King Tut; the Coneheads; Brian Fellows; Amy Poehler grasping the Weekend Update globe; the androgynous, long-forgotten Pat; and even Gilly, the badly behaved grade school student played by Kristen Wiig. (We couldn't find Toonces the Driving Cat, but we haven't been there ourselves.)

Maialino, the Roman-style trattoria that is the first collaboration between two restaurant-world titans - the restaurateur Danny Meyer and the designer David Rockwell - opened this week at Ian Schrager's Gramercy Park Hotel. T asked Meyer a few questions about the eagerly awaited project.

Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund executive accused of participating in a massive insider trading scheme, moved on Thursday to unseal a 2000 criminal case against the woman who admitted to giving him confidential information about a number of companies. (Read the motion after the jump.)

Like the start of a classic gaming cheat code, it was an up-and-down week of news for the video gaming business. On the upside, the debut of the highly anticipated shooting game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 set a sales record for the industry, Variety reported: the game sold 4.7 million units in its first day of sale in the United States and Britain, taking in $310 million for the game publisher Activision Blizzard. (By comparison, the year's highest grossing movie, "Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen," earned $220 million in its first weekend.)

A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Craig, was stepping down from his post as the White House counsel, a departure that was timed to coordinate with a Justice Department announcement that five terrorism suspects held in Guantánamo Bay would face trial in New York.

Last week, small-business advocates once more tried, and failed, to get new consumer protections for credit cards extended to small-business cardholders. For the dozens of television scripts he wrote, David Lloyd is best remembered for a single episode of "The Mary Tyler Moore Show" called "Chuckles Bites the Dust.".

In Friday's New York Times, Bruce Weber writes an obituary of David Lloyd, an incredibly prolific television comedy writer who contributed to programs like "The Bob Newhart Show," "Lou Grant," "Rhoda," "Phyllis," "The Tony Randall Show," "The Associates," "Taxi," "Dear John," "Amen," "Wings," "Cheers" and "Frasier." Mr. Lloyd, 75, died of prostate cancer on Tuesday.

So now we're working on the assumption that the future -- or at least the glimpse of it that everyone received in their flashforwards -- can be changed, even negated. That's the lesson people are taking from Agent Gough's swan dive off a building at the end of last week's episode of "FlashForward." If it's true, does this new wrinkle make the show better -- more complex and open-ended? Or does it drain the show of much of its dramatic tension and make the detective work, which has been more interesting than any of the relationships, seem irrelevant? Just asking.

The first review A.O. Scott wrote as a film critic for The New York Times was in January 2000. The movie was "My Dog Skip," which featured a Jack Russell terrier with a taste for bologna, Kevin Bacon, Luke Wilson and Frankie Muniz. Since then, he notes, more than 5,000 movies have come and gone and been reviewed in The Times. In The Magazine this week, Mr. Scott takes stock of the past decade in film and asks: "Which movies are sure to be remembered? Which movies deserve to be? Are these really two different questions?"

Part D.I.Y. and part pro, the Slideluck Potshow offers photographers — many of them highly paid professionals — a chance to show the stuff they love in another context: at a potluck party. Bring a dish, grab a drink and watch the images float by tonight.

The Numero Group is a Chicago-based label that reissues obscure, unusual recordings, scoured from thrift stores and garage sales. Tonight at the Music Hall of Williamsburg they present their debut tour, the Eccentric Soul Revue, with artists including 1970s Midwestern R&B crooners and an early-period, female hip-hop M.C. from Harlem. For more retro sounds, hit the 35th anniversary party for Afrika Bambaataa on Sunday at SOB’s, with performances by Naughty by Nature and Grand Master Melle Mel.

Catch two movies this weekend that are more than what they seem. Though it’s beyond cute, Wes Anderson’s “Fantastic Mr. Fox” is not just a kid flick; it “is in some ways his most fully realized and satisfying film,” A.O. Scott writes. “Once you adjust to its stop-and-start rhythms and its scruffy looks, you can appreciate its wit, its beauty and the sly gravity of its emotional undercurrents.” And “The Messenger” is more than just an Iraq War movie; it is “remarkably textured, with room for humor as well as anguish,” Mr. Scott writes.

A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about Gene D. Cohen, a pioneer in the field of geriatric psychiatry, gave the incorrect year in some editions that Dr. Cohen was shown with a patient. It was 1990, not 1960.

An obituary on Thursday about John J. O’Connor III, the husband of the retired Supreme Court justice Sandra Day O’Connor, misstated the title that William H. Rehnquist held on the court. He was chief justice of the United States, not chief justice of the Supreme Court. The obituary also misidentified the publication that was the source of a story about the O’Connors’ early days in Washington. It is The National Law Journal, not The National Law Review.
The evening sale of contemporary art at Phillips de Pury brought a vibrant week of auctions to an anemic close on Thursday night.
To the Editor:.

An obituary on Monday about the corporate raider Samuel Heyman included several errors. Mr. Heyman took over his father’s real estate development business when his father died, not because his father needed him to take it over. The Partnership for Public Service, which Mr. Heyman founded, works to encourage young people to pursue careers in public service, but it does not provide fellowships. Mr. Heyman died on Saturday, not Sunday, and he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1963, not 1964.

An article on Thursday about increasing attention being paid by charities to individual donors misspelled the surname of the executive director of the Robin Hood Foundation. He is David Saltzman, not Salzman.
A 36-year-old man surfing off Rockaway Beach in Queens died after getting caught in pounding surf churned up by a passing tropical storm, the authorities said.

In recent days, Dame Edna Everage, below at top, and Michael Feinstein, bottom, have been sniping back and forth about their similarly titled Broadway shows, “All About Me” (his) and “It’s All About Me” (hers). (He: “Titles are not copyrightable. I wish Ms. Edna well. I’ve heard of her.”) (She: “I’m sure Mrs. Feinstein is very proud of her son.”) Turns out the two performers will be working together — and, one assumes, were in cahoots all along. On Thursday, publicists said the two would appear in tandem in a show called “All About Me,” to be directed by Jerry Zaks and written by Christopher Durang. In a statement, Mr. Feinstein said, “I have always been a huge fan of the Dame, and despite our previous friction, now that my mother has forgiven her, I couldn’t be more excited to be joining her on Broadway.” Dame Edna added, “Michael Feinstein is a performer of the highest caliber, I believe, and I couldn’t be more than excited to be sharing a Broadway stage with him, in moderation.” The show is to begin previews at a Shubert theater on March 6 and open on March 23.
Olafur Eliasson is at work on a project that will give the residents of another city a different way of looking at a nearby body of water.

Because of an editing error, a Bloomberg News article on Tuesday about Joshua Gotbaum, President Obama’s choice for director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, misidentified Mr. Gotbaum’s mother. He is the son of Sarah C. Gotbaum, a retired sociologist and the first wife of Joshua’s father, Victor Gotbaum, a former municipal labor leader; he is not the son of Betsy Gotbaum, the New York City public advocate and Victor Gotbaum’s current wife.
A ruling by a Nevada district court judge will allow students at a Las Vegas area high school to perform “Rent” and “The Laramie Project.”

Lemony Snicket, the pseudonym of Daniel Handler, right, and the author of the bestselling “Series of Unfortunate Events” books, has agreed to sell the North American rights to publish a new four-part series to Little, Brown & Company, moving from HarperCollins. The first volume in the new series is scheduled to be published by Little, Brown Books for Young Readers in 2012. Mr. Handler has also signed a deal with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers to publish his first young adult novel. The book, as yet untitled, will be illustrated by Maira Kalman, who composes an occasional visual blog for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, and will be published in 2011. As part of the deal, Mr. Handler’s longtime editor, Susan Rich, will join Little, Brown as an editor-at-large in the young readers’ group. The “Series of Unfortunate Events” books, which have sold 60 million copies worldwide, were published in North America by HarperCollins Children’s Books.

The musicians’ union and the producers of the New York show “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” have made a preliminary move toward resolving a labor dispute, though the producers challenged the union’s account that its members were locked out of the show. Performers with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians have not played in the show since Oct. 10 after a disagreement with the show’s producers, Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, over a contract, which the union says is valid through May 2011. In an e-mail message, the Ricciardis said they have no “contract or tie to Local 802” under the show’s current terms. The Ricciardis also said the musicians were informed they could not play at the show until the dispute was settled, and allowed them to pick up their belongings from the Edison Hotel, where the show is performed. On Thursday, a union representative and the producers said there had been contact between each groups’ lawyers, which the union said “we interpret as a very positive first step.”.

COTTON--Eugene, one of the leading labor lawyers of his generation and a tireless advocate for working Americans, passed away Wednesday, November 11, in New York City. He was 95. A native New Yorker, Cotton was educated in NYC public schools, attended CCNY and Columbia Law School before spending most of his professional life in Chicago. He achieved national prominence in the labor bar while serving as General Counsel of the United Packinghouse Workers of America from 1948 to 1968. He represented the union in many precedent-setting labor agreements and bitter strikes that received national attention. Cotton moved back to New York City in 2003. Cotton graduated magna cum laude at age 19 from the College of the City of New York (voted by his classmates as "most brilliant" in the class), and received his law degree in 1936 from Columbia, where he served on the Columbia Law Review. After a year at a New York law firm, Cotton's interest in the progressive politics of the New Deal, and in the labor movement in particular, led him to work at the NY State Labor Relations Board. In 1941, he headed to Washington, DC as Special Counsel at the Federal Communications Commission to lead hearings on the Commission's policies on newspaper ownership of radio stations. Drafted into the Navy in 1943, he was headed for the Pacific theatre when the war ended. Cotton then returned to his "first love," the labor movement, holding a dual appointment as the Assistant General Counsel of the CIO and of United Steelworkers of America. In 1948, Cotton moved his family to Chicago, to become the General Counsel of the United Packinghouse Workers of America (UPWA), a position he held for more than twenty years Following that union's merger with the Amalgamated Meat Cutters & Butcher Workmen (AMCBW), he served as General Counsel of the Packinghouse Department of the AMCBW until it, in turn, merged into the United Food and Commercial Workers. Cotton also represented the Amalgamated Lithographers of America, a relationship that flourished through a series of mergers that eventually brought the separate unions of lithographers, photoengravers, bookbinders and printing pressmen into a single union. He also served as General Counsel of the Inter-Local Pension Fund, which evolved from five participating union locals to more than 50 participating locals backed by assets of approximately $1.75 billion. During his 20 years with the UPWA, Cotton negotiated contracts with the major meat packing companies that set the pattern - and the standard - for that industry, including some of the first negotiated pension and medical benefit plans in the Nation. Throughout his career, Cotton was at the forefront of many of the major advances in employer-union relations during the post-War period, many of which represented ground-breaking settlements on wages, safer working conditions, and precedent-setting medical and pension benefits for workers in the packing and graphics industries. Beginning in 1951, and throughout his career in Chicago, he also served as a senior partner in the Chicago law firm, Cotton, Watt, Jones & King for 43 years. He was an active participant in Chicago's civic and political life, including serving as President of the Chicago City Club from 1966-68. Near the end of his legal career, he was outspoken in expressing regret at what he called the "weakening of legal protections of collective bargaining rights" and the reversal in the meatpacking industry of many of the advances that he had fought so hard to achieve over the prior 30 years. In an interview he gave in 2001, long after he had retired, he expressed the hope that "my younger and more vigorous colleagues in the labor union bar will continue to contribute to the effective performance of labor's vital role in society." A memorial service will be held on November 29 to treasure memories of Gene's dry sense of humor, razor-sharp wit, commitment to progressive politics and the labor movement, and devotion to friends and family. Cotton's wife of 68 years, Sylvia, pre-deceased him one year ago. He is survived by his two sons, Richard Cotton of New York City, and Stephen Cotton of Andover, Massachusetts; daughter-in-law Rebecca Backman; former daughter-in-law Jamie Fellner; niece Judy Quittman; nephews Stuart Cotton, Richard and Robert Glickstein, and Daniel Steinbrocker; and two grandchildren, Rachel Cotton and Jon Cotton.

EDMONDSON--John Richard, died November 12, 2009. He was born on March 1, 1927 in New York City to Richard E. and Josephine Schroeter Edmondson. He graduated from The Loyola School in New York, Georgetown University and the Columbia University School of Law. He served briefly in the military police in WWII. He began his career ad an associate at the law firm of Winthrop, Stimpson, Putnam and Roberts. He moved to the legal department of Bristol-Myers where, after a distinguished career, he retired in 1992 as General Counsel and Senior Vice-President for Corporate Affairs. He served as the Chairman of the Mercantile Library of New York and on the Board of the Visiting Nurse Services of New York. He served as President of the Lake Waramaug Country Club in Connecticut and was a longtime member of the Honorable Company of Edinburgh Golfers. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Rozanne Hume Edmondson, his five children Lisa Kiernan, Timothy Edmondson, Katie Gilmore, Nicholas Edmondson, Julia Luce, and nine grandchildren. The funeral Mass will be held Saturday, November 14th at 10am in the Chapel of the Canterbury School in New Milford, CT. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Loyola School or the Canterbury School.

Military officials charged Maj. KOZAK--Lillian, passed away peacefully in her home on November 11, 2009. An ardent leader in the fight for women's rights, as well as a professional accountant and auditor in the Nassau County Attorney's Office, Family Court Bureau from 1977-2002, Lillian was appointed Chair of The National Organization for Women-New York State Domestic Relations Task Force in 1975. Professional surveys show that the number one reason women contact NOW is for issues related to divorce. Lillian and the core of women she attracted to work with the NOW Task Force were fierce in their determination to end the impoverishment of women and their families once they went through the legal process of divorce. Her background as an accountant gave her the professional skills to monitor such technical issues as laws covering joint bank accounts, the hidden drawbacks in equitable division of property and poorly drafted divorce mediation agreements. Early on, she warned that alternate dispute resolution programs could put women at a disadvantage economically or in cases of child custody and support. Lillian advocated not only for making domestic violence an element in any court evaluation about the "best interests of the child" but also for ending practices that resulted in fraudulent statements about assets. Lillian was a recipient of the Susan B. Anthony award of The National Organization for Women-New York State, The National NOW Woman to Woman Award, the Long Island NOW Lifetime Achievement Award, and recently, The Award for Lifetime Service from the Coalition for Family Justice. She is survived by her daughter Ellen Kozak and her son-in-law, Scott Miller of New York City. Her son Jeffrey Kozak is deceased. A memorial service will be announced.

The McCain campaign dissed Sarah Palin, muffled her, and then stuck her with a $50,000 legal bill: that, at least, is how she tells it in her new book, due to be released next week. Ms. Palin writes that the legal bill was for vetting her to be John McCain's vice-presidential nominee, according to The Associated Press, which bought an early copy of the book. After the election, when she asked if the campaign would help her pay it, Ms. Palin says aides told her the bill would have been covered if the ticket had won.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is normally a mild-mannered man, at least in public, but he unleashed a torrent on Thursday about leaks during the investigation of the Foot Hood shootings and during President Obama's deliberations on sending more American troops to Afghanistan. First, on the president's meetings on Afghanistan: ''I have been appalled by the amount of leaking that has been going on in this process,'' Mr. Gates told reporters on his plane en route to a Wisconsin factory that is churning out thousands of armored trucks for use by American troops in Afghanistan. He added that he thought ''a lot of different places are leaking'' and that he was ''confident that the Department of Defense is one of them.''

Democrats are trying to build popular support for health care legislation by enlisting people who voted in the presidential election last year for Barack Obama. Organizing for America, the Obama campaign arm of the Democratic National Committee, sent e-mail messages on Thursday to Obama supporters in 32 Congressional districts represented by Republicans. They are districts that voted for Mr. Obama in 2008 but whose representatives voted against health care legislation in the House last Saturday.

It's been a confusing few weeks. As we have entered Eastern Standard Time, the temperature has risen to levels not seen since, well, trick-or-treaters were sweating in their costumes two weeks ago. Gen. Sarath Fonseka, who led Sri Lanka's rout of the Tamil Tigers, resigned Thursday, feeding speculation that he would run against President Mahinda Rajapaksa next year.

The White House counsel, Gregory B. Craig, has told associates that he intends to step down from his post on Friday, putting to rest long-running speculation about whether he would remain as President Obama's top lawyer. Mr. Craig had been at the center of controversial decisions over whether to close the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, as well as revising administration policies on the interrogation and detention of prisoners. For months, questions have circulated inside the White House about his status, but an official said early Friday that Mr. Craig had made the decision to resign.

A suicide bomber struck near a United States military base in the Afghan capital on Friday, officials said. ''It was a suicide attack near Camp Phoenix,'' said Zemaray Bashari, spokesman for the Afghan Interior Ministry.
International NATIONS HIT BY SWINE FLU RECEIVING EMERGENCY DRUGS

Emergency supplies of antiviral drugs are being sent to Ukraine, Afghanistan and other countries in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, where hospitals report that they are being overwhelmed by patients with swine flu, the World Health Organization said Thursday. Ukraine in particular has ''a shortage of ventilators and they have counted more than 100 deaths by now,'' Dr. Nikki Shindo, a medical officer with the organization's global influenza program, said at a news briefing.

Militants stepped up their fight against the Pakistani government on Friday, striking a building in the northwestern city of Peshawar that belongs to the country's main intelligence agency, Pakistani television reported. The early-morning explosion killed at least eight people and wounded more than 30, in what has become a grimly familiar cycle of violence. The Peshawar police chief, Liaqat Ali Khan, said a car bomber had attacked the main gate of the complex, The Associated Press reported.

EVEN when the days grow shorter and colder, the open road still beckons to motorcyclists. Weekend traffic is lighter, and heated gloves and jackets make it possible to venture out in comfort. A trip on scenic roads that in summer are clogged with motorists and other cyclists can be a serene exercise in solitude. ''The whole idea about motorcycle touring is that it is about the journey, not the destination,'' said Grant Parsons, the managing editor for American Motorcyclist magazine, the publication for the 250,000 members of the American Motorcyclist Association. ''Somehow, when you're sitting on a motorcycle, your mind-set is different.''

MARKOWITZ--David, died peacefully at home in Princeton, NJ on Thursday, November 12, 2009. He was the husband of the late Rosalie Jaffe Markowitz, father of Joseph (Sharyn) Markowitz of East Greenwich, RI and Laura Markowitz of Stamford, CT and the most loving Pop to Stacey and Allison Casper. He was predeceased by his older brother Seymour Markowitz who died on this same date two years ago and is survived by his sisters Alice Rubenstein, Gertrude Aronow and Sarah Schumer and a large, loving extended family. Born in the Bronx, he graduated from Brooklyn Polytechnic High School and The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn where he earned both his Bachelors and Maters Degrees in Chemical Engineering. He started his career in 1943 at Koppers Company before joining the Foster Grant Company where he rose from assistant plant manager to President and COO. He led the company through several major domestic expansion projects as well as joint ventures in Holland and Brazil. Following the acquisition of Foster Grant by American Hoechst he became Senior Executive Vice President and a director of the combined companies. After his retirement from Hoechst he became Senior Vice President and member of the Board of Goody Products from which he retired in 1993. Funeral services and burial are private at the Princeton Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to The Jewish Center, Princeton, NJ (thejewishcenter.org) and the American Lung Association (lungusa.org). For information: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400.

Many Americans do not think twice about taking medicines to prevent heart disease and stroke. But cancer is different. Much of what Americans do in the name of warding off cancer has not been shown to matter, and some things are actually harmful. Yet the few medicines proved to deter cancer are widely ignored. Take prostate cancer, the second-most commonly diagnosed cancer in the United States, surpassed only by easily treated skin cancers. More than 192,000 cases of it will be diagnosed this year, and more than 27,000 men will die from it.

Lawyers for Sterling Equities, the investment firm controlled by Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, said it lost money as a result of the Ponzi scheme orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff, according to a filing Thursday in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The trustee recouping money on behalf of victims of the fraud has disqualified claims from investors who took out more money than they put into accounts with Madoff's firm, Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities. Sterling Equities was among those disqualified on those grounds.

Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley has been applauded as a hero across the nation for shooting down Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during the bloody rampage at Fort Hood last week. The account of heroism, given by the authorities, attracted the attention of newspapers, the networks and television talk shows. Thanksgiving today may bring no threats of marauding animals or Indian raids, but certain risks are inescapable. Now the wild beasts tend to lurk in the back seat of the family automobile, while the flying arrows, though verbal, still sting. That's the atmosphere at the start of ''Matthew Takes Mannahatta,'' a refreshingly clever musical for audiences 5 to 12 from Vital Family Theater. The title character and his sister, Piper, live in a state of perpetual squabbling; caged wolverines would be friendlier. Aurin Squire, who wrote the show's book, captures the hell that is a holiday car trip (best lines: ''I can hear Piper breathing. Tell her to stop.''), and Sammy Buck, the lyricist, has humorously rewritten ''Over the River and Through the Woods.'' Here Grandmother's house is a Manhattan apartment, and ''Under the Hudson and Through the Tunnel'' includes a refrain about circling for a parking space. The rest of the music, by Daniel S. Acquisto, is upbeat pop, except for a gentle flute that represents Grandma's antique whistle.

CBS’s “CSI” earned its highest ratings of the season on Thursday with the conclusion of a crossover plot line that involved episodes of “CSI: Miami” and “CSI: NY” the same week. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the final episode of the “CSI” trilogy drew the largest audience of the three shows, with 16.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. on Thursday, enough to lead the night over all in the ratings. CBS’s “Survivor: Samoa” also delivered its best ratings of the season, leading the 8 o’clock hour with 13.2 million viewers. CBS won the night, and ABC placed second with “FlashForward” (8.3 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” (14.4 million) and “Private Practice” (10.2 million). Fox was third with “Bones” (9.8 million) and “Fringe” (5.9 million), and NBC was fourth with its comedy lineup.

Thieves in Norway stole a rare lithograph by Edvard Munch on Thursday, Agence France-Presse reported. A police spokesman said on Friday that the robbers broke an art gallery window, grabbed the work, called “History,” right, and escaped. Though several lithographs of the work exist, the one that was stolen had been hand-colored by Munch himself. It sold at an auction in 2001 for about $35,000, but Agence France-Presse reported the current value at more than 10 times that amount, about $355,000. Munch artwork has been targeted by thieves before: in 2004 two armed masked men burst into the Munch museum in Oslo in daylight and stole “The Scream” and “Madonna” paintings before escaping in a getaway car driven by a third man. Ten years earlier another version of “The Scream” was stolen from Oslo’s national gallery on the opening day of the Lillehammer Winter Olympics. The works were recovered in both cases.

After years of battles over the Barnes Foundation’s plan to bypass its charter and bylaws and move its art collection from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia, the foundation broke ground on Friday for its new home, designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. A 2004 court ruling permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to go against the wishes of Albert C. Barnes, who built the collection and stipulated that no picture in it could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion. Judge Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans’ Court said in the ruling that he considered the move “the only viable alternative” to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But opponents — a couple dozen of whom protested on Friday morning outside the groundbreaking ceremony, above, waving signs with messages including: “Crime Scene. Do Not Enter. Destruction of National Historic Landmark in Progress” — contend that the collection’s financial troubles are surmountable and that the move is motivated primarily by the Philadelphia political establishment’s desire to generate more downtown tourism. “This is not about art — it’s about politics,” said Evelyn Yaari, a member of Friends of the Barnes Foundation, which organized the protest.
The Army has announced an investigation into Arlington National Cemetery a year after workers buried cremated remains at a grave site already in use.

Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the Navy, “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is scheduled to appear on the satirical news show, Comedy Central said on Friday in a news release. It will be the first time Mr. Biden has appeared on “The Daily Show” since he was elected vice president; he has previously appeared on the show twice, including on Jan. 31, 2007, the day he announced he was seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. President Barack Obama appeared on the show on Oct. 29, 2008, just before winning the election.

It was an up-and-down week of news for the video gaming business. On the upside, the debut of the highly anticipated shooting game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 set a sales record for the industry, Variety reported: the game, which retails for $59.99, sold 4.7 million units in its first day on sale in the United States and Britain, taking in $310 million for the game publisher Activision Blizzard. (By comparison, the year’s highest-grossing movie, “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” had earned more than $200 million domestically by the end of its first weekend.) On the downside, the industry saw its overall sales decline during October, compared with the same month last year, according to a report from NPD Group. Sales of hardware, software and accessories totaled $1.07 billion for October 2009, down 19 percent from the $1.32 billion in sales in October 2008. NPD predicted that the industry’s revenues for the year would be from $20 billion to $21 billion, most likely down from last year’s tally of $21.3 billion, though coming releases like New Super Mario Bros. Wii and Assassin’s Creed 2 could still turn things around.

The fabled crossroads where Robert Johnson is supposed to have sold his soul to the Devil in exchange for his guitar prowess has not been definitively located, but the musician’s birthplace has been determined, and plans are in the works to restore it as a tourist attraction, The Associated Press reported. Johnson, the blues guitarist of “Sweet Home Chicago” and “Love in Vain” who influenced artists from Muddy Waters to Eric Clapton, was born in 1911 in Hazlehurst, Miss., in a home built by his stepfather. The birthplace was verified in a letter from his half-sister, according to the cultural affairs office of Copiah County, which is seeking to raise $250,000 to restore the home as a destination for music fans and Johnson acolytes. “He was so good that he would literally turn his back when they were recording him,” said the screenwriter Jimmy White (“Ray”), who is working on a script about Mr. Johnson’s life. “He didn’t want the other musicians to see his fingering technique.”.

MINOFF--Marvin, Producer passed away Wednesday night, November 11th, at home with his family and friends. He is survived by his wife of 29 years, actress Bonnie Franklin, his daughter Julie and her husband Glenn Mar, his son Jed and his wife Madoka, his two granddaughters, Natasha MarMinoff and Maya Grace Minoff, his brother Bruce and his wife Susan. He was the much-loved uncle of Melissa Minoff, artist Edward Minoff, and the godfather of Adam Bush. Born June 26, 1931, in Brooklyn, New York, Marvin attended Lincoln High School, Syracuse University and NYU before entering the U.S. Army, where he served in intelligence during the Korean War. Returning to New York, Minoff joined the William Morris Agency. In 15 years he rose quickly at two major agencies, William Morris and International Famous Artists (today's ICM), and became vice president of the motion picture department. He represented renowned actors, writers and directors such as Cicely Tyson, Sidney Lumet, David W. Rintels and Bruce Joel Rubin while packaging such blockbusters as "The French Connection" and "Love Story." His triumphs as an agent were always featured in Variety as "Another success by Marvin Minoff, son of famed theatrical haberdasher Harry Minoff," a tip of the hat to his father, who owned a clothing store up the street. Minoff left the agency business in 1974 to become president of David Frost's David Paradine Television, Inc., where he co-produced with Frost the historic "Nixon Interviews," as well as subsequent interviews with Henry Kissinger and the Shah of Iran. While at Paradine he also produced James Michener's "Dynasty," "The Ordeal of Patty Hearst," and "Portrait of a Rebel: Margaret Sanger," starring his soon-to-be wife Bonnie Franklin. After leaving Paradine he continued as an independent producer until 1985, when he formed Farrell/Minoff Productions, a partnership with actor/writer Mike Farrell. The pair worked together for the next quarter century, producing motion pictures for television starring such luminaries as Shelley Fabares, Fred Savage, Helen Hunt, Tess Harper, Patricia Wettig, Jill Clayburgh, Missy Crider and Edward Asner, along with two features: the award-winning "Dominick and Eugene" starring Tom Hulce and Ray Liotta for Orion Pictures and Universal's "Patch Adams," starring Robin Williams. A beloved and highly respected veteran of "The show-biz wars," Minoff enjoyed the esteem of all those with whom he worked and was universally regarded as that rare thing in the business: an honest man. Services will be held Sunday at Mount Sinai Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills at 11am.

Dr. John E. Wennberg is the founding editor of the Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care, the widely cited research project that tracks the huge variation in the practice and pricing of medicine in this country. So when he and a few colleagues study how the Congressional health care legislation addresses ''our dysfunctional, disorganized and wasteful delivery system,'' a tough assessment can be expected. And that is what he delivers in a recent blog post on the Web site of the policy journal Health Affairs. Yet Dr. Wennberg and his co-authors also cite examples in which they say the legislation is heading in the right direction.

WERTZ--Olga (Dormia), peacefully at home on November 12th. Beloved wife of the late Georgeo and the mother of the late Catherine. The Chinese government had a special message for President Obama on Thursday: He is black, he admires Abraham Lincoln, so he, of all people, should sympathize with Beijing's effort to prevent Tibet from seceding and sliding back into what it was before its liberation by Chinese troops: a feudalistic, slaveholding society headed by the Dalai Lama. ''He is a black president, and he understands the slavery abolition movement and Lincoln's major significance for that movement,'' Qin Gang, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said at a news conference.

The German government was sharply criticized on Friday by its economic council of experts, who accused it of neglecting the budget deficit and focusing instead on tax cuts. The group said the move would fail to make the economy stronger once it emerged from the worst crisis in decades. The Council of Wise Men, as the group is called, is composed of four men and one woman. It said the center-right coalition government, by making promises to cut taxes by 24 billion euros ($35.7 billion) in 2011, would make it much more difficult to curb the budget deficit.

President Obama, seeking to mend fences with Japan, America's most important Asian ally, announced Friday that he would establish a high-level working group on the contentious issue of the continuing presence of a Marine base on Okinawa. The decision, announced at a news conference with Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama just hours after he touched down in Tokyo to begin his first presidential trip to Asia, appears to represent a concession by the Obama administration to at least consider Japan's concerns about the base, which is unpopular on Okinawa and which the new Japanese government had promised to try to move off the island.

During the war between Georgia and Russia last year, many Georgians felt abandoned when their closest ally, the United States, did not enter the conflict. But they remained steadfast in their support of Tyrone Ellis, a basketball player from Dallas. On the court, Ellis did something his fellow Americans had not done during the war: He fought for Georgia, and he won. The Georgian national team featuring Ellis became an unlikely success story, especially considering that its 2008 season began with an evacuation as bombs fell within earshot here in the capital. The Russian army bivouacked 30 miles away. Despite the war, the team won 9 of 10 games over two years and clinched Georgia's first berth in Division A, European basketball's biggest stage.

THOMPSON--Wade F. B.,69, of New York, NY and Old Black Point, CT died peacefully after a long, dignified battle with cancer. He is survived by his devoted wife of 42 years, Angela, his children, Charles A. Y. Thompson and Amanda Jane Thompson Riegel, his daughter-in-law, Olya A. Y. Thompson, son-in-law Richard E. Riegel III, and six grandchildren. Born in Wellington, New Zealand July 23, 1940, Mr. Thompson came to New York City in 1963 and received a scholarship to New York University. Prior to this, he graduated from Victoria University in Wellington, New Zealand, which in 2004 awarded him with an honorary doctorate to mark his achievements in business. After a lifetime of hard work and dedication, Mr. Thompson was chairman, president and CEO of Thor Industries Inc, the world's largest manufacturer of recreation vehicles and a major builder of buses in the United States. He co-founded Thor with his partner, Peter B. Orthwein in 1980 and the company was listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 1986. Since arriving in New York 46 years ago, Mr. Thompson has been inspired to give back to his adopted city, most significantly in the founding of the Seventh 7th Regiment Armory Conservancy. For 15 years he worked tirelessly with Elihu Rose to save the Park Avenue Armory at 66th Street. His determination to preserve this important national landmark is finally a reality and for Mr. Thompson it stands as a monument to the city's character and quality of life. For their work on the armory project Mr. Thompson and Mr. Rose received the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis medal given by the Municipal Art Society for their outstanding contribution to the City of New York. In 2008 at the Library of Congress in Washington, DC, Mr. Thompson received the Restore America Hero Award from the National Trust for Historic Preservation for his dedication to landmark conservation. The recent renovation of the landscape between Bethesda Fountain and the Loeb boat house in Central Park by Mr. Thompson and his family displays their dedication to improving the quality of all New Yorkers' lives. In recognition of their lifelong commitment to the park, Mr. and Mrs. Thompson received in June this year the Frederick Law Olmsted award from the Central Park Conservancy. A true believer in cancer screening and early detection, Mr. Thompson founded the Drive Against Prostate Cancer in 2000. The Drive, consisting of two Thor mobile medical vehicles, has traveled coast to coast offering free prostate cancer screenings to over 100,000 men, largely the under-served and armed forces veterans. Mr. Thompson, a five time cancer survivor himself, devoted enormous energy to funding cancer research. In 2007 he was the recipient of the Cancer Research Institute's Oliver R. Grace award for distinguished service in advancing cancer research. A man of great passion and dedication, Mr. Thompson will be remembered as a true New Yorker. A celebration of the life of Wade F.B. Thompson will be held at the Park Avenue Armory at 66th Street on Friday, December 18, 2009 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Mr. Thompson's memory to the Park Avenue Amory, 643 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065 or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022.

This resort town was long known for Leatherback Sea Turtle National Park, nightly turtle beach tours and even a sea turtle museum. So Kaja Michelson, a Swedish tourist, arrived with high expectations. ''Of course we're hoping to see turtles -- that is part of the appeal,'' she said. But haphazard development, in tandem with warmer temperatures and rising seas that many scientists link to global warming, have vastly diminished the Pacific turtle population.

Marsh & McLennan Companies, the large insurance broker, will pay $400 million to settle a lawsuit by investors who said they lost money because the company failed to disclose illegal practices. Investors led by state pension funds in New Jersey and Ohio sued the company after its share price dropped by about half in October 2004 as Eliot Spitzer, then the New York attorney general, investigated bid-rigging in the industry. About half the sum to settle the case, in United States District Court in New York, will be covered by the firm's insurance and the rest will be paid with cash on hand, the company said in a statement.

Suncor Energy, the largest Canadian oil company, said on Friday that it would resume the development of some oil sands projects that were suspended at the onset of the recession. Richard L. George, the company's president and chief executive, left, said the company would spend 5.5 billion Canadian dollars ($5.2 billion) next year on capital projects. Of that, 1.5 billion Canadian dollars will go toward growth projects, an amount that Mr. George acknowledged might disappoint some investors because of its relative modesty. Most of the growth money will be allocated to the Firebag Stage 3 oil sands project, which was about half-finished when work on it was halted early this year.

The Obama administration said Friday that it would prosecute Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, in a Manhattan federal courtroom, a decision that ignited a sharp political debate but took a step toward resolving one of the most pressing terrorism detention issues. "Leviathan" is arguably the most influential work of Western political thought, and one of the most analyzed. Yet the first full Hebrew translation of Thomas's Hobbes's work was only published last month. Gambling may be Macao's major activity for risk-takers, but every November, the city goes outdoors for a different set of thrills: the Macao Grand Prix, which runs this year from Nov. 19 to 22. The Macao GP is a Formula 3 race, essentially a feeder circuit for the elite F1 series. Although F3 cars are not as advanced or as fast as F1 cars, there's plenty of what you expect to see from spectator racing: sleek cars traveling at ridiculous speeds, as well as the inevitable crash or two. And the tickets will set you back far less than a few losing hands at the table games at the Venetian.

World leaders, clearly trying to limit political damage given the lack of progress in climate-treaty talks, made it next to official over the weekend that no new binding accord would emerge in Copenhagen next month. [UPDATE 9:14 p.m.: We have a story examining how an end to hopes of "sealing the deal" on a new climate treaty reflects the constraints on President Obama and the political hazards he faces in tackling this issue.] Meeting with the Danish prime minister on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Singapore, President Obama and other leaders said Copenhagen would be a steppingstone toward some final eventual accord, as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had described the impending session last week. (Presumably the pressure came mainly from the two dominant players in the global greenhouse, the United States and China.)

An article on Nov. 1 about libraries with rare-book collections open to the public misstated the period of time covered by Oscar Wilde’s college notebook, at the William Andrews Clark Memorial Library in Los Angeles. It was written during 1876 and 1878, not 1876 and 1978. And because of an editing error, the article rendered incorrectly part of the Latin title of Galileo’s “Starry Messenger,” at the Linda Hall Library of Science, Engineering and Technology in Kansas City, Mo. It is “Sidereus Nuncius,” not “Sidereus Nucius.”.

The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 18, about deals available before the holidays in Mexico, Scottsdale, Ariz., and Florida, omitted part of the terms of a Walt Disney World offer of free dining with a five-night package from Oct. 1 through Nov. 24 and Nov. 29 to Dec. 17. The package had to be booked by Sept. 26.
Although resorts in the region are being more selective with sales this year, it’s still possible for travelers to nab a deal, especially if they’re flexible.

E-readers like Amazon’s Kindle have caught on with the small set willing to buy a device just for reading. But pretty soon, most of us will read books — or at least parts of them — on our ubiquitous smartphones. Forexample, Shortcovers, a Toronto-based company, has created free reading apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre, as well as for Google’s Android phones. There are many free books available. Newer best sellers cost $10.Paul boutin.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, October 31st 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

DAVIDOFF--Jerry, 83, of Norwalk, CT, died November 7. Champion of civil liberties and Unitarian Universalist national lay leader. Survived by wife, Denny (Taft); sons, Douglass and John; daughter-in-law, Jacki; Doug's partner, Marta Flanagan; grandchildren, Rob, Sarah, Josh and Jasper. Service on Saturday, November 28, 5:30pm, Unitarian Church in Westport, CT. No flowers, please. Contributions requested to Living Tradition Fund of Unitarian Universalist Association, or Interfaith Alliance Foundation or Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund.

The New York Times asked readers last week to cast their votes in the horse of the year battle between the filly Rachel Alexandra and the mare Zenyatta. As of 10:15 p.m. Eastern on Saturday, Rachel Alexandra had 68 percent of the 2,657 votes. Ballots for horse of the year are cast by the 282 voters from the racing secretaries and chart-callers, Daily Racing Form writers and members of the National Turf Writers Association. The horse of the year will be announced in January at the Eclipse Awards. Readers can still vote and offer their thoughts on the debate on The Rail at nytimes.com/therail.

THOMPSON--Wade F. B. The Board and staff of Park Avenue Armory warmly remember our founder and Chairman, Wade F. B. Thompson, a visionary and determined man who made a difference in everything he touched. We will miss Wade deeply. Our heartfelt condolences to his wonderful wife, Angela, his children, Amanda and Charles, and their families. Elihu Rose, Vice Chairman Rebecca Robertson, President and CEO Park Avenue Armory

DELL' ARIA-SEGUI--Marina, born September 28, 1940 in Addis Abba Ethiopia, died October 15, 2009 in her home in Huntington Bay, NY. Educated in Italy, and at Mary Mount High School and College in New York City. Daughter of Dr. Salvatore Dell' Aria and Carmella Comis. Survived by her daughters Sabrina, Cynthia, and Desiree Girifalco (Michael), brother Massimo Dell' Aria (Nancy), dear friend Madge Grant, and grandchildren Joseph and Ann Girifalco. Known for her creative genius and love of animals, gardening, and the sea. She will be deeply missed and mourned by all those who loved her.
